description:
Whoa Nellie.. Pump the brakes... Yank Sing offers some excellent dim sum, but it is EXPENSIVE! Here are a few examples. 

Pork and Shrimp Sui Mai (4) - $7.60
Potstickers (6) - 12.70
Roasted Duck with Bao - $6.96 per slice
Chicken Stuffed Mushrooms (6) - $12.70
Crab Claw (2) - $14.00
Sesame Balls (4) - $11.70

See, I wasn't exaggerating. You have been warned.

My favorites were the Xio Long Bao and Salt and Pepper Sea Bass. 

I'll come back when my ship come in.
author: Paul C.

description:
The other Yank Sing location is a little nicer and has an outdoor seating area, and doesn't seem as busy so it is a good alternative to the Rincon location. We ordered very similar items and mostly everything was the same. 

We ordered and shared the savory vegetable, mushroom, spinach, and pea dumplings. All the dumplings are great and have great texture, but the savory vegetable one stands above all. It is full of flavor, but not too spicy. I'd recommend not dipping it with any soy sauce or mustard that they give on the side because then you might miss the flavor. I also really enjoyed the mushroom dumplings - they are not as flavorful but the mushrooms are extremely juicy and still taste great. The spinach and pea dumplings are good too, but not as tasty (although they are a bit healthier). I would recommend dipping them in a little soy sauce or mustard. We also tried the eggplant Hunan sauce and it was super tasty. Again, not a fan of eating eggplant straight up but it was really soft and tasty. The sauce was also very flavorful, but a bit too salty and oily.  For dessert, I got the egg custard tart and ate it warm (although I prefer it a little more cold because it doesn't burn your tongue) and it was great. 

I liked this location a little bit more, but both locations in SF are great. Would highly recommend for some dim sum, but definitely have to make a reservation.
author: Sampath D.

description:
3.5 stars (overpriced imo). Food (dim sum) is one of the best I have tasted. However I am not sure if it is justified for the price perhaps it is only worth it for special occasions. 

Two people and 6 total dishes turned out to be almost $70 (6 pork xlb is $13 and 6 chicken mushroom thing is $14). They should probably update the price level from $$ category to $$$. 

And who charges for tea?!?! Here in Fremont I can have complimentary tea with almost every meal with better tea quality.
author: Richard Y.

description:
Yank Sing is overpriced for what you get but that's what you get for being located in the Financial District right? Walked over for lunch on a Wednesday and it was packed. There was a table on the patio which is outdoors but pretty covered up. We were seated outside and service was nonexistent even though there were so many people walking around. We got our tea after 2-3 things were on our table already. 

Dim sum was pretty average. There were enough dim sum carts going around but the food got cold really quick. My favorite would have to be their bbq pork buns!! They made it very nicely and it was warm and soft when I ate it. 

The line for takeout was super long the whole time we were there but I heard they don't offer the full dim sum menu for takeout!
author: Kristie L.

description:
I really shouldn't come to dim sum places when I'm ravenous but that's exactly what I did the last time I went to Yank Sing. This restaurant is a bit of an institution for SF dim sum and it has maintained a great quality of food throughout the years. 

The food comes fast and furious - upon taking a seat, I was greeted by an army of dim sum carts. As usual, I ordered enough food for two and ate it all - chicken stuffed mushrooms, Peking duck, siu mai, sticky rice in banana leaves, Peking spare ribs, fried crab claw and mango pudding.  My meal was done in 30 minutes flat.  

The real issue in this place is the service - it's really not that great and while they brought out the hot tea, I never got that initial glass of water.  Including tax and tip, this meal was $80. Again, it's probably enough for two.  I would recommend this place for higher end dim sum in SF.
author: Andrew S.

description: I haven't been here since I worked in SF but wanted to take my friend to dim sum since we were in Union Square.  Arrived when they were just opening and got a table right away.  There are carts but you can preorder the dishes you want. We had shrimp and scallops siu mi (not too flavorful), har gow, fun gow, gai lan veggies, Shanghai dumplings and and Peking duck buns. Everything was good and I was pleased with the outcome. A bit pricey but you are eating downtown. A nice place to take people from out of town. The menu is smaller that other dim sum places but okay for our meal.
author: Mitzi W.

description: Super AMAZING good. It's a great place to go in big groups because there's so much to eat. I fell in love with the tea they serve. I love this place!
author: Dorys P.

description:
Love it here!
All I have to say is wow.
Just sit down at the table and await for delicious options to be brought to the table.
Sweet pork buns, cabbage chopped salad, the duck pork bun, soup dumplings, just everything is so good.

They also have the nicest people serving you the options.
author: Hannah C.

description: This may not feel as authentic as some other places in Chinatown, but this restaurant never fails to blow me away in terms of quality, variety and service. The place is always packed, and such was the case last week when we took a break from the convention center for lunch. It's housed in a glass office tower south of market, very spacious and clean.  Clearly I am not the only one who makes an effort to hit this place every time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Dimitri V.

description:
When our friends suggested we go to Yank Sing for dim sum, I got a chilled down my spine: could this be the same Yank Sing where I had such a marginal experience last time we were in San Fran? Yikes!! It was EXACTLY the same place...oh well, guess I have to take one for the team.

Well, surprise, surprise: either this place have radically upped its game since the last visit, or (more likely) I ordered the wrong  things last time / they were having an off day / my taste buds were having an off day. This time, everything was really good: Peking duck breast with bao, baked custard, pork spare ribs, Chinese broccoli, shui mai, har gow, steamed bao, chicken skewers, Shanghai dumpling.

I still prefer my go-to spot in Monterrey Park, but I know now that (1) this place rocks dim sum, and (2) my older reviews are not always an accurate barometer of future earnings.
author: Jonathan G.

description: Fast service and delicious Chinese food. Would definitely recommend! This is now my favorite dim sum place.
author: Nickoh O.

description:
A coworker decided to stop by Yank Sing to grab lunch. Luckily for me, she's a light eater, so I benefited from her leftovers. (For some reason, I was starving that day and just wanted to eat everything.) She shared her lunch on Thursday, May 10th around 2:30pm.

PHOENIX:
*SPRING ROLL
*POT STICKERS (2)
*SIU MYE
*CHOW MEIN
*FRIED RICE

I believe she got the combo above. Not sure of the price, but the website lists the dish at $9.15. This sounds correct as I think she said she paid less than $10. I ended up eating the two pot stickers and a siu mai. Both were tasty with the chinese hot chili oil I had at my desk. I did think the wrapper of the wor tip (potsticker) was a little too thick for my liking. And I've definitely had better and meatier shumai. Though for takeout, the items fufilled that meat craving.

Good spot for takaway if you just want some basic Chinese food. But for me, I need my feng jiao and pai gwat!
author: Elena N.

description:
We really enjoyed eating here. The menu options are a bit pricier than other dim sum places but it was worth it. It's really easy to spend a lot of money on smaller dishes without realizing it (we had the salt and pepper sea bass, which was amazing but you have to check the menu to realize it's over $14)

Ask for the shrimp wonton soup, which serves four people   ($14)! That being said, if you don't see an item you're looking for on the cart, ask an employee -- the service was awesome.
author: Kristina H.

description:
The "fancy" place to get Dim Sum in SF.

There are a few things that Yank Sing does really well but for my money, I'd rather be at Great Eastern.

The good:
The soup dumplings were very good!  Almost good enough to come back for alone. 
Tea comes right out in a pretty pot. 
Pork dumplings were tasty. 

The bad:
Peking Duck by the single. $7 for a few bites of duck?  :/. And it wasn't even amazing. 
Prices for everything.

Their steamed bbq pork buns (my favorite) were just okay and a slightly different style which I didn't love (smooth top vs a more rough top.)

If I'm wanting soup dumplings, I'll go back but generally, I'll take my crew somewhere else for dim sum.
author: Dan K.

description:
Had dimsum today in this place for the 2nd time. Great dimsum in a great convenient location. I would definitely recommend this place and intend to go back when I'm in San Francisco.

The location is very convenient, near Market Street.
author: Benjamin S.

description: The best dumplings I've tried in the US. Make reservations!! I love that you can bc most dim sum places have long lines. The food here is pricier but it makes up for it in quality and service. There's so many unique dumplings you can't get anywhere else! The total came out to 50 bucks total for the two of us which isn't horrible for the quality. The soup dumplings were the most expensive at 14 bucks each. They were pretty standard but good nonetheless. Stand outs were the seafood basil dumplings (very unique and fresh tasting), the fried scallop ball (also huge and filling), and the coconut cream dessert (omg I could eat 10 of these). I would seriously come visit SF for these... still thinking about them 3 days later
author: Lydia A.

description:
Yank Sing reminds me of Din Tai Fung - a classier and cleaner dim sum restaurant. They took reservations for 13 with just one day notice so they definitely get points in my book for that! They have carts but it's a pretty small place so they also had servers coming around holding plates of dimsum to
offer. If they didn't have it yet they would go back to the kitchen and bring it out to us when it was ready. Everything was quick and efficient which is hard to do with large parties and a lot of orders. As for the food, it was so good!! I didn't eat one item that I didn't like. My favorites were the siumai (always), fried shrimp, XLB, salt and pepper sea bass, and the egg tarts. 

It's a bit pricier than your typical hole in the wall dim sum spot but definitely shows through their quality of food and the atmosphere. The location is in a weird back alley so parking is difficult, since it's in the Financial District. If you can Uber here that would probably be your best bet because the closest parking would probably be a few blocks away! Other than that, a solid choice for a hearty lunch in the city. Definitely recommend!
author: Ashley C.

description:
Service: 5
Food: 3.5

Great staff & yummy dim sum in a large, clean restaurant in a very quiet part of town.
author: Cece Y.

description:
Properly good dim sum- but not AMAZING, as the previous Zagat/Beard era would suggest. Had rez for 2 on a Friday as our first foodie stop in the Bay, and while we came appropriately hungry but wanted not to have to be rolled out ready to burst, there was a flurry of activity with the carts right at first (we knew better than to say yes to all up front), once we were about 6 dishes in, servers/carts/employees of every kind seemed to dissolve! 

Highlights: BBQ PORK BUNS (steamed) were HEAVENLY = soft and perfect.  
Crab claws and Phoenix tail shrimp (both fried) were very delicious and a type of dim sum I would never make at home, so that was a special treat! 
Lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice was also a solid dish, went far for the price compared to others. 
Lastly, that XO SAUCE! So bummed it seems they no longer sell it! 

Bummers:
No peking duck available at 2pm. Another table asked for a different option that was also sold out.
Never were asked about anything from the dessert menu after we were done. Waited for that for about 10 min, then seemed to wait another 10 (with nothing on our plates looking like we were still nibbling) just to get our bill totaled up. Our server seemed to be pulled into napkin folding duty and left us hanging to the point we needed to ask someone for our bill. The damage was $80 for us and we did not leave ready to die with fullness, but it was a solid meal. 

Final verdict: I'd probably try another spot next time, but wouldn't avoid Yank Sing by any means. Would have been 3.5/5 but XO sauce rounded up that half star :)
author: Nicole C.

description:
I don't understand the high ratings for this place.  Not at all.  Upon coming to San Francisco I had raked through online reviews and hit up many of my friends who live/lived in the area.  Part of the reason for this weekend getaway was to get good Chinese food (something that's slightly hard to do in LV.)  So when everyone said "Yank Sing" I thought to myself well, we HAVE to go there.  I wish we didn't.

First, the service is terrible.  Absolutely terrible.  We were sat by the manager who asked if I wanted tea.  Now, usually I do but we just didn't feel like it so we said no.  He asked again and again I refused.  Then he looks straight at me and goes "No tea?  Huh?" in an upset voice.  I almost ordered tea just to get him away from me. 

Then to the carts.  Now I love cart service.  I love how the ladies try to force you to get things.  This is part of the dim sum experience and I really do appreciate it.  What I don't appreciate is that the same carts were coming to our side of the restaurant.  It would be nice if all the different carts came around so I wouldn't have to ask for stuff.  Not that I have a problem with asking, but the service isn't good so it was hard to get what we wanted.  

There was one shining grace of a dim sum lady who helped us get the items we wanted and was very friendly but she was it.

Service problems aside, the dim sum wasn't even that great.  Most of it was lukewarm.  The flavor wasn't spectacular for the high high prices they charge.  I mean some of the items I feel like I could get better from a box.  The only one that I truly liked was the pork bao buns and that's because it was the only non soggy hot item.  The flavor of the turnip cake was great but again, I want hot food.
author: Christina R.

description:
I came here with my girlfriend after a long day of adventuring SF and honestly, we were disappointed in this place for a number of reasons.

Yank Sing is listed among the top 25 best Chinese foods in San Francisco, according to Eater SF which caught my attention. It's always packed every day when I walk out of the office to get some fresh air. As a Chinese American and self-proclaimed dim sum connoisseur, I feel a strong urge to provide my insights for the sake of my fellow foodies and other diners out there.

To be frank, the pricing is a scam from my point of view. If you look at some of the pricing of their dishes and you've been to many dim sum places, it becomes very obvious. I feel as though this place is selectively jacking up the prices on items that are popular to people who don't know how to eat dim sum. Below are a few examples that support the pricing scam of certain items. 

*How are 4 sesame balls and egg custard tarts, $12.70?! It's just fried dough and flour! If you go to other dim sum restaurants like Dragon Beaux, it's $3.50 for 3 pieces of sesame balls. So at most, it should be $5 something for Yank Sing's 4 pieces of sesame balls. 

*Wonton soup for $14?! You gotta be kidding me, bro. I'm sorry but wonton soup is very simple to make but I guess they decided to charge higher because it's something a lot of Americans are familiar with. 

*More dishes that are popular in the American market when it comes to Chinese food: Honey Walnut Shimp ($14.70), Potstickers ($11.70), Shanghai Porking Dumpling ($14), 1 Peking duck slider for $7 each, and the list goes on. Now let's compare it to dishes that are popular to the Chinese market, which are priced lower ($5 something), for example, the turnip cake, chicken feet, steamed spare ribs, and taro dumplings. 

*A tiny cut of honey baked sea bass for $21.75?! Ok buddy, I can get a plate of lobster noodles for way less at another dim sum restaurant. 

Now if they used higher quality ingredients, a lot more complex cooking techniques, and outstanding service then I would understand. However, after tasting some of their foods, it does not stand out compared to many Dim Sum places I've been to. Read the other yelp reviews and you will notice a trend of yelpers talk about the pricing. 

There's one major thing I learned as a long-time consumer and that's, "more expensive does not mean that the product is better". I cannot stress that enough, especially for food. I've been to restaurants that are priced low or fair but have amazing products, and I've been to restaurants that were overpriced and the foods were terrible.

If you want to enjoy dim sum to the fullest and love your wallet, I highly recommend going elsewhere.
author: Victor Q.

description: Such a weird place to have a dim sum restaurant. It's in the middle of a less crowded side of town inside of a post office plaza. On the weekend nothing else was open but this place. I had made a reservation and had arrived a little early so we had to wait a bit. They pack in the tables so it was a little bit of a tight squeeze when we sat down but the great thing about dim sum is the efficiency. This place was good though probably not as good as the ones in actual chinatown. Still it's a decent choice if you're around the area and want some place close.
author: Jen L.

description:
I saw that there were two locations for Yank Sing. We were staying in the financial district, so this spot was the closest. What surprised me about Yank Sing was that it was extremely clean. Most Dim Sum restaurants are ... you know... not so clean. I always have a facial expression of  when I walk into Chinese restaurants.

You can say this place is a bougie version of Dim Sum. It is much more expensive, but delicious. Service was on point, the ladies with the carts spoke decent English and didn't scream at me.

The manager was very kind. 
My favorite was the soup dumplings and the pecking duck!
author: Cathy K.

description:
There are two locations for Yank Sing and this is the smaller of the two. We were able to make a reservation for 3 at the last minute for a Saturday at 11am and easily accommodated. What I didn't like was that upon sitting the ladies with the carts came by immediately, but the bamboo baskets were opened to reveal no steam. Consequently by the time we picked several baskets and proceeded to eat, the items were tepid at best. After we were full, we noticed the fresh steam coming out of bamboo baskets as the lids were removed. Lesson learned!

Also by eating the dim sum at not an ideal temperature, the casings had completely adhered to the paper lining of the basket. I did enjoy the crab claw skewer which is not typically found in your average dim sum restaurant. There was another seafood skewer that was also delicious and again atypical for dim sum. Wasn't wild about their shumai and felt the har gow was just ok. However, the dessert of mango pudding and coconut rolls in mochi were well prepared. This is definitely a pricier dim sum restaurant. I would give their other location a try next time I'm in San Francisco just to compare.
author: Nicole F.

description:
Some of the best dim sum that I have ever eaten in my life, tempered with the fact that it was also some of the most expensive, by a factor of probably 30% over what we have in San Diego.

We didn't have reservations on a Sunday morning, about 10:30 am, and I was worried there was going to be a long wait, but we were seated after about 5 minutes of waiting...will just get to it-....

Ambiance/Cleanliness-VERY clean, white linen napkins and tablecloths....that adds a lot of expense to the bottom line right there.  Relatively high ceilings, cream colored walls and floor tile, sparse art, honestly, it's like an art gallery with a restaurant, as far as overall feel.  It had the feeling of a somewhat busy cafe, but the noise level, save for a number of screamy children was not bad.  4 stars

Service-OUTSTANDING....we got everything we needed quickly and the ladies made every effort to ensure that we were satisfied for food and drink....5 stars

Food-EXCELLENT dim sum.  We had soup dumplings, couple different kinds of shu mai, meatballs, fish balls, chive/shrimp dumplings, duck pancakes, crab claw balls( LOVE THEM), some steamed pork bao....only thing I was REALLY not happy about was they were out of baked porked bao....THAT is my favorite.  The tea was excellent, others have written about it extensively....4 stars

All this said, in a city like San Francisco, with so many dim sum possibilities....I would not return here.
author: Steven G.

description:
What is more to this glorious mecca of upscale dimsum? Clean taste.

Shu mai , bean curd, taro puff n other staples are delish. Yes even d much talked about seared Chilean sea bass is a selection to behold.
The dimsum flavors explode and it's totally different from the it's Chinatown peers.

Staff and servers are all nice with smiles.
author: Nelce S.

description:
I have never been to this location, I usually go to the one inside the old post office building.

This one is a little harder to find at first (thanks google maps). 

There is inside and outside seating which is a plus on a nice day. 

Food is just as good as the other spot.
author: Basil M.

description: Overprice , if you are a real Cantonese person, don't go there, most stuff u are expecting in a transitional din sum place are no there, the servant even told me the thing the served is for western people.......
author: White J.

description:
The food is delicious, the prices are way too high, and the service is mediocre. I tried to grab a table and start ordering so we would have food ready to go when my husband joined me in a couple of minutes. 

The lady at the front was so rude about me wanting to start to order, apparently I had to wait (the restaurant was barely 1/4 full), that really set the visit off to a bad tone unfortunately. The service once in was meh. I was really hoping the visit was more pleasant, because quite frankly if service is exceptional you can justify price to a degree. 

The lettuce wrap was ok (and you only get one for such a high price), the fried crab pieces were probably the most disappointing item we ordered (not very tasty or much to them). Steamed buns were very good, the shanghai soup dumplings were lovely, and the har gow were just your standard har gow and nothing to write home about. Tea was good, location was handy. 

I probably wouldn't go back here if I was in San Francisco again, I'd rather try somewhere else new.
author: Mary P.

description:
I have never been to a place that immediately starts serving you food when you sit down.
I barely got my napkin down before they already had options for us to eat.
First time here & I enjoyed all the food.
This is great for a group setting, everyone gets to try all the items offered.
They walk around with trays of food & ask if anyone at the table wants the item, if anyone does they place the item on the table & it's every man for themselves tying to get the food off the plate.
Just kidding we are cultured ‍.
The desserts they offered looked very good but I was too full to accept anymore food.
A must visit if you are in the area
author: Daryl O.

description:
We opted to get takeout here rather than the traditional, sit-down dim sum experience.  And we loved the food overall!

My husband and I both ordered the Yank Sing Express, but even though they specified that we couldn't request customizations, they were out of spring rolls and subbed those with a sweet, sesame ball. While we weren't thrilled with that, it was a great experience otherwise!

The potstickers were great - moist and flavorful.  The steamed buns were to die for - we loved the barbecue-style sauce!  The chow mein had delicious noodles and flavorful meat.  We weren't a fan of the sesame balls, but I could see how someone else might love them :)

I would definitely recommend for an authentic, delicious Chinese food experience!
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Came here for Sunday lunch. We booked from OpenTable and waited for 5 min to be seated after we arrived.

Just so-so Dim Sum place. We had Beijing duck w/ bun, pork rib, egg tart, beef steamed rice roll, shrimp dumplings, pork sui mai. We were recommended by at least 2 friends about the place, but food here was below expectation.
author: Yu S.

description:
We had invited a large party of twenty odd people here for lunch to celebrate our nuptials. It was a Friday and we wanted to take people out for a dim sum experience. I had called a few days prior to make a reservation and also confirm that we would be largely vegetarian and that we would need veggie friendly items. The lady on the phone assured me it would all work out.
Fast forward to Friday. I arrive with my group to find that they've seated us OUTSIDE in the cold. I had never been here before and did not realize they had an outdoor eating area. I went and asked the hostess why we were seated outside. She said that all large parties were always seated outside. I was very upset so she sent for her manager.
The manager was very helpful and gracious. I explained that we had some guests who could not sit outside in the cold, and that we were not told over the phone when making the reservation that we would be seated outside. She quickly had her staff put tables together inside for us and we were promptly seated at two tables inside. 
The food was great. The staff was great. The vegetarian food was great. We had a great experience here although we had a rough start. This is all thanks to management. Our friends and family enjoyed the food as well and some even came back for more the next day!
author: S C.

description:
I used to love Yank Sing.  The food is excellent, even the take out selections are delicious. 

But I skipped it the last FEW times because (each time) there was a bum going through the garbage at lunch and no one was allowed to shoo him away.
author: Ricardo O.

description: Very good dim sum in the financial district, not too far from their Ferry building. Loved the potstickers, sesame buns, and dumplings. Left full and happy.
author: Alison Z.

description: It's 7:22 am on October 8, 2018. I think I will pass on this restaurant forever. I just walked by this restaurant. A male chef is outside smoking a cigarette picking his nose. He hen proceeds to look at the booger and go back in for more. Just the person I want preparing my food. Nope. Never.
author: Scot M.

description:
When every guest  at the restaurant is speaking mandarin and Cantonese you know that the food will be good.   It Is between confident and cocky, with a great mix of all your favorite and a great variety for everyone tastes.  

Be prepared for them to wheel carts around with all the menu items and drop off dumplings at your table.  It is the Brazilian steak house of Chinese food.  

The wait can be long so head there outside of lunch hours and enjoy the experience and don't go hungry.  

The only reason I gave it a four star was the service was a littl lacking.  I had to flag down carts on a regular basis to get my food which was a bit frustrating.
author: Rich S.

description:
Tldr - even the local birds think this place is BOMB. And they got some schwanky heaters.

Came here for a going away lunch for a coworker. As soon as we were seated we were immediately greeted with a card of dumplings and had the soup dumplings. So dope! Even experienced dumplingers can have some trouble though, I bit in to my first one and accidently squirted across the table. 

The pot stickers were really good, as well as the pork buns. Spicy chicken confirmed dope, as well as the literally everything. 

If you sit outside a lot of local birds tend to fly in and walk around the tables. They're just jealous of the food I think bc it is so good. 

Dessert - the flan pastries were toooo good. 

They even have some schwank heaters.
author: Samraaj B.

description: Although expensive, this is by far the best dim sung I have tasted. If you aren't too fond of the dim sung you have had in your past, I guarantee this will be better then any other and you might just fall in love. Anytime I go up to the city this restaurant is first on my list. I do not eat sea food, but have found some of my favorite foods there. The potstickers are, I guarantee, better then any you have tasted before, the soup dumplings are bursting with flavor and you will not be able to get enough, and the pork buns are so yummy and delicious. If you have enough money to splurge on an amazing dim sung meal, Yank Sing should be your destination.
author: Ava S.

description:
This is not what I thought the San Fransisco Dim Sum would be like. At first, I thought it was really cute the way they served tea and sat us outside in the heated patio. But once the carts started coming around, I realized there was barely any selections. They didn't even have flat rice noodles! 
To summarize, overpriced for nothing special. Food and service was good. If you want to try dim sum for the first time or if you have it all the time, don't waste your time and money here.
author: Sylvia M.

description:
I never thought I'd give Yank Sing less than a 4-star rating but things have changed since I last dined there: Service has gone off a cliff or maybe it was a very bad day. 

They were busy but not overly so when I checked in and then they seemed to forget about us. I asked about our table and when we were finally seated, a server briskly approached me to order but most of our little party of three had disappeared to wash their hands. 

I ordered tea and water and asked for a hot towel for my hands (didn't they used to automatically bring those to the table, a little terry cloth towel on a plate?) The server seemed surprised but returned with a moistened cloth napkin she'd poured hot water on. Uh, ok.

A steam cart came but before everyone was seated. It was 10 minutes before they returned and from a full cart loaded with bamboo baskets they showed us two items and annoyed, asked us which one we wanted ("Uh, neither.") I politely asked, "What else do you have?" and she was visibly irked and showed us two more selections. 

I was embarrassed for the out of town friend I'd brought, raving how great Yank Sing is and how it's written up in every epicurean magazine and so good. 

Additionally, trying to order vegetarian dim sum for my friend was met with puzzlement from the staff. I thought they were confused we'd taken XLB and (very mediocre) "spicy chicken" from the steam cart so I explained that my child and I were meat eaters but my friend was vegetarian. They walked away looking not quite satisfied with my explanation as well as a little irritated.

We'd taken the Chinese broccoli offered from the cart but the the other 3 vegetarian dishes seemed to be special ordered from the kitchen, ones that are normally circulating on the cart (pea shoot dumplings and another steamed item with spinach). 

I guess because my friend hesitated that both vegetarian dim sum items had mushrooms (he doesn't prefer them) but then said good-naturedly, "That's ok, I'll order them" an assistant manager marched  over with a server a few moments later to confront us that "Everything vegetarian has mushrooms. Everything." 

Geez ok, we hadn't made a fuss in the first place!

There was barely a circulation of steam carts, plates were brought by hand from the kitchen to surrounding tables.

They were out of Peking duck. And shrimp with chives and something else I asked for- and I had to ask, "Do you have anything else with shrimp?" as she'd already walked away.

Another manager formerly attired in a handsome blue suit walked around looking stern. I didn't see him approach any table in the dining room to ask, "How is everything?"

It was weird. This is not the Yank Sing I knew and loved.

And it was the first time I really minded how expensive Yank Sing is (because you know it's going to be and just pay) and I scrutinized the check ($14 for XLB?)

The indifferent to nearly hostile service seemed to infect pockets of the dining room as if a married couple were fighting, turning the frequency of a dinner party from festive to toxic.

It may be another 6 years before I return, yikes.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Great dim sum!  

Mother's Day & Father's Day or special occasion works. 

Its a "go to" place
author: Mike R.

description:
I recently got married at city hall and went here for a post wedding brunch with friends.  The food here is FANTASTIC and so so flavourful. They have traditional style carts with an array of dim sum to choose from. I might have tried the whole menu (since we are so much) and loved it. 

Make sure you leave room for dessert because the sesame crusted dough ( not sure of the exact name )and the custard filled pastry is so so delicious. Will certainly recommend this to everyone, yes it is slightly pricey but I can assure you it's an experience that's worth it. The staff is also so friendly and kind that the whole meal was memorable for me.
author: Shivani B.

description: One of the best dim sum place I've been to. Food was really good. Had the Chilean sea bass, duck, shrimp dumpling, sticky rice and XLB. All were really good especially the Chilean sea bass and duck. Chilean sea bass was almost as good as the one I've had at Nobu. I've had xlb from other places including my go to spot Joe's Shanghai and these were right up there as some of the better ones. Food was pricier than normal but in my opinion worth it since the service was great. Loved how you could order whatever you wanted from anyone, they'd talk into a mic with your order and shortly after the dish would arrive vs at other restaurants you'd have to wait for the cart to wheel itself around. This resulted in the food being fresher than other dim sum restaurants and more than worth the extra $. Wouldn't hesitate to go back and highly recommend!
author: May F.

description:
This is a decent Cantonese rolling cart style dim sum house. You can taste that the dim sums are made fresh unlike the packaged frozen ones found in most places that serves dim sum. The prices are pretty steep. My husband and I spent $80+20tips for lunch. We had 10 dishes. They come around a lot with all these stuff, make sure you only take the stuff you love or ask about what they are made of. We ended up wasting 2 expensive seafood dishes because we weren't sure but was kind of pressured into saying yes.

I recommend: Shanghai dumplings (thin skin and delicious soup), chicken mushroom dumplings (*infinity!), scallop dumplings.
Not recommended: 
Fried stuffed crab claws, fried turnip cake, fried fish (really anything fried are way too greasy), egg custard tart (tart itself isn't bad, but they come in packs of 4, which cost 12.50.)
author: Tata X.

description: It was great dim sum, especially loved the soup dumplings.  But quite pricey for the portions.
author: Jeannie V.

description:
This restaurant makes pretty good dim sum. I came here with a group of 14 people with a reservation from 1 week in advance. Within a few minutes of arriving, we were brought to our table in the outside seating area. We thought it was going to be a bit chilly sitting outdoors but there were heat lamps that kept us warm enough to not complain.

As we were still taking our seats, the servers immediately started rolling their food carts soliciting their food from one side of the table to the other. We said yes to about half of the food that kept on rolling by: shanghai pork soup dumplings, pot stickers, fried shrimp balls, snow peas, Peking duck, BBQ pork buns (steamed and baked), chicken satay skewers, chicken stuffed mushrooms, fried scallop balls, chicken feet, and last but not least, egg tarts. I'm probably forgetting to name some other dishes that we had ordered, too. This was all in a span of just 1 hour.

Overall, this restaurant serves tasty Americanized Chinese food and it is located in a convenient location in the Financial District. It is very clean and the servers can speak English well, something that can't really be said for authentic Chinese restaurants. I believe the high prices of this establishment is warranted.
author: Wesley S.

description: If you arrive early, you get great service and no waiting. Prices are high, but the food is so good. Particular favorites: shrimp balls, green beans, the sea bass (but $$$). Potstickers and shumai are good (but not fantastic, but consistently good). Bao is great. Soup dumplings always leave me underwhelmed. Miss their old location, which seemed bigger too.
author: Lisa B.

description:
My family and I first came here a few years ago, and everything was delicious back then. The carts would come at regular intervals, the food had more flavor, and the dishes were very hot and fresh. 

We just finished our meal here today and it was very disappointing. The first dish we got was the "famous" soup dumplings, which were soggy and cold. Because this is their so-called signature dish, we were expecting the flavor to be much better. We ordered many different items, but all of them continued to be flavorless and cold. 

Overall, we will not be coming back. Very disappointing.
author: Sabrina M.

description: Ok, so the food was yummy and fresh. Service was good. The host was super rude. Definitely a great dim sum spot. Go for the fresh food and fast service, go with thick skin and try not to let the host hurt your feelings.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Got food poisoning from the chicken buns. I know it was the chicken buns because my partner and I had all the same dishes for our first meal of the day here, but only I ate the chicken buns. They gave me awful diarrhea and stomach cramps for the entire day. 

Prices would indicate a much higher quality of food than what you actually get. You could have dim sum of equal quality for about 1/3-1/2 the price of what you would pay here. 

All in all, best just steer clear of Yank Sing. Your stomach and wallet will thank you.
author: Publius M.

description:
Convenient dim sum in FiDi, not sure worth the pricey bill you end up with.

All tables are given some tea and the servers will quickly refill if you place the lid upside down.  Interior is pretty posh and clean.  Service is usually ok if you can avoid the rush hour but note that the later you go, the less items they'll have to choose from- around 1pm, they ran out of Peking duck and some of the typical steamed items were low on stock.  They also have servers walking around with new dishes and will show them to each table to see if anyone wants it.  Note that this place does get REALLY LOUD.

Usually go in a group of at least three and try to order a lot of variety: we usually end up ordering the shrimp har gao (4 for $6.50), pork and shrimp shumai (4 for $6.50), spinach dumpling (3 for $5.50), pork cha shi bao (2 for $5.25), Shanghai soup dumpling / xiaolongbao (6 for $12.95), Peking duck (1 piece with bun, sauce, and scallions for $6.05), and Chinese broccoli (plate for $6.50; note that this dish is COLD).  Sometimes you can ask for things like shrimp changfen (not sure what price is for this).  Dessert we usually get the fried sesame balls (4 for $11.10).  

As you can see, the prices can be a bit high for the amount you get.  I don't hate the food either- it's just not as special as some other places I've been to (but maybe I'm just spoiled).  

If my friends want to eat dim sum, I'd come back; I'd just have to mentally prepare myself for a higher-than-normal bill.
author: Audrey H.

description:
This is a review of Yank Sing 2go takeout, not the sit-down part of the restaurant.

My usual order is the Yank Sing Express combo with noodles, pork bun, potstickers, egg roll.

The great thing about this place is that it's fast. The menu is simple for the most part, just different combos, so it's easy to order.

The food is not bad, it's your typical greasy chinese takeout food. Be careful not to let the box move around too much, or else everything will get mixed together and you'll have pork bun covered in grease.

The pork bun is actually the best part of the combo, it's nice and large. Everything else is solid and will definitely give you a food coma afterwards.
author: Posu Y.

description:
I guess that because this restaurant is in the Financial District the owners think they can charge insanely exorbitant prices. The bill was $45 a person for four people! We were so surprised that we recalculated our whole bill to make sure, and it turns out they charged us $6-$8 for each plate, with some only containing two small dumplings. And only two of the dishes we ate were notable at all. 

Most of the dumplings were completely bland, probably because they used shrimp paste, crab paste, and scallop paste balls inside instead of the real thing, making them pretty flavorless. I would never recommend this to anyone. Their's much fresher, cheaper, and better Dim Sum to be had at Hang Ah, spend your money there.

THE TEA WAS $8
author: Ali M.

description: Came here for lunch with 3 friends and the bill came out to be 180$. Everything there was 8$ or more with very limited options. In addition to being overpriced all the food came out bland. Without the chili oil or soy sauce everything was flavorless. 8.00$ for a pot of tea is absolutely ridiculous. Take my advice and go to another dim sum restaurant in San Francisco there are many better options.
author: Jeffrey K.

description:
If you're looking for a true dim sum, please, find somewhere else. The food is decent, but they are missing so many classic dim sum dishes. 

Let's talk prices. This is the main reason for the low review. Never have I left a dim sum place still hungry because I just didn't want to pay $8 for each mediocre dish. 

Seriously, there are so many other options. Save this for a last resort.
author: Grace P.

description: Walked in Yank Sing thinking it's an ordinary dim sum place, but it surprised me with a large variety of dim sum dishes.  Their house special dumplings are not really the typical dim sum type of dumplings but they are really good.  Highly recommended.  Chicken feet is very good as well.  Everything else we order was average.  Customer service was exceptional.  It's definitely a $$$ place - two of us spent $100 here for lunch.  Great atmosphere and clean.  Overall, 4-star for me.
author: Andy C.

description: Jenny and Karry were wonderful very nice and welcoming. All of the items were delicious. My favorite would have to be the steamed BBQ Pork Buns. Also on the menu today was the chicken and mushroom dumplings, pork and shrimp dumplings, spinach dumplings and potstickers. Egg rolls and the Szechuan chicken was to die for. Need to come here and try more of there items. Make a reservation as it gets very busy on the weekends. Not open after 4pm so lunch time is the best time to come in and get your belly full of some savory meals.
author: Jade L.

description:
The best bao
The staff is so polite and does such a wonderful job packing that to go orders delicious cuisine
author: B L.

description: We love this place. Dim sum here is delicious.  It is not the typical dim sum experience at a loud and crazy atmosphere.  The service is excellent and the food refined. It is pricey which is another big difference. But it is worth it.  Every time we are in San Fran we come here for lunch.
author: Daniel C.

description: By far one of the better and cleaner dim sum places I have eaten in the Bay Area. Definitely make a reservation because it gets crowded. But it was worth the wait. It's a bit hidden off an alley but had a nice ambiance inside. They have the carts that come around which makes it convenient to see what you are ordering. My fav was their steam pork bun. It was so soft and tender in the inside. The bun was slightly sweet and the whole thing just melted on your mouth. Their egg custard was my second fav. The crust was very buttery and flaky with the custard portion warm and semi-soft that made you want more. The service was friendly and they were efficient as well. I definitely would recommend this place and I would come back. It's more pricier than other dim sum places but I like my restaurants to have a clean restroom and be more presentable. For how busy this place is they still kept up with their cleanliness! At least on my visit.
author: Daniela B.

description: This place is amazing.  The food was excellent and service was great.  We came for lunch and did not expect the place to be packed with long lines.  Thank goodness we had reservations.  All the dim sum dishes they brought out looked so good and you can choose whether you would like to order it or not.  We had the peking duck, shrimp dumpling, snap peas, crab claw, spring roll, scallops and the fruit cup.  It's quite pricey but it's well worth it.
author: Retired M.

description:
This restaurant has a very good reputation. We were seated in less than five minutes however we felt so rushed as the waiting staff went by the table for 1 to two seconds and if we hesitated they were off. 
Another problem was that you don't know how much things cost when you order them from the waitress. We were surprised to get a bill that was probably one and a half times what we thought it would be.
We felt we were in a fast food restaurant and that is not what we wanted and we wanted to relax a little bit to enjoy the meal. This was absolutely impossible if you are in a hurry go ahead and go. If you want to enjoy your meal go somewhere else.
author: Antonio J.

description:
I'm not sure what they put in the chili oil here but it's seriously SO good. Their dim sum is pretty good, very fresh and not too oily which is why I really enjoyed my past few visits here. 

What really set the bar is their xlbs, I could have 3 orders to myself! 

Definitely the most expensive dim sum I've ever had so it's definitely a "treat yo self" meal. Service is better than your traditional dim sum restaurant (aka absolutely horrendous - which I don't mind because I know what I'm signing up for LOL) which is why they get a 3.5 Star that's bumped up to a 4.
author: Jaimie W.

description: Delicious!! A little pricey but totally worth it. Service was great and food came quickly to the table. Everything was incredibly fresh and the staff clearly works very hard to prepare this amazing food. The location is really beautiful. We went on a Wednesday during lunch and it was bustling with people. It seemed like a lot of tables were businesspeople on their lunch breaks/ holding lunch meetings. I highly recommend the Shanghai Dumplings and the Peking Duck buns. The spare ribs were also on point.
author: Maria R.

description: Best Dim Sum in the world. I have been a customer since its first place on Broadway 50 years ago.
author: Ron F.

description: My love for this place knows no bounds. Clean and fun. Food is amazing and I love the tea. It is expensive but that's to be expected with this level of quality.
author: Andy R.

description: Very disappointing (2 Go). Service was good. Food, well let me say underwhelming. The actual dining room was closed one hour before the official closing. Pork bun had paper wrapper stuck to the bottom. The wrapper wasn't any more tasty with soy sauce. The rest of the super special isn't worth mentioning. Too many good lunch spots in The City to spend another visit to Yank Sing.
author: Rod B.

description:
Most expensive Yum Cha we ever had. Six items for a baffling $96. Completely overpriced restaurant with okay, clean atmosphere. Nothing extraordinary that would justify the extreme pricing.

Be aware this is listed with two dollar signs, but it should be four.
author: Henning V.

description:
I came here for a weekday lunch right before noon and was surprised they had immediate availability without a reservation. We had to sit at the patio outside but they have outdoor heaters so it wasn't bad! My only complaint about sitting outside is the birds flying around the tables. 

The outside tables received more attention than I was expecting; the food carts came by pretty often. We ordered various dim sum including spare ribs, fried taro stuffed w/ meat, dumplings, duck buns, etc. and it was very average in terms of quality and taste. However, this is one of the few options in FiDi to satisfy dim sum cravings. If I want something quick, I usually go next door to Yank Sing 2 go and order the dim sum platter for a variety of food including potstickers, an eggroll, etc. Super filling! 

This place is definitely overpriced for the mediocre food but the service was decent. I would still come back when i'm in the mood for a dim sum lunch.
author: Mandi H.

description: It was nice to bump into a traditional dim sum place where they pushed around carts with a variety of dim sum options. There were also lots of delicious choices on the menu. The food was amazing and worth the money, but definitely bring someone who speaks a little chinese!
author: Sabrina H.

description:
Pricey. But worth it to splurge once in a while on delicious dim sum. It's not every day dim sum. It's a celebration, special occasion, "got a fat bonus" type of dim sum place.

Yank Sing was our plan B on a Sunday afternoon in the city. We tried to score lottery tickets to Book of Mormon (plan A) at the SHN Orpheum down the street but we weren't lucky that time. 

Went to Yank Sing to spend the money we allocated for the show. My family and I have only been to this location. Thank goodness for google maps otherwise we would have never found it.

We had the siu mai, chicken feet, steamed pork buns, shrimp har gow, salt and pepper sea bass, egg rolls, stuffed mushrooms, dumplings, mango pudding and a few other dishes I can't remember. I do remember the check, though. It came out to $150.00. For 3 people. That's about 3 times the amount we would pay at an average dim sum spot. But Yank Sing isn't average. It's special. It's so special that I can only afford to come here about once or twice a year.
author: Rose C.

description:
Can you eat dim sum without soysauce, chili oil and mustard?  No?  Me neither.  

Ordered Yank Sing togo today, haw gao and spinach dumplings.  Order came to my work with no chopsticks, no soy sauce, chili oil, mustard. =(  By the time I ran from floor to floor to scrounge up a soy sauce packet, my dumplings were extra cold.  

The worst part is on their online order form, they don't allow you to add requests like soy sauce!  

Spinach dumpling tasted like it would have been good hot.  Haw Gao was so hard and cold by the time I had it, it was hard to tell what it was originally.  

Super annoyed right now for them ruining my lunch.  $20 for 7 dumplings delivered.
author: Vi Y.

description: This place is right by my work and has always looked really good. A bit disappointed when I finally got the chance to try them. The chow mein I had tasted like dirt and was really pricey for the order. The dim sum was decent but I've had better. Probably wouldn't advise going here if you want good food.
author: David P.

description: Came here only to try the soup dumplings, they were pretty bomb. Which was unexpected cuz their yelp reviews aren't that great. I have to say, the dumplings here might be better than din tai fung...don't kill me! They were super juicy and the meat filling is slightly larger and more flavorful. They taste more homemade rather than the almost factory like dumplings of din tai fung hehe.
author: Michelle N.

description: Wonderful authentic food. Very popular so you'll want to make reservations.
author: Dan N.

description: Possibly the best albeit pricy dim sum in the city is also available to go. For about 10 bucks you get a large always changing carryout  sampler platter of dim sum items. It was hot fresh and ready instantly. Mine came with a bbq pork bun, 2 pot stickers, 4 shu mai, a crispy spring roll, and a custard tart. It was filling, a great deal, and among the best dim sum iv had minus the whole lenthy experiance on my lunch break. The spring roll was hot and very crispy and flakey, the bun fully stuffed on filling(alot are mostly bread at some places), the potstickers full of herbs and flavors and crunchy on the side, the custard soft and crumbly, and the shu mai solid pork inside. Hard to beat this quality and price.
author: Sean G.

description:
First impression, the food is quite pricey compared to other dim sum places. 

This particular location is quite nice and clean. The service is also attentive.

The chicken feet was delicious. 

The dumplings were okay but way overpriced.
author: Foodie C.

description: Yank Sing is typically bustling with activity during the lunch hour because it's a great spot for a quick sit down meal. The food is served by waiters who push carts of dumplings and other dishes for you to choose from table side.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Fantastic food. The service is frequent too. A great place to bring friends and family in town. I've done so on two occasions and we were seated within an instance - even without reservations!
Highly recommended! I'm always looking forward to my next outing at Yank Sing
author: Lyndon G.

description:
People are harsh here, the food is pretty good but expensive. Not comparable at all to their fast food hub at Rincon.

=====Favorites=====
* XLB - Really delicious, soupy and satisfying.
* Egg tart - Rivals golden gate, delicate custard, flaky buttery crust. Must order!

=====Good, would order again=====
* Siu Mai
* Ha Gao
* Seen Jook Goon (Tofu curd fu pay goon)
* Taro puff

=====Would not order again=====
* Baked pork buns - Not enough meat, too sweet
* Shiitake dumplings - Just didn't taste very good.
author: Jess C.

description: Yum! Totally worth the trip! This place is amazing, and the pork bao brings back childhood memories! They bring food to your table and you pick what you want. Fantastic experience. #legit
author: Evet S.

description: Went to this place on a recommendation of a hotel guest we met up with. Said it was the best around. Went on Monday around 2 in the afternoon. It was not super busy. At first we were bombarded by employees pushing what was on their cart. We tried a few things and like Nicole C said all of a sudden we were put on ignore. Funny cause our server was folding napkins too! Any way no desert offer. Totaled up the bill and $85.00 later we were out the door. An hour later we were at Ghirardelli's for desert! Not bad but not great.
author: Steve W.

description:
Great quality dumplings! 

Yank Sing is arguably my favorite dumpling spot in the city. I love getting to sit on the patio out front, and have a dumpling experience that includes great service. 

The shrimp dumplings have the most shrimp in them than any other place. The peking duck has perfectly crisp skin with soft meat inside a soft bun. Those were for sure my favorite 2 items, but all the other dumplings are also delicious. 

They also have 2 locations and a take-out option, so you can get your Yank Sing craving whenever you want.
author: Nikita K.

description: Loved it!! Great place for dim sum in Sfco. Book your table online, takes only a minute. I recommend the mango pudding dessert.
author: Melissa B.

description: The food is excellent! Get there as soon as it opens to avoid a wait! The pork soup dumplings are one of their signature dishes and a must have! The egg rolls, shrimp dumplings, fried shrimp and pork buns are amazing! Most servers are friendly, but they are quick to get food around.
author: Sarah D.

description: First time here and loved the dim sum! I'm from Hawaii and grew up on dim sum.  First of all, quickly say to the waiter how many in your party are having tea  or else everyone will be charged for tea. It's not free.  The dim sum was very good and the wait was worth it.  The priority in considering to eat here is to MAKE RESERVATIONS! It's that busy. That good.  I liked the red cabbage with walnuts. The orange jello was very refreshing at the end.
author: leimomi k.

description:
As a Cantonese I am a bit disappointed at Yank Sing. 

I came here on Wednesday but the food carts are really slow. My friend and I were waiting with hunger. 
A lot of classic dim sum are not provided here, including 肠粉 金钱肚 榴莲酥 马拉糕。

The custard tart is really good tho. It is a must try if you have to settle down at this.
author: Sidian L.

description: This place is not only overpriced but be careful, they overcharged my friend and I on some items. The tactic they employ is giving you more than one order and therefore charging for two when you only ask for one. They just stamp away without explaining each stamp. The total for my friend and I for LUNCH came out to $105 before tip. SWINDLERS.
author: Joey T.

description:
I usually eat at the other location off of Spear Street- which I'm a huge fan of.

I found that this location doesn't have as big of a selection as their other location, and it's more a quick lunch spot for people on the go. 

While the food is still good, I most likely won't be visiting this place again and will opt for their Spear location.
author: Lainey L.

description: Good service, but the food didn't knock my socks off. I think there is better dim sum in Oakland. Even though this place was good, it reminded me of the dim sum in Seattle, leaves much to be desired. I appreciate Oakland dim sum (the one that's on the second floor of some shopping complex) and the dim sum in Richmond, BC.
author: Paige W.

description:
food is just ok, waiting 15mins and nothing served but tea. Trying to order but got refused said everything is in the cart. 
All my friends got so hungry and after a few dishes we decide to leave to other places. We just ran out of patience.
author: Qing H.

description: We have been here many times and this is the best dim sum in the world it has never changed, been coming here since it opened since it's existence it's the best  Sea Bass so great the walnut shrimp the best the cha su bou, service is incredible.
author: Marie S.

description:
I'm a little torn because the food was soooooo good but it was also really expensive. That's the most I've ever spent on a lunch. Heck that's probably the most I've spent on a meal and it didn't even include alcohol. 

First off it's really busy during lunch rush but it's a really big place so the wait wasn't too bad. They have an outdoor area where it was really easy to have our strollers by the table. 

Service was great. We basically stayed until closing because the babies were being a little fussy and they didn't mind. 

Food is really good. Very fresh and super hot when they come around. Our eyes were so much bigger than our stomachs and we ended up selecting wayyyy too much food. Its definitely a trap because they keep coming around with all this delicious food. I loved everything I tried. Pot stickers, steamed buns, lots of vegetable dumplings, fried shrimp stuffed crab (super delicious), all so so good!
author: Lisa D.

description: I love dim sum and every time Im at SF, I always  make plan to eat here. It's nice and clean, service is good. Mostly I love the taste of their dim sum!
author: Ellen L.

description:
Knowing that Chinatown in SF is the oldest in the US, we really wanted to eat dimsum and found a couple spots close to our hotel. Our friends were hesitant about the 2 star ratings so, asked our bellman outside the hotel which lead us to Yank Sing.

After a decent walk (to get Pokémon), we found Yank Sing in the financial district.

Very clean and busy and typical dim sum place where they walk around with carts of food. Got the standard dumplings with chives, shrimp shumai, pork and taro, crab, and even chicken feet. 

We were even treated with delicious jasmine tea.

When our bill came, it was an unexpected chunk of change...to the tune of around $40 a person...there were FOUR of us  0.o

Needless to say, that had us wondering about the cost of the 2 star dim sum spots lol

Regardless, we had our fill of SF dim sum...exactly what we wanted! haha
author: Laurie V.

description: Dim sum doesn't get any better than This! These guys have been consistently been making the best dim sum on this continent for at least 30 years that I have been a patron. I love this place and a trip to San Francisco wouldn't complete without stopping here. Your taste buds will dance with joy! Fresh, timely, and delicious.
author: Josh K.

description:
Take a seat for a quick, light business lunch.
A plate with a chunk of stuff immediately appears.
What is it?
"Sea Bass. Very good."
Uh - OK.
Bill for 5 small plates + tea comes to $73.
The Sea Bass is a big chunk.

Later that day ...

Girlfriend - you fell for the Yank Sing Sea Bass song and dance?
They've been doing that trick for years! Ha-Ha-Hah
You need to get that SUCKER tattoo removed from your forehead.

So ... yeah ... don't go in here with SUCKER tattooed on your forehead like me.
author: Anthony A.

description: Hands down my favorite dim sum place. It really makes me sad because this place is in SF and I live in socal. The food is great and the staffs are really nice. There isn't a single thing I could complain about this place except the wait. Great news! You don't have wait if you make a reservation. You could go online and make a reservation on their website or through opentable. Make a reservation the night before and arrive at the restaurant, then you shouldn't have a problem.
author: Peter R.

description: First stop on my most recent San Francisco food tour. I've had lunch here before but somehow forgot the Yelp about it. We walked right in on a Sunday afternoon without a reservation, though the place was super busy. Within a minute of sitting down, those delicious carts of goodness were making their rounds. I loved the soupy dumplings and seafood dumplings the most. Their spicy chicken was also super tasty. Unfortunately my eyes were bigger than my stomach and we ordered too much and got full faster than we anticipated. Rookie move. I really like that Yank Sing makes you feel welcome - no intimidation for not knowing anything about Dim Sum or how to order. Will be back on future SF trips.
author: Jamie W.

description: The dim sum was authentic, freshly made and elegantly prepared. But expensive. After all this is dim sum with Peking duck and real white cloth tablecloths. Not the layered pieces of disposable paper like the Chinatown establishments. Peking duck was awesome. So was the honey walnut shrimp, char-siu baos and dumplings. Sticky rice had the perfect consistency. We were in dim sum heaven until we got the bill. Good for special occasions and business lunches. Dim sum here for three costs about the same as a banquet dinner for 6 in Chinatown.
author: Arthur C.

description:
Dumplings are very good ... onion cake was awesome .. had a lovely time .. good ambience. Thank you so much .. 
fried rice was not great hence rated low .. probably I need to order something else ..
author: Sushanti M.

description: The place was nice however they ran out of more than half their menu an hour before they closed. Everything I wanted on the menu they would not make.  And the food was ok along with the service.  I felt very rushed and not relaxed.  I would not come back.
author: Richard B.

description:
It's been a few years since I was last at Yank Sing, but on this visit I was pretty impressed. The weather was amazing, so they had outdoor seating available which was quite nice and much quieter than inside. 

I started with the pork soup dumplings which were perfectly prepared. Following I had the steamed shrimp dumplings and the steamed chicken and mushroom dumplings...all of which were awesome. I also tried the chicken lettuce cup which was fabulous! 

Service was quite friendly and even on a busy Sunday they didn't rush the service. I'll be back my next time in SF!
author: Michael R.

description: Absolutely great. Lots of fun. Make a rsvp. Everything good.good, good. Will return. Go to location in financial center.
author: S P.

description:
I cannot describe my love for this place in words. I usually end up craving for dim sum whenever I am downtown SF ​and pop by Yank Sing for a "quick" lunch. I am OK waiting for 20-30 minutes for a walk-in table however if you are a bigger group than 2 persons, MAKE A RESERVATION online. Otherwise, you will be watching​ other people enjoy the delicious​ dim sum for a while before you are seated. 

My all-time​ favs are, but not limited to:
1) Snowpea dumplings​
2) Pork and Shrimp dumplings
3) Spinach dumplings
4) Chicken Mushroom dumplings
5) Curry Vegetable dumplings
6) Pork Buns​
7) Shrimp tempura
8) Sasame balls
author: Matt A.

description:
Been to Yank Sing twice, and both times were decent. Their dim sum, quality, and service is quite good; I'd say quality and cleanliness is better than other dim sum places in the city, but price is definitely reflective of location.

Most recently, I came with a colleague, and lunch for 2 (just a few standard dim sum items -- we couldn't have ordered more than 5 items) came out to be $70. Yank Sing is smack in the middle of FiDi/SoMA, so prices are ridiculously steep. Unless you really value convenience of location or are eating on a company budget, I'd recommend you go somewhere else in SF.
author: Jackie Y.

description:
Good quality dim sum and the service is fantastic but wow is it expensive!!! 

My girlfriend and I came here during the weekend and we had our fill of all the standard items - shumai, har gow, etc. They were all on point and delicious, but by the end of it our bill came to over $100!!!! 

That would've been only $40-50 at most other dim sum places in the city. 

If you're trying to impress someone then this might be a great spot but otherwise you can get similar quality for a lot cheaper elsewhere!
author: Brian C.

description:
Hands down my fave dim sum place in the world! I wish Yank Sing existed in L.A. But I guess for now I'll have to make my way to SF more often.

Everything here is tasty and oh-so-delicious! Can't go wrong with the sio mai and the har gow, as well as the juicy pork xiolongbao. One of my fave dishes is the chicken stuffed mushrooms -- simple, but packed with flavor! I also love that they offer a single serving/order of Peking duck - you don't see that very often. 

Just thinking about the deliciousness makes me want to hop on a plane and Yank Sing it up again!
author: Patricia G.

description:
Pretty decent dim sum, but for its very expensive price, my rating of this place tops at 2.5....for better dim sum for less money, you either take a walk or an Uber a few blocks up north...  if money is of no concern for you and you work/live nearby without much time to fool around, this may be your best bet.

What I'm really saying here is... for the high asking price, the taste and quality of the food should be much betters.  For example, I was quite put off by a very think tasteless batter for deep fried crab claws...I had about 3-4 dishes and ended up with a $50-60 bill.  Don't tell me I'm mathematically challenged--I was multi tasking with a conference call so didn't pay much attention to the price...
author: Straight N.

description: Best Chinese food in San Francisco. My wife and I had a little bit of everything. Great food and great service. We will go back for sure next time we are in San Francisco.
author: Matthew C.

description:
A great place for dim sum. We made reservation for 11am. We only had 1/2 of our party and when we checked in it was no problem- our table was ready and we got seated right away. The dim sum was fresh tasting. The peking duck is a must try. Loved the walnut shrimp. 
Parking can be difficult on sunday- surrounding parking garages are closed and so you're left with street parking- hence minus 1 star for that. Otherwise, location is great!
author: Glenda M.

description:
Yank Sing is a Chinese Dim Sum restaurant located in San Francisco's Financial District. The first time I was here was actually for a wedding reception - they rented out the place and it was amazing. The restaurant basically pours into the floor of the Rincon Center, surrounded by waterfalls and a high ceiling. 

The food at the wedding was fabulous! The best way to describe it is that the menu puts a Western twist on non-traditional Chinese. The second time I came here was for dim sum with a few friends. Call in to make a reservation in advance to avoid the wait times. They offered traditional dishes, as well as some interesting takes on what would usually be main courses. Their xiao long bao tasted great and seemed like it was made from high quality ingredients. Very delicate though. I would consider it to be a classy Chinese establishment with very decent and authentic dishes. It is rather pricey to eat here, but if you do, make the most of it!
author: Steve N.

description:
Yummy! I love the old school vibe of this place. Makes sense why there is always a line at the door. However, if you do not want to wait in line like most people do, call ahead and make a reservation. I was able to walk right in, check in and be sat within a minute. I was almost done eating when I saw some folks who were waiting in line finally get seated. #survivalofthefittest.

PS - Get the shrimp with scallion dumpling. So delish!
author: Tanya A.

description:
The dim sum here is very expensive. If you can get over the sticker shock, the quality of the dim sum is actually quite good.

The dim sum is not over oily and not too salty. Each dim sum piece is well crafted and the skin sticks perfectly to the filling. We ordered lots of veggie dim sum, har gow, shu mai, sticky rice, mushroom stuffed with pork and shrimp. Every dish was a hit and it was all devoured by the very end. The only dish that I would have passed on was the sea bass that was overpriced at $20 and wasn't all that great. Cooked well but not much flavor and I'll definitely pass it on it next time. 

Service here was extremely fast as all the dim sum carts swarmed us as soon as we sat. The tea was refilled quite often and no complaints on the speed.
author: Edward W.

description:
This is definitely an upscale restaurant. Normally the cart experience at dim sum places are what you go for, here however, since you dont get to see the price of the dim sum you are ordering, when the check comes... itll always be more than you expected. 
The flavors of the food here are really great, dont get me wrong. The chicken feet were soo flavorful and well done. The skin just slid off the bone. The bbq pork buns were very soft and had a good amount of meat in them. They also had peking duck and lettuce wraps come around on those carts too, which isnt something you would normally see. (too bad they didnt have the super thin tortillas that comes with peking duck but just hte fat buns)

we paid about 45$ per person here... and to me that is too much for dimsum, esp if we can get good dimsum for less than 20$ in chinatown.
author: Mingyu H.

description: My husband and I read a lot of reviews before visiting this place. We both visit SF from Toronto, Canada and hoping to find some authentic dim sum. We waited over 30 mins and was surprised to find that they only have limited choices for food! 2 push carts, approx 10 items combined would go around us 5 times! The waiting time and the amount charged for the food were extremely disappointing! Food was not authentic! Many essential items for dim sum were missing (I.e. rice shrimp rolls, curry cuttlefish, deep fried calamari).  In addition, the server was quite pushy for us to leave as we were waiting to see other items! Not impressed! Overall, this place is just mediocre at best!
author: Jessica C.

description: I knew about Yank Sing for a while, but hadn't been to this location until today. My mother took me. I just knew that the dim sum was more expensive. For 2 people we got 4 dishes and one dessert including XLB's, taro roll, shrimp dumpling, chicken curry puff pastry, and egg custard buns. It was a nice lunch. I like Dragon Beaux on Geary more because they have more finesse and interesting touches to dim sum cuisine. This was traditional with no surprises. I don't know why it is more expensive to eat dim sum at Yank Sing. It's not necessarily better, but not bad. The customers in the restaurant were mostly non-Chinese. Okay.
author: Denise C.

description:
Yank Sing order to go:

I have walked by this place before. Somehow I had the temptation to get shu mai for lunch today. Without  further thought, I decided come in and get something to eat. The dim sum is fresh, delicious and not greasy. I have tried only one item and will be back to try other items from the menu. Praise for clean restaurant facility, good layout and it's a great place for dim sum in SoMa.

Based on my observations:

Up: clean restaurant facility, friendly staff and good food.

Down: menu items seem to be leaning closer to the pricey side. However, cleanliness of the facility and prompt service really makes up for it.

- Side A: dine-in, guests wait to be seated and get a guest check once seated at a table. Same scenario as seen at other dim sum restaurants.

- Side B: order to go, quick and easy as always. Go up to the counter, make your selection and pay for it. Once the order is ready for pick up, retrieve and enjoy.

The dine-in and to go areas are divided, making it smooth and easy to settle on a choice.

I also admit some of the customers are very nice which is always a good thing. Overall, I enjoyed my food and good first experience here.

*Good luck finding a parking spot if driving here. Best alternative is to take public transportation.
author: Bennett W.

description:
Quite good, but you can rack up a high bill in a hurry. 

I really enjoy the staff pushing carts of ready-to-eat food around. You can get in and out quickly.  The food is quite good and some of the better dim sum I've experienced.  

Only negative is how pushy the folks with carts are trying to get you to take more than you can eat or want. 

I would definitely come back - everything I had was worthy of re-ordering.
author: David B.

description:
I typically have a few customer meetings in this area, so we randomly visit this place out of sheer convenience. From the few times I've been here, there is always a line out the door, so I'd advise arriving prior to Noon to avoid that 30 minute wait time!

Since I am not really a dim sum expert, I can't name everything we tried, but I do know we had the following:
Honey Walnut Shrimp
Honey Baked Seabass
Shrimp & Pork Dumplings
Mango Pudding
Egg Custard Tarts

I've actually been here a few times, and my experience has been consistent. You are never really "wow'ed" by anything, and you are never really disappointed by anything. Actually I take that back! When you tell them you are ready for your bill, that is when the shit hits the fan my friends! I do have to say this is the most expensive dim sum place I've been to in the Bay.

If it weren't for it's convenient location, I don't think I'd ever come back. It's not bad, nor is it great, but this high cost of dim sum doesn't reflect the quality one would expect. If I do make my way back, it is only because it was a request from one of my customers.

Conclusion:
Decent dim sum, but outrageously priced! Their desserts are probably better than their entrees!

"I WON'T BE BACK!"
author: Robert H.

description: There's a reason why this place is famous. They stay true to their roots while still serving up the kind of dim sum that Americans have come to know and love, at prices that most of us can afford. The service is spot-on and the food is delicious. I highly recommend Yank Sing if you're having a hankering for some Chinese dumplings!
author: Jeromy C.

description: I eat here everytime I come to San Francisco. The service is excellent and the food is great.  Love the Shanghai dumplings and Puer Tea.  Reservations are recommended.
author: Douglas C.

description: We chose this place mostly out of proximity.  Selection was plentiful and service was good enough. Between three people we spent nearly $100--with that being said, I hoped for warm and flavorful dishes, not the lukewarm and under seasoned ones we got. Not the best dim sum and definitely not cheap--will be trying another spot next time!
author: Tammy N.

description:
I loved my experience at Yank Sing. The restaurant itself is more upscale, and clean, which draws in a bustling crowd and most likely the higher price tag. But, the service is attentive and the food is delicious. 

Carts go around with servers offering the different selections so always lots of food to choose from (and why so easy to rack up the bill) but so tasty. The soup dumplings here are some of the best that I've had, and the potstickers have such a great cook to them. Also shout outs to the bbq steamed bun and the shrimp in the flat noodles. 

Very good aside from the damage it did to my wallet!
author: Kayla U.

description:
Didn't get a chance to check out this place last year I was in San Francisco. 
I'm glad I thought of this place and actually had the time to visit. 
Put my name on the waitlist and was seated in 20 min as I was told at around noon.
That hot tea!!!! You can just feel that health running down your throat, stomach and cleansing out the junk in your gut and blood!! Very nice clean taste. Water temperature just great!!
It was very very busy like any other day but we could focus on our food without huge distractions. 
We were able to order what we wanted to try. 
But I feel like the carts didn't come by with variety of food. 
It's quite a bit pricey but I think it's worth the buck
author: Jason B.

description:
Pretty good dim sum and one of the best service staff in a dim sum place I've experience.

Reduced two stars for:
1. Limited selection. Very westernized. Did not have shrimp crepe/roll, trip or anything considered too exotic
2. Way over priced for what you get
3. I got a veg dish that was cold and they said they served it cold (Chinese broccoli)
author: Minh H.

description: The quality of the food is fine, but for dim sum standards prices are far too high.  As well the selection seems to be taylored to the western palate and excludes many classic dishes synonymous with dim sum in place of panda express type items.  If you're looking for an authentic experience, don't look here
author: Kevin L.

description:
I was going to give this place 4 stars, but as soon as I saw the bill I was immediately less happy about the whole experience. This was definitely the most expensive dim sum I have had - $46 per person with tax/tip after splitting among 10 people. I would say we ordered an ordinary amount of food, nothing was left over and nobody was stuffed to the gills. And here we were, with a total of $450+

The food here is good, definitely better than your average dim sum place. I was a little disappointed that they do not carry any congee, but overall the selection is pretty diverse.
