I would highly recommend their Shanghai Pork Dumplings and Chicken Buns. Their dessert cart is delicious as well. It's located in an ally off 2nd street. Not too sketchy or anything, just make sure you don't miss it. The restaurant itself is very nicely furnished, well-lit and fairly spacious. So no need to worry if you have a big group.

My only complaint is about the price. It seemed like a rip-off to pay that much money for the amount of food we got. Maybe this is due to the location (in all fairness, SOMA/FiDi land is pretty expensive), I cannot say, but please be warned about it.
author: Angel C.

description:
Very tasty. 

Try their signature dumplings and awesome
Crab legs. Amazing. For lunch
author: Jennifer S.

description: Dim sum is one of my Sunday staples, and upon moving to SF I was excited to build my list of go-to dim sum places. This place is located right adjacent to the financial district in a really clean and classy spot that's not too busy on a given weekend. It's bustling and there's a great crowd that comes in - and the dim sum carts seem to build your appetite as you're waiting to be seated. Once seated, the service is really great and the carts come around fairly often, but I sadly wasn't impressed by the quality of the food - from the sea bass to the xiao long bao, I didn't think the price justified the food. Honestly, when I got the check the first time after ordering everything a la carte, I was surprised, and not in a good way. It came out to $80/person for just enough food for 3 people. I think that I would definitely be happy to add this place to my list of go-to's if the price was half of what they charge. In the meantime, I'm happy to keep hunting for my next Sunday dim sum spot!
author: Marites S.

description:
I can't believe it took me 17 years to finally eat at Yank Sing. The restaurant and overall experience exceeded my expectations. Yes, it was expensive at $200 for three people, but overall, the food was delicious and well worth the high price tag. I'd say it deserves the ranking as the best spot in San Francisco for Dim Sum. It was extremely crowded at lunch time, and we were glad we had a reservation. I wouldn't recommend going without a reservation unless you are prepared to wait.

We had 14 different dishes that came out rapid fire. My advice would be to pace yourself, and don't feel you have to order or eat everything that's presented to you, as more than likely, the item will be offered again a little later.

Some of the better Dim sum items included the Shrimp dumpling, the mushroom dumpling and the spinach dumpling. We really enjoyed the Honey baked Seabass, it was probably my favorite dish. The Peking Duck bun was disappointing as the skin came off the duck, the bun was doughy and the duck was unremarkable. The Minced Chicken Lettuce Cup was equally as good as others I've had elsewhere. We ordered a vegetable dumpling that was yellowish in color that wasn't that great. Everything was hot and cooked well. 

My niece had to try the Orange mellow and mango pudding for dessert, and both were a hit.
author: Emily C.

description: The restaurant is tray service dim sum which I was excited about but it let me down.  The servers don't come around often enough and skip over tables when going around.  Several times we were sitting without food on our table and no servers around for 10 minutes or so.  We stuck with shrimp dishes which were good but the dumplings were quite heavy rather than thin and soft.
author: Alice G.

description:
Quick and pleasant service for the 4 of us. Great selection of dim sum
And they modified their normal chow fun order to accommodate us.

Pricey and delicious- well worth the trip- parking on a Sunday is impossible- as the lots are shut..- and they don't have a valet.

Enjoyed the shu mai , chow fun, green beans, char siu  bao and szchechuan chicken dishes- no white or steamed rice was offered and the tea was nice.

A good find outside of China town proper
author: Greg B.

description: Ridiculously delicious dim sum!  All fresh and tasty but expensive when it all gets added up.  Memorable shrimp dishes. 5 star for quality, dropped down a star for cost. Plan on around $50 per person, unless you go for the most expensive items, like the sea bass. Jasmine tea was excellent, too.  Quite a treat, and not as frenetic as some Chinatown places.
author: Christine W.

description: Stopped in for dim sum...overall good but not great. Not much variety and the food was ok. Would recommend the ribs and the duck. Service was ok.
author: Peter L.

description: Incredible food and brilliant concept! Must try while in SF!!! New and great find for us when we were craving dim sum and didn't want to Uber to Chinatown. Make a reservation or call ahead because the place is slammed!
author: Pam P.

description: All around excellent dim sum, and some of the highest quality I've had in SF. That said, it is definitely over-priced (was ~90 for two people post-tip/tax) so I wouldn't frequent this place. I'd say that the few dollar dim sum you can get in Chinatown is only slightly worse in quality but 1/10 the price. However, the main thing that keeps me coming back are the egg tarts! They are always hot, fresh, and perfectly flaky. Will keep coming back just for those.
author: Theodora C.

description:
A busy upscale little place right off market. A lot of choices for you to try along with many favorites.
I think big parties are going to find seating a challenge so try to keep it to four or less. Carts come by fast and furiously and even if that one doesn't have what you want, they speak into wireless headset to have the other cart come by with your request. 
This keeps things moving fast that way.  We will be back and recommend to friends. This is now our go to spot for dim sum. Unless there is yet an undiscovered treasure yet to be found... Stay tuned!
author: Craig G.

description:
Prepare yourself! 

This restaurant is tucked in in an alley. And make sure to make reservations! Wait times, especially on weekends, can be pretty lengthy!

Food: delicious options! So many to choose from. My absolute favorite would have to be the Peking Duck. Sooo gooooood! But it's also about $7 per order. 

Customer Service: Aside from the wait time for the table... customer service is great. Everyone was quick and attentive. 

Price: a bit pricey, but you are in SF.... so it's expected! Our bill was about $140 for 4 people, yikesssss.

Would I come back? absolutely! I'm already craving for the Peking Duck.
author: Jadelann J.

description:
Crazy good...and crazy expensive

Yank Sing was recommended to us by our concierge as THE place to go for Dim Sum. And it was quite simply the best dim sum I've had in the past 20 years. Everything...EVERYTHING was a cut above your normal dim sum palace. Even the desserts - which I normally ignore while my wife and kids chomp on a fried sesame ball - were spectacular.  That said...our lunch came out to $75/person with no alcoholic beverages.

The service was quite good as well. Lots of carts rolling through the aisles and no problem specially ordering something from the kitchen that we hadn't see come by our table. Lastly, the decor is modern Asian with lots of wood and light.

I recommend a reservation unless you come before or after the lunch crowd...otherwise expect to wait 30-60 minutes for a table. And I do recommend eating here...at least once...to experience what dim sum can and should be.
author: Leo M.

description: The only reason I am not going to give it 5 stars is that although the food was great, I expected a little better service for the steep prices and was not thrilled with the BBQ pork buns. Obviously, this place is a killer dim sum restaurant because the place was packed the entire time I was there and I was generally impressed with everything I had. I feel like a little more information for us inexperienced "dim summers" would have been helpful. Also, I didn't know the soup dumplings (the Shanghai ones, which they are known for) came in 4 or 6 qty. Even though I loved the soup dumplings, because I got 6, I was too full to try other things that looked delish. I was also slightly disappointed with the BBQ pork buns. The bun to pork ratio was off, which also filled me up. Overall, I would definitely go back and I would ask more questions before going all in on some of the offerings.
author: Caitlin J.

description:
The famous Yank Sing in the financial district. Came here for lunch for a client meeting around 11AM, wasn't too crowded, but it starts popping around 12:30PM!

Service was quick and fast. I really enjoyed their the small little details here. Such as their chopsticks are branded and the tea pot is super cute and cool. Just like a normal dim sum place, they just come around and you choose what you want.

We ordered:
Har Gaw: Pretty good and standard, the dumpling was kind of small
Siu Mai: Good not bad
Leaf with Sticky Rice: Liked their presentation, enjoyed this one
Shanghai Dumplings: Steamy and juicy, recommend ordering this
Pork Chop Buns: Hot and yummy
Fried Taro Cake: Loved this, can't go wrong
Steamed Spare Ribs: Recommend, other places usually cook the spare ribs pretty dry, but they do a good job here
Chinese Broccoli: Basic, nothing special
Meat with Wrapped Lettuce: Not orth ordering, wasn't satisfying
Fried Lobster: OK, kind of cold when it cam out
Mushroom Dumpling: OK
Chive Dumpling: OK

One thing I can say is their hot sauce is SOOOOO good and their hot mustard. You can buy it at any Chinese market. I highly recommend!

Overall, I found this place mediocre. I have had better. Not sure I would come here again honestly. But worth the try.
author: Natalie L.

description: I get the Phoenix, it's delicious, comes w/pork chowmein, pork fried rice, 2 potstickers, 1 shrimp shumai, 1 spring roll for $9.15. The lunch section is open from 1 to 3pm.
author: Lisa L.

description: Overall good quality. It's a very busy establishment so good for groups. Not for romantic !
author: cee b.

description:
Booked a table for seven for a work event on a Wednesday for 1 pm.  Sat out on the tilted patio.

Very limited variety of dim sum and not much of it.  After a first round, 20 minutes went by and I had to start calling one of the two managers over to ask for more dishes to be brought over.  

They started playing that game where everything you asked for they'd shake off and tell you it would be twenty minutes.  It was obvious they were more concerned about leftovers than feeding their customers.  No desserts whatsoever.  None!

Our bill was $220 for the seven of us, mostly due to taking on four orders of Shanhai Dumplings just to get something on the table.  Exactly one plate of daikon cakes.  Zero steamed ribs, no tripe.

For a high end restaurant with prices in the stratosphere we shouldn't be chasing the managers down to get food on a table for seven.
author: Tobi B.

description:
Foods:
+ There were plenty of delicious selections of dimsums.
+ The duck was nice but quite pricey.
+ The foods are not as oily as usual dimsum place. 
+ The tea (oolong) was really delicious too.

Service:
- Waiting time can be a problem as many people come here (seems to be a destination for tourists).
author: Rafael W.

description:
One word: meh.  The food was alright, but nothing particularly stands out in my mind.  It also doesn't help that this is super expensive dim sum.  

Came for a Friday lunch and it wasn't too hard getting a table without a reservation.  Maybe it's because we were sitting outside, but there didn't seem to be too many options in the carts that came by.  We had to specifically ask for certain dishes.  

The upside is that the people here are friendlier than your typical dim sum place.
author: Shannon L.

description: It was OK. Not bad, not awesome. Very catered to Americans. Little bit on the pricey side. Lunch for 3 was $115.00.
author: Terri V.

description:
I am so happy that my family introduced me to yank sing. As a vegan/ vegetarian, dim sum is virtually impossible to partake in but YS had many vegan options available.l. I had the spinach dumpling, shiitake mushrooms dumpling, and string beans. I saw that there were 4 more dumpling options as well that were veg. Which is about 5 more than the usual one veg dumpling option available. 
Easy to make a reservation on line even for a Saturday morning. Was very pleased. PS the rest of my family who are carnivores very much enjoyed their plates too.
author: Linette E.

description: If you want quality Dim Sum this is one of the best in San Francisco! Really busy at lunch so plan accordingly. They do have a side order takeout window if you are in a hurry. I have never had a bad meal at this place. A little pricey but worth it!
author: Fred W.

description:
BEST dim sum I've had in the states! Highly recommend as long as you're okay with the price.

It's quite interesting how inauthentic yet authentic Yank Sing is. The inauthenticity comes from the lack of many traditional dim sum dishes like cheung fun (rice rolls) for example whilst offering many non-traditional dim sum dishes like black cod or crab claw. Given that, you would expect their traditional dim sum dishes to taste very inauthentic, non-traditional, westernized BUT that is most definitely not the case. Their traditional dishes are SO authentic and taste so similar to how they do in asia! They're definitely the best in the area.

I highly recommend their soup dumplings, lotus leaf sticky rice, shrimp dumpling, bbq pork bun, egg custard bun, shu mai. If you like hot sauce, try theirs - it's to die for!!

-1 star for the crazy prices (2x the price of typical dim sum dishes), insanely long wait (they told us it'd be 1 hour and we waited for 2.5 hours), the mediocre service (not very attentive)...however, despite all this, I'll definitely keep coming here. It's so good! Highly highly recommend!
author: Cynthia H.

description:
Sorry YS lovers! This place is so over priced and not that good. Been here a few times and all they care to do is selling you shanghai dumplings and $22 honey cod! As for steamed dim sum not many choices and it was mediocre. I think Koi Palace is better. However I do like their hot sauce.

I can't believe sesame balls are $12.70 for 4! OVER PRICED! I refused to ordered that lol. We had 4 steamed kind of dim sum and the bill was $35! 

Service was 2 stars! It was a little better then nothing.
author: Vivi C.

description: I feel stupid to come into this place for dim sum! There are a lot of better ones like koi palace, way much better or cheaper dim sum than this place. Tank sing is on every website top recommendation of dim sum. So we came in to try the dim sum, but feel very disappointed and stupid! Xlb charges about 14 bucks 6pieces, but all xlb broke when you use chopsticks to pick it up ( usually frozen ones will break right away). And some other fried items like sesame balls, green onion pancake, are way overpriced! 3 times more expensive than upscale dim sum places! Giving them 2 stars is about their to go service! To go service is cheap and reasonable!
author: Nina H.

description:
Came here to try some great dim sum despite the known high end prices they are known for with their dim sum I had to give it a try and share my unbiased review with everyone.

We ordered 2 orders of the steam bbq pork bun this comes with 2 buns for each order. This was really good compared to all the dim sum places I have gone in so cal and Phx. The buns weren't soggy like other places and it just taste so fresh.

The Shanghai dumpling was the first time I've ever tried it. Quite honestly I was not a big fan of it. It's a soup dumplings with meat inside I think this was $14 I wouldn't get it again but it worth a try. 

The Seabass was really good I was hesitant to order this because it was a little piece of fish for $20 but I'm glad my girlfriend grab it  you have to try it

The shu Mai and har gow is definitely worth a try you can tell it was cooked with higher quality. It's noticeably different from all the places I tried.

Peking duck hmm it was $6.50 for a slice of duck with a bun we ordered 3. Honestly this taste just like any other places you're pretty much paying for presentation. Please feel free to try one and be your own judge. But there weren't anything special about this other than the presentation.

I recommend ordering one qty of everything you want to try and taste it before ordering 2 or more of the same thing because this place is expensive. 

I would definitely come back for there bbq pork buns, Seabass, shu Mai and har gow. 

Give this place a try if you want to seek a food adventure 

I took a star away for some overpriced items that weren't as great as the price it is stated to be.
author: Keniff K.

description:
This place is fine. It's totally fine. It's not terrible, but it's not great dim sum. If you want great dim sum, I don't really know where to tell you to go, but this isn't it. It's also very pricey.

We tried:
- Chicken egg rolls
- Stuffed crab claw
- Steamed pork buns
- Shrimp dumpling
- Pork shu mai
- Shanghai dumpling (their signature dish)
- Pot stickers
- Green onion cake
- Curry chicken pie

The green onion cake was the best and I would say it was excellent. The pot stickers and curry pie were also stand outs. The rest were pretty bland.  It kind of took a while for the food to come. And we were skipped for a while. I ate well but it was also $100 for two people. It's not work that at all.

If you have friends who have never had dim sum, this is a good starter place. But for the deep cuts, go elsewhere.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Always a wait, always delicious and always walk out thinking: this is why I have to go to work to make money. 
Don't miss the glazed sea bass- just a few bites for $28, but man, tasty! While I feel slightly guilty about eating this endangered specie, but I reconcile my guilt with the fact that I only ear 3 ounces of it per order.
author: Michelle K.

description: Food is good and service is quick but it's hard to leave without spending $50 a person which is pretty steep for brunch and especially for dim sum. This location is smaller and more personal, which I love. Due to miscommunication, we actually walked in around 1230 on a Sat without any reservations (eek!). Luckily, they were able to seat us immediately and I noticed several empty tables. I ordered a glass of bubbly and we were ready to get started. If you are hungry, this is great as the carts start rolling around and targeting newcomers immediately. We ended ordering 6 dishes (2 of which were veggies), tea, a glass of bubbly and a beer - couldn't believe how steep the bill was! Yikes! Food is good but not worth the price tag. Good thing is if they don't have something you're looking for, they'll call into their walkie talkies and within 5 minutes, it will magically appear :)
author: Yin H.

description:
Although there were plenty of other dimsum places in SF, my friend and I chose here bcuz of the high rating. 
I wasnt really happy with the price, but I was so hungry and we had to wait 40min for lunch and my friend had a hard time looking for a parking spot for 40min. 

It was 2 of us and we ordered pretty much....
My fav was
-pork&shrimp shumai
-scallop shumai
-shrimp dumpling
(All juicy and nicely chewy)

And we also had 
-chicken&mushroom one
-sth w meat and chive
-honey walnut shrimp($13 ripoff but tasty)
 
Oh and the hot tea was charged too.....it sucks
So we spent freaking $84(plus tax n tip) and i wasnt even very full but my friend was. 
Lolol but no regrets! Im coming back soon!
author: Angie S.

description:
I loved Yank Sing when I was visiting San Francisco!  This is hands down the best dim sum I have ever had.  This place was suggested to me by friends in the restaurant business in Texas.

We made a lunch reservation, and when we got there realized our weekday lunch reservation was overkill.  Possibly because we were eating a later lunch, but they wasted no time getting carts to our table!  They were asking us if we wanted certain items before we even sat down.  That was tough because it was our first time here, and we had not even seen the menu! Also, I did not get a pleasant reaction when I would say no, thank you or please come back in a few minutes so I can look at the menu.

The food was absolutely delictable!!  We started off with melt in your mouth Shanghai dumplings that were tasteful and offered a flavorful broth on the inside with pork, scallions and ginger.  Heaven in a dumpling.  Had the curried chicken turnover- lovely filling of chicken and mushrooms, turnover had a slight sweetness on the top, and the pastry turnover itself (oh my goodness) was yummy, flaky, and buttery.  Potstickers, pork Sui Mye, BBQ pork steam bun, green beans were all great choices too!!  It was hard not to keep going back here while visiting San Francisco, but I had a list of places I really wanted to try while I was there!  I will return.

Downsides: got a little bit of attitude from waitstaff, from asking carts to come back or saying no thank to asking for water, it's expensive for lunch dim sum (San Francisco dim sum pricing??).
author: Kim H.

description:
While this is one of the pricier dim sum joints in the city (think I would rate it as $$$, not $$), Yank Sing consistently delivers with delicious food. I recommend the soup dumplings, they're outstanding. Would also recommend making a reservation, especially at lunchtime. 

As a side note, Yank Sing makes an excellent corporate lunch spot because it's sit-down, fast (the food is already prepared -- you just point at it and eat it!), and delicious -- one of the few nice lunches where you can be in and out of the restaurant in under an hour.
author: Neha S.

description: So, first off, this is not the cheap, village-style dim sum. We enjoyed Yank Sing because it is a higher level of dim sum. We could tell that the food quality was higher, and the food was prepared freshly, so we understood why it is more expensive than some other places over in Chinatown. Yank Sing Stevenson Street is a one block walk from The Palace Hotel, near Market and New Montgomery. It's kinda hidden, so you might forget it's there. They have a cool covered outdoor patio seating for days when San Francisco is warm enough, but plenty of indoor seating, but I do recommend a reservation if, like us, you need to get to the theater on time. All our food selections were fresh and delicious, if not abundant. The service was upbeat, and responsive to our requests, and they worked well as a team. It seemed like a kinda special treat, given the prices, but you won't go bankrupt.
author: James G.

description:
The food here is very high quality--no blobs of gristle/fat in the dumplings, especially the pork buns, and the noodle dishes aren't mushy and the baked items very flakey and flavorful. The presentation is thoughtful--the shanghai dumplings are like works of art, holding in all that soupy broth in their thin noodle casings. Ingredients are super fresh, there's nothing fishy tasting (or smelling) and the bites, although small (since it's dim sum), are very filling. The hot chili sauce on the table is to die for. One person at our table even stated that he could eat it by itself--it's that delicious.

The pricing is a little out of control.... $16 for 6 Shanghai dumplings, $11 for a plate of potstickers, 1 peking duck bun is $6, 4 small pieces of jian dui are $11, and a small bowl of mango custard will run you $5.50. Traditionally, I'm used to rice and tea included in the meal but here it is a la carte, and adds to the final bill. For a modest midday lunch, expect to pay at least $35 a head, not even including any of the super fancy stuff like the sea bass, etc. 

Definite must-haves when you go: chicken curry turnovers (so flakey, buttery, and really delicious curry flavor), Shanghai dumplings, and chicken spring rolls. 

However, the ambiance is very upscale and it is located in between the Fidi and SoMa, so a high price tag is somewhat to be expected. All in all, a great place for an upscale business lunch or an intimate celebration.
author: Alison A.

description: Good food, esp egg rolls. Price will catch you off guard for sure though. 50 big ones per person easy.
author: Brent B.

description:
Other then the grand ambiance and love for being in the city, this place does have its ups and downs, big pros if you sit outside it is first come first serve, look for the steamed trays with piping hot goodies 

Here is what I sampled and how it faired

Shu Mai - pork & shrimp meshed in a steamed roll - even though made fresh tasted as if it was not made in house, tasted as if it was defrosted then reheated

shu mai - scallop meshed in steamed roll - different taste to original shu mai offering also tasted as if it was not made in house 

xia long bao - dumpling with sauce found in bottom - piping hot, slight waxy aftertaste, red vinegarette to dip in, had it straight up, I would order this again

steamed pork - diced pork ribs some with soft ribs some with hard, piping hot portion wise for 1 person is perfect, slight garlic flavor, unlike most spots this place offers more meat then bone on this dish, definite plus

bean curd - doesn't sound appetizing but here it was just ok, 2 pieces sliced into 4 pieces, usually comes with worcestershire sauce, here it did not, piping hot yes, without the sauce it lacked its luster, not a flavorful as some other places I have sampled this dish

tea- fancy tea pot, see through, tea is mild good for all that dim sum

food *** sampled several of there dim sum offerings just ok
price $$$
service **** very friendly and helpful staff
ambiance **** fancy inside and fancy outside
author: Clarence A.

description: The Stevenson location is more intimate and less crowded. The dim sum is just as good.
author: Colin W.

description: Super overpriced. Went there and got a handful of standard dim sum items (5-6) that were NOT fancy (pork bun, shrimp dumpling, etc) and a cheap glass of wine, and the bill ended up being around $100. I was legitimately shocked at how overpriced this meal was - I would have expected to pay $50-60. Will definitely avoid in the future.
author: Brian K.

description: I find it unsual this place is so highly rated. It's has an interesting concept. Bring around food on carts as it's cooked and you order what u want. The problem is this is horribly executed. I was here for over an hour and left hungry. The carts came around very slowly if really at all and the people pushing the carts didn't or couldn't adequately tell u what they had. So you sort of had to guess or comprise with what you want or thru shear luck they bring out what u want.   I  really wanted spinach  rolls but they never came around  My wife  has a seafood allergy and got seafood, that was fun. It was expensive and overall the food just  wasn't good.
author: Steven C.

description: My friend took me to this place.  I am (pleasantly) surprised that for such a hot Chinese restaurant It actually took reservation.   The food is excellent, I am usually not a big fan of cha shu bao, but the baked version is so good.   Lastly, the staff are well trained, warm, friendly, respectful, yet prompt in service.   They coordinate well amongst themselves so the request food come quickly and fresh.  Lastly the restroom are clean and maintained.  Rare to have all these quality at the same time.   I love took my friends and coworker here for lunch.   You can enjoy a good meal while getting in and out within an hour, very much suited for the fast pace of financial district clientele.
author: Lost L.

description:
Going to preface this by saying it was not the best idea to come here on Christmas Day without a reservation... It ended up being a 1.5 hour wait but the food made it (mostly) worth. If you're going to walk in, you give them your phone number and they'll take you when your table is ready. They'll hold your reservation for 10 minutes so don't wander too far away. Another option is their take out store. It's on the side of their main store and its called Yank Sing 2 and it's only for take out.

Most of their store is inside but during busy times, they'll seat you outside. If the weather is good, sitting outside is quite nice but when it's cold the heated lamps just don't keep you warm enough especially if the wind is blowing. If you come here during the winter and don't mind the wait, ask to get a seat inside.

For the food, this is pretty expensive dimsum. You're looking at $6-$10 per dish. Most dishes come with 2-4 pieces depending on what you order. For 2 people, we spent about $40 each whereas you can get just as much food in Chinatown dimsum places for less than half the price. Honestly though, I was pretty impressed by the taste, it definitely felt authentic. 

Must haves:
- Shanghai Dumplings (their signature dish, very very tasty)
- Egg Custard Buns
- Mandarin Dumpings with Chives

If you're looking for cheaper dimsum, head up to Chinatown area. This is more appropriate for people who may not be as familiar with dimsum and ordering in cantonese/mandarin. It's
author: Cassie Z.

description: I recommend making a reservation online especially for big parties. That said, we were seated pretty promptly. Hot tea is not standard and you have to order (pay) for it. They bring the dim sum out by carts and you order what you like. I judge my dim sum by the standard of their ha gow (shrimp dumpling). There was a lot of shrimp in it but the taste was just ok for me. I prefer the skin to be more translucent. The rest of the dishes were good but not amazing. I did love the egg tarts, which was made to order (I think) and it was piping hot. Service was better than most dim sum restaurants. Prices are VERY steep. Between my husband and I, we racked up a $100 bill. So order wisely and don't try to order everything.
author: M Y.

description:
Food was good but grossly (no insanely!!!) overpriced. I've been to my fair share of dim sum places in my life and food here is pretty good. So good that they charge $12 bucks for soup dumplings that the best place in NYC charges $5.50 for?! Hell no! $7 bucks for a Peking duck bun? Ridiculous... But hey I ordered it and knew it cost that much. Was it amazing? Not at all.. If it were my complaining about the price would be a non-issue.

Overall decent to good dim sum.. But for prices .. I thought I would be getting exceptional food, which it wasn't. 

I'm from out of town so did not mind spending more especially as we came with my in laws.. Who thought it was good (but they didn't see prices). Would I ever come again? No, but nice time for a tourist like me. Would otherwise NEVER be a regular.
author: lesley l.

description: Always love Yum Cha (Dim Sum) lunch, arrived in a late Sunday afternoon, still lots of people, good food and service，handy location, highly recommend.
author: Mark S.

description:
Very decent Dim Sum restaurant situated in the financial district of San Francisco. You get a taste of traditional rolling cart style Dim Sum dishes. You don't really need the menu, you can just wait for the carts if you are feeling adventurous. I love the soup dumplings, pork buns and chicken mushroom dumplings. And the Chilli sauce compliments most of the dishes too!

The service crew is very responsive to your requests and orders even though this place is very crowded. And I love the Chinese tea that they serve there too. (Especially great for cold weathers to warm your body up)

Lastly, this place is very crowded and there's always a queue, so you might want to come early to avoid queuing.
author: Clement W.

description:
When my coworkers asked if I would take them to dim sum, I took this as an opportunity to try Yank Sing's soup dumplings. And they were okay, guys. Not mindblowing, but pretty good!

What wasn't good? The service. I tried to order something in Chinese, and my waiter actually glared at me. Seriously, no one would communicate with me in Chinese. It was crazy. They would just respond to me in English, so they clearly understood me but just chose not to respond.

Also I tried to order baked BBQ pork buns, and our waiter (pretty rudely) told me they didn't make any that day, but I saw him deliver two plates to a white lady with a fanny pack on. Weird.
author: Christina S.

description: I miss Yank Sing after moving from San Francisco to Fresno. Having my beloved Dim Sum at Yank Sing is on my to-do list every visit back to the city!  Soooooo good
author: Kim W.

description:
Booooo . . . got ya!!! Only tourists and clueless corp. types will get suckered by this place.  Food seems and taste no better than what you would get for much much lower in SFCT.  Or that could've very well been the case. Buy it in bulk at one of the major dim sum producers in SFCT, truck it over, put them in fancy plates served by waiters in bow ties or in a black and white garb, roll them in carts and it's time to gouge all the unsuspecting customers.  Voila!!! Caveat emptor! Monay, monay, monaaaaayyyyyyy!!!

Now, who wants to take the next sucker's seat?
author: Marc F.

description: Food is great dim sum. They roll them out on carts to you. I would recommend this place to friends.
author: Dora S.

description: Had a really nice dim sum lunch here! All of the food was really good, and service was friendly and efficient. Prices were probably a bit high for dim sum, but it's a great space and location so I didn't really take off points for that here.
author: Mari K.

description:
The pork and shrimp dumplings were my favorite. We got three orders of that. The fried sea bass and the grilled sea bass were a close second.

Our party of five arrived at noon on Saturday and were seated immediately because we made a reservation. I highly recommend that you make a reservation as the entire restaurant was packed...no open tables.

The prices are pretty steep. Our bill was $180 for five people and we ordered a moderate amount of food. Had we arrived with hungry stomachs, our bill would have easily been over $220+

Yank Sing, for me, is a one-time experience as I believe there are cheaper dim sum places that serve equally tasty foods.
author: Tien L.

description: Quick, okay dim sum available for takeout if you're short on time. And of course, be prepared to pay FiDi prices for it. So if you're willing to trade some quality for a time crunch, I would recommend it for that to satisfy a dim sum craving.
author: Briget P.

description:
Can't get enough of their xiao long baos! 

I have gone here ever since i was in elementary school with my parents and their quality has always been the same. Yes they are pricer than most dim sum places in the bay area aside from Koi Palace but their staff here are a lot friendlier and quicker. 

Other top picks: Mushroom dumpling, pistachio ice cream pie, and mango ice cream pie.

Tip: Do your best to make a reservation because there is alway a wait. A table of three on the day before July 4th took around 40 minutes. Now you know why it's best to make a reservation and don't think about making one the day of. Everyone tends to make reservations days in advance.

Why you should come here: life is about experiences, why not enhance your foodie experiences at one of the best!
author: Eva O.

description: Great location, nice interior but high price tag. Unfortunately I did notice anything special.
author: Sato A.

description:
Dim sum was one of my main priorities on our recent visit to San Francisco. My friend suggested Yank Sing after having several people recommend the restaurant so we made our way there on a Sunday morning. 

The place was pretty busy, but we were seated quickly and service was attentive. Food rotated quickly on the carts and there was a large variety of options available. I enjoyed every item I tried. 

The only downside to our meal was the price. I don't mind being a little spendy with my meals but I think they were a little more overpriced based solely on the location.
author: Emily R.

description: First spot we stopped at during our trip to San Francisco. Fantastic start to the trip as the food is excellent. This is a higher end dim sum place with good variety. Chicken satay, Shanghai dumplings, duck, mushrooms, Shumai were excellent. Highly recommend, but plan as a wait quickly ensues here
author: Andrew T.

description: We came here after hearing recommendations from friends.  It was located within walking distance from our hotel.  The restaurant is very clean and the service is very friendly.  They didnt have much of a line on a Sunday round 2pm, which was great.  We were seated pretty quickly and the carts of dim sum came out fast.  They are great with advising whats yummy and speak english, which is helpful.  The prices for dim sum are much higher than you'd get in chinatown area, but I guess thats what happens when you move further out from there.  They also have beer and wine too.  The dim sum was pretty up to par from my experiences in San Gabriel Valley in LA, just the prices were much higher.  Overall a yummy place to grab lunch.
author: Jenn T.

description:
Okay food but way too EXPENSIVE.  
Two small pieces of crab puff cost me $14! I don't really get why so expensive! 
Another thing I don't understand is that there are waiters pushing carts around and advertise for different dim-sums. If you want to get one, they will put a stamp on your card. So the problem is that customers are not informed and fully aware of the prices for each different dim-sum. If I knew the crab puff is 14 dollars, I wouldn't get it the first place. 
I had 5 different sets of sim-sums, and it was already more than 50 bucks. The quality is also ordinary, not as good compared to other similar ranked Chinese dim-sum. Overall this is not a good experience, if you want to get some authentic dim sum with good service, defiantly go to the Dragon Beaux on Geary.
author: Ender L.

description:
Where are we?! Did the server just smile at me AND say thank you . . . at a dim sum place?! Say whaaaa?!?!?  Just for that, I'm definitely coming back! Ha! 

Seriously tho, for a dim sum place this is pretty fancy!

- It's CLEAN! No really, even the bathrooms are clean :)
-Service with a smile! There was an issue getting our table but they were very apologetic. During our meal, there were lot's of smiles and thank you's. Soooo not used to that at any Asian place!
-RESERVATIONS! I've never even heard of a dim sum place accepting reservations! Call in or use the Open Table app
-Modernized! They'll text you when your table is ready. And the cart waitresses have headsets to communicate. So, if you're looking for a certain dish they'll call over the cart waitress to come to your table.
-Great food . . . the XLB (Shanghai Soup Dumplings) and the warm egg custard tarts were ahhhh-mazing!!!

One star taken off for the price. Its just way too pricey for the quantity and portion of the food. I believe for 6 of the XLB's was $14 and about $11 for 4 egg custards. Can't remember any of the other prices since I wasn't in charge of collecting the money (thank goodness! I hate that job!).
author: Marissa P.

description: Fabulous dim sum and great service!  The duck and sea bass are heavenly!  The chicken skewers were also quite good as well as the pork buns!
author: Sue P.

description:
I went to Yank Sing on a Sunday around 10am with a friend to celebrate a belated Chinese New Year for the both of us. The restaurant was relatively filled for an early 10am dim sum. We ordered off the carts and got around 11 dishes between the two of us. Everything was perfectly authentic and I was pleasantly surprised that they did individual servings of Peking Duck with buns and Chicken Lettuce Wraps. I have never been to a dim sum place that does this and it really solidified my enjoyment of this restaurant. I think there was also a special set menu for Chinese New Year because one of the ladies pushing the dessert cart told me that the Milk Tea Pudding was part of the set menu. Upon seeing how sad I was about that, she still let me order a serving of it. The pudding was very creamy and the milk tea taste was strong and authentic. It was really nice of her to allow me to order it and I enjoyed it immensely. 

This restaurant is definitely more on the pricey side though; for two people, it came out to be around $100! We each paid around $60, including tip. I've definitely had cheaper dim sum that is around the same quality, but I think the individual servings and the dessert really pushed this restaurant to 5 stars for me. I would probably come back with a bigger group so we could order more and try different dishes.
author: Isabel C.

description: Everything we ordered was ok. Egg tart was prob the best item. I don't have much expectation for dim sum or Chinese food in SF - most are not that great.
author: Gloria T.

description:
The pea shoot dumpling was probably the best vegetarian dumpling I've ever eaten

Expensive for the portion sizes
author: Jesse E.

description: Great dim sum! Everything tasted hot and fresh. Good quick service and they were very patient in explaining the different varieties to us.
author: Laura W.

description: Excellent service. There's someone there to take care of your needs at all times. Singapore family style family servings where people just move around with carts to serve you food. They have amazing variety of dumplings. It's moderately expensive. But worth it. The egg custard bun was very yummy for dessert. Highly recommend it.
author: Shashank R.

description:
Yank Sing was my first experience with dim sum, and boy was it tasty. I am a huge fan of dumplings of all kinds, and couldn't wait to get my hands on their BBQ Pork Buns! They definitely have the factor of enticement down (carts are constantly passing by your table and you are being offered more delicious food than any one person could handle), so I had to learn to say "no" after hitting the ground running for lunch...

We started with snap peas, potstickers, and some sort of fried shrimp and asparagus dish. Other highlights included the BBQ pork buns, Shrimp Sui Mye, Shanghai dumplings and my particular favorite, sesame balls. I could have eaten at least 23 of those. Overall I really enjoyed the meal, and the tea which paired perfectly. However, I couldn't believe the price of the meal once we got the bill! It seemed pretty steep for the amount of food that we got.
author: Clara T.

description: Authentic dim sum, great location for casual business meetings. Be sure to make reservation. Most dishes are great, a few a little sub par but all good. My go to place other than hakkasan
author: Brian T.

description: This place had amazing food! I really enjoyed it. I can't really say much about the food I ate because I don't remember what they were. They were all very good though! The service was fast with the food but took awhile for the beverages. I recommend this place.
author: Jerome N.

description:
This place has really gone downhill... service is quite terrible and everyone treats you with the most dismissive attitude. We came more than an hour before closing time and seems all the dishes they had left to offer was a small series of fried and steamed dumplings. They give you a menu of all the selection, but whats the point? They were out of more than half the food. Anything that wasn't a bun or a dumpling they we're out of. My family and I have been coming here for years, but never again.
The only reason i'm giving two stars is because the food is good, but you can get even better dim sum for actually REASONABLE prices anywhere else in SF. I have local friends who laugh when I used to tell them I liked this place, now i know why.
author: Vivian N.

description: It's too oily and salty for a lunch takeout. I feel drowsy all the afternoon. It's probably because it's meaty (eggplant & beef), quite a mount of rice and does not have much green vegetables. If you want to stay productive for the afternoon, have a take out that has more vegetables, less salt and less oil.
author: Frank W.

description:
Will not return.. 
We're from Orange County, CA and we heard that we should try Yank Sing for delicious dim sum.
We came around 12 and there was about a 15 minute wait for 2 people (not bad) 
I've tried many different dim sum places and top decor has to go to this place.
Now, for the food... So disappointing. Especially for the prices. It's marked up 2-3x more than what we normally pay for dim sum.
We were skeptical at first because of the prices but wanted to try due to a friends recommendation. 
We got their famous soup dumplings, fried shrimp (4pcs) , fried crab legs (2pcs) , pork/shrimp shumai (4pcs) , potstickers (I think 8pcs) , & bbq pork bun (2pcs) 
Food Details
-Soup Dumplings: soggy, bland 
-Fried Shrimp: VERY small piece of shrimp inside the batter 
-Fried Crab: Where's the crab?? Hardly any crab meat (STEER CLEAR, NOT WORTH $15)
-Pork/shrimp Shumai: THE WORST, tasted funny
-Potstickers: Highlight of the meal , very delicious/juicy
-BBQ Pork Bun: Very tasty with lots of flavor
Majority of these were mediocre, nothing spectacular about them especially for the price people pay.
We paid roughly $70+ tax & tip for these.
Definitely not worth it..
author: Misa L.

description: As a native San Franciscan this is one of my go-to places for Dim Sum. Fresh, tasty as hell, and pleasant surroundings with nice staff. I can't give it five stars in good conscience because I am not informed enough to judge the authenticity of the food, but i note a fair amount of Asian people eat here so I take that as a good sign of approval. The Rincon Annex location is not as good as Stevenson so i wouldn't bother with it. Unless your a tourist who won't know the difference.
author: leana a.

description: Very good. Fast service but can feel rushed (to be expected ) Food quality is very good. Suggest shrimp dishes over chicken dishes . Price is moderate. Good ambiance. Would come back for sure.
author: Beaumont J.

description:
I absolutely love dim sum and I did my research before trying this place. I have to admit  I hesitated before trying due to some 2 star negative posts. After trying for myself Yank Sing is my new favorite spot for dim sum hands down.
Service was impeccable. Atmosphere was clean and organized.  The food was super delicious. 
I have to say, they took dim sum to a whole new level. They offered everything from your basic dishes to Peking duck, sea bass w/miso honey, chicken lettuce cups, walnut shrimp and so on, the list goes on.
I finally got why the negative posts. Those people are basically complaining about the price.
 Do you know the cost of sea bass by the pound? Its $18.99 per pound at its cheapest. 
If you want quality food it will cost you. Please don't ruin this great restaurants reputation just because you want inexpensive food.
Everyone else please try for yourself you won't be disappointed.
Just be cautious of what you are ordering since depending on what it is it may be a bit pricier.
author: Tristan K.

description: Food is fine, service wasn't great. I made a reservation in advance but they still sat me in an awkward table by the bathroom. Took forever to get water or service.
author: C H.

description: Kerry is the best server on the planet !! Food is fresh, hot, tasty and authentic. Love the chili oil that they sell by the jar to go.....yummy!
author: Lucy R.

description:
My family and I took the BART out to SF to take a day trip to visit the SF Mission. We wanted to have some Dim Sun to start our day and Yelped Yank Sing and saw all the great reviews. It didn't mention in the reviews that the restaurant was attached to a hotel so it threw us off a little. The place was a bit crowded and small so we sat out in the patio which was ok cause they had the heaters on. 

The food and service was phenomenal! I would definitely go back. It is a bit pricey for dim sum but you will not be disappointed. Everything was delicious. They use quality ingredients. As the daughter of a chef I know when restaurants cut corners.
author: Mei C.

description: We've been going to Yank Sing since we were little and my parents before then. It was always really good but I never appreciated the dim sum until I went to other dim sum places my friends recommended in LA. Today, the dim sum was SO good. The shrimp har gow, the chicken and mushroom dumpling and the Peking duck are my favorites. And we also order the snap peas for a vegetable. Make sure you make a reservation because there was a crowd of people waiting in the wind and rain this morning for a t
author: Emily Y.

description:
This is a long overdue review. The dimsum is decent but way over priced. Since I lived literally right across the street from here for half a year, I probably still would have come out of convenience. 

BUT I only came once, and that was enough for me because the service was so horrible. Frankly, I felt the servers (host?) were racist and rude. (The irony is that I'm Chinese, and this is a Chinese restaurant). Avoid, unless you are not Chinese, maybe older in age, and don't care to pay a premium for subpar dimsum.
author: Cynthia X.

description:
Food is decent, but expensive. I also left hungry 

Sea bass - greasy 
Siu long bao - no soup in the dumpling
Potstickers - cold and gummy
Sticky rice - one tiny wrap per order, probably the best dish
Siu Mai - meh 

Excellent service. Waters were refilled without having to be asked. 

About $80 for 2 people. A reservation is a must on a weekday or be prepared to wait. I prefer the other location on Spear Street, although that one probably cost more (and you'll leave just as hungry).
author: Angelica C.

description: Yank Sing 2 has the same top notched Dim Sum, as their Rincon Center location.  The crowd at this location tends to be more of the Financial District, as the other place has a combination of tourists and wealthy Chinese people.  Please note that this place isn't for the value conscious, expect to pay $25 to $50 per person!  Unlike many Chinese Restaurants in Chinatown, Yank Sang has exceptional customer service and will continuously push those delicious plates, which somehow gets devoured!  Another upscale feature, is the assortment of teas served in a clear glass teapot.
author: Richard H.

description:
Really good dim sum.   I've been here many times.   It's really overpriced for what it is, but the quality is consistent.   Once, I had some overcooked sea bass, but I sent it back and they took it off the bill.  The main draw is that it centrally located and close to Bart where most of the other cheaper places are a bit more out there.   

So, yeah, not a good value at all, but at the end of the day dim sum isn't going to break the bank, so the convenience of this place keeps me coming back.   

Also, I have never had to wait more than 15 minutes to get in....a far cry from the hour long waits to get in at Koi Palace.  Bonus.
author: Christian C.

description: Definitely was a huge fan of the service and amazing food. I loved that everyone was very coordinated and able to serve their clientele in a timely manner. The outside restaurant seating was pretty nice considering it sat in front of a water spout. The food was delicious and freshly made. Loved the variety of vegetarian and meat lover dishes. This includes BBQ pork chow fan and xiao long bao. There were also a wonderful variety of desserts such as mango pudding, egg tarts, and pistachio ice cream. Overall although a bit pricey definitely am a fan
author: Elizabeth N.

description: Great dim sum in authentic atmosphere - great for anyone looking to go out in San Fran for excellent Chinese and great service
author: Sebastian S.

description:
Everything is on pricey side but food quality is better than cheap dim sum in Chinatown or clement street. However, dim sum on weekend for 2 individuals shouldn't cost $90. 
I'd rather go to Hakkasan on market st for better quality food although they give you less food. For a person like myself who doesn't eat too much and value quality vs quantity, this is not the place for me.
I'm def not coming back here. 

Service was slow too just like other dim sum places in town.
author: C M.

description:
YUM!!! 

So four stars for the food, four stars for service, but two/three stars for the fact that dim sum should never cost this much.

Le fiance and I were in the area for a family wedding, cruising down Market, when we suddenly realized we were insanely hungry. We wanted a cheap and easy place to eat (but didn't want fast food), and quickly realized in the area we were in that was going to be unlikely. We stopped in here just intending to get an order of dumplings to go, but the waitress didn't really acknowledge that was an option and ushered us to a sit down table. Because it was raining, we accepted this fate. After giving le fiance a stern, we are only ordering two orders of dumplings look, we went for it. 

We got an order of the soup dumplings and the siu mai. Both were delicious!! I saw some other reviews that they weren't hot enough but ours were fine. Super flavorful. You really have to watch them though, I saw them pushing their most expensive items multiple times (like that $17 sea bass). That didn't sit well with me - I like being able to relax when I eat, not be on guard that I'm going to be massively overcharged. Maybe people in the Financial District don't care. But to me $17 for a dim sum item is just pure craziness. 

Anyway, probably won't be back because you can get dim sum for much cheaper that's just as good of quality in the East Bay. But for the situation we found ourselves in, this place definitely hit the spot.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Not recommended if you really want good Chinese food served by smiling staff. 
The place is quite unorganized and they don't offer suggestions for first timers. Since their menu was unusual I wanted to take my time and ask a few questions/ suggestions but it seemed like the staff was uninterested. 

The food itself was not as per my liking. I actually didn't even eat half my dish. 
Wouldn't go back there again.
author: Arjan N.

description: Had been there years ago and was impressed. This time around they lost me as a customer. Soup dumplings were not as great as I remembered them. Pecking duck portion is a joke and pricey. Won't be coming back.
author: Dal G.

description:
This review is for the smaller of the two Yank Sings located just behind Market.

This experience has taught me one crucial fact about dim sum: it is best to brave the lines for an *earlier* experience rather than later. When the No1DP and I finally got settled in our tables at 2pm on a Sunday afternoon, there was only a limited selection of dim sum on the carts and it was best to pick off the menu, and even then it wasn't guaranteed that the restaurant would have the item. This is how I missed the baked BBQ pork bun; it was sold out at noon (restaurant opens at 11am).

VENUE/SERVICE: White cloth fancy schmancy dim sum, a step up from the usual setting you would find in SF Chinatown and/or the Chinese communities in LA. Although the lady taking reservations took our names and phone numbers so that she could text us when a table would be ready, we never got a text. When we came back 30 minutes later per estimate she gave our spot away to another party. Luckily when we returned we were seated 5-10 minutes later.

Service was still on the busy side though customers stopped trickling after we were seated. At least they told us right away that they were out of an item immediately after asking about said item. They were also nice enough to hold onto a custard tart for me to eat later.

Tea served was jasmine tea served in a fancy kettle. Gotta look the part if you're serving fancy dim sum.

DIM SUM: In general, mostly average and like many people have mentioned, you can get the same quality for lower prices elsewhere. 

Much of the steamed items were available on the carts. Their signature dim sum is their "Shanghai Dumpling", which consists of their kurobota pork and is in the style of a xiao long bao. I had XLB before in NYC and SoCal and thought that their rendition was honestly forgettable, as was their scallop shu mai, which didn't contain much scallop. Their har gow tastes much like any other decent har gow. What stood out was the mushroom dumpling and the seafood basil dumpling due to their intense flavors in a small dim sum.

The only fried item we had was a Phoenix Tailed Shrimp. LOTS of bread filling but shrimp was scant. Not even the sweet and sour sauce can save this dish.

My two favorite dim sums were the desserts, the sesame balls and custard tarts. Sesame balls used yellow bean as opposed to red bean yet still tasted the same as red bean. The balls were cooked just right - light and crispy skin yet glutinous and piping hot on the inside that you need to slice the ball in half to eat it right. Custard tarts were served in flaky pastry shells and a little more eggy than creamy yet still delicious. 

The next time I take the No1DP to dim sum it will be at a more price-appropriate establishment. At least this experience satiated my dim sum craving. If I were to ask Michael Bauer one question it would be how did this restaurant manage to stay on his list for so long contrary to public opinion?
author: Isabella B.

description:
Here's the deal, at least for me, this place is good but not extraordinary good. 

My family and I have been going to dim sum for years so it isn't a new concept for me. I know the standard fare at most places. Yank Sing didn't offer much that was out of the normal scope with the exclusion of their soup dumplings. 

My family and I went during the week and hit the afternoon lunch session. Service was good, our tea was always full and our water glasses were replenished mostly within decent timing. 

Food was good, don't get me wrong, just not $45/person good. Sorry. 

We ordered 12 items between 4 people:
Crab puffs (2)
Soup dumplings
Taro cake
Sautéed edamame 
Egg custard cups
Steamed pork buns
Shrimp and chive dumplings
Sticky rice
Sesame balls (lotus)
Egg washed pork buns
Can't remember the last item

Overall all items were good but nothing so exceptional to warrant the price tag. The egg custards were served warm which made them gooey and luscious in texture. The sesame balls were also warm and if you've never had a warm sesame ball you should fix that problem pronto. 

They still do the carts which is rare these days and a treat to be able to see your items rather than ordering off a menu. They also walk around with some of their speciality dishes but none of which tickled our fancy. 

It's doubtful I'll be rushing back with the plethora of delicious dim sum in the area at any price point lower than this and equally delicious food.
author: Mandy L.

description: Fabulous upscale dim sum in the financial district.  Perfect start to our San Fran vacation. Carts are frequent and everything was of the highest quality. Loved the sticky rice, shrimp dumplings, potstickers, and sesame balls. Service was very friendly. Make a reservation if you can though they also have a to-go window if you can't get a table.
author: Tami H.

description: This dim-sum restaurant is on the more expensive side, comparing to the others in Chinatown. There is not so many varieties that one would expect. I was sorely disappointed that there was no congee. However, I could tell the quality of the ingredients used to make these dishes better than typical dimsum restaurants, that probably explains the higher price.
author: Vi T.

description: Delicious and fast. Carts come around to show you foods and hand them right there to you!
author: Meagan N.

description:
I've come a few times over the past years. I enjoy the large selection of dim sum. The quality is still outstanding! 

I have a few favorites I always leave room for:
Scallop sui mai
Chinese broccoli
Shrimp dumpling

Although anything you see that looks good most likely is. 

It is more expensive compared to other dim sum restaurants. I recommend to pace yourself by checking out the menu and waiting for your favorites to come around. You can also ask the waitstaff to bring what you want out for you. 

Staff is courteous but not always aware of your needs so be polite but direct and obvious if you need assistance. 

Great dim sum and I will continue to enjoy this restaurant.
author: Katy F.

description: This is the only dim sum place I go to in SF. I love their turnip cakes and pork buns. Yum
author: Martha S.

description: This was a great place for a Dim Sum brunch. My boyfriend and I got here right around 11 and were seated immediately without a reservation, but there was a line after about 30 minutes. We started off with oolong tea which was great. We really enjoyed all the food we got. The steamed pork buns were killer and the peaking duck was delicious. Overall, it was a really great experience. The service was good - we asked for something we hadn't seen yet and they immediately told whoever over their mics what we wanted. The only setback was that it was a little pricey compared to other Dim Sum places.
author: Laura L.

description:
Been here for dim sum a few times.  Food is good, but it's pricey.  The variety and selections are OK compared to other dim sum restaurants.  

I've also ordered from their 2 Go window.  This is a nice option and they have a lunch menu that is convenient and quick.  Kind of heavy on the carbs, but the prices are good if you get the lunch specials.
author: Lon H.

description: Out-of-this-world Dimsum! I've been to MANY of them in the US and Hong Kong. Nothing can beat Yank Sing (both locations)! The food, service..impeccable! It's the reason they still exist and Michelin Star recipient.
author: Bobby M.

description: Went to this place after my hotel concierge recommended it. Amazing dim sum, fast service. I mostly had several types of dumplings offered on the menu and they were all really good. All of the food was flavorful and fresh. I left there completely stuffed and smiling. Hope to go back very soon.
author: Dan D.

description: An incredible culinary experience. Their signature Kurobuta Pork Dumplings were delicious and their Sesame Rolls were the best we've ever had. Service was great, quick and helpful. Yank Sing is a must stop in San Francisco.
author: Raymond G.

description: Half way through my San Fran trip I came here, being from Chicago I had to see what all the hype was about here with the Chinese cuisine and dim sum is one of my favorites. Now this dim sum spot is not in Chinatown just a little further away. We got seats right away before a big lined formed, now I wasn't disappointed in the food but the prices about 100 bucks for me and my wife WOW. I could get the same dim sum in the Chi for half that price with the same service. But the dim sum overall pretty good only thing that wasn't all that were the shui mai no caviar on top pretty average I've had much better. All the spring rolls I had were spot on the shrimp and taro. The fried prawns might've been my favorite thing there bomb, along with the Peking duck served with the traditional white buns and hoisen sauce on the side with carrots very good. Tea wasn't cheap good brand went well with the dim sum. Can't forget the soup dumplings I had there awesome one of my favorite dumplings anywhere they did a damn good job on those here. Overall nice place service was good too and it was very clean and lots of space. But the prices, I never think dim sum should ever be that expensive. Didn't have enough time on my vacation to try the dinky dim sum spots in Chinatown which usually are the best spots to get it in Chicago next time for sure. Very good spot though wasn't disappointed at all.
author: Thomas R.

description:
Dim sum here is great, flavorful, and 'clean tasting' as my Chinese wife described it. We waited about 30 minutes for a table on the afternoon before New Years.
Beware the cost, however- our tab was forty-five dollars per-person with no alcoholic drinks, but two bottles of spring water. Also, the waitress who stops by your table to offer unsolicited dishes is pushing the most expensive items they have.  Nonetheless, you'll have a great meal.
author: TeeJay D.

description: Good dim sum experience at high rent district pricing.  Food and service was solid but the prices were 3x that of Chinatown pricing.
author: OC Foodie O.

description: We were in the mood for a great dim sum... And thankfully, the concierge at the St. Francis Hotel steered us in the correct direction... Yank Sing, their dim sum is nothing short of amazing! A real treat! Their vegetarian options were fabulous as well, don't forget to try the mushroom shumai.
author: Heidi M.

description: My favorite dim sum spot. A must do every time I'm in San Francisco. Better with 4 than just 1 or 2 so you can try as many different delectables before getting too full. Word of caution: Pace yourself, savor the flavors and experience. Delicious iced tea!
author: Scott T.

description:
I think most of the reviews cover everything. The one thing I well note is that IF YOU ARE VEGETARIAN OR VEGAN, THIS IS YOUR PLACE FOR DIM SUM. They have a wide variety of vegetarian options. Most dim sum spots have about 90% meat based items. This place changes it to maybe only 65-70%. 

But every other review is accurate: overpriced (about $30-$35 per person), food was mostly good, and service was mostly good.
author: Stephen L.

description:
If you love pointing to little plates of delicious things on carts and you have some dollars to spend, this place is for you. I can't speak to the authenticity of anything they serve, but I can say that I've eaten here 20 or so times in the last 5 years and the food is tasty and high-quality every single time. Their claim to fame is their soup dumplings, but all their dumplings are really quite good. Personal favorites are the shrimp dumpling and the pea shoot dumpling. (They have more and better vegetarian dumplings here than the other dumpling places I've tried in the city. There's a mixed veggie dumpling - but also a pea shoot, a mushroom, a spinach, and a curried veggie dumpling.) Other personal favorites include the honey walnut shrimp, chicken spring rolls, and mango pudding.

They also have a location at Rincon Center, but I prefer the Stevenson Street location. Rincon is a bigger space (especially when they put tables in the atrium) and you can usually get a table even on a busy weekend. That said, it feels pretty busy and the reservations don't usually seat on time. Food quality is the same though. 

One con about both locations: If you get a seat that's outside the regular path of the carts, sometimes you have to get assertive about your dumplings. That said, whoever you're able to catch will usually let you request the things that you haven't seen come by yet.
author: Emma D.

description: Worst service ever, they never have any of the food on their menu. This place used to actually be good. Now it's just an overpriced tourist trap. What a waste of time and money
author: Belinda R.

description: In comparison to Vancouver, this is a low quality dim sum with $$$$ price tag. The bill for four was $80, tea was $8. The speciality item was xiao Long Bao which was a disappointment; Din Tai Fung has perfected it and it's way better there. The Peking duck bread was doughy, though the duck was good. The pawn dumplings were ok, average size. The lotus wrap rice was tasty but too sweet, it tasted like BBQ sauce. All in all, better off going to Chinatown or Oakland for dim sum for a good value and quality of food.
author: V L.

description:
Not sure why, but I find this location on Stevenson, tucked away in an alley rather cozy (more so than the Spear, though that is just as good food-wise). I start relaxing upon entry, as I catch a whiff of the freshly brewed green/oolong tea. Obviously, the bigger the group, the more dishes you can try, but I like going there as a couple or with a friend and order select few dishes. 

My favorites are the BBQ pork buns, pork in puff pastry, pan fried potstickers, chive dumplings, mango moose, egg tarts...yummm. They are so consistent and delectable! I love the mustard and hot sauces to spice it up -- sometimes I get puzzled stares, neighbors are like WTF?! As if they are offended that it may mask the authentic flavors, but hey, their dim sum is divine and I just turn it up a notch, for my palate! This is a solid, no nonsense dim sum for decades now, my staple in the City.
author: Art I.

description: Great selection of "Americanized" dim sum. Fresh, hot and tasty. Tough to get in without a reservation but their text system lets you wander around outside until your table is available. I found the final bill a bit pricey for what we ordered, but everything in SF seems expensive. Still have no regrets and would go back in a second.
author: David L.

description: overpriced. beware of the nearly $25 (incl tax and tip) tiny serving of bass. yes, that's one small item for nearly $25 that was quickly brought to the table and i accepted without being aware of the price.  needs to be posted as $$$$, not $$.
author: Claus L.

description:
Yank sing is for rich yuppies or non-asians.  Yank sing does a good job of bringing dim sum to Americans, minus the chaotic screaming ladies peddling dim sum in carts and trying to yell over other screaming children/parents/families.  

I, for one, enjoy the loud rambunctious scene a la cantonese dim sum.  So when you put me in a place that is clean, quiet, and even the tea is fancy as shiet, I really don't know what to do with myself.

But alas, the food is really actually quite good.  Even if it's 5x more expensive than any other place (I think me and the hubs ordered 3 dishes and spent $40), which basically anywhere else we could have gotten a whole table of food (at least, in LA).  So save your nasty comments, I'll go back to LA now.
author: Pauline M.

description: Awesome brunch here on a Sunday.  Service was fair to good. Food was amazing.  Really enjoyed it.  Steamed buns were perfect.  Peking duck preparation was also amazing.  Glad we found this place. Highly recommend
author: Sean U.

description: Always the best. No one can say more than what has been said. I have had dim sum in Singapore - not even close. Only complaint is they no longer sell their chilli sauce.
author: Frank R.

description:
I'm trying to stave off my mini food coma by writing this Yelp review... 

You know, I simply marvel at how dim sum places always manage to remind me that my eyes are much, MUCHHH bigger than my stomach.  I enter skeptically pondering what mega burrito joint I can hit up afterward for the "full feeling" factor, but leave clutching my distended paunch, swearing off all edible items.  How does this happen?!  One of the little mysteries of the universe, I suppose.

Anywho, I was scheduled to meet up with my good friend, Jacque C., at around noon today.  I got there a little earlier and ended up in the line for Yank Sing 2... which is definitely not supposed to be confused with Yank Sing.  The former is their no frills takeout operation; the latter is for those who've got some time to sit and savor.

After reorienting myself in the proper line, I was able to get seated right away.  Score!

Within moments of setting my stuff down, a waitress came by and asked me what I would like to drink.  I asked for chysanthemum tea (my favorite!), and she brought back a beautiful, large, clear glass teapot with the flowers sitting pretty in the central infuser.  Most places throw them into those metal teapots, so I really appreciate this elegant touch.

The plates, on the other hand, were pretty badly scuffed up.  Quality control seems a wee bit lax in that area.

When Jacque arrived, we quickly filled our table for two with the following:

2. Shrimp Dumplings/Har Gao (4) - 6.50
6. Pork & Shrimp Siu Mye (4) - 6.50
9. Shanghai Kurobata Pork Dumpling/Xiaolongbao (6) - 12.95
33. Honey Walnut Prawns (6) - 12.15 

I'll admit that I have a bias against frou frou/shi shi places, and I came into this dining experience ready to dislike Yank Sing because that's the vibe I perceived it to have... but the dim sum is pretty good and every waiter and waitress we encountered was very pleasant and attentive.  Yes, it's pricier than most other dim sum places, but let's think about the kind of rent they're paying for the spot they've got out here in the Financial District.  Yup.

All in all, I wouldn't be against coming here again, even though I like to save dim sum for the weekends when I have time to stuff myself and really catch up with friends.

Before Jacque and I left, we noted that pineapple buns might be a good addition to their dessert menu.  Hope they take that into consideration!
author: Iona C.

description:
A great spot for dim sum, and a great location if you're in town for a conference at Moscone Center or otherwise landing near Union Square. 
Sampled a variety of things-my favorites were the sea bass, soup dumplings, scallop rolls, green beans, some sort of steamed bun, short ribs and sesame dessert. 
The restaurant was clean, waitstaff responded promptly to specific requests and it was a great place to enjoy a leisurely lunch-even with a large group!
Will be back again and again...
author: Kelsey K.

description:
The sesame balls, crab and shrimp items are to die for.  This was first and definitely not my last experience dining in here.  

I was extremely blessed that the company I work for took us to lunch here and showed us the ropes of how to order. The sesame balls are exquisite and I can't stop thinking about how I need to take another trip to San Francisco just so I can being my husband here to experience it!
author: Amanda S.

description: The dim sum is excellent. We had pork dumplings, spare ribs, and curried chicken turnovers. All very good. We also had jasmine tea, which was also surprisingly tasty--not too subtle. We didn't enjoy the atmosphere very much. There was a frenetic pace to everything. First cart came by literally as our butts hit the chairs.  We had a late lunch (arrived maybe 12:30, seated by 1:15 ish) and were out the door in leads than 45 mins.  If you're in a hurry, I suppose that's a plus, but we weren't. We were looking to enjoy a multi course meal served at a leisurely pace. We definitely didn't get that.
author: David R.

description: Price way too high, not worth it. Food is computable to other dim sum restaurants near Chinatown.
author: Michael L.

description: Mind blown by the food! Do get the Xiaolong baos or "soup dumplings " because they are so good! Definitely busy so do reservations ahead
author: Julie N.

description: Great option for Dim Sum, arrived at 10am to get a table, we were lucky because they were super booked but we managed to get a table at open, XLB is on point, very tradtional dim sum done well
author: Jeff G.

description:
How does this place not have a five star rating?

Absolutely authentic Shanghainese soup dumplings, incredible steamed buns and a host of other things driven around on carts - none of which was a disappointment.

Really fast and attentive service.  Decent location in downtown with parking on a couple of different streets.

Best dumplings I've had outside of Shanghai.
author: Bob K.

description:
Since we had all ready parked our car, we didn't want to drive or Uber to Chinatown, I remember Yang Sing from 20 years ago, the original one located at 101 Spear. This one was the closest that we could walk to. We had a 20 minute wait during lunch hour, which isn't too bad.  

The price of dim sum is quite expensive, i.e. 2 crab claws was $14 a plate. Hey, we are on vacation. The food was filling and tasty, but if you were in Chinatown, you'd probably would get away with half the cost.

When you order tea for yourself, they bring a big pot and charge everyone at the table. So, if you're the only one drinking tea, make sure you let the server know and then check the bill after.

Since I'm a native San Franciscan, I'd probably go somewhere else for dim sum. But my wife and daughter hadn't been so I gave them a treat.
author: Charles D.

description: I love both Yank Sing locations,the dim sum is really excellent.  This one is located on a small alley.  No street parking, but a garage across the alley if you get there early enough.
author: Carol F.

description: This restaurant offers a wide variety of very good dim sum (including vegetarian options), as well as other Chinese dishes, Nice atmosphere, very courteous and attentive service. Not cheap, but prices are reasonable for a restaurant of this type.
author: Jethro B.

description:
One word. Cockroach. Nuff said.

Okay a few more words. Got take out: shrimp dumplings and sticky rice in one box, ate the dumplings and spotted this guy stuck to the outside of the banana leaf thingy too late. AGHHHH disgusting. Never again!!!!
author: Cat C.

description: food is good.but wait a long time to tell me they donot have what i want. And price is much higher than general dim sum. should not be $$ but $$$. i had two piece of dim sum and cost me 17 bucks...
author: Xin S.

description: Dumplings were good. Turnip cake was my favorite. Egg tart was above average - buttery and fresh, but I would have preferred if the egg custard settled more. Great service. Limited menu... and pricey.
author: Ana W.

description: Solid dim sum in a higher end, cleaner appearing establishment.  The food was all good, mostly solid stuff, although I really enjoyed the duck and green onion cake.  The price is on the higher end, although you pay for the location and the 92 health score in the window I think.  Service was a little scattered, but friendly.  Did not get a few things we wanted to try, as they never came out, like baked bbq pork buns.  We tried to inquire about ordering directly, but that did not seem like an option for us, although it looked like a few other tables were receiving items brought straight from the kitchen, so who knows.  Overall, it was good just like the other location.
author: A. L.

description:
Had a reservation here with a friend on a Sunday before some afternoon shopping at the mall.

I had heard a lot of good things about this place, but very little of it resonated with me when I dined here. When we walked up there was a long line to the front counter, which composed of people putting their name in, and people who had reservations. I feel like things would have been more efficient if reservation people didn't have to wait in a long line.

3 things we ordered off the carts, 1 thing we ordered off the menu. From the carts we had the xiao long bao, pork potstickers, and bbq pork bun. Potstickers had good flavor, but were pretty cold. Not just sitting out for a bit, but on the cold side of room temperature. Still enjoyable but tasted like something off a buffet where the heat lamps were off and the door is open with cold air blowing in. In fact, that was happening with the front door here, and our seats were nowhere near the closest to the door, and we were still catching the occasional chill. Maybe the carts were catching it too.

Xiao long bao was fine, but was looking forward to something more special with all the raving reviews. It was also not steaming with hotness, which is one of the best parts about soup dumplings. Bbq pork bun was decent, also very middle of the road/standard flavors.
