The shrimp dumplings we ordered off of the menu took FOREVER. We reminded them FIVE times that we had ordered shrimp dumplings, and we were ready to just pay when they finally brought them out. Shrimp seemed of high quality, but one of mine had a really hard gritty piece when I bit into it. You never want that moment when you bite into seafood/meat.

And when we got our check (after asking twice), took them a while to pick up our CCs, and then they disappeared for 10 minutes. What?! That's a long time to be gone with our cards. We had to hail them down and remind them that they had our cards in order to get them back.

Go to a hole in the wall cheap and authentic dim sum place for better food and service than this.
author: Sarah B.

description: Really overpriced. The food is not as good as the other more popular dimsum places in the area.
author: S S.

description:
This is not your average chinatown dimsum spot. No, I'm not saying that the food is any different -- what's different is: the Price. 

We went to this restaurant on Sunday for lunch. We were a party of 3, had a tasty (albeit run-of-the-mill) dim sum meal. When we got a bill at the end, we were shocked to find an invoice for $180. Yes, over $65 per person including tip. 

Dumplings + no alcohol + chinatown-grade atmosphere = $65 / head? Something doesn't add up. And when you try to do the calculation, you only see a smattering of stamps and an illegible receipt. 

TLDR: Good food, absurd prices.
author: Samuel S.

description: This location is not as nice as the one on Spear street, but the food quality is equally good.  I alternate between the two locations, depending on who I'm meeting with.
author: HQ S.

description:
I imagined this place to be a lot classier. I imagined it to have a more authentic look and feel to it. All in all I was not disappointed for the most part. If you are a frugal person Yank Sing is definitely not for you. The food is good, very good, but it is not the best I have had. Service however is very good! That's quite difficult to obtain when you go to dim sum places where they push the carts full of the menu items. Here you pay for the location most definitely. It's located in San Francisco's Financial District. 

First off their tea is very good. Many places serve you diluted tea. They serve it in cute glass teapots. When they served us tea after it was nearly finished though, they just added hot water to the same teapot. As you can imagine, the tea was not so great the second time around.

My favorite here was the Signature Shanghai Dumpling. It's one of those soup dumplings they serve with vinegar and ginger. This dumpling was nowhere near as good as it is at Din Tai Fung. Have yet to find a better soup dumpling.

The XLB was pretty good but they were stuck to each other. Quite annoying. The shrimp dumplings were also very good! 

The best thing we had that we have never ordered before elsewhere was the Sea Bass. Highly recommended. It was cooked just right and it came with a really tasty sauce.

I also really enjoyed the Peking Duck. It came with a great sauce and a bun. Beware, the bun has a thin sheet of paper underneath it. I accidentally took a bite out of it haha. 

The underachievers  were the sticky rice, the Chinese broccoli and the fried taro dumpling.
The sticky rice was good but was not the best we have had. Mind you, my BF loves it and he always orders it. The Chinese broccoli was cold. The taro dumpling was greasy and kind of bland - just OK. I ordered it imagining that it would be like the delicious taro dess
author: Miguel R.

description: Great dim sum but slightly overpriced. Service was okay-- I wish the carts came around more often. We had the shrimp dumplings, shu mai, shanghai pork dumplings, and many other dim sum classics. We enjoyed all of them and would definitely come back again!
author: Emily Z.

description: It was a little hard to find this place since it was on an unassuming street, but once we saw the decor and the cantonese speaking waiters, we knew we were in the right place for good dim sum. We got a lot of the hot food- pork buns, shrimp dumplings, shao mai- all of which exceeded expectations. We were going to get dessert, but it was already very pricy so we passed! Would definitely come back again though for quality dim sum.
author: Aaron G.

description:
We decided to try dim sum for lunch while in San Fransisco.  We were seated after 5-10 minutes, but there was no where to put my luggage. We were told to place the luggage next to our table which was in the middle of a key walking path (particularly in a place where they are pushing around carts and offering you dishes).  

The food was just okay, and it seemed that our spot in the restaurant continuously got passed up by the servers pushing carts around the room. We asked for some pork buns, and we didn't receive them until we asked about them 15 minutes later. The server was nice enough to not charge us for them, but our interaction with her was really the only redeeming moment.
author: Dana S.

description: Great spot. Get a reservation because they get super busy. Most items aren't clearly priced as they're offered from the carts, but the staff is friendly and will tell you if you ask.
author: Katherine S.

description: Great dimsum place in the heart of Financial district. Went there for a business lunch and had a great experience. The only reason I won't give 5 stars is coz they did not have a lot of vegeterian options. Service was decent and friendly.
author: Sumeet S.

description: Seated right away, excellent service, very clean. Definitely enjoyed the experience and the dumplings!!
author: Donna S.

description: I love this place. Get a reservation if you can, there is always a wait. I'm not sure if there is better Dim Sum in SFO and if there is someone needs to send me a message! Is this place as good as Hong Kong? No. But it's the best I've had in the US. Get the Shanghai dumplings!
author: Mark H.

description: Their Shanghai Kurobuta Pork dumplings is the best in town, but at a price of $14 + tax, fees, and tips, that's about $19 for only 6.  It shouldn't be that expensive.  Lunch for two is easily $100, if you don't drink any wine.  If it was reasonably priced, I would give it a 5 star.
author: A Z.

description:
POLITEST DIMSUM JOINT
(3.85 stars)

I truly believe the waitstaff are programmed robots because this is the first DimSum joint where they say thank you and were very attentive to each table. Friendly Dimsum servers killing me with kindness. You don't get that at any Dimsum joint. Trust. 

- FOOD, yum
- PRICES, wtf 
- SERVICE, friendly robots 
- AMBIANCE, small cute clean 

Came here on a Sunday morning as I was on-call and had to work. Line, none. But it was almost full house. Scored a table immediately as I walked into the door, I considered myself lucky. I was greeted, thanked, and was given smiles to... Is this a Dimsum joint? Is this a dream? Am I hungry and delusional? Did they spike my tea with opium? I can't believe these people have great customer service!!!! 

HEFER STATS. 

SPINACH DIMSUM ($5.5) - for three pieces, that's not cheap. I had to try it, never had booger green Dimsum before. It's a great option for vegans and vegetarians. Great flavor especially with the dipping sauces provided on the table. The green rice wrap tasted typical, the filling reminded me of creamed spinach minus the cream. It was light and "healthy".

SHRIMP AND CHIVES STEAMED DUMPLINGS ($5.5) - for three pieces, again, that's not cheap. However, it was really good. Not oily or greasy as other Dimsum joints. Great flavor, the rice paper was perfectly steamed, not soggy nor tough. Shrimp and chives are always a good combo... You can't go wrong with this pick.

ORANGE JELLO ($5.5) - this was refreshing. Reminds me of being Las Vegas poolside and pool service would walk around giving out frozen orange slices. The jello had a very fresh and refreshing orange flavor. It's cute presentation using real orange peal with the jello inside. 

Will I be back? It's a great place I'd definitely come back

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description: This place was great 15 or 20 years ago.  Now, it is a way way way overpriced tourist trap.  Lunch runs $50 per person for very average dim sum.  Just skip it and go to Chinatown.
author: Reggie V.

description:
Aggressively overpriced but mediocre dim sum. This is a fairly popular spot so it is hard to drop in for lunch during a workday since you will likely face a 20-30 minute wait for a table.

You pick the dishes from carts being pushed around by employees which is common at dim sum restaurants. But the problem is Yank Sing has a lot of outdoor seating and SF temperatures are pretty cool so some of the food is no longer hot when you get it.

The turnip cake is not very good. The shrimp dumplings are good though. The Chinese broccoli is served chilled which is not something I've seen before. 

Waitresses are very aggressive with the dishes on their carts. They will put a dish on your table without you even ordering it (especially with the pricier dishes such as the $13 chicken stuffed mushrooms and the $21 sea bass). Don't be afraid to say no if you don't want it.
author: Rica Z.

description:
One of the biggest dim sum rip off I have ever had. This place is expensive even by SF standard. They call what they served dim sum, the food might look like dim sum, but they are not dim sum! They don't taste like dim sum. Matrix would just make all of them taste like chicken. We don't find the service to be anything we would call home for, the place is cramped as well. Really, I understand rocket science but I don't understand why this place would average above 3 star on reviews.

Cost is not why I give it a zero star, its the value that you get for the price, which is nothing. Cost, taste or service, if they are good at any one of them, then I would give it a star. BUT IT HAS NONE! AND YES! I AM YELLING!

So save yourself from pulling your hair out like I did, go to any other dim sum place for a more satisfying meal. And by that, I truly mean just ANY! Or just go to the closest McDonald and buy everybody there a Big Mac meal with the same amount of money that you were going to spend at Yang Sing. At least a dozen people will be thanking you for a free meal. Now that would be much more satisfying than going to this place. :D
author: D L.

description: Keeping this short; not even worth the effort to write too much for this place. Westernized selection, very salty, over cooked, rude rude staff (keep in mind my group is all Chinese...). They refused to give us vinegar and said it was reserved for a dish we didn't order. REALLY!? One star for the tea.
author: Fanta O.

description:
The spot for me for great dim sum in the middle of the city, in the middle of the work week. Better than the SF Chinatown standard tourist dim sum that you can get, albeit at a higher price. But get a reservation here, it you want to cut your wait.

Service can be spotty at times if you're a business person trying to get in and out, but yes it is that good. Try the Shanghai soup dumplings (with a spoon, strongly recommended).
author: Glenn H.

description:
Yank Sing is the most un-Chinesey Chinese restaurant I've been to. Let me tell you why:

(1) Civility. I don't have to get all savage status and clothesline people to get to the hostess stand or to the table. Didn't see any tables brawling to pay the bill either; probably because they didn't want to get stuck with a $100-$300 bill. "Oh you got this? Why, thank you!" *evil laugh inside*

(2) They take reservations for dim sum. Don't come without one especially on the weekends and holidays. It was as packed as Koi Palace and Hong Kong Lounge on New Year's Day.

Fyi, don't think you're hot shit just because you're one of the few that can spit some canto there. It's not going to get you a table any faster. Trust me, I tried. Fail.

(3) It's ridiculously expensive: $4 pp for tea...nearly $3 for a mini dan taat...$6 for one slice of duck?!?! *grabs ankles*

(4) "Omg, did the waiter just say, "thank you" and "you're welcome"? *gasp*

Customer service IS excellent at Yank Sing; a close second to the bougie Hakkasan. The entire staff is polite, efficient, attentive, and speak conversational English. Oh yah, and they actually smile.

(5) Limited variety of Americanized dim sum items on the cart (no cheong fun--boo!) but high quality ingredients and minimal to no MSG used. I had no MSG after effects like I usually do with most Chinese restaurants. If you don't see an item you want on the cart, ask your waiter and they'll cook it to order for you.

Once you get over the culture shock of how un-Chinesey Yank Sing is, prepare yourself for some solid, high-quality yum cha grubbing. 

We ordered 10 dishes for two people which was a lot but in true Yelp fashion, we always over order when we yum cha: http://bit.ly/1eY8QZm. Expect to spend about $50 pp before tip; the same amount that can feed an entire family of 4 including tip at other dim sum places.

MUST ORDERS:
*XLB (Shanghai Soup Dumplings - $12.95): The best? Nope, but pretty damn good with a thin skin, succulent filling and tons of broth. It's a step below "world renowned" Din Tai Fung's XLB.
*Siu Mai (Shrimp & Pork Dumplings - $6.50): Super juicy and topped with a whole shrimp.
*Pai Gwaat (Steamed Spareribs - $5.25): All meat and barely any bones.
*Honey Baked Seabass ($19.95): Silky, flaky, savory sweet goodness. Worth the price tag over the Peking Duck.
*Dan Taat (Egg Custard Tarts - $11.10): Umm, herro thunder thighs and muffin tops! Served hot, the crust is buttery and flaky crust with an uber velvety custard. When fresh out of the oven, it rivals Golden Gate Bakery's dan taats.

You can't go wrong with any of their steamed dumplings as they have the skin down to an art; perfect pleating, thickness (not too thick), and elasticity (didn't fall apart upon picking up). 

Make sure to use their housemade chili oil sauce and hot mustard for dipping. SO bomb!

Skip the $6.05 a slice Peking Duck (skin wasn't crispy) and anything fried (they're known for their Wu Gok: taro dumpling though which was sold out). Their Fung Zhao: chicken feet was mediocre so I would also skip this next time.

Don't bother with their takeout either. I use to regularly get their combo meals when I worked nearby. It sucks and the quality is not on par with what's served at the sit down dining area.

I hear their Rincon Center location is even better. More spacious; fits 500+ people. More dim sum variety. Free validated parking.

Me: "Can you we go to Yank Sing at the Rincon Center next month?"
Mr. NSS: "The place where rich people have their fancy wedding banquets at?"

Me: "Yup!"
Mr. NSS: *grabs ankles*
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Literally the best dim sum and xiao long bao I've ever had. Service was attentive, food was amazing, and of course the atmosphere was great. Parking sucks, but hey. Worth it.
author: Charissa T.

description: Xiao long bao,, Xiao long bao!! One of the true delights in the city! I understand there is cheaper Dim Sum, but this place is clean and very well run. Just don't feel pressured into ordering anything until you see what you like.
author: Robbie C.

description:
Let's be clear: the food here is delicious, but a little pricey. If you can stomach paying a little more for quality food and kind/courteous staff, then you should definitely check it out. We absolutely loved the baked char siu bao.

It's located in a nice part of FiDi, and is clean, well lit, and relatively spacious inside - there's even comfortable seating outside thanks to space heaters.  

If you're in a hurry, check out Yank Sing 2go by the outdoor seating area. It's equally delicious!
author: Sonny N.

description: For the 2 of us enjoying 5-6 items plus tea was $77. Had to have the soup dumplings, Peking bbq ribs, shrimp dumplings and orange jello dessert. 1-2 other items too. It is not for those wanting a quiet romantic or calm formal dining experience. It's crowded [wish our table was not near an aisle], noisy from the nearby conversation,  the street outside and the servers coming by with carts of menu items. But then again, that's why you are there. An elegant food frenzy.  If you are a foodie like me you will likely have difficulty saying you've had enough and ask for the check. The staff likely speaks more English than you speak Chinese but it's enough to get everyone through their meal. Very old establishment with staff that knows their routine so just go, enjoy and leave full.
author: Steve J.

description:
This is a really classy place for Dim Sum. I usually travel all the way down to China Town for Dim Sum but I was in the area and found this 4 star restaurant. 

I got a table for two, the food was nice and hot, but very expensive!
They charged $3.00 for 3 little pot-stickers which was crazy. Overall it was about $120.00 for the two of us. We were extremely full. But the only thing that I really enjoyed was the hot tea! 

It's not worth the money, I would suggest taking a cab down to China Town and looking there.
author: Marina S.

description: Best Dim Sum ever. Expensive, but good. Not as expensive as Hakasan though.
author: Richard L.

description: I come here on my lunch and order from their take out area next to its main restaurant.  My favorite is their desserts and dumplings.  I have to still try out other food options on their menu.  I think I'm coming here 3 days a week for take-out lunch because I work on the same block.
author: Stephanie I.

description: This is the first time I came here with my friends. We waited for 30 minutes to get into. We sat on the right corner. They didn't push the food carts to our table, so we asked for the carts and they just came 2-3 times( they came to the next table and went back- except our table). We told the manager and she said maybe they got " traffic" in the room and can't come to our table. I give 2 stars because the food is ok but the service is so terrible.
author: Vi H.

description:
The food is OK. Average but not excellent. The place is ridiculously expensive. The menu says $5.5 for only 2 xiao long bao (soup dumplings) but they only serve a plate with 6 of them, making it $16.5 for 6 baos. We spent $80 for two persons for the lunch, which I think is insane for the quality of the food. 

We tried:
- Xiao long bao: taste authentic but no soup so no juicy at all
- Phoenix Tail Prawns: greasy
- Peking Duck: $6.5 for a bite (you can have a entire duck for only $35 in Great China in Berkeley)
- Chicken rice: good
- Snap peas: heavy taste and uncooked

In addition, the place is very crowded in peak hours and you have to wait for seat. The service was very good, though. Most servers are very friendly and helpful.
author: Dabing H.

description: Awesome as always.  Make a reservation, packed at 10:30am. Worth the wait. Must have,  honey baked sea bass,  shrimp dumplings and shumai. Service always quick and friendly.
author: Eric C.

description: Best dim sum I have ever had.   Serving  was impeccable.   Food the best!   Recommend this joint to all!
author: L G.

description: Best Dim Sum.  Pricey but well worth it.  We always make it a point to visit Yank Sing whenever we travel to SF.  Never disappointed.   Love the food and the efficiency of the staff.  Prefer the more intimate setting off Market as the Rincon location and size just not our preference.
author: Dick G.

description: came here for lunch, the service was fine, the food was disappointing. there's few reasons to come here other than convenience, assuming you work downtown. the majority of the food we got, over 8 dishes, were lukewarm and when you're paying premium top dollar for what's supposed to be dope dim-sum then it's hard to come away not disappointed.
author: Alex S.

description: The best vegetarian dumplings in the city! They bring you food as soon as you sit down. Very first service.
author: Haru I.

description: Yank sing is really good. Sadly the seating was too small. The food is very good, clean and properly made.the staffs are very nice and sweet too.
author: Shore K.

description:
Back for another round, this is one of my regular stops when I'm in San Fransisco. Never fails to deliver! 

However a warning - everything is so delicious and looks so good - you can overstuff yourself in a very short amount of time :)

Pace yourself and enjoy. I recommend the scallop balls, stuffed mushrooms and the ones with lots if basil in them - absolutely delicious!!!
author: Christina H.

description:
This restaurant is located near Downtown which is good in facilities for communication. 
We had lunch for 6 adult and one child on Sunday after made a reservation.

The atmosphere in the restaurant is like a chinese taste. In the restaurant was busy and active. Some servicer were carrying wagon to have chinese food around in the restaurant until the they called somebody to stop.

Service is businesslike.

The value is a little comparatively expensive.

There are a lot of unique menu items.

(Rating: +++ is perfect)
Soup dumpling +++: 
This is my favorite in this restaurant. It might be popular menu in this restaurant. 
The dumpling was chewy ,and the inside of the dumpling was juicy. We have to be careful when we ate it because it was a little hot inside. 

Shrimp Dumpling ++:
The dumpling was chewy, and works shrimp.

Honey walnut prawns ++:
The fried shrimp over mayonnaise was a creamy and sweet.
The walnut was a good accent.

Snap garden peas ++:
This is boiled and pouring like a soy sauce.
The taste was simple so that we refreshed our palates 

Kidney beans dish dressed with sesame sauce ++:
This is average.

Peking Duck ++:
The duck of the texture soft and juicy. I sandwiched the duck, Miso dip and slice green onion with a steam bread. The taste was good.

Jeen Dui ++:
This is one of the dessert menu. The taste was a little sweet and good. The inside of it was bean jam.
author: Hiromi S.

description: Went there once. Food was amazing. Service excellent coz u weren't wondering where the wait staff was. They kept bringing more food around. It was very crowded. Best to make a reservation. I passed by a second time on a Saturday but the line up was just too long.
author: Mona H.

description: I love this place, Got here at 10 AM Sunday morning, there is already a short line, but no real wait, as they efficiently seated all the clients. We had all the great ones, Har gau, Siu Mai, Xiaolongbao - 2 orders, really spectacular.
author: Dave Y.

description:
Came here on a saturday around 12 with my boyfriend. We didn't have reservations and the place was packed, so we waited about 20 minutes to be seated. Overall worth it. Probably the top dim sum experience I've had in San Francisco for the price and convenience of being in the Finance district, nearby the Palace hotel.

Pros: 
Clean, updated decor (in comparison to other dim sum places) prompt service & availability of food carts. If they didn't have the plate on their cart, they had people walking around or could use their mic to get someone to bring the specific plate over. 

Prices weren't too bad, although of course you'll find cheaper in china town. Quality of food was great and delicious. Highly recommend: Honey walnut prawns, shrimp dumpling, and Shanghai Dumplings, 

Cons: 
To be expected--if you don't make reservations, you will have to wait 10-35 minutes depending on your party size.
author: Nancy A.

description: Overpriced and overrated. Decent dim sum, but comparable to the more authentic dim sum places in sf at double the cost. They are missing key dim sum items like shrimp rice noodle cakes, chicken feet, and the sticky rice. Perhaps they are trying to water down the options for the masses. Still good but not worth the price.
author: Jay H.

description: We've enjoyed Yank Sing since we first discovered them over 20 years ago on a trip to the city, and it was our daughter's pick for her 18th birthday yesterday. The soup dumplings and sea bass were delicious, and we had the sweetest, best waitress, Anna. I didn't give them five stars because parking is a bear at this location, and I'm still recovering from the check that was $155 + tip.
author: Susan S.

description:
Probably the most expensive dim sum I ever had. On average, it's about $5.00 per dish, but it's located right at the heart of financial district. I came here based on my friend's recommendation, so I had to give it a try. I only got 3 dishes because this was my 3rd meal I was having before 1:00pm. 

I started with the turnip cake, which is crispy on top and soft on the inside. The dry shrimp taste is pretty strong, so if you don't like dry shrimp, this might be the dish to avoid. The 2nd dish I got was shu mai. The shu mai is good and like any other shu mai, so nothing profoundly memorable about it. Then, my favorite, chicken feet. The chicken feet is one of the best I ever had. The feet's skin is tender and flavorful. The feet has sucked in all the flavors of the sauce, which is the way those feet needs to be made. 

Tip: Be ready to wait during lunch time rush hour (11:30 ~ 1:30).  This restaurant is only open from 11~3 on weekday and 10~4 on weekends.
author: Rosemary T.

description: Not very good experience, came for late lunch around 2:30pm it's not even that full the food is good but it's ridiculous pricy. Service is pretty bad? I had to ask 3 different people to get one order which cost 20mins.
author: Alex Z.

description:
Tasty dim sum, done right!

A large group of us stopped by here for lunch at peak time - naturally there was a wait. Luckily it wasn't too long, and we were shown to our table quickly and efficiently. I love that they have the carts here, and during the lunch rush you know it's all fresh! We absolutely ate our faces off.

I can't even tell you everything we ate because it was all the food. We ate all of the things. Taro dumplings, XLB, shiu mai, pork buns, you name it, we ate it! Everything was fresh and hot, and although it was also extremely expensive, it was worth every penny!

Definitely somewhere I'd come back to - but with a healthy chunk of change in my wallet.
author: Ayla C.

description:
Diana Y had scoped out this place in advance for us and recommended that we only order xia long bao (xlb). We sat down and ordered only 2 orders and I have to say it was delicious. The skin was thin, the soup thick and delicious. If this was priced lower, I'd eat my fill. However, we paid almost $30 for two orders of xlb (12 xlb). That alone dropped it down to 3 stars. I don't mind paying for good food, but I do mind overpaying.

I didn't think I would ever say this but I would rather go to Din Tai Fung.
author: Hae A.

description:
We ventured to Yank Sing for my sister's birthday celebration. There were a total of 12 of us, and they sat us at a table in the corner. Sometimes we're loud and can be a little inappropriate, so that was perfect for our group. 

I had never been to deem sum before, so I wasn't quite sure what to expect, but I took a cue from the rest of our party and jumped right in. 

The dumplings were perfectly steamed and delicious. The veggies were fresh and well seasoned. The rice was fluffy and the soups were hot and tasty. I would love to venture to this location again to enjoy another deem sum Sunday brunch.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Limited selection especially if u are used to having dim sum in the peninsula. They didn't have rice roll. :( Relatively good service as they have servers who can actually speak English and didn't ignore you.

Prices of food here was sooo expensive. $104 for a table of two before taxes o.O, be prepared to pay a lot. 

The soup dumplings passed my test :) Order the egg custard and seasme ball. So good!
author: Yilin T.

description:
One of my favorite dim sum places.

More up market than chinatown dim sum. The dumplings are great. They skip some of the more unusual scary items that you can only get in chinatown, but they have a great selection and the quality is excellent.

Modern decor, good ambience and friendly staff.

I particularly like that the cart waitresses all have radio headsets. If you are looking for a particular item it arrives fast. You can almost hear them say "Eater on table 7" and before you know it there are 4 carts around your table.

My favorites here:

Xiao Long Bao - They do a very good version of these

Miso baked Chilean Sea Bass - so good but share it - it is very rich

Steamed BBQ Buns - excellent

Shrimp dumplings - very good

Shrimp and chive dumplings - very good, just the right amount of chives

Peking Duck - Always good at Yank Sing

Chicken and mushroom dumplings - very good

Lai wong bao - very good
author: David T.

description: This was my first time trying Dim Sum and this place set the caliber quite high! Everything was hot and delicious; there were plenty of options for anyone trying out this spot for the first time. Happy to recommend this to any tourist. Only reason I wouldn't give 5 stars is for the curt atmosphere. Little patience was given for us tourists trying out Dim Sum for the first time.
author: Anahi G.

description:
After my extended meeting across the street from Yank Sing, a group of my work associates grabbed a late lunch at Yank Sing because it was convenient.  We arrived and the place was still packed!  However, the nice and friendly server accomodated us since we informed her that we were limited on time since we had a flight to catch.

We were seated and ordered a variety of dim sum items which included dumplings, siao long bao, shu mai, buns, string beans, noodles, and spring rolls.  Our dim sum and lunch entrees were "ok".  I've had better dim sum in Monterey Park with a cheaper price tag.  However, my lunch at Yank Sing was "A-OK".   3 Stars!
author: Maite H.

description: Decent but expensive. Soup dumplings very average. Excellent warm egg tarts. Sticky rice not great.
author: Alison D.

description:
The dim sum here wasn't that great -- have had much much much better in Inner Richmond, not to mention Chinatown. Way overpriced as well. It came out to be about $50/person for lunch (two people in our party). Walked out being borderline hungry, and yet the same dishes (prepared better, btw), at Great Eastern would be $25-30 total. 

Additional note: the kitchen staff who came out of the bathroom before me at best rinsed her hands as there was no soap there. Makes me question cleanliness. Hopefully there were sinks with soap in the kitchen...
author: Alison Y.

description: Great food, the soup dumplings are amazing. We liked the pot stickers a lot too. It was sort of chaotic so we didn't get to try many things but those dumplings are enough to keep coming back.
author: Tara C.

description: Honestly hands down the best dim sum I've ever ate!!! This place was amazing and the Peking duck was my fave! Pretty pricey but hey,nit's quality food and fast service. I'm from outta town so finding where it was located was kinda confusing but we made it! I think every time I'm in San Francisco I will be here getting my dim sum fix! The place was nice and clean, I enjoyed my brunch here!
author: Kristina L.

description: This place is packed when we arrived. The food was alright, but definitely not the best dim sum I've had.
author: Haoxiang W.

description:
Came for dimsum. Got the marquee Shanghai xlb (twice), shrimp crab claws, pan fried-turnip cake bbq pork buns, hargow (shrimp dumplings).

The food was authentic enough. Xlb had the requisite soup so you have to delicately pick up and display your chopstick skills to lift without tearing the skin. The shrimp crab claws use authentic crab. The turnip cake was "meaty" with materials (other places give more white turnip rather than mushroom, meat, dried shrimp, etc.). Finally, BBQ pork buns seem to use genuine char siu (not the leftover and not fatty). Hargow was okay.

I seem to be saying the food is great. So why the 2 stars?
Well, selection is pretty light. Regular items I expect were either unavailable, always out or delayed such as leaf-wrapped sticky rice, black pepper pork, chicken feet, tripe, and shrimp/beef/char siu wrapped rice noodles.  I think it is more the "unavailable" as I did not see any carts that carried 'em.

This place is definitely for folks who dip into dim sum but want a genteel atmosphere. As listed above, I listed some of the standard dimsum fare that were unavailable. And, I mean, they were serving mimosas with dim sum?!?! That's a new one for me. Whatever happened to tea (FYI, tea is suppose to help wash that all that good greasy dim sum stuff).

I guess it is fine for business lunch--you wouldn't want yourself or your client spitting out bones from chicken feet, or unwrapping the sticky rice.

The service and the fees were what dropped it from 3 to 2. 
* Service was sloooow...we requested some standard fare (sticky rice) and it is "getting ready." Arent' you ready for lunch crowds? Service was slow (yes I said it again). We had to wait 1/2 hour while we noticed there were four or five empty tables. Eventually they did use it (especially the one I noted was empty and talked internally...why aren't they using it).   Are they just trying to create a sense of busy-ness? It is !@#$$ cold to wait outside instead of being seated when there are empty tables!?!
* Fees. The XLB was $16 a tray. Whoa. It is good but not THAT good. I've had better on Peninsular/South Bay that were less than half the price. Similarly, the real crab claws with fried shrimp priced the same (May be worth it since it uses real crab claws and crab meat, but I don't have a basis to value it..There were only 2 pieces too).  Perhaps it is the rent....

In any case, if you have business lunch and want to feel international, this may pass , as the few items that are made are really well. but expect long waits. Otherwise, take the trek to Chinatown (only about 3/4 mile) to build up your appetite and get more selection, faster service (note I didn't say faster, not better---you ARE dealing with real Chinese employees after all, so it's a free cultural experience), and a cheaper tab. (I forget but there is one I usually frequent that even FPOTUS Obama had eaten....Great Eastern was the name?)

But if you are into mimosas with dim sum, stick to this place....
author: Sonny W.

description: Came for yummy dim sum...what we got was mediocre at best. There are better dim sum restaurants that are way cheaper than this place. Ridiculously expensive!  Lunch for 2 (only 5 items) was over $60?!?  I would have no issue paying this much for quality but it just wasn't that great. Won't be back.
author: Sheri C.

description:
Mediocre! I'm going to keep this review short. 

This was my first Dim Sum experience that my friends absolutely raved about. So I was pretty excited. After seeing the EXTREMELY high prices, I couldn't wait to see what all the hype was about. We order a few sets of dumplings, spring rolls, and some chicken dishes. I took my first bite expecting to experience one of those mouth orgasms that you get when the food is so good you don't even take a breath before the next bite.  Instead my face shriveled in disgust and disappointment. It wasn't that it was bad, it just wasn't GREAT. 

If I'm paying $50 for something that I can get down the street from my house for a 1/4 of the price I want to be amazed! That's what turned me off from this place and why it deserves 2 stars. If you are going to charge insane prices, then you better come with it. The service was also slow it took them 3 tries to finally bring us water. 

Like I said, this was my first Dim Sum experience, but I have had dumplings before and I KNOW there are cheaper and better places than Yank Sing. Save your time and money.
author: D O.

description:
Went here after three of my neighbors recommended it as the best Dim Sun in SF.  I'm not too sure what they're comparing it to, but the food was mediocre at best and the prices were ridiculous.

I sat at the bar by myself and had four half-orders of varying Dim Sum (with tap water) and the total for the check was $56!!  (Not including tip).  Unfortunately, I had the basics and nothing fancy or exclusive.  

I understand most restaurants in SF are expensive, but this was excessive for the minimal meal that I ate.  

From my first impressions, I certainly won't be going back.  There's got to be much better options!
author: Brock G.

description:
Really consistently great dim sum. Especially love the xiao long bao. Prices are a bit high for dimsum, but it's the location. 

Overall love!
author: Emma T.

description:
Ambient okay,  service okay,  egg custard was great. Too pricey,  plates averaged $12-14. 

Prefer city view restaurant instead because they are exceptional in cooking techniques, flavor profile and variety.
author: Wai Y.

description: Very good dim sum.  Rating was impacted by the selection and the price.  The place definitely provide the    Hangover Chinese meal we wanted.
author: Michael G.

description:
I can't believe this spot exists. They have several locations bunched together so be sure you know which one you are- half our party got stuck at a different location. Xiao Long Bao is great! I tried a few other things off the carts that come around frequently. The ladies don't speak English to well so it's a bit hard to figure out what certain dumplings are made out of but you can order off the menu if you have dietary restrictions. Fav highlights: White table cloths, good food, and they take reservations as well as have a separate area for take out. It's also really nice and clean inside. Some things could use a bit of flavor and the price is a bit crazy.

but I'll definitely be back...
author: Sia P.

description: I believed that this is the best dimsum restaurant I ever had in the US. The food was fantastic and make me feel like I am back to hongkong. But I don't know why there is not many Chinese come to this place. I strongly recommend this restaurant.
author: Lijian Y.

description:
I really have no idea what the hype is about. My boss took me here for a late lunch and I was unimpressed. 

Let me break down dim sum to you, it's suppose to be cheap, delicious, and hot. This place fulfilled none of that. I understand that the price point can be higher due to the location, decor and the quality but I didn't think the food was good, it was okay AT BEST. 

Let's start with the soup dumplings, first off, the they weren't that hot, warm more like it, second way too much ginger in the filling and last the meat was not flavored well. When I have to pay about $11 for soup dumplings, I expect some din Tai fung quality dumplings but they were far from it. 
We also ordered the Peking duck, it was 6.95 for 1 serving of duck that was 1.5 inches by 1.5 inches. Okay, I can just pay $10 and get half a duck in chinatown.... also the duck was cold! 
The rest of the food wasn't memorable and lukewarm as well. 

The lunch cost me way to much for the quality and amount of food I received. 
That being said, the service and the decor was pretty good. 
But in the end, the food is what counts. I think if you never had dim sum before, this is a safe environment to try it in, if you had, keep moving.
author: Janice C.

description: Loved the ambiance and the food! The signature dumpling with the soup inside was fun but a bit bland for my taste! The Peking duck, wonderful. The sea bass not my favorite but the string beans and spinach wontons so good. Ate to much but rate this place a must visit! My girlfriend said the best pork buns she has ever had.
author: Tina D.

description:
I had lunch at YANK SING on two occasions, once in autumn of 2014 with my little sister and once alone in spring 2015.   The restaurant can be considered to be "best-in-its-class," that is, a genuine gourmet restaurant.  The restaurant is typically packed in the mid-day hours, but the first time we had a reservation and the wait was only about 15 minutes.  The second time when I was alone the wait was only a minute or so.  Both times, I ordered a plate of shrimp and a plate of crab.  The breaded coatings on the shrimp and on the crab were very even, and the tawny color was pretty.  The meal was delicious.  

On my second trip, I also had an "egg roll" dish.  This is a fried cylindrical won ton with who knows what inside.  The server cuts the egg rolls in half with shears right in front of you, and the coating makes a crunchy sound when cut.   Although the egg roll might have been the best of all egg rolls, and although it might have represented the very pinnacle of centuries of refinement in the technology of gourmet egg roll-making, and although it might have been the "Mother-Of-All-Egg-Rolls," it did not make an appealing part of my meal, since it really seemed no different from egg rolls from an ordinary neighborhood Chinese restaurant.

During my first visit, my sister picked up the tab.  But on my second visit, I got sticker shock.  My little dim sum lunch with the three small plates cost me forty dollars!!!  Yikes!!!
author: Tom B.

description: I like this place for cleanliness. It wasn't noisy as China town. There were lots of none Asians there ... carts were organized and our waiters & waitresses were quite hospitable & nice . Food was excellent ! I highly recommend this place to people who never tried dim sum
author: Hannah K.

description: Treated my amazing grandparents to a dim sum brunch and we had a great time catching up over some of our favorite foods. We were pretty starving (at least I was) so it was nice that once we sat down, we were immediately greeted with several carts of shu mai, soup dumplings, shrimp dumplings, guo tie, etc. Some of the dishes were a bit greasy for my taste, but most were quite decent. The dessert dishes (sticky rice cake, sesame balls) were also very nice. What was surprising was the bill...especially considering that the ambience of the place didn't strike me as high-end or anything. It looks and feels like a normal, no-frills, Chinese restaurant. Definitely not hole-in-the-wall (as it's located right near the Financial District), but definitely not a place that ought to charge $200 for 3 people (yes, we were hungry, but we didn't order THAT many dishes). All in all, the food was still pretty good and though the bill caught me off guard in the end, I'd say it was worth a try. We went on a weekday around 11am and got seated immediately, but the place became packed by 11:45am.
author: Katherine Z.

description:
I have a high tolerance for pricey food, but this place takes it too far.

$14 for 6 xiao long bao (soup dumplings). $11 for 4 egg custard cups. 2-3x the price you'd find in a normal restaurant but doesn't taste much better.

food quality is good, but you're getting nothing extra for the premium price.
author: Jimming C.

description: The reviews don't do this place justice. One of the best dim sum places I've ever been to (and woohoo, they have PUSH CARTS, which are hard to come by in SF). The Shanghai soup dumplings are incredible and everyone speaks English (and is as smiley as can be). That also means it's on the pricier side ($35 a person without alcohol), but highly recommended if you want the full dim sum experience and are willing to slap (not punch) your wallet in the face.
author: Yara E.

description:
Yank Sing still sounds like the name of an S&M parlor for opera lovers to me, but I do come to this Yang Sing 2 Go kiosk for pure convenience...that is, if I can just remember it's there. I work nearby, and sure, there are a number of fair-to-middling places to grab a lunch and belch my way through my 1PM meeting. I find myself in a time pinch a lot and am surprised that this Yank Sing is not more of a default choice for me. After all, you have the buzz-saw line where you are met with the intentionally brusque staff dressed uniformly in their starched white shirts, their scarves peeking out from their collars, their drab brown aprons and their poker-dealer hats. This is definitely not the hippy-dippy staff at Peet's where they ask you how your weekend was or what your birth sign is. No, tell them what you want and just step aside.

That's it. Maybe it's the lack of love that makes me forget about this place since I could get yelled at on Muni or at work during a rough one-on-one. But when I do remember, I come over and get the $4.20 Small Chinese Chicken Salad which comes with plenty of poultry but also plenty of those fried won-ton chips and that thick sweet mustard dressing on the side, both of which are disastrous for my girlish figure (see photo). A large version at $6.60 can be just as satisfying when I'm feeling really famished or depressed, take your pick.  Oh sure, I've had the dim sum of which Yank Sing is justly renowned, but those are bit too calorific for me these days. Plucking those fried won-ton chips off my salad is difficult enough without having a set of plump and/or fried dumplings in front of my mouth. But I'd order them...if they'd just crack a smile for me once.

FOOD - 3 stars...the chicken salad satisfies on those fast lunch hours that really are just twenty minutes long
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...the kiosk is a blur since you're in and out so quickly, but there is patio seating in case you have a few minutes to eat in peace
SERVICE - 3 stars...they're machines
TOTAL - 3 stars...if you yank me, do I not sing?
author: Ed U.

description: Really amazing dim sum but incredibly overpriced.  It was just the 2 of us... Ordered moderately and ordered sesame balls to go... Our bill was over $80 for brunch Yikes!
author: Young-Ju O.

description: Was recommended to us when we were vacationing in SF. What great tadtng food. Closes early so go for lunch. Great dim sum.
author: Richard S.

description:
A bit pricey for my tastes, but the dim sum here is really good. 

On the food, I ordered the siu mai, xiao long bao, green beans and fried prawns. The xiao long bao is great, definitely up there with the best dim sum places. The biggest disappointment was the fried prawns - textures were fine but it was overall a very bland dish. 

Service was fair for the most part, though I had to wait upwards of 15 minutes for someone to get me my check (I asked twice) and again when I was waiting for my card. This knocks off a star in my book, since I expect higher level service for the price I'm paying.

Conclusion - nice, albeit busy, dim sum place strikingly close to the Embarcadero Bart station that is somewhat pricey comparative to quality and service. Would eat here again, provided it were on someone else's dime.
author: Alex V.

description:
I went there for lunch to their To-go counter. I am a vegetarian and I was able to find a combo meal that was vegetarian. The combo had Eggplant with Hunan sauce, 2 dumplings and lots of noodles. I wouldn't recommend it. It was very greasy and the taste was not to my expectations. The combo meal has 3/4 noodles and it is full of carbs with not many veggies. 

The staff barely speaks English and I had a tough time getting answers to my questions.
author: Hiral P.

description:
Before coming here, I was told two things about Yank Sing: The dim sum is good but the prices are insane. Yank Sing often makes it to the top of the "must visit in SF" tourism lists, so I figured it had to be decent. I came here with two of my friends and our bill came out to be almost $120. Priciness aside, the dim sum was actually good.

It was noon on a Friday, and we only waited about 20 minutes. Once we sat down, we were literally bombarded by three Chinese ladies shoving dim sum in our faces. No need to go hunting for any food. It's like a machine in there. Everything tasted better than I expected, but perhaps I willed myself for the food to taste amazing knowing how much I was going to pay.

There was not a huge variety, but there is definitely enough food to satisfy your appetite. The egg tarts, crab claws, and walnut shrimp were notably good, so I would specifically recommend those. I can see that many would call this place overrated because of the price, but I would honestly come here again. It's conveniently located in FiDi, the service is fast, and the food is amazing. Just... maybe a few times a year until I can afford to eat here more often.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Yank Sing was suggested to us as the best dim sum in San Francisco. The food was fantastic and the service was great. Expect to pay about twice as much as any other sit down dim sum. Get the Shanghai dumplings for sure.
author: Dustin P.

description: This was very good dim sum. I came here twice and was satisfied with my meals. The soup dumplings were very good along with the sticky rice, BBQ bun, and desserts. I would recommend this place to eat for breakfast or lunch. The service here is very kind as well. I would suggest you to get reservations because it can get crowded. Overall, this is one of my favorite dim sum places I've eaten at.
author: Nick P.

description: Oh Yuck Thing... First off, I had read reviews and expected it to be expensive but tea was $2/person! Ah. At least it was legit tea and they ain't that cheap on the tea leaves. But heck, might as well spend another $2 on boba instead. Anyways, I'm giving 3 stars because it's one of the best XLBs I had ever. I was so surprised. The wrap was perfect not too thick or thin. There was soup in my dumplings!! Omg. That's like the best part. Pork was fresh. Had sticky rice and it was so tiny and rarely any meat or taste. Their signature hot sauce was gross. I had way better. Now let's get to the dumplings, pork and shrimp siu mai was fresh but lacked flavor. The other dumplings were bland and no more cha siu bao with the crust?! This is a place good to try once .  Except maybe when I want to spend $14 on some XLBs and I'm not sharing!
author: Ann L.

description: Been here so many times. Always get disappointed by their disorganization. Even if you have a reservation, expect to wait at least ten minutes. Go to some other Chinese dim sum place with good price and service.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
LOL nice one, Yank Sing, charging us $30 pp for dim sum.  No.  This is not acceptable.  You are only getting away with it because you're in SOMA and not Chinatown.

Definitely the type of Chinese that caters to Caucasians.  When I was seated, a waiter asked me if I would like to order soda.  With dim sum?!  No, please, I'd like to get tea (which is usually complimentary at the yumcha places I frequent).

Alas, tea here was almost $8.  Granted, the teapot was very cool and the tea was fragrant...but again, no.  I cannot justify spending this much for tea unless the leaves were picked from the heavens and brewed in angel tears.  And even then, I still don't think I'd pay that much for it.

As for the food...it was mostly good but NOT worth the price.  Highlights included the lettuce wraps with minced pork and the mango pudding.  But everything else was mediocre (not bad by any means, but not incredible either).  The absolute most disappointing thing was the xiaolongbao (soup dumplings with pork).  Anyone who says they're good is just...deprived.  Good xlb does not taste like YK's. I picked one up and the skin immediately broke.  Not well made.  Meat wasn't that juicy, skin wasn't thin and chewy.  There are so many other places in SF and in the East Bay that have way better xlb that charge less than half the price, so why would you eat them here?  Like another reviewer pointed out...if I'm going to be paying *this* much for dim sum, it better be the best San Francisco has to offer.  That is not the case here.

I will say this, though: Yank Sing has excellent service, quite possibly the best I've ever experienced at a Chinese restaurant. I called the day before to make a reservation and was worried they wouldn't honor them (because, after all, it's a Chinese restaurant), but they did, and our table was ready before the expected time.  All the servers can speak English and everyone is competent and on point. I was by far the most poorly dressed customer there (I don't try to hide my true colors as a broke graduate student), but they still treated me like I was a CEO of some company. 

In summary: exceptional service and atmosphere, decent food, wretched prices.
author: Tiffany H.

description: went to the downtown location for sunday dim sum. We arrived early and it was packed so definitely go earlier than later if you want to get a seat comfortably.  My wife has a shell fish allergy and once we told them about it, they were very attentive and accommodating.  All the dim sum was brought by very quickly and the food was delicious. The pork dumplings were probably my favorite. They don't have everything that the other location has but still one of the better dim sum in SF.
author: Lawrence R.

description: Yum indeed.  Everything was tasty here.  The soup dumplings and spicy chicken was awesome.  Dried dumplings were good too.  Actually everything we had was good.  The only downside is their price, . Too high indeed for the size portion you get.  But on the whole definitely worth going to,  I will be going back anytime I can.
author: Peter T.

description: This place is like a PF Chang's of dim sum, y'all. I have never been to a more expensive, non-Authentic dim sum place in my entire life. My friend was visiting from NY and have never had it before, so I brought her here because of the high Yelp rating. We ordered maybe 3 things (plus tea) and our bill was over $35. Maybe acceptable for tourists or people who don't care how much they pay for average quality, but if you are neither, skip this place and go somewhere else.
author: Sally L.

description:
Fastest service I have ever experienced! The restaurant was packed too. We sat down on the heated patio and not even a minute later, a server with a tray full of dim sum came by. Vegetarian options, baos, fried shrimp... It all looked very yummy! 

I had the snow pea & shrimp dumplings, hubby had pork bao, pekin duck and pork dumplings he loved. We finished by Lotus Seed buns and coconut rolls/balls. Super fresh and good.

The dumplings' price is around $7 for 2 to 4 pieces except the pork ones which are around $14 (and the duck), so the bill can easily get pricey. We actually looked at the menu AFTER ordering off the tray. I'd look at the menu first next time but when you have a server and all this food in front of you, it's very tempting to order right then :-D

Great experience regardless, go there if you're craving good quality dim sum!
author: Leslie S.

description:
We drove to SF all the way from SJ to try this place... the verdict: Not worth it!  This place isn't located on a street... the entrance seems like it's in a back alley.  You'd definitely need to find street parking or a nearby parking garage. 

Thinking that there would be a long wait just like any good dim sum place would, I called the restaurant at 11am to make a 12pm reservation.  I'm actually surprised that they did, whew!  When we got there, they served us tea in an ultra-cool glass teapot.  The carts started coming around and we took some of the standard dim sum dishes (shrimp har gow, shu mai, shrimp dumplings, egg rolls...), but then we were waiting for the fried shrimp balls to come.... oh wait, they don't have any!  So then we wanted to order fried rice but wait... $20 for fried rice?!  When it was time to order dessert, it was $6 for a serving of mango pudding... ugh....

Definitely overpriced just as the other reviews say, and we likely won't be coming back. But, this place is pretty clean.  And probably the cleanest dim sum place I've been to.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I'll be honest, I was seriously thinking of giving this place only three stars.  Being from L.A., I simply cannot justify dim sum being this redonkulously expensive.  Plus, it's clearly dim sum catered for Americans.  That said, I decided to stick with four.  Why?  Because it was really good dim sum catered for Americans, and I can't give three stars to a place that left me satisfied (but I CAN deny it a five).

I will say this...if you pay for it, you get the highest quality stuff.  The xiao long bao were quite good...not quite Din Tai Fung good, but good.  It's hard to screw up the old standbys of har gow and shu mai, and with the fresh ingredients that was never going to be an issue here.  Peking duck, turnip cake, sea bass were also pretty good.  Had some other stuff too that I have no idea of the name, but it was good.

The service was pretty good, very attentive waiters.  And I can't complain with the interior of the place, it was clean and very comfortable to enjoy some dim sum.  So once you get over the fact that you're not getting value for money here and the fact that it's not truly authentic Chinese dim sum, you'll enjoy your experience.  And yes, my bill was over $100 -_-.
author: Alexander Y.

description: I always like Yank Sing. Yes, it is pricey. But it is also in a high rent area and they have a big selection. They also have a lot of vegetarian options (which isn't always the case for dim sum). The spinach and mushroom dumplings were great. Their (pork) soup dumplings are really good -- I think they are close to as good as Din Tai Fung. I also really like the eggplant and string beans. Father had the chicken feet and was loving them (apparently they are close to as good as what he has had in China).
author: Jen G.

description:
This is a fun place, and obviously popular. I arrived 11:30 AM Saturday and already crowded (possibly extra crowd due to St. Patrick's Day parade in SF). You get your seat and they wheel carts around, then select what you want. Be warned - you're going to have dribbles on your table!

As soon as I arrived they offered chicken satay. Then a cart with mostly fried foods and also cold snow peas in a sesame dressing. I got shrimp and snow peas. Chicken very good, peas also, shrimp great - personally though I preferred a dab of mustard to the dipping sauce. Later tried sweet rice dumpling from same cart. The only disappointment, it had a glue-to-your-teeth texture and not sure what the filling was but unimpressive. Then came steamed dumplings. Pork buns huge and you had to get two. I was getting full by this point, so got the smaller chicken/mushroom dumpling, also good. 

My one criticism is that the timing of carts is inconsistent. When I first arrived they were wheeling carts constantly, then they slowed. I waited quite a time for steamed dumpling and then, when I figured I was done except for dessert, took a full 15 minutes and asking two people before they brought the dessert cart. It had been around several times earlier, but then disappeared. They did not have the egg custard tart, so I got the coconut cream cake, sort of spongy cake with filling. Not bad, not spectacular. 

Bummer - they did not bring around the Peking duck until I'd had five things and was quite full. I had a sad since duck is one of my favorite things. Maybe come back with a friend, we can then order more things and split them. Hopefully get duck and egg tarts.
author: Carol S.

description: Great Dim Sum. They have a variety of different things and all of it is very good. It is on the pricey side, so maybe better for a special occasion. Still worth going at least once.
author: consuelo w.

description:
I'm not that into dim sum. In terms of dim sum quality, it's the best I've ever had. I thought it was even better than the venerable Din Tai Fung. Compared to other moderately priced sum places, I would say it's only 20% better, but 60% more expensive. While good, the utility per dollar is low. 

The selection wasn't that great either. Probably not worth your money but worth a try.
author: Dian X.

description:
Pros:  best dim sum we've ever had in San Fran. We've been to other places in the city/, but this is the only place we'll go to from here on out. 

Cons: the parking situation. We got super lazy and paid to park in a garage several blocks away. Wish they had Peking duck. San Fran is the only city I've ever been to that serves Peking duck at dim sum? I've come to expect it. This is now my favorite dim sum spot in San Fran, but they don't serve duck. Darn.
author: Crystal C.

description: Had been meaning to go here for ages and finally had the chance yesterday. We arrived around 1:00 and were told it would be a 20 minute wait for inside and we could be seated immediately on the patio. The patio turned out to be great! The heat lamps made it very comfortable. We enjoyed all the dim sum on the carts that came around to each table- soup dumplings, chicken mushroom dumplings, fried prawns, chicken egg rolls, BBQ pork buns, sesame balls and egg custard tarts. Everything was excellent and the service is super fast. Just beware that everything does add up cost wise pretty fast. For the three of us to eat it was about $85 total...totally worth it though. Not great decor, but location is good, bustling atmosphere, clean, and the food is authentic and delicious.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
When it comes to Dim Sum, I'm definitely a big fan! And don't get me wrong, this place is delicious! But extremely overpriced! I feel like you can get the same quality for half the price at Ton Kiang in the Richmond.

My most recent visit to Yank Sing my friend and I both woke up that morning and decided we needed Dim Sum, and we needed it now! So we took and Uber from her place over to Yank Sing, and got there about 10 minutes before they opened. There were already some people there, so we claimed our spot as the third party in line, and shortly after we arrived the line started to grow even more!

Shortly after they opened, we were seated and the carts came around right away. Most things we ate were pretty standard, but I really enjoyed the fried prawns, soup dumplings, and the sesame balls the most! We enjoyed the sesame balls so much, that we took an order with us on our way out the door.

One thing I would have liked is if they would have came around with more variety right away. You can order from the menu, but most of the Dim Sum experience (at least in my opinion) comes with getting your food right away. By the time I started getting full, they were coming out with some delicious looking options that I would have surely picked over some of the ones I already had.

If I ever come back i'll definitely be making sure my wallet is full and my stomach is empty! We easily spent $50 a person, and probably could have eaten a few more dishes.
author: Evan A.

description: I was nearby and was craving some soup dumplings (xlb) so I walked over to this dim sum restaurant, tucked away on Stevenson st. I've only been to the other yank sing location and thought it was ok. It's been a long time so I forgot how expensive it was! Service was good. The staff can speak English and everyone was polite. It's definitely an upscale dim sum restaurant. He also take reservations so that's a plus. However, Im not sure how they can justify charging $13.60 for the soup dumplings. Especially since it was nothing spectacular. I've had better elsewhere and at half the price. I guess you're paying for service and ambiance. But their food is just ok. I probably won't be coming back.
author: Lynn V.

description:
My friend works around the corner so we walked over for lunch one afternoon. We sat there for a while and had limited trays of food come around. We kept seeing a tray with some good looking food, but they never brought it by our table.

The food that we did get was okay and typical Dim Sum faire, but I was shocked when we only got a few cheap (at other places) items and our bill came to $45 for two people. There are so many better places to eat in SF I will probably not come here again.
author: Casey S.

description:
How many stars can I give this place??? I wish there were more.

I've been here twice, and both times to this location, which seems to be lesser known but is incredible. The only con I can think of is that the staff bring around about 4 more carts to offer you food, even when you are so happily full you are going to faint. I wish they would slow down on that, but honestly, that's what you get with dim sum. I think they know their food is amazing, so they are confused when you stop eating.

Just like everyone else says, the Shanghai dumplings are great. The duck-pancake wraps were incredible, and I love pretty much anything with "pork" and "bun" in it. Some broccolini for greens, why not? We had the sesame balls for dessert, yum and yum, I wanted an order to go but resisted.

I'm bringing every tourist friend here that comes in town. You've been warned!
author: Nadia B.

description:
2 stars because the food is good but the service is horrible. We have been waiting for a full hour. The check in desk at the front decided to ignore us, god knows why. We were so tired and hungry that it ruined the pleasure we would have had to enjoy the food.
DO NOT GO unless you have a reservation on the books.
author: Catherine M.

description:
Mediocre dim sum in a nice setting and great location. They definitely are more accustomed to handling non-Chinese customers and charging a premium for it but it isn't great food (and it isn't bad either).

The shrimp dumpling (haw gaw) is not as much fresh shrimp and seems like it has some shrimp paste in it. The shumai is a bit bland. I would only come here cause they take reservations and are convenient in the financial district. It shouldn't be surprisingly they can get away with charging a lot more than the typical chinese restaurant as a result. 

You won't be blown away by the quality.
author: Victor W.

description: Loved this dimsum place in the financial district in SFO. Traditional steamed dimsum way better than the fried variety. Steamed buns were delish, shrimp & scallion soup dumplings were delish.
author: ritu b.

description:
Took one of my work partners here for lunch yesterday to discuss some business related items. He had recommended it and I've always heard about it - so we decided to go there since we were in the area. It's kind of tucked in an alley/in-between street from Market and Mission.

It was around 1:30PM and we were seated immediately. I've heard it gets filled up pretty quickly so I guess we got lucky and came at a good time! Right as we got seated, servers immediately flocked our table with offerings. Mind you, I haven't even put my laptop bag down or my suit coat off! We were then asked what we wanted to drink so we settled with hot tea and water. The hot tea was good as it also came in a cool looking glass tea pot.

We only ordered 4 items: soup dumplings (about 5-6 small pieces), shrimp dumplings (about 4-5 small pieces), a shrimp and spinach (or some kind of vegetable - 3 small pieces) dumpling, and the crab pops (2 good sized pieces). There were all good/okay, but I've had way better at other dim sum places around SF, Chinatown, and even in the East Bay where I live.

Then the bill came - over $50.00 for all and when I included about 18-19% tip, came out to $60.00. Again, that's for hot tea and those 4 items mentioned. That's pretty expensive. But I guess it is because it is the location (Financial District) and the hype that drives this place.

In my opinion, it was alright. I would rather recommend going to a place in Chinatown or something for that matter. Maybe I'll try the Yank Sing To Go at the Rincon Center next time too. But we'll see.
author: Daniel M.

description: should  be only 3 stars,dim sum mostly below aveage in taste ,we did not see a price list but it must be $12-15 each small dim sum dish,after spending hundreds of dollars you will be still hungry,you can get better dim sum else where for half the price,if you want to sit and talk and relax this is not the place for you,every minute the come to your table to sell another dish,the only good dishes are pork,the chicken is bad,some of it had blood coming out,
author: cc c.

description:
Never ever dine-in here on an empty stomach because it'll cost you a shiny dime to fill up!!  Between 2 people and ordering the basic dishes, the bill came out to a whopping $60!  I mean, yes, the dim sum is fresh and tasty here and their signature Shanghai dumplings is mighty delectable.  But no freaking way is it worth it to me to dine-in.  I know other dim sum houses that taste just as great but the dime stretches further.

However...

Their lunch express menu is reasonable.  This is one of my default "I feel like Chinese food restaurants".  It's a separate entrance to the side for you to order to go.  It is usually packed with lots of hungry people during lunch hour.  The wait is almost non-existent since the food is already prepared, which is why it's called 'Express'.  Ha!

Well, actually, if you order one of their specials, then you'll have to wait like 5 minutes or so.  But even at that, it's worth it because its usually tasty and hot off the wok and more importantly, priced right!

If you don't mind spending shiny dimes for basic dim sum, this is the place for you.  Otherwise, I'd recommend going elsewhere for your dim sum fix.  However, if your itching for a quick Chinese food bite, then Express is the way to go!  This should definitely be your default 'I feel like Chinese food restaurant" place.
author: Jenny T.

description: Great food loved it not as fancy as the other restaurant but still great food great quality yet it was a bit on the expensive side for some dishes all in all I loved it
author: Theo H.

description:
Pricey... but good.
Overall great dim sum. The food tasted really fresh. The must-try is the soup dumplings. Har gow and siu mai were impressively fresh. The menu is limited at this location though - they didn't have jook (congee) or lau sar bao (duck egg custard buns). We tried the lau yoong bao instead which wasn't bad but nothing to write home about. The chicken feet were yummy. The gau choy gou (Chinese scallion and shrimp dumplings) were juicy and also very fresh. The service was a little disappointing. We were already 20 minutes into our meal and after asking repeatedly for drinks, we finally got our tea and ice water. It also took over 20 minutes to get our check.
author: Benjamin R.

description: Place was great. I was served within a few minutes of sitting down. All of the food options were delicious especially the soup filled dumplings. I would definitely include this place in my top dim sum restaurants.
author: Zachary S.

description:
If you come to Yank Sing, you're here for the dim sum cart experience and not necessarily for the, albeit good, dim sum itself.  That being said, as predictable and cliché as it may be, do not skip the potstickers!  (Really, why would you?)

I was mad because just as we were leaving, we started seeing different things on the carts that looked really good.  But oh well.  I had my fill of potstickers (I'm serious, get a ton of them), enjoyed the seafood dumpling, and wrestled endlessly with the slippery stuffed mushrooms -- so much so that I splashed chili oil all over my shirt and jacket and have yet to get them dry cleaned.  

I was excited to try the Shanghai dumpling after seeing people rave about it here on Yelp, but didn't really like it.  It had an herbal, almost-medicinal aftertaste.  Strange.  As American as this will sound, I really do wish they had more dessert options!  I was craving some good ol' sugar after all that dim sum goodness.  I need to re-energize after strategizing my dim sum maneuvers, fighting to out-dim sum the table in front us.
author: Yelena K.

description:
One of the most coveted dim sum places in San Francisco. This place is always always always busy. Literally I have never seen it experience any sort of down time. The food is quite yummy and speedy since its dim sum. The dumplings were delish! 

Cons:
-BUSY
-Overpriced
-Good food but I would not say it is the best in the city by any means

Tips:
-ALWAYS always always make a reservation first. It will save you a lot of time and anguish.
author: Sami F.

description:
Definitely overpriced, but FINALLY some soup dumplings in San Francisco that aren't awful.

I'm giving this four stars because I genuinely enjoyed much of the food, but I have to say, I really didn't love the setting or the service (though I also came into this with the understanding that it would likely be fairly brusque).

We had Sunday dim sum brunch here, which we made a reservation for the night prior.  We were about 15 minutes late, but we were still seated right away.

Service was on a regular rotation, but still fairly slow.  It took us about an hour to eat until we were full, which seems a little long to me for dim sum.  The ladies manning the push carts were efficient and nice enough, although our male waiter was quite rude when I asked for more water (yes yes, I realize we're in a drought.....almond farmers are much more to blame than my second mini glass of water).  The restaurant itself is simultaneously too fancy but too spartan - you'll know what I mean if you go.  Like, they tried to make it upscale but in a very plain, early 90's way...

For food, we had pork sui mye (erm, shumai...), scallop dumplings, Shanghai dumplings (i.e. soup dumplings), some kind of chicken/mushroom steamed bun, some kind of stuffed mushrooms, Peking duck (with buns), Szechuan chicken, broccoli with oyster sauce, and yellow bean sesame balls (for dessert).  The shumai and Shanghai dumplings I loved (we had two orders of the Shanghai dumplings), although to be fair, I loved them because they're better than anything else in San Francisco.  More soupy, more savory, etc. - but they're still a bit small and the pork "ball" inside has weirdly crunchy bits (maybe celery or something similar?).   The Peking duck was OK but it needed a sauce / topping, and all they had was plum sauce, which I hate.  The broccoli was good, but I recommend asking for it hot.  I loved the sesame balls and ended up taking a few to go and eating them later that afternoon.  The Szechuan chicken was OK but not very spicy.  The scallop dumplings were pretty bad, as were the steamed buns and stuffed mushrooms (we literally could not figure out what was inside of either).

While I would go back given the proximity to BART / my office / other things I do in this area, I really want to find somewhere a bit more laid back / less expensive.
author: Tay H.

description:
The dim sum at Yank Sing can be a bit pricey, but I'd pay for the quality and freshness that they put out. They also have a superb wait staff as compared to other more homey dim sum restaurants. I have nothing against the classic, small, hole-in-the-walls, but I don't mind the extra customer service and food quality that Yank Sing offers.

Yank Sing has two locations and during my short trip to SF, I went to both...

The two locations are: the Spear St. location and the Stevenson St.. The Spear St. location is within a business building food court and it's very nice. The Stevenson location is smaller and not as popular so you may not see as long of a line, but there will still be a wait. Food is consistent between the two.

So were there any notable dishes? Absolutely. The Soup dumplings (Xiao Long Baos). I first discovered these Chinese delights in NYC's Joe Shanghai restaurant. It's well-known for their soup dumplings and I can still taste my first bite. Unfortunately, New Orleans has no such thing, but I've discovered them in major cities like Houston and more recently in San Francisco. Yank Sing has one of the best soup dumplings I have ever had. The dumpling casing is so delicate and very similar to a won-ton. It holds the perfect temperature of soup and dumpling within. Once it's in your mouth, it just melts...Be sure to add the ginger and red vinegar. It balances the flavors so well. It can be an acquired taste so start with just a touch!

Overall, excellent food and service. Yes, the dim sum prices are pretty steep, but it's worth a try! Honestly, I would just go to Yank Sing for a few orders of Soup Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) and some tea. That would be the perfect meal right about now on this Sunday morning...
author: Leslie L.

description: Great lunch. We ate widely and steadily. The shrimp and basil dumplings were probably my favorite. But, really everything was great. People complain about the prices, but I didn't really think it was so bad. I'll definitely go back.
author: Tom C.

description:
Costly business restaurant in downtown SF.
Long lines at lunch, dim sum was good, but at 150% of price as you would find in Millbrae.  Marketeers would tell you 10 minute wait, but be prepared to wait 3x when lines are long.
Good quality & costly food tasty food
author: David H.

description:
I'm no Dim Sum conneuseur.  As a matter of fact, I can count on one hand the number of times I've had legitimate dim sum in my entire life.  I also learned today that there is a proper way to eat But after a filling Yank Sing lunch with some friends today, I think I'm going to have to make more effort to seek out dim sum more often.

Despite heading over during a busy lunch hour, we were seated on the outdoor patio withing minutes of arriving and before I knew it, our table was filled with a variety of food.  I know what you're wondering... what did we eat?  What didn't we eat?!  

It all happened very fast, and four of us definitely ate a lot... I'm now wishing we didn't dig right in and perhaps taken some pics, but we were a hungry bunch.  Some of the highlights from our meal (based on my short term memory and comparing that to Yank Sing's online menu) were:

Snow Pea Shoot Dumplings, Chicken Fun Gwor, Vegetable Dumplings, Shrimp Dumplings, Spring Roll Crisp, Potstickers, Scallop Dumplings, and Chicken Lettuce Wraps.  I didn't eat anything I didn't like... 

I loved the variety and the fact that there were plenty of veggie options and plenty of steamed options too... I didn't love seeing the price when the bill arrived, (it is indeed pricey), but the food quality, convenient location, and timely meal were well worth it.  

I look forward to returning on a future trip to SF, but hope to find some dim sum in AZ that comes close to comparing in the meantime!
author: Gabi M.

description:
Really great dim sum! And trust me everyone in the area knows that, hence our 30 minute wait. Torture to wait so long when your starving for dumplings but so so worth it! I'd recommend trying to come before their crazy lunch rush, would have saved us lots of trouble. 

Service is fast and the carts coming flying by you 24/7. We were never left without food on our table, it was awesome & everything was nice & hot, you could tell they keep bringing freshly cooked products out & nothing is left sitting out for too long. 

Everything we tried here was really good. Great shu mai & shrimp dumplings, even the egg rolls were good here (which often get overlooked & aren't so good at dim sum places). Wish I could remember the name of one of the dumplings!!?? It was longer with shrimp & had an amazing broth over it, if your a frequent dim sum eater I'm sure you'll know what I'm talking about, it's the bomb! Great place I'd definitely recommend it.
author: Melissa L.

description: The food was mediocre for the pricing. The options were limited and they didn't even have the baked BBQ buns ready an hour into service on Saturday.
author: Ari R.

description:
