During my recent work trip to SF we had an  hour lunch break and decided to let our  pregnant colleague choose the restaurant, knowing she'd choose the tastiest (although perhaps not the healthiest) cuisine. She didn't let us down by suggesting dim sum. Yum. 

I worried we didn't have enough time for a sit down lunch, but lunch here was even faster than a McDonalds drive thru and certainly way tastier. Within minutes of sitting down we were greeted by several carts and our table was soon filled with all sorts of delish dumplings. It was difficult to say no to anything so if it was anything but pork it made its way in front of me. My party of 4 devoured it all pretty quickly, called for yet another cart and then got to work finishing the rest. 

We weren't the only ones craving dim sum because this place was packed, but a table on the heated patio was delightful (even on their cooler San Francisco day). By 130pm it started to die down and we had the patio to ourselves. 

Once I got the bill i noticed it was more expensive than most lunches I've had in the area, but that's what happens when you say yes to pretty much everything on the cart.
author: Andrea R.

description: I've not had dim sum before, but this is exactly what I envisioned.  The carts are pushing around busily and you just keep getting food until your heart/belly is content.  We had reservations for 4 at 12:30pm and were sat on time.  You really have to pace the food, because they will keep your table full and feed you quick if you let them.  We had broccoli, soup dumplings, pork buns, Peking duck, sea bass, and fried crab/shrimp as well as tea.  We had no room for dessert.  Everything was tasty and seasoned well.  I would come back for sure.
author: Crystal L.

description:
This place is fucked up delicious. My go-to dim sum spot, especially when friends visit from out of town and are looking for some delicious Asian fare. (Don't expect outstanding service but it's dim sum and they turn tables so quick to meet demand, so who cares- just feast)

The Peking duck served w/bun is pretty much out of this world. So are the pork soup dumplings and the lotus leaf. You are a fool to not get the aforementioned items.

Not a huge fan of the scallop dumpling as it is really dense and a lot to handle. Foiled chicken is really hard to eat but has great flavor. Veggies are not really worth the stomach space when there are so many other delicious options. I ordered Chinese broccoli and it was served cold. 

Pro tip- Show up starving and ready to feast like it's your last meal on earth. 

Pro tip #2- bring a wheelchair to escort you out of the restaurant as it will be hard to walk. Then, prepare to fall into a severe food coma.
author: Alex R.

description:
Did they serve a side of diamonds and gold bars with your first order of Shumai here? NOPE!

I knew this place was bad news when we walked in and I didn't see a single Asian person in site. On top of that, I saw a lot of tables with fancy champagne glasses. WTF is going on here?!

We looked over the "fancy" menu while waiting for our group of friends to arrive. I couldn't believe my eyes. $20 for a piece of fish? Wait, what are you doing service fish when it's Dim Sum hour?! $12 for some soup. $7 for 2 egg tarts?! YIKES!

I was hoping this would be the best damn dim sum I've ever grubbed on since we were paying a pretty penny. All hope was lost when I saw how tiny the Shumai and Hargow pieces were. And on top of the portion sizes, they weren't all that (not juicy and flavorful enough). Just standard in my opinion.

I really wanted an egg tart cuz I'm obsessed with custard-filled pastries. But these were probably the most bland and soggiest egg tarts I've ever had. BOO!

I would have to say the only positive thing that happened was that the staff didn't make a big deal when our entire group wanted to split the Michelin-star-restaurant-type bill. And of course the company we were with was another highlight of our experience.

P.S. They charged a pretty penny for each pot of tea that we had on our table too. :(
author: Michelle V.

description: Horrible. You should go to the one on Spear street instead. We tried to order 5-7 times and the waiter either pretended to take our order and never delivered any food or they said they don't take orders. The selection of the food here is also not the complete menu of the Spear Yank Sing.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Way better for weekday lunch. Been here on a few occasions on the weekend and was not impressed. Weekday, on the other hand - is great. 

Came in around noon and was seated within 15 minutes for party of 2. Lots of carts going around. Their dumplings are surprisingly good. Had the scallop and mushroom, vegetarian mushroom, and shrimp. All were great. Also had some fried dishes: the crab claw and a shrimp paste wrapped around shrimp tempura.

Prices are on the expensive side, though. About twice as expensive as nearby/comparable chinatown options. Wouldn't frequent, but is a nice alternative for the monotonous weekday lunch option.
author: Stine H.

description: Tasty dim sum.  Enjoyed lunch there last Sunday.  Guest also enjoyed it, especially the egg custard.
author: Craig H.

description:
At first glance, we were a little skeptical of this place. Fancy dim sum doesn't always equal to real, taste worthy dim-sum.

But overall it was good quality dim-sum. Chicken feet was decent!  Shanghai dumpling was good. Nice, speedy service. That's 3 for 3, right. It's not the best dim sum I've ever had but it was pretty decent.
author: Quinn V.

description:
Vegan friendly and the best dim sum I've had outside of China. The fillings are flavorful and well balanced, with the ingredients finely minced. Wrappers are paper thin and very delicate, yet the dumplings don't fall apart when you pick them up or take a bite out of them. With dumplings this perfect, you don't need a dipping sauce. 

The place gets packed during lunch (they don't serve dinner) so a reservation is highly recommended. 

When you see something on the menu that is not on the cart simply tell them and they will bring it on the next run, although they might forget or someone else may grab it off the cart before they get to you. 

All of the vegan options I had were delicious. Between the vegetable dumplings and turnip cakes, my favorites were the spinach and the mushroom dumplings. 

Don't leave without dessert. The coconut roll is out of this world. Glutinous rice flour, slightly sweet, shaped into a roll and filled with coconut custard, then steamed and sliced. OMG I could have 10 of these. The steamed dessert buns took a long time to come out and in retrospect were out shadowed by the coconut roll, although still good. 

Yes, some of the dishes are close to $20 so look at the menu before you start grabbing stuff off the cart. There are plenty of reasonable options so you don't have to break the bank.
author: Ute L.

description: As soon as I sat down, they started to ask if I want the appetizers. I ordered shrimp dumpling and shanghai dumpling but they were not worth it. I had exactly same dim sum at the china town ( mong kok bakery) and it was SOOOOO much better but with lower price. It was a CHAOS and not worth waiting for 30 minutes.
author: Sung Young J.

description:
I am giving this dim sum 3 stars only because they had a small variety of dim sum. They were missing the rice noodles and other key components to make have the true dim sum experiences.

Also, it is ridiculously expensive here. For the six of us, it was $202 before tip. I look at the menu and normally the siu mai is $3.00, here it was $7.15. Although, delicious but SO FREAKING expensive.

Even with tea, they charged us $2 per person. 

Definitely will not be coming back to such an expensive dim sum place.
author: Tina K.

description: The food was pretty good. Very expensive. Roughly 2x in price from what you would normally expect at another dim sum place. The dim sum here seems more 'put together' -- like, it took them some more time to make and more care taken in the cooking. Definitely good job here. I thought the flavors were relatively mild. The xiao long bao is great here.
author: John N.

description:
If there were an option to give these idiots 0 stars I would. 

Walked in to try to get a quick lunch. Seating outside and inside available but once we got to the front desk they asked if we had reservations. We didn't but we looked around and there were plenty of free unoccupied tables. It was only two of us and a table for two available and asked us to wait 20min.

We left.
You suck.
Never again.
author: Avery K.

description:
This is the smaller of the 2 Yank Sings, which I preferred.  Seemed to have less tourists and more locals than the one at the Rincon Center.  Used Open Table the night before, and made 10:30 brunch reservations, and that worked out well as the restaurant was already crowded at that time.

I really love everything about dim sum except the price!  I know that they are labor intensive, and this is San Francisco, but $110.00 for 2 people is a lot of money!  Some items just seemed to be priced outrageously - like the Peking duck bun, which was $7 per bun, which had about a 1 ounce portion of duck, and 4 egg custards for $14 - come on!

So, the food is a solid 4 stars (those egg custards were the best I've ever had), but I had to knock them down a star for the cost.  Best to go if someone else is treating :)
author: Jen G.

description: Really enjoyed the food.  You definitely want to call for a reservation but still may have to wait.  Restaurant was very clean.  It has a different vibe then Chinatown.  Pricey but it was good and very close to the hotel we were staying at.  I would go again.
author: B D.

description: Lunch from 2go was good. I got the veggie combo. Line moved quickly. Sesame ball was the best part, don't forget to add it!
author: Virginia L.

description: My ex used to tell me about their other locale all the time. Not sure why it took me so many years to hit it up. Had to have a quick lunch before hitting one of the museums before close. Dim Sum is pretty instantaneous when it comes to food delivery. Strange thing we had to wait 10 min (they told us 20) when there was a table setup for exactly our group number against the wall. We waited and that's exactly where they put us. So weird. XLB, siu mai, har gow, and all the other standard dumplings. Fast, decent quality and fairly appropriately priced. The service staff were actually nice which is far from the surly/pushy im used to for dim sum. we got in, we got out. 3.5 stars
author: Kim N.

description:
This is a great spot for soup dumplings. And pork buns. Fast service and delicious food.
It is, however, a bit pricey. My pro-tip is to avoid the very expensive fish platters.
author: Edward M.

description:
Food at yank sing was delicious BUT (and I mean a BIG BUT) the bill came to $163 before tip for a party of three for lunch. No alcohol. Only tea and it somehow cost $163 BEFORE tip. 

We didn't even order anything crazy--the most expensive looking item was a duck sandwich. Operative word there is that it "looked" expensive. You have NO IDEA what things cost; when they come around with the carts or when you get the bill. There are just category numbers and then quantity number (for each category). There's no way to understand how much you're paying for what!

Really good food but absolutely outrageous prices for LUNCH without DRINKS. Won't be able to go back...
author: Kristina R.

description:
Expensive. And the first time I came, I was disappointed. Steam soup dumplings w/o crab? ($14 a serving BTW) no shrimp noodle? no soft tofu dessert? These are really standard items here. So I'm told these items are all found in the Ricon center location. So I came to the wrong location apparently.

taste of others were pretty decent, chicken feet, sticky rice, peking duck was just not good, sea bass was done well (but again way overpriced).

Overall, it's a nice clean place. but walking away around $40-50 a person for dim sum is way too overpriced.
author: Grapes T.

description: Food was not good at all!  Ha gow wrap was sticky and everything we got in general did not taste fresh. China Live has way better XLB for cheaper and way more fresh and delicious! For the high price you pay and mediocre food and noisy crammed seating, I will not recommend this place to anybody. Non Asian people who go here don't know what good dim sum is.
author: Cookie B.

description:
Just this past Saturday, I visited Yank Sing restaurant for a dim sum lunch. Since I arrived early in advance of my friend (who made the reservation) and her family, I was left waiting by the door. Following me, other couples who arrived in advance of their party were immediately seated. If their policy is not to seat groups until their entire party has arrived, I don't understand why I wasn't seated. Strike one.

We sat in an alcove right behind the maitre d' station which seemed to be the last stop on the dim sum trail. If you find yourself in this corner, note that you'll be mostly exposed to sun. For San Francisco, it was an extremely hot day and the restaurant offered no respite or air conditioning in our area. Strike two.

You would think with the temperature that the service staff would be quick to deliver glasses of water. They didn't. Instead, I had to walk up to a server who was standing around with nothing to do and ask for glasses of water. Strike three.

Having eaten dim sum in fancy pantsy places and humble shacks, I think the food was nothing special. Even though they've been much hyped, I've had better dumplings at Shanghai Dumpling House in the outer Richmond, a family run business without the posh prices. I'm outta here.
author: Joanna T.

description:
My husband and I had brunch at Yank Sing. The restaurant was quite busy for it being 10:30 am so I can't imagine how busy this place is at peak lunch or dinner time!  Verdict was that we really enjoyed our very early lunch!

We ordered a fried prawn dish, should've ordered the half order but I wasn't aware it came in halves. The servers don't tell you that some dishes come in halves so pay attention to the menu. We also ordered Shanghai dumplings (soup dumplings), and steamed pork buns. It was all delicious. Soup dumplings are hard to find and soooo good!  It was my first time having a pork bun and it was really tasty. 

We didn't order dessert because it was way to early for dessert. Haha. Next time we'll plan further in advance and try to get a dinner reservation!
author: Elyssa S.

description:
Yank Sing is very average. I have had the sit down dim sum / lunch as well as the takeout box. Every time I go here, I keep hoping it will be better but really I have no idea why people go here and love it so much.

The sit down service is obviously much better than the takeout side. The food is fresh, and while you're not going to find weird meat parts in your food, it also is not as enjoyable as traditional dim sum for me. And it costs at least 4x as much.

The takeout food is just not good. I would prefer Panda Express. Because of the pre-set menu offerings, everything is very mass produced, heat lamped, and extremely oily. I had a lot of leftover fried rice and noodles in my lunch box, but opted to just toss it instead of saving it for later. I would much rather walk 15 minutes uphill into Chinatown and get takeout dim sum on Stockton for a fraction of the price, better selection, and a less greasy feeling after eating and digesting the food.
author: Hayley C.

description: Definitely more expensive than your regular dim sum but the non-regular items  are worth it! Salt and pepper sea bass and chicken buns were incredible! Unfortunately found the soup dumplings mediocre.
author: K T.

description:
OK dim sum. Ran out of Shui Mae!? 

Pretty overpriced for average affair. Nice egg tarts though.
author: James M.

description: Excellent! We ate just about everything they brought by! I wish we could have tried more things but we filled up pretty quickly! The only thing that I would pass on were the sesame sticky buns, they we not our favorite... now I wish we had a dim sum restaurant near us!! This place is a must go place!!
author: Jack G.

description: A CLASSY AND DELICIOUS DIM SUM EXPERIENCE. Conveniently located in the heart of the financial district. Pricy for dim sum but the service and environment make it worth the extra expense, and obviously the food. On par with din tai fung, even a bit more authentic here. Get the Peking Duck. Most memorable SF experience over our two day vacation.
author: Eliot L.

description:
My preface is that my husband and I have had dim sum across the country and the world so we have pretty particular expectations when it comes to dim sum.
I'll say that the food here is solid.
For two, we ordered Xiao long bao, shu mai, hargow, spare ribs and the baked pork buns.
Everything was pretty good---but I don't know that i would really consider anything stellar.
The service was fine. I would even say better than most dim sum restaurants.
That being said, my dissatisfaction is with the price. Our bill came out to $51...
I understand paying for quality ingredients and cleanliness...but sometimes if the difference in price is so dramatic, you question if the difference in food was really all that worth it.
author: Tammy P.

description: First experience of takeaway dim sum. Smaller menu than use to but decent considering it was to go.
author: Christy A.

description: Really good dim sum place. Everything is pretty well done and the location nearer to the water has valet parking. If you come here, you just have to remember that the food is expensive for Dim Sum but to make up for it the portions are also generally larger than a typical dim sum place. All in all really good just be prepared to spend up to 50 per person.
author: Ian C.

description:
This place is a huge disappointment. The food wasn't great as it's raved..

Mango pudding - 2.5 more starchy than anything..
Shanghai dumpling - 1.5 the dumpling just sucks..little juice and small piece of meat
Steam bbq bun - 2.5 - the bun is just weird looking, not the traditional looking bun..hardly any pork inside too
Siu mai - 3.5..not bad, it's on the lighter side so i do like this
Shrimp dumpling - 3.5 not bad either as it has a lot of shrimp
Peking duck with bun - 2.5 the duck is on the fatty side and the bun just didn't suite well
Chicken in foil - 2 got bones! really? and it's only two pieces..meaning two foil..flavor was bold but damn..bones and fat?
Lotus rice - 3 didn't taste it but looks and smelled great
Veggie dumpling - 2.5 didn't care for the skin..i ate the inside though..it's eh..nothing special
Honey baked seabass - 5..this is probably the best and most memorable item of all..it's really good..

Tea was nice and all but service was slow and water got to us super late..I like how you can make reservations, but still..

Seriously all of that..$114 bucks? really? gah damn..

It's super small and no AC..so people are constantly fanning themselves..kinda gross I would say..
author: Minerva L.

description: This type of food was a bucket list item for me. I have always wanted to try it and living in south Florida does not make it easy. The closest thing is hot pot for me. I loved every bit of my experience here. The food was fresh and the staff was great. It is a good idea to make a reservation here. We walked right in and to a table and others waited a while who didn't call ahead. From the moment we sat down food was arriving in bulk. We ate a bit too fast and missed some items that looked great, but everything I had was delicious. We were in and out quickly and left very full and satisfied. I would recommend this place to anyone, but deep pockets is a must. We had four people and ate what I would call a normal amount and the bill came to $155.
author: Jeff S.

description: Yank Sing is a fancier dim sum restaurant (it's no Crystal Jade or MY China, but definitely nicer than the average dim sum place). The food is probably just as good as Koi Palace or Hong Kong Flower Lounge, but the prices are a little higher. Located in the Rincon Center of the financial district, this only seems right, so I'm not complaining. However, one thing I don't is that they don't push any carts around for you to see what they have to offer. Sometimes they carry trays and offer it to you as they pass your table, but even that practice is not guaranteed. Most of the time when I come here, I have to wave down a waiter and tell them what I want by a whole bunch of broken cantonese and pointing to other people's tables (still no complaints though, my success rates for ordering all the delicious dim sum is pretty high ;).
author: Lisa N.

description:
To summarize - decent food overpriced with a wait.

Came around 1:30pm on a Sunday and waited about half an hour. Wait wasn't pleasant because it's windy and cold where the restaurant is and everyone waits outside. Once we got seated, it's all cart-pushing style dim sum. Pro of getting plates off the cart is no wait; whereas the con is they only brought out some of the menu items and you might also fill up on your secondary choices before your favorite dish is finally brought out.

Shanghai soup dumpling was yummy, so are the pork bun and sticky rice chicken. Pot sticker is too oily. My general observation was they make as many fried dim sums as steamed which I can see as a pro for some, but since I'm more of a fan of traditional style dim sum (lighter, mostly steamed dishes), I was slightly disappointed by the amount of fried dished presented.

Bill for two came out to be around $100 including tax and tip. It could be because we pigged out :p, but this place certainly charges a premium for the decor/location etc.
author: Heidi B.

description:
Yes, the dim sum here is expensive. But the quality and service are excellent. We made reservations, so we didn't have to wait :0) Our favs were the soup dumplings, the wonderfully crispy-bottom gyoza, and sea bass. Yum!  If the carts don't happen to bring by what you want, just ask and they will bring it immediately!
The service was top notch. As soon as our teapot got low, a full one immediately replaced it!  Servers were nice and spoke English.
author: Dale H.

description: $15 for shiomai? $5 for tea?! Get the F outa here! Not even worth it, wife and I spent $80+ here for dimsum. Never again will I fall for this trap.
author: Soh T.

description:
DimSum is like Chinese fast food. I'd say this place is better than most. Very busy lunchtime dining area due to location, go early and it's not an issue. Black Bean curd is something they rarely have on the carts so we order it immediately. Nomnomnom
Two people can burn through $100 for lunch easily, so be prepared for that. Validated parking.
author: Ragenvald G.

description:
Good: Sea Bass, Peking Duck
Bad: price

The See Bass melts in your mouth, but the price really reaches into your wallet!  It's a must try nonetheless.  Same holds true for the Peking Duck. Portion is extremely small but worth that one try. 

The shumai was better than most, but not to die for.  They holds true for most of the dim sum here, all above average, as was the price.   Also, my wife tried the mango cheesecake. She liked it. I didn't.  

This place is definitely not your hole-in-the wall econo dim sum joint.  Above average, high priced. Worth it? Maybe. Just make sure you get the Sea Bass.
author: Arnel L.

description:
Always excellent.
Quick service - great staff.
I've been going through its various locations for more than 30 years.
Overtime I'm in SF.
author: David B.

description: Worst dim sum experience, very few dim sum choices, they charge 20 bucks for a tiny little steamed seabass which is actually cod, I was so surprised they cheated on the name, it's ok for you to charge 20 bucks for a cod, but you cannot charge under sea bass's name, will never come back to this place again, don't know how they got michilin recommended!
author: Violet W.

description:
Satisfied with the food. Wish the price was little cheaper. 57 items in the dim sum list. Price range between $5.25 and $12.95. 

Very busy place. Was waiting in the line for about 15 minutes before getting a table. Maybe I should've made a reservation before coming over.
author: Mir A.

description:
One of the best dimsum places I've ever been to! Service was prompt and efficient, carts are well stocked, and freshness - oh wow! Almost all items were steaming! Particularly loved the steamed BBQ pork buns, shrimp and pork siu mye and sticky rice. These items are my all time favorite and Yank Sing nailed them!

However I feel the bill did end up to be more than expected
author: Alex P.

description:
We traveled out of the state. Started with Shanghai dumplings and everyone so loved them and ended up ordering 3 more shanghi
Price tag was high but worth it!
author: Clear S.

description:
Really pricy for the quality of the food. The waiters were pushy to bring food on the table and the bill in the end was really salty - not an authentic Dim Sum place. 
I would not recommend this restaurant.
author: Charlotte R.

description: We had an excellent lunch here, mostly dumplings. The BBQ pork buns and minced chicken lettuce wraps were also really tasty. The only drawback is that it's expensive, we spent about $35 per person.
author: Kathleen K.

description: This is the third time we've been to this restaurant in two years, and it's getting worse every time. To be fair, the quality of the food is not too bad, and people there are still nice. But combined with the price factor, this is not worth it.  So we are done with this restaurant at least for a while.
author: Yuqiao S.

description:
Perhaps the best dim sum I've had including many places in Boston and New York. 

Ask for items on the bottom - taken from the top tend to be a little cold - no body wants cold soup dumplings stuck to the steamer!

Carts came out quicker than most places and special requests came out remarkably fast. 

Prices were much higher than any other dim sum I've had. Given the neighborhood, I'll let it pass (typically a lost star). 

I look forward to my next trip to San Fran so I can get some of these xiao long bao!
author: Michael O.

description: By far the BEST Dim Sim I've ever had and while it was definitely expensive (as in we spent $100 on two people in like 40 minutes) it was damn worth it.
author: Isabella J.

description: Great place to walk to from the Powell street area. The room is small, so there's not too much noise. As everyone ahead of me stated, the soup dumplings are pretty killer. We also got the Chinese broccoli, the Peking duck, siu Mai and ice tea. Super yum!!
author: Cynthia S.

description: Ordered their Phoenix combo and the dim sum was delicious but the combo was mostly fried rice and chow mein. Will individually order their dim sum selections next time!
author: Cindy Z.

description: Probably the best dim sum I have eaten.  My friend Anna and I wanted a good dim sum and I recall over 5 years ago eating at this place.  They have amazing flavor profiles and some really unique dishes.  The textures and taste were so flavorful and delicious.  Every dish we ordered we loved.  While we had to wait almost 45 on a Sunday at noon it was worth the trip.  Still crowded even at 2 pm when we left.  This place is good I will be back the next time I am in the bay area.
author: Eddie O.

description:
Showing up here you are greeted with chaos. I had a reservation but it was essentially worthless. After finally "checking in" with the hostess, I was told they would call my name. When did that happen?  It happened after every single person waiting in front of me had been seated, despite the fact that about half of them had no reservation. 

Was the food good?  Who cares?  There are tons of great restaurants, so there is no need to wait in line for over an hour at this place.
author: Brad B.

description: Can't believe people rave about the xiao long baos here. Poor San Francisco! There are so many better places for that. Din tai fung and my dumpling in the South Bay are 1000x better. This dim sum place is pretty Americanized and was missing a lot of the traditional dim sum dishes. Food was mediocre and I still left hungry after spending about $40 per person. This place is also overpriced. We ordered the mango ice cream cake which was $9 but was literally one tiny slice. Would not come back.
author: Leslie C.

description: Fantastic food and service. You'd swear you were in Hong Kong at the Peninsula or something. Pricey.
author: Michael J S.

description: I'm allergic to soy, wheat and peanuts eliminating 99% of what I could eat there but my family loves the place so they made me a vegetable fried rice without any of the allergens - decent- giving a five star for the extra effort to all my allergies. Family was happy!!!
author: Jule P.

description:
Over rated and why am i eating at a high end chinese DEEM SUM restaurant when im chinese?!!

but its always good to try at least once.

i have to admit Yank Sing's dim sum are good but i wish there were more variety.

so is it DEEM SUM or DIM SUM??! 

and customer service was good they were able to accomdate my LATE reservations (30 mins) on the day off especially since there was a line out the door. call before hand and they can pencil you in right away!
author: Carol Y.

description: This place is good I am just sad that one it is so pricey and 2 that they don't have all the popular dim sum items.  They don't have shrimp rice roll I was like really? And egg tart is 11.90 a order that's ridiculous.  Egg tart is worth no more than 4 dollars, I know my parents owned a dim sum restaurant.  Sadly I won't be back too pricey.  I did like the sticky rice though
author: Judy C.

description:
Interesting combination of two unrelatable words and you get the name of this unique food establishment. Upscale at the very least (food prices reflect it), and situated in a random alleyway in the Financial District, Yank Sing is the kind of place that's reserved for fancy business meetings or special events (think birthday, anniversary, etc.). 

My co-worker (fellow Yelp Elite Gold member Stephen D.) and I happen to drop in on this place randomly, having already scoured the entire FiDi for decent lunch joints. It was his first time here and after being seated (with less than 3 min wait time) in the outside heated patio, we ordered the basics: Siao Long Bao, Pork Spare Ribs, Jasmine Tea, Har gow and Pork Shumai, all of which were equally delightful. I can't name one complaint about any of the food. Service was quick; as soon as we were sat, ladies with carts of dimsum flocked around us, frequently offering their dishes. After a polite "no", they scurried away, tending to other hungry customers. 

After a brief 20 min. of discussing travels to Asia whilst devouring the food, it was time for the bill, which amounted to ~$46 after tax and tip. Considered it to be a bit on the expensive side, but what can you expect from a upscale Chinese restaurant located in the middle of the Financial District? A quick glance at the clientele eating here and you'd soon notice that, in the midst of European business suits and luxury apparel, a $46 lunch for two people is considered pennies.

I'll rate it a 4/5 for awesome service, delectable food but overall pricey ($4 for a pot of hot jasmine tea?). However, I'll definitely be coming back for special events! 

Damage: $$$ ($25-$35 for a small amount of food)
Noise: Medium (patio dining available)
Parking: Paid street parking
Dress code: Business Casual
author: Carloalexi M.

description:
ALERT!  If you're looking for dim sum, this isn't your place.  However, if you're looking for PF Chang sample portions.. you may have found a winner!  I would have been gotten better portions at an afternoon sampling at Costco.  1 banana leaf sticky rice?  2 taros?  Despicable!

Beware of the specialty item "Shanghai Dumplings" - they fail to mention that you must have an 800 credit score and a cosigner to afford these bad boys.

All I have to say is - what type of dim sum doesn't serve tripe?!  Tripe is the sole reason I ever go to eat dim sum to begin with.  They also have hot mustard at the table and hot sauce that isn't expired.. not at all authentic.  Not to mention:
- they speak perfect English
- accept Open Table reservations
- serve lettuce wraps
- serve honey walnut prawns
- and order from the kitchen via Bluetooth headsets.

What happened to the good old days of a grandma doing hand calculations, pineapple buns and gaudy chandeliers?

Totally put a damper on my day.
author: Lan L.

description:
Short Version: Very poor value, not seasoned enough.  Pass

So completely not worth it.  I knew this going in, but didn't expect it to be quite so not worth it.

Cha Shao (Xiu) Bao: Good bread/bao part, but so skimpy on the filling.  The filling was sweet, but could have been more flavorful.  2 bao for ~$6

Shrimp Dumpling: Good rice skin, but the shrimp part was too dry and compact.  Was very average.  4 dumpling for ~$6

Shanghai Soup Dumpling: Decent pork (advertised as kurobuta).  Would be nice if they had another option (crab!).  Served properly with vinegar and ginger in it.  This was not bad, but pricey.  6 dumpling for $14

Spring Rolls:  Big portion!  4 big rolls for $10.  Really solidly good and fresh/cripsy.

Chicken Feet: So dry, not enough flavor.  When I pay this much for dim sum, it better be fall-off-the-bone good with solid seasoning.  These were some of the weakest chicken feet I've eaten.

People say the flavoring here is dumbed down for non-Chinese.  I don't know if that's the reason, but I'll say across the board, not enough seasoning, and very poor value.

The atmosphere is busy, service is average.  They were busy for lunch and completely ignored my table for 15 minutes after we were seated, I don't expect that from dim sum, as normally people want to start eating immediately.
author: Alice S.

description:
Somebody said "Overpriced dim sum. But I won't hold that against the quality of their food, and if you think about it, the kind of rent they must be paying in order to score a location in the Financial District."

It is not my problem if they located in financial district. They are just too expensive to warrant eating there. Besides dim sum all taste the same, shu mai, har gow, xlb....all over bay area, they all same, there is no magic formula ! It is basically a for white folks experience of dim sum .
author: Wei L.

description:
First of all, I LOVE dim sum. 

Never have I ever experienced a dim sum dining experience like the one I had here. 

1) Impeccably clean. The tables, chairs, utensils, sauce holders, walls....clean. 

2) Surprisingly attentive/quick/helpful/organized staff. After the many places I've gone for dim sum in my lifetime, I've learned that dim sum service can be long and annoying. This place however... Seems dedicated to ensuring that their customers receive any and all dishes they crave. The waiters/waitresses had a very convenient microphone attached to their shirt so any request we had was handled in a timely manner. (At a dim sum place?!?! Unheard of!) Each item we requested came out hot within a matter of minutes. (Except one which they completely forgot to bring...which worked out because we had ordered too much anyway) All in all, very impressive staff.

In all honestly the food was just ok. I thought the haw gao, sui mai, potstickers, shrimp egg rolls and spare ribs were sub par...I wouldn't order them again. The pork shanghai dumplings, dan taut (egg custard) sesame balls and fried shrimp with a dash of cilantro (no idea what it was called) were my favorite dishes. We also ordered these bacon wrapped pieces of shrimp that were pretty good. 

If I recommended this place...it wouldn't be for the food, but for the experience of seeing what a higher end (and MUCH more expensive) version of dim sum is like. Our total was over $100 for nearly 10 little items and some sodas so it was pretty expensive for dim sum. Still I enjoyed it so I would probably go again and simply order other things. The dessert cart looked amazing btw.
author: Kristy F.

description: Looks nice, but a completely disorganized hot mess. It wasn't clear if the line was for seating or to take a number. You couldn't even ask the "hostess" because she was busy running around doing credit cards and getting money from the register, at the same time not even once looked at the dozen of people waiting in front of her. Customers had to find out from one another what their system was. Customers kept piling up and inadvertently cutting other people in the "line". We stood there for 15 minutes only to find out the wait was 45 minutes if you had no reservation with multiple people cutting in front of me. No one got a number or were asked many seats they needed at all the time we were there. We ended up walking to Chinatown to New Asia, where the dim sum was decent and the service was impeccable.
author: K T.

description: Best Xiao Long Bao in the Bay Area. You can't find thin wrapper like theirs anywhere else.
author: Bubble T.

description:
Over priced is an understatement. Meh dishes.  The pork dumpling execution was awful.  They put the dumplings directly on the paper vs putting in foil    So when you tried to pick them up they broke and all the soup poured out.  Service was nice enough but felt they were trying to push food on us.  

Won't go back unfortunately
author: G S.

description: This has become our favorite dim sum restaurant. The food is consistently good and the service is good as well. It can get busy during lunch (no surprise there), so allow a little extra time. Be careful as the price of the meal can definitely rise quickly without you realizing it!
author: Alexandria D.

description: Remains a 5 Star in my book. Glad I got the opportunity to visit again Yank Sing is the best Dim Sum I have ever had. I especially enjoyed the Peking Duck on this visit. I will go there every chance I get when visiting San Francisco.
author: Shawn R.

description:
TOP quality
Good tea
Big selection of dim sum
There was a special the last time I was there, a sea bass dish was EPIC.
I prefer the other location for the view.

It's pretty authentic. However, the presentation is too nice, its dressed up for the locals. If that makes sense.
author: Jen L.

description: Good dim sum and friendly service. Kid friendly. If you're in Financial District, you should go. Otherwise, there are better places in Chinatown. Recommend
author: Rojelleo H.

description: The best Dim Sun around(including Chinatown) although a bit pricy the service was good and the taste of the food was excellent. Slightly better than the location on Stewart St. Come early on the weekends as the line outside gets long very fast. I recommend reservations.
author: Wally C.

description: Consistent and convenience dim sum in downtown San Francisco. Always a must stop when visiting from Florida.
author: Colman B.

description:
I've been here many times for their To Go food. They are fast, prices are reasonable and the food tastes good. 

For dining in I have sat inside most of the times and once outside. I can safely say that the service while patio dining is subpar compared to interior dining. Service is prompt and regular on the inside. While dining outside, our waiter did not come by with the requested tea until we asked again towards the end of our meal. We flagged our waiter more often for all other requests or questions. 

Food is delicious. I love their variety of dim sum, the presentation and taste. I have enjoyed every item thus far. I will visit again but stick with sitting inside.
author: Shell I.

description: Most amazing food ever!!!! Traveled 3hrs just to go here for lunch, well my friends had other business and I just tagged along. It seems like a buffet, but not. They wheel around little carts and you just grab what you want. They do give you a menu, which have the prices of everything. It can get pricey when you just start grabbing because you're so hungry
author: Joyce M.

description: Supposedly the best Dim Sum place in San Francisco! It was amazing, but definitely on the pricey side. It is a lot smaller than the dim sum places that I'm used to, but the quality and service are there.
author: Elise K.

description: Nice location in the heart of the financial district but so ridiculously overpriced with limited selection of oversteamed chinese broccoli with a dark green hue and mediocre shumai and sticky rice, have no idea why anyone would come here again.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Went to a hosted birthday party at the Spear St branch but still feel obliged to report the experience. It is nice and clean but open to all passing through this business complex. Noisy, to say the least, could not talk across the table and be heard. Okay.  A pot of tea  $10, so I had a beer for $5. Although we continually told the sellers who wheel their carts of ready made dim sum that we preferred seafood, veggie, or chicken, they were aggressive in trying to have us accept what was offered (mostly pork ). This is a place for tourists who have not ordered dim sum and are omnivorous but not for true foodies. The fried shrimp were slightly undercooked and the "vein" with its sediment had not been removed and the spring rolls were overbaked or overfried (looks like they were baked after frying - as a warmup? The pot stickers were nice and freshly prepared, the shredded cabbage was an  attractive cole slaw cone, delicious and a good contrast to the other foods. The asparagus dish was also innovative, but then the disappointment over some cold watery bok choi or other greens went uneaten by all 12 of us. Egg tarts as dessert  best cut in half and have another split dessert or no other- more than enough for 1 person.The staff was accommodating as to time and it was not crowded by a long shot, even on the day of the Chinese New Years Parade. Discussion with them in trying to order from the menu or asking about the contents of the offerings on the cart was difficult- better order from the menu if you care about the choices. HAPPY NEW YEAR, year of the rooster, something to crow about! One of my fellow diners works down the street, said if you want a lunch here and don't need the table, order at the take-out stand nearby  and have plenty of choices and affordable prices. For a party, of course, the Yank Sing is a good choice.
author: weedy t.

description:
I have to say the strangest thing about Yang Sing is the $$$ for dim sum. The food and service were great. The staff was super friendly, I guess that's the one thing I had a hard time wrapping my chopp sticks around. I even saw one of the dim sum ladies smile.
Since I was there for a company lunch I didn't have a problem stopping every cart that flew buy. The bill was over 200 bucks for four of us chaaaa ching!! (chang chong)!
author: Ray B.

description: Bomb. Not as good as city view dim sum on Kearny and commercial but pretty dang close !  Love the fried and steamed ratio and hate the lines on Sunday.
author: Britt E.

description:
I'd sum up my experience today as an expensive waste of my tastebuds and dollars. I hadn't been back to Yank Sing for a long time after finding MANY other tasty and less expensive dim sum joints in the city and surrounds. But, since ratings have been high and it appears on all the go-to lists in the city, I thought I should give it another shot. My mistake.

Started out with the basics: har gow (shrimp dumplings) and shui mai (pork/shrimp dumplings). Bland is an overstatement. The shrimp were done well, but that's about it. I ordered the char chiu bow (pork buns) and they were OK, but just OK. Had better at most every other place we've been to. 

The tsim so goong (bean sheet rolls) was the first really tasty item I ordered. Pork ribs had absolutely no taste. Finished up with mai gai ( flavored rice in a lotus leaf). It was passable, but not great.

I expected more, much more, out of Yank Sing. Been to Hong Kong dim sums in Hong Kong and this is not even close in quality, quantity or price. Amazingly costly dim sum that was, at best, instantly forgettable. At worst, I felt ripped off and will not be back.
author: Diane K.

description:
I came to the to go area to pick up some of the Shanghai pork soup dumplings for lunch. Only had to wait a few minutes for them to be ready after I paid the $13 (!) for them. Service seemed very speedy overall. 
When I got back to my desk I was disappointed to find only 6 small dumplings especially for the price. The dumplings themselves were very good, the savory broth inside was tasty and dumpling/pork cooked perfectly, just wish they were bigger or I had maybe..2 more? 
I wouldn't mind returning to try more dishes but only if I wanted to "splurge" on lunch.
author: Miss H K.

description: Yank Sing: you should definitely go (at least once) when you're in SF, particularly if you're visiting. The location is great, but there's no parking. [You're in downtown SF, remember?] The place is clean, almost kinda trendy. And the food is simply outstanding- 6 stars. I feel like I'm letting the cart ladies down when I don't take their offered stuff. Be tough though: wait for what you really want (hey, that's how it works). The place can get almost hectic busy, particularly during lunchtime.  I know- my office used to be in the building upstairs. It's pricey though, you're paying for location & hipness.
author: Dan D.

description:
Ugh so the dimsum was actually quite decent-- even great. But the service was helllllla irritating.

Like come on, I just want to enjoy my dumpling (which was really tasty) without having to repeatedly tell you that no, I don't want to purchase the $23 seabass-- which I have seen you walking around the restaurant for for at least 1.5 hrs. Seriously, I'm already an anxious person-- pls don't make me more anxious.

Also, it's so expensive. I would say to come here for a business meeting where maybe you don't want to eat a lot-- but even then, the waitress will ask you every 5 minutes if you want a desert, or the $23 seabass, or pork hash, or o ro ro ror or....

Plus the kitchen was almost out of dim sum-- grant it we came at the end, but if you're going to be an expensive dim sum place in the financial district, you should be able to serve your product all the way thru your restaurant's hours.
author: ミカ S.

description:
From the quick service on traditional dim sum carts to tasty food, this restaurant doesn't disappoint.

To start, the steamed options are plentiful.

The baked and fried items quickly follow.

Make reservations early as they open at 11a. By 11:30a, all tables were filled.
author: Brian G.

description:
The Family retreated to Yank Sing at 49 Stevenson Place after the memorial service for our friend.  The Mother asked The Sibling if they had lunch before the memorial, and the answer was no. The Sibling had time to have lunch with us, and suggested we eat dim sum at Yank Sing.  Dim sum seemed to be the perfect to celebrate and remember our dear friend. And to catch up with The Sibling.  It has been awhile since we noshed at this Yank Sing in ages.  We were delighted this Yank Sing was still here and  open.  

We were seated immediately as the peak of the lunchtime crowd was winding down for dim sum. The Mother and The Sibling ordered the Shanghai Dumpling, steamed Kurobuta Pork, ginger, and scallions wrapped and steamed in it's own aromatic broth.  Other dishes we had were the fried pot stickers; shrimp har gow; pork/shrimp siu mai; spring roll; honey walnut prawns; two orders of chicken/shrimp stuffed mushrooms; and Chinese greens. The Mother ordered her favourite sesame seed balls for dessert.

When it was time to pay the check, The Mother and The Sibling were surprised by the price. Fortunately, one of the managers was at the ready to answer questions.  And much to our surprise, there was a menu/price list.  (Seems to me the Yank Sing organization does read the reviews on yelp.)  I was surprised that one has to pay for tea.  Tea used to be a staple in a dim sum/deem sum place.  

The food at Yank Sing was worth the price.  Yank Sing seems to be appropriately a place to come to either celebrate a joyous occasion or to memorialize a dearly departed friend.  Not for everyday or once a week.  Once a month, at least.  Or whenever the occasion warrants for it.
author: Chiara A.

description:
Where do I start??? I go the front to check in for reservation.  I give the lady the name. She types something in then speaks to the other people waiting. Then she seats them. She then comes back and asks me what name again. I tell her again and even spell it for her.   She then asks for my cell number then leaves me without a word.   I stood there again as she seated someone else. I asked her am I just supposed to wait. And she says yes.   I left her not knowing if she really understood what I was saying. This place would do well to have someone who actually speaks and understands English. 

Once we got seated we had typical service. Asked and got our drinks. Food arrived per carts as in any dim sum place.   Our waitress never returned. Never checked on us. I watched her check on everyone else, but us. My sister wanted shumai so I ordered it. Waited 10 mins and ordered it again. Then waited another 10 minutes and ordered it with the our original waitress.  She returned 5 mins later to tell us they were all out. Unreal. 

Food as a whole was pretty good. The service was just stupid bad. I can see why people like the food but I won't be eating here again. The service was just that bad.  And I felt I wasted every dollar spent there.
author: Billy M.

description: Dim sum dishes are pretty good though they are bit too meaty.  They are so hard rolled that the consistency became like hard meat balls.  The most shocking experience is the price.  Pork Siu Mai (4 per dish) is $11.50, same price as Shrimp Ha Gaw.  Spring rolls came in 4 rolls per dish and are also $11.50.  These prices are at least 2 times of top rated dim sum restaurants in the Bay Area.  Service is fair but we felt the servers were trying to rush us out (lunch time).  Dim Sum meals are meant to be a social experience while enjoying good tea.  I was disappointed overall.
author: Albert C.

description: we lucked out and bypassed the waiting line by sitting at the bar. highly recommended for a wide array of dim sum selections - all so tasty! duck bun, shanghai dumplings, cabbage salad w/ yummy walnuts, and those delicious green beans! don't forget to finish w/ pistachio ice cream pie. bartender quite nice and helpful too.
author: Dianne M.

description: If you are looking for high quality dim sum, Yank Sing is the place to find it. It is very pricy but worth it. The Shanghai dumplings are delicious, as well as the Curried Chicken Turnover. For dessert my favorites are the Mango Pudding and Sesame Seed Balls.
author: Marc U.

description: Dim sum is hot and fresh here. But nothing too spectacular nor special since I've lived in Hong Kong and have had plenty of dim sum in LA, NY, and Vegas since I've been in the U.S. The basic har gai and shumai are tasty and pretty large in size. Pot stickers are not too bad and 6 came in the order instead of the normal 3. The soup dumplings is the focus and what this place is allegedly known/famous for so the staff is literally shoving that in your face and make you order it. I asked for steamed custard bao, was told it's a special item and the kitchen will make it now. Two follow ups and 40 minutes later. No baos. We got tired of waiting and pay our bill and left. No apology from anyone or explanation why my order didn't show up. And the bill was $72 for tea and 8 plates of dim sum. Meh. Not impressed and quality and selection do not match the price. It's a Zagat rated place so I guess this place feels it is justified to have high prices for really basic food. And frankly, not traditional dim sum food. If you must have dim sum in SF, this is good if you are also willing to pay the high price for dim sum. Make a reservation. This place is a madhouse after 11 a.m.
author: Tracy H.

description: The food for Americans is just all right. But my friend and I don't like it at all. Besides the price is very expensive. More importantly, the service is very bad. There is no one gives us any drinks(not even asking) I asked them to have some water. They told me later, but there is. We finished the whole meal in 20 mins without any drinks. I will never come back again. And I don't suggest any of you to come here.
author: Tammy L.

description:
I would give Yank Sing 1 star for the super overpricing and 2 for flavor/service. Underwhelming, the most disappointing dim sum experience I've ever had.

Right around the corner is blocks and blocks of more authentic and affordable Chinese food all over Chinatown. Yank Sing is a big tourist/financial district meal trap. Too expensive, and many of the dishes that came around the cart were cold...
Although the Peking duck buns were delicious, we got 7 slices of duck for $6.60 a piece! I could easily get 1/4 pound of duck on rice for $5-8 everywhere else in Chinatown. The Siu long bao (steamed pork dumplings) were tasty, but also overpriced. And 4 dahn tat (egg tarts) for $12? That's just not fair to people visiting SF that want to actually enjoy a Chinese dim sum meal. We bought a dozen egg tarts for $12 right around the corner from there.
And there wasn't any variety of dishes circulating around on the carts, just the same plates of cold chinese broccoli, "potstickers" duck, shu mai, and a few more. The tea was nicely displayed and served.

They didn't even have "ha churng"(wide noodles), "pie kwat"(small square ribs), "gnow chop"(tripe)!!

Really disappointed but at least we gave it a try. Not coming back here again.
author: Jenny A.

description: We had already enjoyed dim sum at Yank Sing last month and decided to share the experience with immediate family. Lucky for us, Ed was our go to person for the entire dining experience. Yes, we came for the food but Ed was so spectacular in his execution of service!!!!! He is meticulous and as I watched his movements on our table, he was motions of smooth magic like glass on a lake. ALL the service staff at Yank Sing was great but Ed was amazing. There were 2 tables he was attending to with VIP set up and as we were leaving, he apologized for being busy, it was kind of him to say but I understand this industry as I have been in hospitality for over 40 years. It is RARE to find the service perfection that Yank Sing offers and we will be back and make sure that ED is our attendee.
author: Veronica L.

description:
Today was my first time eating here.  My brother and I debated which dim sum place to try in the area and somehow we settled on this one--could have been because we were too hungry.  At first glance,  it seemed like a good spot because it was packed and there was a wait.  I did notice that there were very few Asians dining here,  not sure if that meant anything,  but something tells me it did and not just about the prices. The food was mediocre to my well-versed-in-dim-sum palate. I've never had Americanized dim sum,  but I'm pretty sure what I ate was that very thing.  They did have the usual items such as shumai, ha gao, lo mai gai.... But I'll be honest,  the fact that they didn't have ha cheong was beyond baffling. My brother and I got various items from the carts and we both only really liked the siu long bao. Their tea was also enjoyable.  Before the  check came,  my brother and I guessed what the bill would come out to. Our average guess was around $60 however when the check came, it was about $94. We knew that it would be fairly pricey given what we read,  but we gave it the benefit of the doubt.  After all it was dim sum and we were just a party of two people. So price wise and taste wise,  this place did not meet our expectations.  

For what it's worth,  the servers were attentive and kept our table cleared.
author: Linda Z.

description:
I have been coming to Yank sing for well over 20 years!it's my favorite special occasion Dim sum in S.f.!The Food never disappoints me.The Food 8 stars!
expect to pay alot, this is not china, but they master authentic top shelf Asian dishes dim sum and dishes ,still very American I zed in my opinion. I PREFER China town's Service in Oakland any day over Yank Sings.Rude Hostesses, slow as nails when I'm alone and not with my loud Asian friends and Family.  makes it that much more lonely. I may be a white girl but I'm more Asian than most of my Asian friends.I should not have to bust out my bad Mandrin or Cantonese to get more tea,, a yaaa.For the price of the food , the service should be better. 
The Shanghai Dumplings,to die for slurp ING  Dumpling soup, sweet and sour chicken feet, stuffed lotus leaf, har gau Dumplings, Deep fried items are crispy yet not all greasy like traditional Broadway hole in the wall places.These are just a few of my favorites! it's all about the Dumplings, chicken feet and xoxo sauce.Give me the Sauce and no one gets Hurt.
Yank Sing House made Xoxo hot Chili oil sauce is the best on this planet. It's a staple in our household.Completly different from traditional $3.49 Chinese hot chili oil , although I also enjoy Basic, there xoxo is its own unique flavor.
Make reservations, avoid going at lunch if you are in a rush..Always buzy. 
I have ordered to go over phone, food was amazing and I didn't have to wait around.
Go with Patience and hopefully you get better service. I have never had great service here , mediocre at best.
It's the darn xoxo hot sauce and Dumplings that are like Crack to me.They keep me coming back.
Qi Qi to the Chiefs..
author: Connie B.

description:
I've been to dim sum in NYC, LA, and even China. And this place kicks every other places ass. This is the dim sum of all dim sum. Everything is so so tasty, you HAVE to get the white puffy clouds (bao-something?), the soup dumplings, and the peking duck tacos (I know I'm butchering the names of everything) are the stand outs. 

The place gets more than packed with SFs finest around lunch time, and it is pricey compared to all other dim sum places, but it's worth it. Pay $20 for the best dim sum of your life and you won't be sorry.
author: Molly S.

description:
Delicious dim sum but I do think Yank Sing is on the pricier end. Some of the choices are excellent - would highly recommend ordering the xiao long bao (pork dumplings filled with soup). 

Some options like chicken feet, shrimp dumplings, are pretty standard..nothing out of the ordinary.

Still, I would come here. If you want to introduce someone to good dim sum and want to make a great impression, Yank Sing is an excellent choice. Very clean Chinese restaurant and good service/ambiance compared to most dim sum joints.
author: Veronica S.

description: Worst experience ever. I made a 2pm rez and waited - which is fine, to be expected ( we were a 4top: 2 adults /2 kids.) Every time I ordered they forgot, didnt know or told me they ran out of it. We were stuck with shrimp dumplings and pot stickers. They rarely came around and when they did it was the same thing over and over again. When I paid the bill I expressed my disappointment and she said the manager would be right out. Manager never came out. I asked the host to please do something. She kept saying 'Im so sorry.' I said 'if you are so sorry do something!  Take something off my bill!' Never ever ever again. Ill stick to the Sunset dim sum places where there is always an abundance of food and when u make a rez you can be assured that they have not run out of half the menu.
author: rosita t.

description: Absolutely bar none the best dim sum restaurant in the entire northern hemisphere! Every time I'm in San Francisco I love to stop by and take an hour and a half or two my day and just sit down and enjoy the dim sum year. Make sure to make reservations as the restaurant fills up quickly and the wait can be long.
author: John P.

description:
Although Yank Sing does not have the best Chinese dim sum, it is one of the cleanest Chinese restaurant that I have been in the States. Except a mishap in the end of the meal, the staff provides great service. While I may not love Yank Sing to death, I would definitely come back and recommend other Yelpers to visit this Chinese establishment.

What makes Yank Sing awesome? 
1) Yank Sing accepts phone reservations. For me, this is a big plus, since I do not like waiting in line on a Sunday morning. 
2) Most dishes of Yank Sing do not have MSG, which is very rare for Chinese restaurants. I definitely recommend Yank Sing to individuals who are allergic to MSG.
3) Yank Sing provides pleasant service, which justifies its slightly higher prices. When I asked for egg custard buns, the waitress informed me that these buns are made-to-order. After I ordered it, my friends and I got steaming hot buns! I have not had hot buns in dim sum restaurants for ages, and am glad to enjoy them at Yank Sing.

What could Yank Sing do to make it more awesome?
1) Although the dishes are authentic, some of them are lukewarm. Less popular dishes, such as Sichuan green beans, are almost cold. 
2) A server claimed that my friend's credit card did not work, and asked for two other credits. The last card eventually worked. My friend's cards, however, worked in other places we went for the rest of the day. My friend immediately got worried and called the card centers to ensure that he was not charged for the meal three times. Luckily, he was only charged once. Does the card machine at Yank Sing have issues? Or is the staff trying to steal information from his various cards? I would appreciate if the management of Yank Sing can look into this issue.

Overall, my friends and I had a pleasant experience of dining at Yank Sing, other than the episode in the end. If you want to eat non-MSG dim sum at a clean restaurant, Yank Sing is the place for you!
author: May Y.

description: The wait is ridiculous but the food is so worth it. The first time I went here I was blown away with how authentic everything tasted. I travel to Hong Kong so often that I was shocked they were able to get such real flavors in California. I ordered the har Gow and the lotus wrapped glutinous rice. I loved both. My husband who was vegetarian had about 3-4 different veggie options which was so nice they had options for vegetarians.
author: Jasmin W.

description:
What more could I ask for?

I get some dim sum.
A bookmark is finally knocked off.
Wonderful service.
The Giants game was awaiting.

Between my Daughter and I, we ordered: steamed BBQ pork buns, shrimp dumplings, Mandarin dumplings w/ chives, pork and shrimp sui mye (yes, that is how the menu has it), crab claw (holy smokes, a plate of this (2) cost me $11.90), and their famous Shanghai Kurobuta pork dumplings.

Although it may seem like a lot of food, it really wasn't but that is OK since I need to eat enough to not be hungry however, I won't lie; my wallet was raped BUT I did like the food and the service.  The ambiance was intimate even though it was 11AM. 

Note* I was the only Asian in the establishment.  

Their famous dumplings were good but it needs to be served on individual soup spoons because the second you try to grab one, it falls apart.  Their crab claw was good but the sweet and sour sauce had a thin consistency and not very sweet nor sour (at least to me).  

I was amazed by the Dijon-like mustard dip.. 

This is a great and fancy restaurant and I'm not complaining because I had a wonderful dim sum experience but to me, this will be a "hit it and quit it" type of place.  For the same amount I paid, I could have bankrupt a dim sum place in Chinatown.
author: Tram N.

description: By calling the restaurant about 1 week in advance, I was able to reserve to tables together for 17 people. The staff were helpful and attentive and the food, as always, was delicious. A great place to taste some of the best dim sum in the city.
author: Daniel J.

description: I went there for lunch with a few friends around Chinese New Year.  Enjoyed the Shanghai Dumplings. The service was fast as they kept strolling around with food trays and you can pick plates as they pass by, then the waiter stamps on the receipt  at the table to keep track of what you ordered.  The tea was served in a clear glass teapot and were many options available we opted in for Jasmine. Craving to go back since but did not have a chance.
author: Suna L.

description:
Dim sum in a great setting but missing the delicacy of traditional flavor. Not a fan.

Staff is great and speaks English, even the dim sum cart servers

Restaurant is small and clean

It's totally awesome that the line is short even if you forgot to make a reservation
author: B N.

description:
One of the best dim sum restaurants we have been to.
Little carts pushed around between tight tables.....
Don't worry if you don't speak mandarin you can still get what you want!
Shrimp dumplings, crab claw, sea bass, chicken buns, shrimp and scallion dumplings etc!

But you will also see it in the check.
For a party of 4 we paid over $180!!!!
It was good and full of quality seafood.  But definitely looking around only the executives are eating inside.

If you look outside, there appears to be an express dim sum?
author: Jo L.

description:
Yank Sing, a San Francisco institution for all things Dim Sum. Since we were in the City for some shopping early, we decided to swing by for early "Yum Cha" as the Hong Kongers call it - that's just Dim Sum Brunch for everyone else. 

The location, while in the SOMA and close to businesses, is odd since it's kind of in a back alley way. The restaurant is not the largest and doesn't have the usual Chinese restaurant feel since there's plenty of glass windows all round. 

Service was generally quick and professional (i.e. not super friendly) and the carts filled with deliciousness came around soon enough. The usuals, shrimp dumplings, Shu Mai, XLB, steamed pork buns, etc. XLB was the standout dish here with the broth within the dumplings (technique to eat: shovel XLB onto spoon without breaking skin (XLB's that is), bite to break XLB skin, juices pour forth, drink and enjoy, finish by shoveling said XLB into mouth, repeat). Steamed pork bun was a disappointment since it didn't have the usual moist bun texture that I'm used to and prefer. Shape was a bit off too. 

Highlight 2: Peking duck with steamed bun: Sliced Peking duck with crispy skin, topped with slices of scallions and sweet Hoisin sauce wrapped in a steamed bun = heaven.

Lastly, dessert was egg tarts. Flaky crust with just right egg custard in the middle. Very good indeed.
author: Norman S.

description:
Apparently, there are multiple locations of this establishment within the city. This particular one does have great food and a lot of non- typical dim sum dishes like walnut shrimp, Peking duck, etc. I was a bit bummed out that they did not carry "ha churng", the shrimp with semi-translucent noodle that a traditional dim sum restaurant would. Then I realize that this is not your usual dim sum place because every cart-pushing server speaks English and every menu item is fully translated in English.   Also, the prices are ridiculously steep! Yikes! $60 for my girlfriend and I.....and I was barely full. 

Food is very good - I'd give 4 or 5. The lack of traditional dim sum food lowers my rating to a 2.
author: Patrick W.

description: Dim sum was average, but I thought the prices were too high. Easily spent $50 for a few small items. The chicken rolls were way too greasy.
author: Nick G.

description:
Taste is great, and the store is very clean.

A good place if you want to invite someone to try some fine chinese dim sum.

4 star in general, could have done better in taste.
author: Justin Y.

description: I'm not sure I got the full experience here.  I'm reading some of the other reviews about food I didn't see while I was there.  In fact, I was surprised by the small variety, as the same things kept coming around.  But everything we had was good; I don't remember anything being exceptional.  I've had better.  It was very busy and chaotic while we were there, but the hostess was very gracious and made every effort to accommodate us, including my mom, who was in a wheelchair.  The staff were all very pleasant.  They also brought a complimentary plate of the jellied orange slices, which was a nice finish.  Bathrooms are a bit of a slog, though, and there's only one for each gender, which staff also had to use, so there was a line.
author: Paula H.

description:
The dim sum here is much better than the other location I visited a while ago. I truly enjoyed all of it -- while it still doesn't compare to the best in Hong Kong, it is easily one of the best in the bay area.

However, it is mighty expensive. Even more so than Koi Palace. Entertain out of town guests, or do a nice lunch with your business partners, but don't try to feed your hungry teenagers here.
author: Alice C.

description:
There has to be another place to buy xiao long bao that isn't so price inflated. Went with a group of 8 for a celebration and they were quick to serve. The food was delicious  and the staff was nice. 

Its just so expensive for dim sum. Not to mention they limited the dumplings we could order because they didn't want to run out for everyone else. What?!?! How is that acceptable in a restaurant that specialize in xiao long bao?
author: Jay H.

description:
Yank Sing serves some mean dim sum.   I enjoy coming here when I visit the city.  I came here Sunday with a friend who has never been to Yank Sing and has lived in the city for a year ( for shame!!!!)  If you want to eat your fill and not worry about the price, then this is your place as your bill can easily exceed $100.  

The service here is excellent.  They are fast and efficient.  My eyes got crossed as the carts zipped around as the servers asked if we wanted any of the dishes on the carts.  This is one of the many times that I wished I could speak Chinese.  All I could order was the shrimp dumplings.  My Chinese Grandmother must be looking down on me with shame.   Just like the scene from Disney's Mulan.  Lol.

I have not had any dim sum dish that I did not like from Yank Sing.  I even ordered Won Bok and I don't like Won Bok!  Obviously, the point that I am trying to make is that even the dishes that I dislike are exceptionally good here.

I Barted it to come here as parking.........well you know how that goes.
author: Dean N.

description:
The dim sum at Yank Sing is certainly not bad, and there's no MSG or excessive saltiness/flavoring. That having been said, the quality and portions don't really justify the high prices, which are double to triple what you'd expect at a normal dim sum house in Chinatown or suburbia.

What really makes this place is the location right in the heart of the Financial District and Market Street corridor. The clientele is all businesspeople paying for business lunches with corporate cards. Since it's dim sum, where all the plates are shared, it's highly conducive to groups, and indeed, the servers here know this. They're all authentic Cantonese speakers, and they also know enough buttery sweet-talk in English to lure you into buying more and more "special" (read: expensive) dishes. After all, who wants to look like a cheapskate when entertaining clients over business?

Speaks volumes that they're only open for lunch and can afford to leave such prime real estate un-utilized the rest of the day. ;)
author: Vincent L.

description: WAY over priced for sub par food. $14 for Shanghai Dumplings that were not even good. Are you kidding me? Have been here once before years ago. But not coming back. The food is less than average and the prices are double what they should be. No thanks!!!!
author: N. P.

description: Best dim sum in the city if you can afford it. The dim sum is also not laden with msg like the ones made in Chinatown if you are sensitive to that
author: Tony Z.

description:
Very average food.  Service is poor.  

After the meal, our waiter came to us and even apologized for the meal not being so good.  I didn't even tell him it wasn't good.  He figured it out on his own!

Sadly, the waiter didn't offer to correct this situation by reducing our bill.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I love this place - def. the most fresh, hot and tasty high-end dim-sum place in SF. The pork buns, green beans, shanghai dumplings and the mango mousse are the amazing!

The service is a little brash but overall a really nice place for lunch or dinner. Def. make reservations, this place is always packed!
author: Shikha S.

description:
This place is hands down the best and highest quality dim sum I've ever had. It's a small, unassuming restaurant. Unlike a lot of dim sum places, they actually list their selections with prices on a menu. It's a good thing they do this, because for dim sum, it's pricey! 

My favorite items were the pork sticky bun and the Peking duck. The bun wasn't super doughy like I've had other places - it was more of a melt-in-your-mouth experience. The pork was tender and well seasoned. The Peking duck was also tender and delicious. 

I would definitely return
author: Daniel C.

description:
Underwhelmed, overpriced, and way overrated. 2 stars for the food at most considering the price, service was friendly.

We eat a lot of dim sum with family and friends (husband and I are Chinese). New to SF, trying to find a good spot besides koi palace which is yum but has a crazy wait!

The soup dumplings were tasty but not for the price, shrimp dumplings and siu mai were ok. Steamed BBQ buns were as the server described, "smooth," better than the baked BBQ buns, which I didn't like because of the honey on top (not big on sweet food that isn't dessert!)

Ordered chrysanthemum tea, which was a doozy. The glass teapots are pretty but don't do much in terms of steeping tea. 

We didn't care to stick around for dessert, which is especially sad at dim sum!
author: Kim L.

description:
Really good food (I wouldn't say excellent though.... So Cal's Monterey Park's dim sum is WAY BETTER and cheaper)... and I've never paid $70 for only 8 dishes of dim sum. Not sure if the dim sum here is worth that much... but it was very flavorful and freshly made.

Make sure you seat along the end of the rooms... sitting in the center and you'll never get the food that you want since they're the last part of the food cart's tour.

The bathroom is single stall and downstairs (kind of scary). 

I highly suggest you go somewhere else for dim sum as this place is WAY over priced.
author: Sujee K.

description:
Some people go to church on Sundays. I go to dim sum! For someone that isn't made of money, this place is a special treat. The dishes are tasty and the service is good. For the high prices of the bill, I feel that we shouldn't be packed in like sardines. There's no ambiance and feels like any standard Chinese restaurant. On the plus side, you don't have to wait long for a table.

To give you an idea, $80 gets you:

4 siu mai - pork dumpling
4 har gow - shrimp dumplings
6 shanghai dumplings
2 steamed pork buns
4 pan fried chicken buns
2 turnip cakes
4 sesame balls
2 custard buns
2 coconut mochi rolls

Tip: Tea is $4 and not free like most places.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Little bit at the high end but quality meets it's standards. The service is very fast paced and they are great at helping you decide what to order. Great vegan options. The mushroom dumplings were to die for
author: Christine H.

description:
Go ahead and call me broke.. I'm just a college student.
Visitors please be aware of their pricing before you even step in... (If you are familiar of what eating dim sum should cost you)
I was wondering how good they are since they got good feedback from many blogs and rating sites, so decided to try it out this morning.
Place looked clean, but still noisy like other dim sum places, and was slow to give my change back (took 10 mins).
Let's cut to the main point, their pricing is just ridiculous. Very super unreasonable for dim-sum $$$$$$$.
First of all, their "House special" Shanghai Pork Dumpling. Looks delicious and indeed it was, but $14 for 6 pcs. What !? World famous Din Tai Fung only charge $9.5 for 10 pcs, and they are more professional too.
Second, Pork & Shrimp Siu Mye, it's nothing special than other dim-sum places, but you have that $7.15 for 4 pcs.
Next, fried "Sweet rice dumpling"... bro you over-fried it, and it was $10.70 for 4 pcs.
And peking duck rolled through, looks delicious, ordered 2 (funny it was priced by buns), $6.55 each bun. ($13.10 for 2 buns w/ little meats, and it wasn't really crispy). With same price, I could get a half duck with 6+ buns.
Most ridiculous one, Egg custard Tart 4 pcs for $11.70, FXXX these are only 3 for $1.60 at Chinatown.
I stopped ordering after I was aware of their pricing... total came up about $85 before tips for 2 people, and we were not full.
Other things to be mentioned, they have 4 Spring Rolls for $10.70, and Wonton soup for $14, lol.

They have the old fashion style food carts and the dim-sum card stamping, but each food have their individual ridiculous pricing.
COME ON PLEASE, YOU CAN GET ALL THESE FOODS IN MULTIPLE DIM-SUM RESTAURANTS OVER CHINATOWN THAT ARE FEW BLOCKS AWAY THAT ARE WAY CHEAPER WITH EQUAL QUALITY OR EVEN BETTER.

I'm a college student, their price didn't seem right to me. If you are not rich like me, you better avoid this place.
If you are rich, I still suggest you to go over Chinatown's Dim-Sum restaurants for a different experience with wayyyyyyyy reasonable price point.
I'm Chinese, and Dim-sum has never been that expensive before... Chill 

Btw there's no free parking.
author: Nick C.

description:
Came here on a quick trip to San Francisco. Been coming here for years and each time it does not disappoint.

It's a classic dim sum place and you can quickly get overloaded with choices which all look and smell so good.  

The Shanghai dumplings were really a stand out.  Baked BBQ pork buns were also surprisingly good. Very fresh and sweet.

The cost of this place is a bit too high. And you can quickly get up there in a bill by accepting too many dishes and not realizing their cost.  Lettuce wrap? Sure, but like $5 per wrap, you need to be careful.

Other than that, service is VERY efficient and the food is delish.  If you're looking for a dim sum experience, this is certainly a great choice. Just bring your gold card.
author: Dan S.

description: Come to SF many times each year and one of my first stops is Yang Sing! My sister comes down from Seattle to visit me and her first question is "when can we go yo Yang Sing" the best I've ever had from East to West Coast. Yes it is a little pricey but worth every penny.
author: Donna M.

description:
Damn son, that dim sum is something else right there. 

Service: The carts are there so quick, you could be burning your mouth on soup dumplings before you even sit down.The place is run like a battleship, servers are in constant communication from ear pieces, and response time for requests is lightning fast. It's the same grumpy cart ladies like at every dim sum spot, but they keep it pretty much to themselves. 

Food: delicious, amazing, poem inspiring. I'm biased because I love dim sum, but this is still pretty top notch.
