All the textures are on point, nothing too soggy, too oily, etc. Har gow is firm and not overly porky, nice sticky wrapper. Soup dumplings are perfect. Duck buns are perfect (but surprising expensive). I haven't had anything here I didn't like. 


Pro tip: if your company springs for business lunches, sneak this one in the restaurant rotation because it can get pricey. 

Go here. But try to get someone else to pay.
author: Patrick T.

description:
My grandmother was a Catholic schoolteacher in China.  After she retired, she raised my two cousins and me, and boy were we terrified of her.  So terrified that still, to this day, I'm afraid to tell her that I just had dim sum for lunch at Yank Sing, and that it cost my lunch friend Sara P. and me $80.  Yes, you read that right.  $80 for dim sum.  For the two of us.

Not bad food, but it's DEFINITELY not a place you want to go if you desire authentic, hearty dim sum at a fraction of the price.  This is clearly a place geared towards the business crowd who want to impress their fellow suits because the place is clean and service is attentive, which are two things that hole-in-the-wall Chinese places generally lack.  Take the trek to Lai Hong or the Richmond district for amazing dim sum without the frills.

By the way, if you're ordering boxed lunches for your office lunch, don't.  It was so greasy everything was leaking out and everyone felt incredibly sick a few bites in.
author: Tori S.

description:
Before I dive in, a short disclaimer.  I've eaten a lot of dim sum in my life both here in the US and in Hong Kong, so I'm nitpicking here.  The food here is good, and it's a solid restaurant in FiDi if you're not as concerned with value.

Overall, decent dim sum at high prices (you can read about the $$$ hate in all the other reviews).  If I had a bit more time for lunch and wanted dim sum in FiDi, I'd go for City View (used to be Harbor Village) instead.  One of the HK Lounge branches in Richmond if you're not geographically constrained, and Lai Hong in Chinatown if you're looking for great value.
---

Phoenix Tail Prawns were the highlight.  Freshly fried and flavorful without tasting too oily and heavy.  Strangely enough, it didn't come with the tartar type sauce I expected, but a sweet and sour sauce.

Siu Long Bao (soup dumplings) were good, but not the best in the city and most certainly not Din Tai Fung quality good (even their US offshoots) as some other reviewers have said.  The two orders were had both tasted a bit oversteamed, though the skins held up well, though the soup within the dumplings just wasn't very impressive.

Ha Gao (shrimp dumplings) were passable.  The shrimp ball was generous and the shrimp texture suggested it was fresh, but there wasn't much taste to it and the dumpling skin wasn't very well made - a bit heavy handed on the flour.

Siu Mai (pork dumplings) were on the other end of the spectrum.  The four pieces in the steamer were stuck together, there wasn't much taste to it, and it just tasted overcooked.  True, they use a leaner meat than most dim sum restaurants, but there's better quality Siu Mai to be had all along Stockton Street for a fraction of the price.  

Tried the Mango Mousse based on recommendations on here and it was fairly good.  Light, creamy, and not too sweet.  Not sure why it was topped with a strawberry slice though.  The traditional condensed milk sauce would have complimented the mousse more, but this is something you can and should ask for.

Also ordered snap peas and string beans so we could pretend to be healthy, but they were both lukewarm, oily, and flavorless.

Their hot sauce is more of a satay / XO sauce than anything.  While good with dim sum since it's not as jarring as the garlic chili sauce you find elsewhere, you could find something with a bit more bite to it at any Asian convenience store or 99 Ranch.

Weekday lunch crowd was fairly packed even around 1:15, but thankfully we had a reservation.  Service was brisk, but they are really heavy on the oversell.  Definitely a few instances where they started putting the bamboo steamers down before even getting a "yes."   I'm not accustomed to having my dim sum introduced to me in English, though it sounded like the employees spoke Cantonese, so I'm sure you could ask about certain dishes in Canto if you found that preferable.
author: Lincoln L.

description:
Yank Sing is where pay checks go to die. A friend treated me to lunch there recently, and I'm not sure if it was something in the tea (which was very good), but somehow the meal ended up costing $120 for two. 

The menu consists of some of the staples (har gow, siu mai, etc) but definitely lacking in the more exotic fare you can get in Chinatown. My friend ordered a lot of the fried specialty items and most of them were lukewarm, but the portions were large. Taste was mediocre, similar to the food court inside 99 Ranch. There's something about lukewarm dim sum that's just foul. The steamed items were large as well but also underwhelming in terms of freshness and flavor. The prices average out to about $5 per dish, which is about double that of other dim sum restaurants.

This is what I call "Chipotle dim sum" where the experience is sanitized and well executed given what it is, but completely lacks authenticity and character. At this price point, even if the experience is not authentic, I would have expected more decadence, but that doesn't seem to be the model of this place. To me, dim sum should feel like a warm family gathering, but this place feels more like a corporate function. This is the kind of face saving dim sum place for business folks who might have an important client in town and want to take them some place close by. But If you want to share in the camaraderie of the dim sum experience (fighting over dishes with other tables, figuring out who should get the last morsel, flagging down a waiter, piping hot dim sum, talking and laughing loud, etc..), get your butt over to Chinatown.

Food: C.....not great, not terrible
Service: A.....perhaps too attentive, especially when hard selling big ticket dishes
Atmosphere: B......nice and clean place, mostly people talking business
Price: Got an extra kidney to sell?
author: Stevey K.

description: We are in SOMA by the Embarcadero best Chinese in the neighborhood but expensive. Staff is warm and welcoming.
author: Susan S.

description: This place is still very good place to visit for GOOD dim sum.  The Shanghai dumpling is their best to my taste bud.  No import cheep frozen dim sum from Asia!
author: Amanda C.

description: This place is way over-priced for the value.  As a Chinese-American, we have been to multiple dim sum restaurants in multiple cities across the US.  We paid twice the amount we usually pay for just marginally better quality food BUT the same rude service by the host staff.  It took about 5 min for the host staff to acknowledge us, even though my family of 4 was standing right in front of her.  The final bill was what we usually pay for a sushi dinner...only this was for dim sum.  Not worth it!
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Came here a couple of times when I wanted a quick lunch to bring back to the office.

I've eaten inside the restaurant and their food is just ok by my standards. I think it's way overpriced for dim sum but hey theres not a lot of dim sum places in the fidi area so i get it.

So far I've only order the yank sing mini which comes with their chinese chicken salad, 2 potstickers and an eggroll. All for about $6 which is a good lunch deal considering its the fidi/downtown area.

I never have to wait more then 10 min before I get my food. It's a salad and potstickers, it shouldn't take that long right? At first I was scared that the portions would be small considering its only $6 but I was pleasantly surprised that there is a good portion of salad with good flavors. The thinly sliced dark chicken meat with the pieces of fried wonton bits make this salad tasty. They do giving you a mustard dressing which is very light but Im not fond of mustard and I usually eat the salad without any dressing and it still has enough flavors without it.

The potstickers and eggroll are good as well just a little more on the greasy side.

I would come here again just because its a quick and easy to go lunch option. I haven't tried their other lunch combos as I'm scared the dim sum might be too greasy like the potstickers and eggrolls I've had, but definitely can't beat the price!
author: Christine W.

description: This is the most elite dim sum place that I've been, everybody is speaking English, place is clean, elegant, with professional service and neat packaging. The food items that I love; Peking Duck, 100 year old egg pork and porridge, Honey Glazed Walnut Salad, Shrimp Dumpling etc. They have thousands of food variations. Restroom is a plus value too, clean and luxurious. Free parking in Sunday with their validation.
author: Lisa I.

description: Solid dim sum right downtown.  The service was quick, we had food almost within a minute of sitting down. I wasn't a big fan of the size of water of how quickly it was refilled. None of the dishes really stood out. Tasty but I'm guessing there are better hidden gems to visit.
author: Trekforbeer B.

description:
Great, high quality dim sum but fits the adage "you get what you pay for".  Easy to get to $50/ person without anything to drink. 
Definitely worth a visit but Yelp can reveal some alternatives if budget is an issue.
author: Jeff N.

description:
We went for dimsum and it was very good!  Lots of vegetarian options.  We told the  waiter with the first cart that came around that we are vegetarian and they communicated with the other staff immediately so we were only shown food we could eat for the rest of the meal.  That's great service if you ask me.  

It was a bit busy/crowded but that's to be expected.  We had to wait 20-30 min for a table even though we had a reservation though, thus the 4 stars.  

It's easy to order too much so take it slow!  There's a lot of great stuff to try.  All delicious and we will be going again.
author: Christina V.

description: Excellent food and great service.   The Beijing Duck and Pork dumplings are just amazing!
author: Ann B.

description:
I can not tell you how many years we have been going to Yank Sing for dim sum. We decided to try the financial district location on this visit and the food and service was as excellent as the original. We filled our bellies with wonderful treats perfectly prepared.

Look who was waiting to eat at Yank Sing! Guy! The food was amazing--especially liked the way they bring the food out on a cart and you can pick what you want to eat. Beautiful and tasty food. Excellent service.
author: Narayan N.

description:
As soon as we arrived at the restaurant, I remembered why I hadn't been here in so long.  Even though we had a reservation, we still waited nearly twenty minutes.  Since the restaurant really has no lobby or waiting area, we were constantly having to move around the others waiting and the servers - it must be hellish to work there!

Once we were seated things improved quite a bit.  The food is really delicious, and the carts keep coming around every few minutes.  We had crab claws, har gow, lotus leaf wrapped rice, egg rolls and Shanghai dumplings.  With the exception of the dumplings, everything was fantastic and piping hot.  The dumplings were a bit of a disappointment since they were sticking to the steamer, and every single one tore as we gently pulled it off, wasting all of the tasty broth.  Kind of annoying presentation when you're dealing with something so delicate.

All in all, a great lunch but expensive!  $52 for five orders of dim sum?  That's crazy talk.  Much better dim sum - and cheaper - available elsewhere.
author: .Hon H.

description:
Best Dim Sum!!!

Yes it very expensive!! $6 for 1 duck bao!!  But it was the best Bao ever!!  Shanghai dumplings are to die for!!  

It's outside of Chinatown in the financial district so instead of hoards of Asian people it is hoards of business suits!  

A must try!!
author: Steven C.

description: My first time here for dim sum this week. I like the setup with indoor and outdoor seating. The food was average to good depending on the dish. It was expensive though and we ended up with a $80 bill for around 2 and I was still a little hungry.
author: Sunil R.

description: Loved this place! On our honeymoon from Australia and wanted some dumplings for lunch whilst checking out the city. It was lunch hour so the restaurant was filled with business men/women getting their fill also. Could tell it was a favourite! I thought it would be a long wait but waiters had trays of dumplings/soups/pork buns/deserts (you name it) doing the rounds, so we didn't have to wait at all for food. Highly recommended!
author: Burt C.

description: Hung out with a crowd I can describe as a combination of the Big Bang Theory and Modern Family. The company was as fun as a sitcom.  The food, however, was a little less exciting.  The quality was good, especially the Shanghai dumplings and the Peking duck. In the end, it was kind of like going to an amusement park;a bit overrated, a bit overpriced but fun nonetheless.
author: Shawn P.

description:
This is a smaller location than the Yank Sing at the Rincon Center.  However, the fare is just as good and expensive.  It's easy to spend $90 for two people without counting the tea, which comes in a number of varieties.  My favorites include shrimp dumplings, turnip cake, baked BBQ pork bun, steamed pork buns, chive dumplings, shiu mai, shrimp or BBQ pork rice noodles, spare ribs with black bean sauce, and pistachio ice cream pie.  The quality is good and refined without the grease, but perhaps overpriced for comparable quality and larger portions elsewhere.

Service is fast during lunch for dim sum with multiple carts being pushed.  The ambiance and decor is fancier than most Chinese restaurant establishments.  This location has the added benefit of outdoor seating near the heart of downtown.  Parking can be tough, but there are nearby garages.  The other location has validated parking.
author: Jenny L.

description: The soup dumplings were awesome, definitely the highlight of the meal. It is very expensive, almost cost prohibitive had it not been for the fact that I was expensing a business lunch. Be careful, as the prices aren't clearly listed before your order. Before you know it, you'll have a $100 bill on your hands (without any alcohol).
author: Andy A.

description:
This location is not as good as the Spear location. The food choices are not as extensive for dim sum.
They also have weird heating issues - Sunday was a cold day and they had the door open for the patio with heaters and let the people inside freeze.
The excuse the hostess gave was that it was about 'the flow of air and the way the building is heated, sorry'...umm, ok.
I explained to her politely that was the least intelligent excuse I have ever heard.
No apology just an excuse blaming the architect for the problem.
Funny that other restaurants with patios actually take the heating and flow of air in to consideration and apologize for the inconvenience.

I was disappointed and will never go back to this location ever.
The serving staff were very friendly so I feel bad about the food quality and the host response.

A once favorite is going downhill - looks like an opportunity for a better dim sum place to establish itself by raising the bar only a little bit to give this place a run for its money.
author: Faisal M.

description: So, this place was pretty good. My wife and I really wanted a dim sum lunch and we had decided to try them out based on their reviews. We arrived for lunch and were promptly seated, before we could even look at the menu, we had two carts right in front of us and food on the table. Buyer beware, the servers will pick up and offer the most expensive plates first. If I had a do-over I would look through the menu and order the specific dishes I was interested in, rather than just saying 'yes' to a $13 plate of potstickers... All in all, it was a great lunch, all be it, I little pricier than expected.
author: Scott B.

description: Delicious dim sum lunch, but at a price. Our bill for 2 was close to $100, although admittedly we  had a lot of different dishes. The star standout was a soup dumpling that burst with flavor and broth when you bit into it. Chicken stuffed mushroom caps were also good, but a little awkward to eat with chopsticks. The pot stickers were adequate, but not as wow as the dumplings. We passed on the sea bass (but it looked incredible) and pork buns (regret missing out on those). I was grateful that the dessert cart offered simple melon balls - a nice treat after all the dumplings. Please do not miss out on the mango pudding at the end. Full of bright mango flavors, it is creamy smooth, light, with a nice tart sweet finish. Highly recommend Yank Sing if you love dim sum.
author: msue A.

description:
No dim sum should be THIS expensive.. One of my first dim sum experiences in SF was at a restaurant in the heart of Chinatown.. $140 total for the bill fed 7 hungry girls and 3 guys - and we were full beyond belief. Here, our bill was $150 for 5 and I still had room in my tummy. 

That said, their siu mai is really good but beyond that, everything else was just ok. I wasn't even that impressed with the xiao long bao . For the price alone, I won't be back.
author: Jamie M.

description:
This restaurant has gotten ridiculously expensive.  It seems their prices have doubled in the past few years.  Food is still good but not worth it. After splitting the bill, it was $40 a person.  For dimsum, that is crazy.  I won't be back. 

Won't see ya there.
author: Susan D.

description: I came to try this place because I read somewhere that's it's one of the top 10 places to eat in SF, and they're known for their Shanghai pork dumplings. With tax, it's about $15 for 6 little pieces of Shanghai pork dumplings, that's $2.50 each. It's yummy, but I truly don't think it tasted like it's worth $2.50 each. Tried my friend's Singaporean noodles, that was pretty good and reasonably priced, but a little bit salty. I'd come here again to try their other noodle dishes, but def won't get the overpriced dumplings again.
author: Judy T.

description: I've been wanting to go Yank Sing so since I was in the area, I decided to stop by to grab some dim sum for lunch.  There was a line of about 8 people but it went pretty quickly and they give you your food quickly so you can grab it and go.  As this was my first time here, I didn't know what to order so I asked some questions - the girl wasn't that helpful and was muttering something to her co-worker after each question/answer (I would've given her a tip but I didn't like that she seemed to be talking about me to her co-worker, whatever).  I ended up getting two dim sum platters [an assortment of shui mai (2), dumplings (2), egg roll (1), pork bun (1) and egg custard cup (1)].  They put it in a eco-friendly to go container and it was still warm when I brought it home.  We really enjoyed our tasty dim sum (I really liked the egg roll, pork bun and egg custard cup) and will be back for sure (hopefully the service will be better).  Yay for dim sum!
author: Maile N.

description:
The good / decent: the steamed dumpling cart. Good xiao long bao, sticky rice, and other dumplings. Decent har gow.

The missing in action: Where the heck were the standard dim sum dishes like fried turnip cake, shrimp / beef rice noodle rolls, steamed or baked BBQ pork buns and taro dumplings? And where was the chicken feet, with which no dim sum would be complete?

The puzzling: Servers walking around schlepping honey walnut shrimp (an abomination of Chinese cuisine) and sea bass that nobody wants.

The not-so-good: Cold gai lan. Overcooked and un-tasty pork sui mai. Dan tat (not warm... why not bring them out warm and delicious?).

The terrible: The final bill. Lucky for me, this was a work lunch. I would have been annoyed if I had to pay that much for a meh dim sum experience...
author: Marcus W.

description: Best dim sum ever. If you don't have a Sunday morning reservation then arrive at 10 a.m. when they open. The selection is not the largest I've ever had, but every bite is a gem.
author: Spin G.

description: Very good dim sum, but the prices are a bit ridiculous considering Chinatown is just a few blocks away and with similar menu items. For example, you can get 6 XLB for $15 here but if you went to another dims restaurant, the XLB would cost probably half as much or even less. However, the presentation of the food was great and everything was very clean. So if you're trying to go for an upscale type of dimsum, this is your place. Otherwise, I would recommend going somewhere more "typically chinese" that isn't as highly priced.
author: Jessica X.

description: People were not kidding when they said this place was pricey.  $12.50 for 6 Shang-hai dumplings!   Having never been to San Francisco before, I was anything Asian on a mission to have dim sum here.  The dim sum was good but no thanks to $8 tea.  Got some $6 pork buns.  If you are looking for decent dim sum food but can overlook the price tag, this is your spot.
author: Elizabeth W.

description: This was one of my favorite dim sum restaurants when I was living in the Bay Area.  Came here for a quick lunch and it was still superb.   The braised sea bass was amazing and their Shanghai soup dumplings were awesome.   They even had Peking duck by the slice!
author: Jung C.

description:
For a town with one of the highest Chinese people ratios, it's shocking how underdeveloped decent dim sum is in this town.  Yank Sing is probably the only place in downtown SF to go to to get good quality dim sum in a reasonable restaurant quality environment.  

I might have rated Yank Sing higher, but the prices were actually quite shocking.  You cannot get out of here for less than $30/ person which seems pretty steep.  I'm used to New York, where there are a million dim sum restaurants with decent prices in the $10-20/ person range.  In SF, there are places in China town, where walk up counter service is the only type dim sum  you are going to find but that's probably more like $5-7 for a meal.   The latter makes McD's looking like gourmet dining. 

Now the food... It's pretty good.  Stevenson was definitely more limited in its choices, and I've been told that Rincon center is the better of the Yank Sing's to frequent.
author: Gloria F.

description: Four of us ate 155 dollar worth of food, while it is a lot more than other Chinatown joints, this place is worth the money. The xiao long bao, 小笼包，shanghai soup dumpling was how we started our brunch, and it is the way to go. Everyone in my family agreeed that this was the best meal we have had on our 3 week long winter road trip. The chicken feet, and tofu rolls were two of my favorite items. All the yellow cream items were delicous, the food is neither too salty nor too sweet. The mango pudding and egg custard is the way to go out, and of course we packed some for thd road. Service was great at first, but as the restaurante got busy, the cart pushers got more and more impatient. So be warned, but the busyness just shows you their popularity.
author: Jo L.

description: Excellent dim sum, although overpriced...  If you're watching the bill, be wary of some of the dishes that come around, like the sea bass, which is much more expensive than other dishes.  Recommend asking the waiter the cost of each dish.
author: David B.

description: Food was delicious! They even had vegan options for a friend I went with. I love the fact how your table will never be empty as they keep coming around with their food carts. Careful on how much you get because without seeing prices and them just marking a card with a stamp, you can easily rack up a bill!
author: Robbie P.

description:
Ordered 4 items + tea = $50 including tip

The items were good but nothing spectacular. 4x what dimsum should cost. Decent place to go if you have cash to burn.
author: CL S.

description: Mediocre dim sum. The dishes tasted quite poor especially for a busy Sunday. The best things were the aromatic jasmine tea and the half decent xiao long bao. Very expensive. $88 for two.
author: William L.

description: As a 2nd generation cantonese american, I find the dim sum here merely passable.   Very average, mixes in other region foods (xiao long bao, peking duck) and is pretty pushy.   Doesn't matter, it's in the heart of SF and we're willing to pay premium.
author: Albert W.

description:
Good dim sum. The ingredients are fresh and the dumplings well made. Great service too - if you're impatient, ask any server with the plastic mike & they will radio stat for whatever you desire. But be warned - this is not Chinatown hole in the wall prices. If you're starving this place adds up quick. 

I like both locations, but spear st is bigger and has more variety. Go early and avoid the rush.
author: Kathy W.

description:
Good food.. innovative takes on classic dishes.. a little pricey though as we paid $60 for two for dim sum.

If you're of the quality and taste outweigh price then you'll like this place.

The tea is amazing too.  This is my goto place when I want to impress friends from out of town.
author: Kenyon S.

description:
The food is ok but The price here is out of control. We went there for a lunch for two, it costed over 100$!

I saw one item charge was as high as 42$, but just did not know what it it was. I asked the waiter, did not really understand him clearly. But sounded like he was saying it was for pork dumpling. I knew we ordered two.  So 42$ for two, still did not sound right. The invoice did not come with item description. It only said 3x#6 42$ in my example.  Found  a few other similar item charges written that way,  it made me wonder maybe they charged twice or three times of the unit price... Without a clear price list, and without a clear item description on the invoice...it is just very confusing.... It was vacationing time and did not want to spend time finding out details and get into unpleasant arguments....
author: Julia C.

description: I don't know why this michelin 3 star restaurant has such a low rating for it. This place have amazing series of menu. Every single one of them are delicious. only down side is all the Chinese waitress are not properly educated about restaurant and some of them are bit dirty. I saw this waitress picking some food out of her mouth while there are customers. Also this dishwashing boy throwing rug over the dessert cart. Food is good but 3 star michelin restaurant should be more proper and clean.
author: Jake B.

description:
I tend to frequent Yank Sing 2 Go more often because it's quick and right next to my office. I have to agree with other reviewers that it is crazy expensive especially for dim sum. I just paid $14 for their Shangai Dumplings, but in my opinion well worth it. My co-workers have been talking about those for quite some time. Not filling on it's own but so delicious.

Their Wonton Soup is also very good - the Stevenson location only has this Monday, Tuesday and Thursday. I can usually fill up on a large portion of that with a Steamed Pork Bun on the side.

I've only eaten in the restaurant one time, but the to go line goes quickly and they all seem to be very efficient with serving.
author: Milli A.

description:
Yank Sing is over hyped.

Food wise, it deserves three stars. However, the price with its portions and sizes are unjustified for its quality.

XLB's - now that Crystal Jade is open in SF, go there. the pork inside broke apart too easily.

Their redeeming points : Har Gow was very delicious, possibly one of the best i've ever had.
author: Vi T.

description:
I came here drawn by the B patisserie CNY special pastries. I don't usually love dim sum because it tends to be very lard heavy and greasy, but it tastes much lighter here.  Coming here, I knew to expect more expensive prices but wasn't sure what to expect for the authenticity of it.  To start, the front of the house was very friendly and polite.

First off, there's no choice of tea, which was a little surprising for a dim sum place, especially as everyone who worked there was clearly Chinese.

Dishes:
- Xiao jiao (har gow): shrimp dumpling - this was undoubtedly the best thing we had, and it's much better than most that I've had anywhere else. The outer skin was a good texture without being too thick, and it was generous on the shrimp inside and well seasoned
- Shao mai: the pork and shrimp one had a lot of shrimp, and it was less greasy than usual, but it didn't have the usual fatty pork flavor that you go for; also, it had been sitting in the steam cart for too long and was dry
- Scallop shao mai: non-traditional, but I actually really liked this one
- Xiao long bao: with Kurobuta pork. It's quite fatty and has the soup inside but also doesn't have the usual pork flavor from XLB elsewhere
- Mongolian lamb special: for new years; pricy at $12.88 for a small plate, but the flavor was really good without any gaminess, and the lamb strips were served with soft steamed buns
- Lotus leaf rice: the filling was not what I expected - it was more dark and soy saucey than the usual version, but it wasn't bad.
- Black sesame kouign amann: this was the reason we came. The inside was like a tang yuan with black sesame paste, but it was quite sweet.  The outer crisp layers were really good, and at $3.88, it's pretty reasonable. It's a bit much for one person, but it's good for sharing and with the tea, which got pretty bitter by the end of our meal.

I'm not sure I would come here again for dim sum (except maybe for the har gow), but if you want a nicer, less loud/hectic, MSG free dim sum experience, it's a good place to go.  Plus, having the option of reservations is appealing, since the wait for dim sum is usually long.

Definitely make a reservation on Open Table, especially on the weekends.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
This was my first experience with Dim Sum and I am so grateful. How much fun and how delicious. All of the dumplings were great, espeically the pork soup dumplings. My two favorite dishes were probably the curry chicken pastry and the garlic green beans. It does get busy so I recommend making a reservation. We had 11:30 reservations and were seated right away. Don't get the chicken satay. I was not a fan of the meat. Do get the pork bun. 
The service is great, but almost too efficient. We hadn't been in our seta for more than a minute before a cart got there. This was nice except that we had so much food in front of us within 10 minutes there was no way to not feel rushed. I suggest making a concerted effort to take your time. You may feel rushed, but order slowly and eat slowly. I was way too full afterwards! Not that too much food is a bad thing. 
Oh and I also loved the cutard dessert pastry and the sesame mochi balls. So healthy ;).
Will definitely be going back!
author: Kelsey J.

description: Several visits to Yank Sing and they continually deliver top notch Dim Sum. First visit to the Spear St location this week. Set in Rincon center, they have 50+ tables that flow out of the restaurant into the atrium of the center when they are busy. What is surprising is that the attentive service, and excellent, hot and fresh dishes do not waver in this challenging setting.7 dishes this day including their signature dish, Shanghai dumpling and all save the chicken feet were excellent.Yank Sing is a gem, as good as Dim Sum gets. It's not cheap, the orders add up quickly, but the setting is modern, the food excellent and the service smooth. Enjoy.
author: Bonnie W.

description:
Perfectly passable. Not worth going out of your way for but not worth turning down. It was fine. I ate it. I moved on.

Recommended? = Sure, if it's being paid for and you have no other options.
author: Chris R.

description:
This is the second location of Yang Sink we tried.

The dim sum was good, but variety was not as extensive as the the other one.

The wait was quite long especially during lunch hour.

The tables inside are out next to one another quite closely that it might be a bit uncomfortable.

We did enjoy the food, but it was not an ideal way to relax and enjoy. On top of it, the wait is too long...
author: Kai Y.

description: So good. I loved the sautéed string beans. Steamed pork buns and chicken stuffed mushrooms were great. We also enjoyed the shrimp dumplings. We will return.
author: Francene F.

description:
Everything here is top notch. But beware! It's very expensive for Chinese!
The stringbeans are an often missed treat.
Hot sauce rocks!
Crab claw, har gao, shrimp toast, quail with lettuce cups... all awesome!
The xiu long bao is the best I've found in the Bay... but still not as good as what you get in Asia (Taiwan: Din Tai Fung, HK: Crystal Jade or Spring Deer, Tokyo: Jin Din Rou... all better)
author: Josh K.

description:
I guess there's really nothing too wrong with Yank Sing - it's the safe kind of place to introduce folks to dim sum. It's clean and comfortable... but perhaps that's just it. It's almost too sanitized here. 

The food is decent though. All your usual staples like siu mai and har gow are here. Ingredients are fresh and most items are well prepared. It's "clean-tasting" dim sum where all the flavors are there but nothing really surprises you. 

The thing that's missing the most though is character. There's none of the busy hustle and hearty chatter that you would expect. Here, folks push their carts very gently through a fairly quiet dining room, smiling, and explaining their various offerings. Give me the impatient server with dagger stares anytime. It's just more fun that way. 

I don't really like dining here, but will do if I have first-timers with dim sum. It's pricier, overly-sanitized, and lacks character but that might be what some are looking for. All up, Yank Sing is a safe bet. Not the most interesting one. But safe.
author: Jon L.

description: Solid dim sum spot in the city. On demand dim sum, instant service. Highly recommend it
author: Dennis D.

description: The best dim sum in San Francisco, if not the west coast.  Only open for breakfast/lunch (until mid afternoon).  You will need to take a major nap after.
author: Jefery L.

description:
This is really a 3.5 review.  

I had the Har gow(shrimp dumpling), shu mai(made of pork), honey walnut shrimp, xiao long bao(soup dumpling), sichuan chicken, pan fried bun, and pork bun.

Har gow: These were delicious and plump.  The shrimp were bouncy and the skins pleasantly chewy.

Shu mai: They were hot but was not very meaty tasting.  The shrimp in here are also pleasingly snappy.

Honey Walnut Shrimp: It was decent but a very small portion.  Since the dim sum are taken out to circulate the room, food can get cool quickly.

Xiao long bao: These are on 7x7, top 100 things to eat in SF.  The skins are thin, the soup is hot and the meat is tender.  These were the best thing ordered.

Sichuan Chicken: It is a small portion of spicy chicken.  I would definitely skip this in the future.

Pan fried bun: Think a steamed chicken (minced) that is then pan fried.  It has a good crunchy crust but the meat to dough ratio is highly skewed to the dough.

Pork buns: Very forgettable.  I would definitely not order these again.  

TLDR: This is an expensive but clean tasting place.  If you are new to dim sum and/or taking clients out for lunch, I would suggest this place.

Cost: You should expect to spend around $20+/person here.
author: Jessica P.

description: The quality of the dim sum here is average to above average, but the prices are probably anywhere from 50-100% higher than other dim sum restaurants. I have no idea how they justify the prices considering there's nothing in the food that set the place apart. We ordered a good variety of dishes (shrimp dumplings, string beans, xiao long bao, a few other types of dumplings whose name nor taste I didn't remember). All in all, if you're in the financial district and work is paying the bill, then go there, if not, I would skip it.
author: Alice W.

description:
This was one place that has been on my bucket list for the past 3 years and I miss the mark every time I'm in San Francisco.  However, I was warned by many viable sources that it's not worth the hype.  I still wanted to try for myself but keeping in mind some reservations.  So, what's the verdict?  Yep, as expected....Good dim sum at best does not equal exorbitant prices.  

Most memorable was the Chilean Sea bass, soup dumplings, and egg custard tarts.  I actually missed out on the Peking Duck Baos and glazed roast pork buns as they 86 certain items to control quality so nothing goes to waste.  

Least memorable were all the dumplings.  It was all the same shrimp stuffing either mixed w. basil, scallop, crab, chives and etc.  Mediocre at best.  Oh, and their green onion cake which we thought was a scallion pancake but no, it was more of a puff pastry.  It was def my least favorite.  

FYI, 3 of us had about 12-15 items of so and the bill was around $150 so be prepared to pay if you really want to try this place.  How does this place compare to other dim sum places?  Somewhat the same type of over aggressive dim sum ladies but servers were much more attentive and professional.  Oh, and they serve tea in a clear pot which was the fanciest aspect of this "michelin star" rated establishment.
author: Ricky C.

description: VERY GOOD FOOD.. especially the sesame balls.. I believe it was sweet potato.. it's delicious along with their little dumplings (Sui Lung Bao)?
author: Cindy C.

description:
While everything we tried tasted great (the Peking duck, pork soup dumplings and steamed dumplings were my favorites with the fried spring roll being the weakest) I had sticker shock when the bill arrived: $55 for six items shared between the two of us before tip (we did not order any drinks). I would say the quality was a small step up from other dim sum venues I have frequented, but we paid approximately double what we normally pay for less food - the increased quality was not nearly substantial enough to warrant such a massive price differential. 

There is a vast array of options and the food is more tame than other dim sum venues I have been (i.e. few items I did not recognize or that contained odd body parts). Good if you are not into challenging foods or are not familiar with this style of cuisine and want to ease into it but if you are seeking authentic dim sum you would be best advised to look elsewhere.

The food comes at a fast and furious pace; the first cart rolled to our table before I even made it back from a quick restroom pit stop. Each cart typically contained a few different items and a new cart approached every minute or two. Most items run $5 to $13 and have various quantities (i.e. the Peking duck was just one steamed bun's worth per order whereas the soup dumplings came with six). It would be nice if they toned back the pace some; within ten minutes we had all the food we would consume on the table and within fifteen minutes were done. 

Service we also just a tad aggressive in that at times they started to put items on our table that we had not requested and had to stop them. If you are not assertive you may end up quickly having far more than you can eat sitting in front of you and wind up with a Great Wall of China sized bill. Tip: If you see something on the menu you want that is not brought by, ask any of the servers and they will notify the person with that cart to come to your table. 

If you want a quick, casual meal and do not mind overpaying then Yank Sing is certainly a viable option for good tasting, approachable dim sum.
author: Erick N.

description:
Ok.  Dim Sum on Saturday is usually unusual for me given the fact that I am not up or at work.  Given that I am away from home and out of all places in downtown SF, we decided to go to Yank Sing.

I cannot remember when was the last time I was here but know it was all good.  We came on a very busy Saturday afternoon when of course, everyone else is going to lunch as well.  We waited maybe for a good 30min before seated.  It was very cramped but nonetheless, we were seated.

We ordered the specialty that everybody on my table rave which is the shrimp dumplings which they are known for.  They did not disappoint even though I am not a huge fan of dumplings.  I must admit they were very good and juicy.  I love their spicy string beans.  They were cooked to al dente with the right amount of spices.  Then there were  the chicken feets which are my favorite and it was so so good.  Their peking duck were good but small in portion which I was terribly disappointed and lastly which was amazing is the spicy chicken.

Services I admit as much as they were busy, they were very attentive and polite.  I would think due to the location, it might of been a pricey dim sum but well worth it.
author: Angela L.

description:
Definitely a great place to go enjoy some dim sum. Don't let the fast pace full you, take your time and drink some tea in between each selection. carts are flowing all over the place.

Go with a huge appetite and get ready for some tasty treats.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Damn! The dim sum are so good, too bad Yank Sing is kinda pricey. 
I had the string beans, chicken buns, mushroom/chicken dumplings, shanghai dumplings, bacon wrapped shrimps, and of course, the sesame buns. Everything was oh so delish. I couldn't eat the whole day because all the dishes were so good from Yank Sing. 
However, I do warn people after receiving the check, it literally was like reading hieroglyphics. That's where they get you because you can't decipher what you ordered or didn't order. But worth returning, nonetheless!
author: C M.

description: Drop everything and go here! The dim sum, potstickers, and fried shrimp are worth every penny. Sweet and sour sauce is made in house and is perfection. Make sure to have jasmine tea with your meal - it enhances the flavors and leaves your stomach feeling full and happy. Been in San Fran for 2 days and have stopped here each day! Thank you for such a wonderful meal Yank Sing!
author: Katherine M.

description:
all of the food was deeeeLICIOUS but the BEST thing I ate here were the short ribs.  The glaze was glossy, sweet, and the tender JUICY meet fell off the bone.

So yummy.

I've definitely had my share of dim sum... and probably many other peoples' too... and what I really appreciate about the food here is that it's not as greasy.

CAREFUL: the waitress came around with sea bass and it looked sooooo good so we grabbed the plate immediately!!  Little did we realize that a single serving was $20.... the fish was delicious but surprisingly pricey.

We also realized halfway through lunch that the dim sum/food menu is on the back of the drink menu.  And they have serving sizes and pries included on the menu.

They have outdoor seating with HEAT LAMPS!!  for those chilly SF days...
author: Kelsey H.

description:
Intersting. A very interesting place. Pretty good for a lunch - not sure for the dinner.

As everybody says - it's a must to try their duck - fresh and delicious. I wouldn't go there very often, but once in a couple of months would do for me.

Other dishes are OK - nothing special, really.
author: Jenna F.

description: The food is good, but the price too expensive compare to other dim sum places. It is my second time here, but I don't think I will come here again. I could eat the same taste dim sum at other place with lower prices.
author: Shuang F.

description: Being from Singapore, we know our dim sum.  Food was very tasty especially the soup dumplings.  Tried both locations and liked the variety of the other outlet better.   Even had chicken feet :-).
author: Julia S.

description:
Great dim sum but yes it is a little expensive. 4 of us was $130 including tips. The shanghai dumplings remind me of authentic ones in Shanghai. Paper thin wrapping and the soup was yummy. Everything else was average for a higher end dim sum establishment. Delicious as i expected at these prices. 

We got there just before the lunch crowd so no waiting and before we even sat down 3 carts descended on us and 15 seconds later (no joke) our table up was full of plates. 

Sat at the patio, which is another unique dim sum experience.
author: Anne L.

description: Solid dim sum. Overpriced for what it is though. Service is rushed and sporadic. I only come here because there are limited options for dim sum in fidi area.
author: Yasi N.

description: Unbelievably mediocre. Unacceptably expensive. Seriously: avoid this place. Every single one of the dishes we tried for dim sum was a C, most were C-. We had Shanghai dumplings, chicken buns, fried prawns, Peking duck, crab claws and Szechuan chicken. The bill for four was $170 and the servers were super nice so I tipped appropriately. $50pp is a monstrous rip off for dim sum, let alone uninspired unremarkable dim sum.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Yank sing is not my fave Dimsum restaurant- not by a long shot.
But the food here didnt make me break out in hives (the other location did) and it's near my office. 
Will only venture here for a biz lunch. 
Otherwise it's completely overpriced, wayyyy too Americanized (read: caucasianized) and there're wayyyy better options in Chinatown or Richmond. 

Oh- ultimate westernized Dimsum restaurant move: they don't even have the most Basic Dimsum dish: Cheongfun ( noodles in light soy sauce with shrimp or charsiu or scallops etc). 
That's as staple as hargow or siumai. So lame. 
Makes me think they don't make their own Dimsum in their kitchen. It's easy to bring in hargow etc frozen. Hard to fake/ bring in  cheongfun
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Had lunch here today on a random occasion and was pleasantly surprised.  I had always heard about Yank Sing but had never visited until now.  Most of my dim sum experiences have been limited to the express style ones in the Richmond district but it was nice to go to a sit down restaurant.

Immediately after our party of three was seated, were were bombarded with many different carts- it was difficult to not get everything that was being brought to us!  (both positive and negative points)

Highlights: pot stickers, sticky rice, green beans w/ shrimp, won ton soup dumplings
author: Natan O.

description:
My friend bluntly told me that we were going to a dim sum place that was COMPLETELY white-washed. And boy, he was right.

Walking in, I was greeted in English, and said in Canton, "table for two". However, the servers answered me in English, and I think they purposely placed my friend and me near the entrance, and me sitting behind the pillar, because they wanted to hide the only Canton speaking customer.

Sad to say, I'm so used to the cheap dim sum places where dishes cost less than $2 a plate, and if I didn't look at the menu... Once I looked at the menu after ordering a plate of the egg tarts, I basically flipped a lid, had dinner plate eyes and my jaw dropped SO far on the ground that I probably broke a few floor tiles along the way. (If you want to experience the same thing I did, $9.50 for a plate of four egg tarts.)

The reason why I gave it three stars is that I was slightly mad at the fact that EVERY single time I talked in Canton, I get a reply back in English. Really? I think only one person, who was one of the front servers, spoke to me in Cantonese when I asked where the washroom was. She said downstairs, and I was slightly confused as to why a restaurant would have a separate floor for their restrooms.

I originally gave this place two stars and bumped it back up one because the decor was pretty nice, something you don't see too often in dim sum places. Then again, like my friend said, "you're paying a high price on food for atmosphere." I rather just go to a take-out dim sum place, buy a few dishes, take it home and enjoy my atmosphere. However, the place was pretty small, so small that the carts had a racetrack down, to avoid bumping into each other.

And I do give them points for having such a cool teapot.

I was confused about a few of the dishes:

- Soup Dumpling: I have never had them outside of Ding Tai Fung, and was confused as to why the soup was lukewarm, instead of piping hot and why the sauce we were given was a red one, instead of black. (I'm assuming it's the red vinegar, but I kind of wanted a more salty sauce).
- Schetwan Chicken: This plate, we had to order it from a walking server without a car, and the dish was cold by the time we got it. I thought it was going to be a little bit warm, but I guess the plate was out on the floor for a while.

I would probably not come back here because of the prices. But can anyone recommend a dim sum place that's a bit cheaper in Chinatown? Maybe I might hit up one of those spots the next time I'm in the area.
author: Tom T.

description:
Want delicious dim sum in SF? You have 2 options:

1- Have your head spin with all the options and places in China town. I get scurred if my Chinese bff's aren't with me when I eat dim sum.

2- Go to Yank Sing and sit back, relax, put your pinky in the air and enjoy this FANCY dim sum. (we did not wait for a table when we arrived)

Shanghai dumplings (aka nut sax) are delicious. MUST have.
Si Mai plump and full of shrimp/pork yummies
Green beans black bean style - BOMB
DIY Pecking duck dumpling

I can go on and on about the dim sum. You just have to come see to believe! They have a BUNCH of other menu items passed around as dim sum. I LOVED that about this restaurant. 

They had these amazing looking pieces of broiled halibut going around and I was soooo tempted to try. I will next time. The portion was just too much for one person.

3 people filled up on 6-7 trays of dumplings and other dim sum items and the bill came out to $150. Pricey, yes. Worth every penny, absolutely!
author: Lily M.

description: My favorite place for dim sum! Is it pricey? Yes, but it's well worth it. Everything is amazing. There a couple a month and always end up ordering at least the xiaolongbao - Shanghai dumplings, honey baked seabass, spinach dumplings, turnip cake, coconut cream roll. Have tried about 80% of the items on the menu and have not been disappointed yet.
author: Brian J.

description:
Definitely the worst service I've received at a restaurant.

After being seated in the outdoor area, we were served tea (never received menus) and waited about 15 minutes. A large group of 10+ sat next to us and the first dim sum cart rolled out and went straight to the large group. This happened about three times over the course of our time at Yank Sing. We never saw our waiter after the first interaction. I asked the person next to us to borrow their menu. When I eventually tried to order items off the menu, I was told they would "check on it". I became so frustrated, I started asking any employee that walked by. I was told repeatedly that they were "sold out". I understand if they're busy and run out of food, but please let people know or close the restaurant early. We paid $80 (party of 2) for a bunch of appetizers (spring rolls, potstickers, shrimp tempura). The only significant dishes we were able to get our hands on were Szechuan Chicken and the Sea Bass. We kept seeing menu items being delivered to tables of Asian families and couldn't help but think preferential treatment was being extended to them. There were a few tables near us that were appalled with the service as well. For the kind of money they charge, they need to improve service drastically. This also isn't their first Christmas, they should have known it would be a very busy day and prepared for it accordingly. I felt embarrassed for taking my Mom here and paying good money for such lousy service. Never again Yank Sing!
author: Jay F.

description:
Great, great place for dimsum. I especially enjoyed the dumplings. Make sure to bite the top off and suck the juice out, without burning your tongue!

The waitresses are so nice, I really have nothing bad to say about this place!
author: Cara K.

description: Pretty Amazing Dim Sum!  EVERYTHING, I mean everything was absolutely delicious!!!!  For sure we will be back again!
author: Ken T.

description:
I was in San Francisco doing ethnographic research for a client and was very excited when I saw that we were close to Yank Sing so we could swing by for lunch in between interviews.  I told my colleagues they would not be disappointed.  

Fortunately, even though I had not been there in a few years, the dim sum was as good as I remembered and my colleagues agreed that it was good.  

Being dim sum the service is fast, but many of the servers have heavy accents so it it difficult to know what you are being presented with.  Its at that point, you just say yes you want to try something and see what happens.  All of it is very good and fresh tasting - which is not always the case with dumplings and buns.

I do know we ate pork bun, shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, hot pepper chicken, shrimp dragon tails (ordered off the menu), and a few other dishes that I'm not sure what they were, but everything was delicious and devoured.

I'm looking forward to my next trip out to San Fran so I can swing by there again.
author: Andrew A.

description:
Let me start off by saying you get a huge amount of food here. Seriously, it's a big plate of food. Service was quick. I had the Yang Sing Express and it wasn't bad. I like the fact that you get a really diverse plate of food that goes well together.

It's a solid option for lunch.
author: Yoni D.

description:
Solid, but overpriced.
I likened it to PF Changs actually.

Yeah, I'd try somewhere else for Dim Sum before returning here, just because I thought it was that overpriced.
author: Sarah H.

description: pricey dim sum, but friendly staff and one of the few dim sum restaurants i know of that let you reserve a table in advance - and they also have the food carts even during the week. if my group hadn't made a reservation, i expect there would have been a sizeable wait since it was lunchtime in downtown sf. the food was good, but near the end of the meal, i almost felt like we were being rushed to leave. convenient location though.
author: Bianca C.

description: Great dim sum, and no, its not all pork!  Dumplings are soft and tender, not too oily like some dim sum places.  The food is clean and fresh.  The servers seem to remember what you like, and make an effort to get you what you want.  Delicious.
author: Neil G.

description:
The hostess smiled and greeted at us promptly when we walked in. SMILED! Right then I know I'm not in Chinatown, or Cupertino, or Milpitas anymore. 

Dim sum was good, but not at all authentic though. Food was very pricy, but service was nothing short of amazing for a dim sum place, I mean hence the upscale price.. you get what you pay for. 

Bottom line? Fancy place to take your non Asian dim sum novice friends.
author: Angie H.

description: I can't give this place anything lower than 4 stars because their dim sum is really good. But you must know that they are super expensive. We had lunch in this location and were done in 15 minutes. We knew to order only 4 items or we'd be breaking the bank. 4 items = $40. It really doesn't matter what you get, just plan on paying $10 per item. Unless you order the bass.. that's $36. Eeek! Still.. very good food.
author: Vol T.

description: Let me preface my review by saying this was my first "Dim Sum" experience. We went at lunchtime on a Wednesday and only had a 20 minute wait. The places was packed and we loved the ambiance. There wasn't really any explanation for how the system worked and at times it was very difficult to hear what they were offering, so we chose to be adventurous. At $84 for the two of us, it was very expensive for what we ate. There were at times long lulls in the carts coming around and we were sitting there hungry. It took a very long time and multiple requests to finally be able to order something special. The honey walnut prawns were DELICIOUS (albeit medium shrimp size) and we could have done without the cream cheese shrimp wantons (tasteless with a weird texture) and the mango pudding (somewhat bland). Potstickers and dumplings were yum. A good experience to try.
author: Jackie W.

description:
This is for the "To Go" Express Yank Sing . . .

Yummy dim sum, greasy chow mein (not a bad thing), large portions, and inexpensive pricing makes for the perfect indulgent work lunch.  Would definitely go there again and look forward to trying the more popular restaurant.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Coming from the Midwest, I was never able to find a good place for dim sum. So the first thing I wanted to do when I knew that I will spend a weekend in SF was to go eat some awesome dim sum. Yelp had this place at the top for good ratings. I went.

The reviews said it is a bit pricey but since it is in a nicer neighborhood, I decided to go because I wanted to dine in more calm and chill environment rather than a typical chinese restaurant with rude servers and loud dining area. I WAS WRONG.

This is a small place so unless you make a reservation, or wait, even with a reservation, you have to wait at least 30 min until you are seated. But that's ok, it's a small restaurant. But what I want to point out is that the service is TERRIBLE.

The cart never goes around the whole restaurant. It starts at the same place, so by the time it came to my table, all the dim sums were gone. When I ordered something off the menu, it took very long for the food to come out. I asked the server when the food is going to be out, he kept saying he is checking, but never got back to me. The servers also had hard time explaining what dim sum is in the cart. 

Bottom line, it is not worth the money to eat here. Go to other places in Chinatown for cheaper and better dim sum.
author: Ashley P.

description:
Okay... dim sum for 2 people should never cost $120!  My first clue should have been the lack of Chinese inside eating AND location isn't anywhere near Chinatown!  

SAVE your money!
author: Charlie B.

description: The shanghai dumplings are of course delicious. Everything tastes great and we were there when they opened so there wasn't any wait.
author: Kiku G.

description:
Dim sum in the San Francisco is some of the best in the country and Yank Sing makes some of the best dim sum in SF. Not to mention achieving a coveted Michelin Star in 2012. I try to visit almost every time I visit SF. This time was no different and It helped that my office was less than 5 min walk away. 

Smaller than it's uptown sister location. I came here hoping to grab some dim sum for lunch and the place was packed at 12. I was told the wait was 30 mins. I went back to my office and came back at 2pm. The place was empty and I was able to grab a seat immediately. 

And then the feast started. First I got a tray of the famous soup dumplings. I get craving for these! The skin is perfectly thin and light and the soup just bursts in your mouth. I'm getting hungry just thinking about them. Next I tried a variety of the dumplings. All were very good.

I finished off my meal with an egg custard tart. This was the one item that was a little more disappointing than the rest. Chinatown definitely has better tarts.
author: Lucy W.

description:
Yank Sing is a nice restaurant but, say you don't want to sit and eat in a nice restaurant.. next door they have Yank Sing 2 go. You order at the register and move down the counter and the number on your receipt will be called when your order is filled.

I wanted to grab their Baked BBQ Pork Bun. It was featured on Food Network's Best Thing I Ever Ate. They were out! They only had steamed left.

They also made 7x7's [2011] 100 Things To Try list (#85)for their Sesame Balls ($1.10). And you know what? It was pretty good. The filling was very peanut butter-y.

I also had a little Custard Tart ($1.40) and that, too, was pretty good. From the few different pieces that I've tried at Yank Sing 2 Go.. I really want to sit down and eat at Yank Sing now.

But being able to grab and go here-- 4 stars.
author: O M G.

description:
Dim sum... When I'm on the Westside of LA, I crave it, I yearn for it. And when I visit SF, I make sure to have it. 

When I went with a group of coworkers to Yank Sing this week, it satisfied all of my dim sum desires. However, I always forget that the prices here are way inflated compared to pretty much any other dim sum place in SF...  and it doesn't make it any better that because of the dim sum format you're not really paying attention to how much you're paying until the check comes. My eyes grew huge when I realized we ordered a small (but delicious) sea bass dish for $17 and four egg tarts for $9.60. 

Lucky for them, their food is incredible and they have a wonderful outdoor patio, perfect for warm lunch days so people, mostly those who work in the offices nearby, keep coming back.
author: Christina P.

description:
Very disappointing, I brought my mom here for her birthday as she kept talking about it after she went once. One thing I didn't know was that there is a HUGE difference in locations, according to her.  She had gone to the one on Spear street, and it was a huge difference.

I dim sum with her a lot, and I was overwhelmingly disappointed with the food.  Most of the dim sum was cold/warm to the touch, the shrimp dumplings were sticky, pork buns were cold, there isn't even shrimp or beef crepe (churn fun) at this location, what a joke.  We ended up eating only random lukewarm dumplings here as nothing was appetizing, and ended up spending $130 on 10 dishes of dim sum.

One star for great service as food wasn't their fault, and one star for edible food, but it's far less quality than what they're charging you for. I've been to plenty of places that I can spend half the price and double the food, and everything is piping hot.  Sorry.  Not impressed.
author: Brian H.

description:
Ahh...it wasn't my idea to eat here, but then again, I wasn't paying either!  Hope I don't ruin my Cantonese street cred by posting this review.  Mainly, we were going here because we needed a place that took reservations.

Yang Sing is a dim sum place that offers more than the usual Canto fare.  The atmosphere is okay, clean, but still bustling and crowded, and there are people who push dim sum carts around.  The staff is Chinese and they will speak Cantonese to you if that's your preferred language.  There were a few other Asians dining here, but most patrons were non-Asian.

The food was quality stuff.  We got 3 orders of Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai soup dumplings), each steamer basket only had 6 pieces.  They were very well made with thin skins, piping hot and full of tasty, greasy, flavorful juice.  Each one melted in my mouth.  It comes with the traditional red vinegar and ginger slivers.  Not a part of Cantonese cuisine, but I no longer cared!

We also tried some classics such as shrimp dumplings (har gow), which were filled with large, succulent shrimp that popped in your mouth.  Very fresh and it didn't leave you with a heavy MSG aftertaste.  The siu mi (pork dumplings) were also packed with flavor & the right consistency, sort of like a meatloaf nugget.

They ordered a scallop dumpling which was also good.  Gai lan (Chinese broccoli) was tasty, but served cold.  Interesting.  The lettuce wraps are decidedly a fusion dish (a la PF Chang), but surprisingly tasty.  It was a round piece of iceberg lettuce with some savory bits of ground meat, topped with pine nuts.  We tried the honey walnut shrimp, which was okay, but not the best I've ever had.  It was the tiniest dish I've ever had, though.  The sea bass was excellent: silky smooth and delicious.  I would never have thought about ordering this at dim sum, but I am not complaining!

For dessert, we tried the orange juice jello.  Basically, it's densely made jello that is poured into an orange half, then allowed to set, and cut into slices.  Cute, but not as cool looking as the picture on their website.  It tasted okay, however, it's not something I'd recommend on flavor alone.

Come with an open mind and an open wallet.  It was $40/head and we weren't completely stuffed full.  You can feed your whole family authentic dim sum at other restaurants for $40 total!  The quality of the dim sum was high, but in my mind, not worth the incredibly high prices.  If I'm paying for the meal, we're not going back here!
author: Kari C.

description:
The dim sum at Yank Sing does not justify the high price tag. There are so many other dim sum places in the Bay Area with the same (if not better) quality of food for a fraction of the price. If Yank Sing was a little less expensive, it might warrant 3 stars, but given the price - 2 stars. This place is definitely Americanized and caters to the FiDi population. I don't think I would come here again if it weren't for a company lunch. 

Also - what is all that XLB hype? Doesn't even compare to those in HK or Shanghai.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Fantastic Dim Sum.

A little expensive, and the hot sauce was *lacking* but you know what you are getting at this well know dim sum institution.
author: William B.

description:
Yank Sing should be named Yank $ing, but I should have known FiDi Dim Sum comes with FiDi prices. Yank Sing is likely one of the nicest Chinese dining establishment you'll ever find. The service (and the crowd) are nothing like what you would find in your stereotypical Chinese restaurants; but being located in the heart of the Financial District, I suppose you shouldn't expect any less... waters always full, waitstaff is always nearby, food is continuously available.

Peking Duck: 3.5 stars
Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings): 3.5 stars
Shui Mai (pork&shrimp dumplings): 3 stars
Hargow (shrimp dumplings): 4 stars
Sea Bass: 3 stars, though my BF would give it 4+
Chicken Feet: 3.5 stars
Mango Coconut Mochi: 3 stars

Overall,
Food: 3.5 stars
Service: 5 stars
Price: $$$

Considering you can find similar if not even better food at hole-in-the-walls for half the price, value (food/price) is about a 1... bringing the overall rating to 3 stars. If money weren't an issue, I would probably love coming here all the time for the food and the comfort... but til you're a part of that 1%, you gotta live within reason.
author: Lana N.

description:
Yank Sing is right outside my office in FiDi. I always see the restaurant packed with tons of business folks during lunch time. If you don't have reservations, it's most likely you'll get seated outside. It wasn't a big deal since the weather was holding up nicely here in SF.

I really liked the dim sum here but the service killed it for me. We spent a total of 40 minutes eating but took almost 30 minutes to get our bill, charge our card AND to get out! They charged us twice for two separate amounts because they mistakenly entered in the wrong amount the first time. It equalled out to the correct amount but it was quite annoying to wait that long when you only have a 1 hour lunch break.

The dim sum in general was very tasty. I loved the sweet sticky rice ball dumplings. We ordered two portions of the shanghai dumplings because it was that good! My bf really liked the su mai and the shrimp dumplings. Overall, I would have to say that the food was pretty good but super expensive in contrast to other dim sum spots I've eaten at.

I also got to-go on a separate occasion and the chow mein was gross. It was dry and the noodles were like spaghetti noodles. The potstickers and the steamed bbq pork bun were pretty good. It was pretty expensive for to-go food but I will definitely try a different portion next time.
author: Stephanie N.

description: This is my second time here and honestly the food is really good, but not worth the high prices and long wait for me. The staff can also be rude.
author: T H.

description:
When your boss is paying for lunch, everything is delicious!

Tip: watch out for those Shanghai dumplings (a house specialty), so you don't burn your mouth as your hungrily bite into it. Piping hot steam and broth will let loose onto your unassuming American mouth. Thankfully, I was warned and poked a hole into the dumpling to let it cool off, placed the dumpling on a ceramic spoon, and plopped it into my mouth after an agonizing 30-second wait.

In general, it's a typical dim sum joint with non-stop food being carted to your table. If you hesitate, they will continue to force you to take it. And bless their little hearts for it.

It ain't cheap (the three of us came out with a $90 bill) so grab your boss and let him/her know you need to discuss a few work things "over lunch" (wink, wink).
author: Adena B.

description: It's quite good, and you won't have an MSG headache after you eat there. At lunch, most everything is hot and fresh, and they have a few items I haven't had elsewhere (seaweed salt and pepper tofu, seafood basil dumpling, chicken stuffed mushroom). However, the reason this has slipped from 4.5 to 3 in my book is that they are doing poorly on value for money. Yes, I expect a price increment because we're not in Chinatown anymore. However, it is not reasonable to charge $6 for a single slice of Peking duck. I am more likely to make the extra trek to a hole in the wall, given the way things have changed.
author: Alik W.

description: The food is fresh and delicious.  The service, of course, is fast since all food items are cooked in advance and ready for service. I would recommend this place. I go there all the times.
author: Soso K.

description: Unlike the majority of dim sum places that I've been to, this place had absolutely no line at 11am on a Sunday.  I thought it was a bit strange and I walked in quite cautiously.  We ordered the typical dimsum fare, but really enjoyed items like their sea bass and sesame balls filled with sweet yellow bean and kabocha (?).  I do think that these are exorbitant prices for dimsum.  We paid $45 a person.  I certainly did not think that the quality and creativity of the food justified the costs.
author: Helen T.

description: Great hangover food! Usually there's a line to sit down but you can order to go and it's just as good and much quicker. Delicious dim sum!
author: Lizzy U.

description: Called ahead to order to go. They said they are busy and won't do to go over the phone but I could order if I go there. Once there they said they can't do to go. Just tell me before , so that I wouldn't have wasted my time walking 5 blocks from my hotel  to get my order. You lost my business . Poor costumer service , will never go back again
author: Kim D.

description: My first visit to a dim sum bat but definitely not my last. This place is first class. The food is wonderful. I made a reservation and was glad I did because the line was down the block. I will return when in the area.
author: Annmarie C.

description: Dim sum is very good here, especially the xiao long baos! I still prefer DTF but this is the (relatively) closer alternative. Service is always better than other dim sum places.
author: Phuong H.

description:
We were 4 hungry co-workers when we visited this place for a FiDi lunch.

The second we sat down, the attack happened.

Except not with weapons, but with steamy dumplings plopped down on our table by screaming Asian servers. 

It felt like a race. No, more like an auction: how about this here plate of dumplings? How about some more string beans? Some tea? Shu-mai fo yu?

The food was good. But somehow the atmosphere of rushed eating barred us from savoring what could have been the best dim sum in the area.
author: Nick A.

description:
I think I had a less than perfect experience because of the timing. The food I ordered was out and more batches were still being prepared. However, the carts of food you can choose from do come by frequently and waiters kept asking if I needed anything. I recommend the shiitake mushroom dumplings and the spinach fried dumpling things.

I was a little disappointed with the duck bun, but I'm not a big fan of duck. The skin was crispy, but it just wasn't for me. The chicken stuffed mushrooms are a little flavorless. But I still would go back to try different things. There are so many options!
author: Maria Z.

description:
This place looks very fancy. Probably the fanciest Chinese dim sum place I have ever stepped into. The restaurant was at about a little over half capacity at around 11am. A lot of ABCs and mix families here. 

Once we sat down we were offered a variety of food before we even got the table napkin onto our laps. We felt a tiny bit overwhelmed. Eventually, we noticed the same items coming around over and over again. Not too much variety here. No meat balls! No shrimp or beef in noodles!  Grr!!!

The food here is very mediocre. Below average. Esp for the price it is ridiculous! We shrimp dumplings' skin were very tough. The chicken bao that is on Best Thing I Ever Ate isn't the best thing my friends ever ate. The sesame ball on my 7x7 list was actually pretty good though but it is probably around the same as other dim sum places. 

The service was very good and prompt. All the waitresses were very friendly and polite. Also very clean! ++  One bathroom for men, one bathroom for women. Clean and spacious. 

It was around 60 dollars for the four of us! WTF! We had like 8 items. 8 items at a not Americanized dim sum place would be half the price! 

I will NOT be returning!
author: Sarah C.

description: wow is the reaction that I give this place.  We went for a business lunch which was both a good idea and bad.  Good because it was more social meeting than serious but bad because we literally were interrupted every 4 minutes with another offer of delicious food.  That should not deter anyone from going here though.  Think of this experience as being caught in the middle of a conveyor belt with delicious options all around you.  The place runs like a six sigma Navy Seal training ground.  They should offer special seating so that folks can see the kitchen because, at the rate of what goes on in the dining room, the kitchen must be busier than SFO on a holiday weekend.  The food was delicious and 100% of what I tried was new food to me.  The peking duck was a favorite at our table.  Yes, it was expensive, but it was a true experience.
author: Stephanie C.

description: The prices are outrageous here (including hidden costs) for food that is poor quality for dimsum (they didn't even have some standard dishes such as shrimp rolls). If I were you, I would heed the one and two-star ratings here on yelp; I sure wish I did...you can get better dimsum at many other places for one quarter of the price.
author: Jan Z.

description: Some good dishes, some not so good dishes. Service was friendly and prompt, and the restaurant was clean with white linen tablecloth and napkins. They have an outdoor seating area that could potentially accommodate people with dogs. So why the two stars? My oh my is this place expensive! I had 8/9 dishes and my one-person lunch was nearly 100 bucks! I can understand the $13+ price tag on the crab claws (you get two), but $12+ for scallop dumplings is ridiculous! With the lowest priced dishes being $5.35, a meal here is going to be more expensive than most sushi meals.
author: DV P.

description: Having been to so many dim sum places I have to say my new rule of thumb if there's a lack of Asian people stay away. Terrible service and super overpriced for terrible food. I think the dim sum here is worse than dim sum from dim sum king. The fried food on their carts looked sad. We paid about 35 dollars a person you can get much better food service and price elsewhere.
author: Catherina W.

description:
The wife and I were in the mood for some quick & cheap dim sum, but didn't want to fight the crowds of Chinatown, so we turned to the handy-dandy Yelp app...

Yelp search: cheap dim sum
Near: SOMA
Results: Yank Sing / Yank Sing 2 Go

Sadly, we were misled to Yank Sing 2 Go, which is apparently closed on weekends.  Regular Yank Sing said that they could help us out anyway, so we told them what we wanted and waited, and waited some more.  Eventually, they brought us a giant bag of dim sum with a bill for $30-something.  Yikes!  Now don't get me wrong, the food wasn't bad, but it was average *at best*.  and when I think of the cost, it just kills me inside!  I somehow thought that they'd give us the to-go price for our to-go order, but it seems that I was wayyy off.

If for some reason I'm crazy for some fancy-pants dim sum, Yank Sing seems like a good place.  It's got a classy ambiance and it's far cleaner than its Chinatown brethren.  But that's not what good dim sum is to me.

Based on the reviews and Yank Sing's prices, I should have been eating the best char siu bao ever.  But I wasn't.  Had I taken the extra ten minutes to drive to Chinatown, I could have had the exact same to-go order in one big pink box (you know the kind) for maybe $12 (probably less), and I wouldn't have to wait around for it, either.
author: Chris Y.

description: Was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the food here given the 3.5 star rating. The Shanghai dumplings were excellent and the best of the dumplings we tasted. The others were fine (har gao, siu mai) but not as good; and not close to Hong Kong quality. Overall though, you can expect a decent meal here but not necessarily value for money. Like most other reviews have stated, it is overpriced but if you're in the neighborhood, it's convenient and tasty.
author: Joy O.

description:
This place is great for a quick tasty lunch. You can order a cheap combo and get it really fast. It is cheap good eats. If you are a dim sum fan and are on a time crunch, like a lunch break, then go for this. 

If you have more time, then you can enjoy sitting in the main restaurant. Dim sum-licious!
author: Sean B.

description:
The BEST Dim Sum I have ever had. And I have had it everywhere. Like the other reviewers have mentioned over and over and over, it's expensive. Probably 3 times more expensive than any other traditional Dim Sum spot you go to. With traditional Dim Sum spots, you expect to feed a family of 5 for under 50 bucks and come home with leftovers. But it's so worth it. Everything was made with such precision and tastes like its made with high quality ingredients.  T

Must try: shanghai dumplings, pork buns, peking duck, fried scallop balls

I wish i tried the black cod! Next time. 

If you don't mind paying for incredible food, go to Yank Sing!
author: Catherine C.

description: Went there yesterday and had lunch with a few colleagues. The dim sum was just okay and I wouldn't say it's the best, especially for the price. Definitely not as good as Koi Palace in Daly City. Although, service is outstanding for a Dim Sum spot.
author: Ngai P.

description: Not a huge fan of dim sum so maybe this review is a little jaded but had to wait 35 min for a table at lunch time. Honestly the food was like something I could get out of Trader Joes freezer section. Tried about 7 or 8 different things and was underwhelmed. The beat thing here was definitely the hot tea though.. That was delicious!!
author: Brittany E.

description:
The Dish: Forget Chinatown dim sum. This place has it all. It is on the pricier side and they realize that many of its customers are business/working people.
