Instead of what I'm used to (waiting for the carts to roll around), the waiters have mini-microphones to tell one another what customers want so the cars come to us. I came with my co-worker who knew all the good dishes. I typically only order shu-mai and shanghai dumplings. I know, no variety. But, here, I had maybe 6-7 different dishes? Definitely finish off with the green onion cake w/ peanut sauce and coconut rolls. 

Ambiance: This place has fast service and really nice people. My coworker didn't know the name of the green onion cake so could only describe it. They came out with the wrong order and was really cordial about it all - and got us the right dish even with just descriptions. They have patio seating as well as inside seating. Good place to come with friends and share a bunch of different dishes.
author: Gina T.

description: I'm not gunna lie, while I think Yank Sing is way overpriced, this place has one of the best shanghai dumplings I've ever tasted. I don't know how they get the skin so thin, but yet pack so much soup inside! I guess it better taste that good though, since they charge you an arm and a leg for it. Apparently, they also use Kurobuta pork, which makes the filling EXTRA delicious! If you ever get the chance to stop by here, you must order the xiao long bao!
author: Audrey L.

description: Uhhhh $165 w/ tax and tip for 3 people...$27 for beef chow fun (guan chow ngo haw).  I knew it would be overpriced being in Fidi, but I was taking clients out.  I was thinking an upcharge of $1-2 for each dim sum dish...try $3-5 upcharge per dish.  I've never had dim sum average more than $20-25/pp and that's pigging out.  I should have check the prices ahead of time, thank god I expensed this through work.  I would never go here ever again.  Dim sum was average at best and cold on top.
author: Andrew M.

description: Pricey for only okay food. Good location. Fresh egg tarts (custard), very tasty. Did not have the flat rice noodles with shrimp.
author: Tom P.

description: Total rip off. The food is OK quality but the price is staggering. For only 4-5 small dishes we are charged with hefty price. Came out bankrupted and still hungry.
author: andy s.

description:
I don't proclaim to be a dim sum expert but after countless dining experiences I can differentiate between great dim sum and mediocre dim sum, the latter being Yank Sing. 

Traditionally, most people associate dim sum with two iconic items, shui mai and haw gow or pork dumpling and shrimp dumpling respectively. I base the reputation of a dim sum establishment on these two dishes because if you can't do those right it doesn't bode well for what is to come. 

Needless to say, they were just A-OK. While nothing horribly offensive it certainly wasn't anything to wow over either. In addition to our meal, we ordered a plethora of items since my friend had never been, so we were able to gauge the strengths and weaknesses of Yank Sing. I throughly enjoyed the tea presentation and the flavor however, this was a first time I had to pay for tea with my dim sum but was worth it. 

Our meal ended up costing $96.63 before tip. While we did order quite a few items I believe that if we went somewhere else and ordered the same we would have paid a fraction of that cost and received better selection and quality. I was extremely disappointed that they didn't carry my noodle dish! 

Overall Thoughts

An upscale dim sum establishment with prices to match. The food lacked character and soul, certainly did not touch my heart.
author: Eddie W.

description:
Great for Vegetarian/ pescatarian! Lots of options to choose from :)

I really enjoyed my experience. I attribute it partly to the fact that I live in the Midwest and I totally crave good dim sum. I was looking forward to trying Yank Sing (made reservation a week in advance) and it didn't disappoint!!

I don't eat meats so I was looking around for places that have dim sums without pork in all of them and Yank Sing fits just that. Also, as a Chinese, I am a little bit of a dim sum snob!!!

I enjoyed every single dish I had at Yank Sing. The steamed items are all fresh, bouncy, and bursting with flavors. My string beans with dried shrimp XO sauce was also super tasty. 

Will definitely build this in as one of the must-eat when I am in the bay area
author: Patty T.

description:
What Fun!

Outstanding dim sum.  Good service.

Glad I wasn't paying the bill as I am sure it added up to an amount I might have fainted from.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Potstickers are the best ever.  Custard buns really good too.

Outstanding service

Really expensive for dim sum.
author: Xela C.

description:
I guess I have not been to SF for dim sum in a while, probably because there isn't any place worth going to. 

I remembered Yang Sing from when they were down on Battery street, so it has been a while. Some friends of mine came to town and asked me to meet them there. I was presently surprised to find it tucked away in a quiet side street. 

We were greeted promptly and led to a table in the open patio (with heaters). The dim sum carts came promptly with a variety of selections in each cart. Another server hand carried so specials. We had the following speciality items:

1.  Shanghai dumplings - skin a little too soft, but still juicy
2.  Peking Duck - you could order by how many servings you wanted (different), tender and not too fatty
3.  Lettuce wraps - pretty tasty and not overwhelmed by the sauce.

Yang Sing is actually a pretty relaxing Chinese dim sum restaurant; could this be an oxymoron?
author: Tony L.

description:
Expensive Dim Sum. 

Everything tasted decent, but the cost is about 30% more just because it is in the Finacial District.
author: Steven F.

description:
Tried Yank Sing 2 Go for the first time today. Their "combination" meals are just like any other typical Chinese eatery - comes with fried rice and chow mein (big whoop). 

Though the menu clearly stated this, I wasn't expecting the typical Chinese fair. I ordered the Pheonix (and Taro Dumplings) and had 1 piece of siu mye and 2 mediocre pieces of pot stickers. 

If you like Dim sum and you already know what you like - I advise that you just order the Dim Sum to-go and not buy into their "combination" meals.
author: Jill G.

description:
Great QUALITY dim sum. If you're looking for cheap American-Chinese food, you're going to be disappointed. However, if you're looking for AUTHENTIC dim sum with flavors reminiscent of those you tasted when you last went for dim sum in Hong Kong or Guangzhou, this is the place to go.

___________________________________

*** Don't forget to order the XIAO LONG BAO (Shanghai Dumplings)! And eat it the right way:

1. You can either prepare the vinegar + ginger + soy sauce in a small bowl ahead of time, OR (do what I find easier) put a little bit of each of the 3 on your spoon - enough for one dumpling.
2. Pick it up carefully with your chopsticks to make sure you don't tear the skin of the dumpling as you transfer it onto the spoon.
3. EAT! But be careful - the soup inside the dumpling is usually hot..
author: Asha S.

description:
Excellent place! Went on a tuesday afternoon! The XLB was perfect along with the fried shrimp!! Could'nt
be better.
Cant wait to go again!!
author: F N.

description:
The greatest most wonderful dim sum I have ever had!!

Upon sitting, it may become extremely overwhelming to be approached by aggressive women on carts but fear not they are not there to hurt you. Actually, they want to feed you some tasty dim sum you feel me?? 

Recommendations: Shanghai dumplings of course, so mainstream but so greatness. The stir fried string beans, my gosh are they delicious and a bit spicy! The pork buns, well duh they are like the best food creations in this world. Oh! The walnut shrimp is pretty good. And the seabass I highly recommend, very tender and tasty dense per bite! 

Watch out, saying yes to carts = destroyed wallet yo. Pick and choose wisely so you can save up for dessert!

It has taken me a few times to get used to my rhythm and to find my favorites, I assure you, you will someday find yours. 

We made reservations for weekend dimsum just to be careful, why not? I say do it brother. 

A favorites in my books, pleases go there and you will not be sorrrys!
author: Michelle X.

description:
My uncle took me here so I have no idea what it cost, though I think it's quite expensive! Not sure how I feel about really expensive dim sum, but if it's as fresh as the stuff I ate here...OK fine.

Had some neat dishes I personally haven't seen elsewhere lately: bacon wrapt shrimp and cream cheese wontons. Also siu mai, xialongbao, pork buns, all the standards. I think Yank Sing may be fairly high up on the Westernized scale, but so what? It's not like I'm going here every time I want dim sum!

The outside seating is actually quite nice - heat lamps very unobtrusive but clearly keeping you warm on a cloudy day in February!

But yes, the quality of the food was really nice, and extremely fresh.

If you want to sit inside at lunch, make a reservation. Also note the take out window is a great option, too!
author: Conrad B.

description: Overpriced, food is average quality, and cold maybe because it was late afternoon. But in general not recommended.
author: Julie Z.

description: The service was very friendly, but the food was mediocre and the price was disgraceful for the quality and selection. We saw the same fried seafood and doughy dumpling selections over and over again, all things I can find in the freezer section at Target. Maybe this restaurant designs their menu around white people who have never eaten dim sum? It was kind of hilarious when the waitress gave us a demo of how to eat a dumpling with a spoon! Having lived in the Bay Area my whole life and eaten better at friends' homes, this place was actually really disappointing. Also! The women's bathroom was out of order, and there was a sign on it to use the men's but there was no lock on the door so I actually walked in on a man using the urinal! I would not go back.
author: Elli S.

description:
Please don't come here. If you really want dim sum.. go to chinatown. If you want to eat in the financial district, eat somewhere else. 

The dim sum was ok.. I didn't hate it, but it was mostly cold and not that great - not worth the 45 minute wait for a table. What REALLY upsets me is the price. For 3 people, we got maybe 6 small plates and a pot of tea? Ended up being more than $100!!! This is outrageous. At dim sum, I expect to be stuffed out of my mind for about $30 for 3 people. I know we're not in chinatown, so I was ok with paying twice that. 

My friend said it best: Yank Sing is for business lunches for people working in the financial district billing the company. I assume most of those people are not reading yelp reviews. =P
author: Lisa W.

description:
I used the To-Go Counter.

I like that there is a Yank Sing near my new work building, I'm a big fan of their Chinese chicken salad! I decided to try something different at my last visit since it was a little chilly. I tried their express lunch; chow mein, egg roll, and pork bun. The pork bun was very good, the egg roll was perfectly cooked, and the chow mein didn't impress me. All the meat pieces looked different and I couldn't tell if they were cooked all the way since one looked more brown then red like the others. I'd go back but I think I'll stick to my chinese chicken salad.
author: Constance D.

description: First off, 4 stars for their soup dumplings, they were pretty good. The soup was flavorful, the skin was medium thickness, and it worked well with red vinegar.  The service was average, it took a while to get our refill on our tea and drinks and also our check.  The selection was limited for dim sum, I was really surprised that they didn't have some standard dim sum items.  They also had too many deep fried items, we wanted more steamed dishes and kept refusing all the fried servers.  We were getting hungry after turning away more of the fried servers, we ordered a veggie dish (dou mieu) and it was cold, I've never had it that icy cold before, warm, but never that cold, makes me think they forgot to heat it up. overall, it was a okay dim sum experience.
author: Dianna S.

description:
Expensive? Yes.  Touristy? A bit.  The food is really good though that I forgive their high price and "business/corporate" atmosphere.

Food - great
The food is always consistently good here.  It always tastes fresh, and unlike some other places the fried items are always served hot and crispy.  I cannot think of one item that I've ordered here where I feel like "oh, this is not as good as that other place".  Being an expensive restaurant they also have 'premium items' being passed around like Peking duck and Chilean seabass.

Service - great
Even when they are full I never feel like I am waiting too long for the food to come out.  They are also wearing earpieces and microphones so when you want something just flagged them and they'll put an order in to the kitchen.  Also, they all speak good English and are patient to explain what everything is.

Atmosphere - ok
It can get a little to 'corporate' and sterile in here.  Definitely not the kind of atmosphere I am looking for from a dim sum restaurant.  The place itself is physically nice though.

Price - bad
This is what's stopping me from giving 5 star rating.  They are expensive.  You can easily spend $30/person here without any alcoholic beverages.  This is an 'issue' because I relate dim sum with cheap meal.  Our 'other' place would cost us around $12 for the equivalent amount (not necessarily quality) of food that we get here for $30.  

Overall this is a great place for special occasion dim sum.  Bite the bullet, pay the extra $20 per person and order one of their premium items that you can't easily get elsewhere.
author: Andi H.

description:
DO NOT EAT HERE!  I've been to Yank Sing many times but now after learning that the owners were underpaying their employees and demanding unpaid hours of work from them, plus taking their tips, I will never eat here again.

Each meal is insanely expensive compared to other Dim Sum restaurants (even other fancy ones), so it is truly appalling that these added profits were not even somewhat shared with their employees.

Do not eat here and support this unjust business!!! You can read about the case here: 
http://m.sfgate.com/living/article/The-dim-sum-revolution-6177566.php
author: Teresa H.

description: Came here for lunch and ordered 2 Shanghai soup dumplings and 1order of pork shumai.  The total was   $42. That's pretty outrageously expensive for average Chinese dimsum. I think you can save more money just taking a taxi a short distance to Chinatown and getting better variety of dimsum there.  I think 4 egg tarts was like $11-13.  Something that normally costs max $1-2. I like spending money on food but this made me cringe.
author: Krystle L.

description: If not the best dim sum, among the best dim sum that I have ever had.  It's more nicely appointed than most other dim sum restaurants.  A reservation is a must.  Dim sum is inherently chaotic and isn't a typical restaurant experience.  Concentrate on the food itself!  The soup dumplings are among the best ever- delicate wrappers, fragrant complex broth.  The pot stickers, breaded shrimp and mixed shumai were awesome.  There were some items that weren't best in class, but everything is way above average.  A must do in SF, if you like dim sum.
author: Joel S.

description:
I've been to both this location and the Spear St. one.  I'm going to start off by saying I have had plenty of dimsum in my life, from SF to LA (San Gabriel) to Orange County (Westminster) to Shanghai to Hong Kong.  And dimsum at Yank Sing, albeit pricier than any other dimsum place I've been to, is legit.

Yes, $5.60 for four Shrimp Dumplings (xia jiao) is pretty hefty (especially when I can get the same in San Gabriel for $2).  Yes, the menu does not have a single Chinese word on it. But the food is GOOD! Everything is fresh, the atmosphere of the restaurant is serene & clean, the service is wonderful, and it's just a nice place to get your weekend dimsum.  I have to admit though, what really got me was one item on the menu I never thought I'd order at a dimsum joint: Honey Baked Seabass ($17.50).  Pricy, and the portion was not very big. But if you like fish like I do, this was a fishy piece of heaven. 

All in all I would recommend trying it once. Just dont expect to make it a regular dimsum spot, unless you have money to burn.
author: Jae Z.

description:
The most expensive mediocre dim sum I've had in my life. Maybe since I'm used to the San Gabriel Valley dim sum in SoCal where they have lunch specials with $2 or less plates, but Yank Sing was just "A-OK". 

I'm not a SF local, but I'm sure there aren't many other dim sum places near this one. The restaurant itself is very low key - nothing fancy. Their service is very good, but it better be for the price you pay!

The food is still good. If you're willing to spend $9-12 dollars a plate then check this place out.
author: Carol L.

description: This place is way overpriced.   The dim sum is very good but not worth the price.  The bill was $50 for 4 dishes.  I had better dim sum in Chinatown at Delicious Dim Sum the previous day for $8.  I know my dim sum.  Don't make the same mistake I did.  Really read the yelp reviews.  I would have saved myself  $50
author: Kimo W.

description:
Ah, Dim Sum.   Expensive - let's start there.  You can spend a whole lot of money for two people let alone if you have a table for 4.  With that being said, all of the food is good.  Service is quick and you can ask for the plate you want instead of waiting and getting full with the things you do not like because you are hungry.  My favorites are the Hot and Sour soup and the Soup Dumplings.  

The wait can be long on holidays.  Reservations always.  Cannot eat here all the time because of the cost but worth it when people come in to town.
author: Doreen D.

description:
Atmosphere good
Food excellent
Service excellent


This is a very busy store. Make reservations asap.
author: Ross Z.

description:
High end dim sum...yup sounds weird typing that and even weirder trying to convince people to pay 10x what you would pay for comparable dim sum about 2 miles away. Still, the quality and service makes this place almost worth it. A group of 3-4 people will run you around $100 so be prepared for the sticker shock when you get the bill. Is it the best dim sum I've ever had? Yeah, probably... the baked pork buns are absolutely the best I've had, but its also not so much better that its worth the price either. 
The food 5*, Service 4*, price 2*... overall probably a 3.5* review but the food made me round up.
author: Chong K.

description:
I've been to this place so many times, at least 40, and it used to be sooooo good. But today I went in and had a pretty bad meal at a pretty high price. It wasn't always like this!!!

First, we came in at 1:30pm and although Yank Sing is usually bustling at this hour the dining room was almost empty. Never mind, we sat down anyway. We usually focus only on steamed dumplings and today was no exception. When the cart came around we took five baskets, one with the house specialty, dumplings full of soup. 

Well, out of the five, one was good, one was bad and the other three just meh. Yank Sing used to blow your mind with wonderful flavors, fresh seafood and all in a dainty dough. Not any more. The dough was thick and the dumpling filling was one you could find at any dim sum place in the area, even those at half the price.

And while we're talking about price, $12 for a basket of 6 dumplings full of soup (so don't tell me the ingredients are expensive!!!) is WAY overpriced. 

Bottom line, sadly, go elsewhere for your dim sum fix. This place has lost it.
author: Hagit K.

description:
I've come here off and on for lunch.  I noticed that the portions have gotten smaller (at least the dim sum).  Food is still tasty and nothing beats cheap chinese food w/o walking to Chinatown.  

I either get the Phoenix or Seafood Supreme.  Phoenix is heavy on carbs (you get rice and mein at the same time!).
author: Wendy H.

description: I have been wanting to eat here for quite some time. The location and restaurant environment were fine but my wife and I were thoroughly disappointed with many of the essential elements. The scallops did not taste like scallop and the peking duck was chewy, dry, and cold.  We had a couple of other cold dishes although the restaurant was not particularly busy during lunch hour on a Friday. The wait for food was rather long and no manager was seen combing the dining room. And staff was not good at removing dishware given the small size of the tables. A manager started to help at the end but she was there to bring you the checks only.  The staff filled our water but they were clearly disinterested, overworked and the restaurant itself was not well managed. They jam packed the dining area with small tables and this restaurant's mission, maximizing profits at the expense of quality and enjoyment for their guests and staff, and obvious. There are better dim sum choices elsewhere in the Bay Area.
author: A N.

description: Really disappointed in my visit to Yank Sing.  At $50+ per person I expect more.  We were seated on the patio, as patio diners cleared out we were treated to banging and clashing as tables were cleared, chairs were moved as they shut down the area while we were still eating.  The ambience was awful.  Our service was slow, many dishes were unavailable or sold out (we had a 2PM reservation).  I have always enjoyed Yank Sing in the past, but this lacked all of the fun and energy of previous visits to the Rincon Center location.  It may take awhile to try Yank Sing again.
author: Sharon L.

description: This place was average at best. I've experienced much better dim sum at much lower prices.  Whatever you do, do NOT order the steamed cod...no matter how much or often the waitress tries to persuade you. Oh sure, it looks delicious, and with all the greasy dishes, having a piece of steamed fish would make you feel like you're at least trying to eat healthy right? Mmmaybe... Unless you want your bill to increase by $30 for a 2x3 inch piece of steamed fish...I implore you, do not do it.
author: Anh R.

description:
I choose this place to eat because it's behind my office building. This place is ok. Food is decent and I think that prices are fair. I was surprised how quickly I got my order.  I got chow mein which was good, but I don't really care for the, I guess it's Chinese sausage. Other than that the chow mein was ok. I also got a sesame seed ball, which was ok too. 
I don't think this is the best Chinese food I've had. Probably find a better spot in Chinatown. But I will go there again just because it's close by.
author: Jeanie Ann D.

description: Wide variety of chinese dim sum steamed, fried, and saute'd dishes.  Cart service is quick, pay $6-20 per plate taken from the carts.
author: Ty S.

description:
This was my first experience with dim sum and I was delighted!  YUM!!  Everything they put in front of us rocked with unique flavor.  Crab claws are a must.  Soup bao is a specialty of the house and a wonderful surprise.  Walnut prawns!  Sea Bass is worth whatever they charged for it -DELICIOUS!

The food is 5 star quality.  So why the 3 star rating?

WAIT till you get the bill!  Holy smokes, Batman!  Way way overpriced even for the stellar quality.

Do it once for the experience and you need never go back.

Currently on a quest to find DELICIOUS and CHEAP dim sum in SF!
(Hint - It's NOT here!)
author: Cyndi C.

description:
I saw all the raving reviews for the yummy dim sum and i was surprised that the quality of the dim sum was not winning the gold with me.
We had the 
Ha gow (shrimp dumpling) 
shiu mi (pork dumpling) 
sweet rice wrapped in leaves, 
shanghai dumpling (their signature dish) 
bbq pork bun 
fried spring roll 
egg tart
Thats all we had this set us back $74!!!! just for dim sum!?!? crazy!!!!! 
It was not terrible but there is MUCH better and MUCH cheaper dim sum in San Fran. 
$74 for dim sum means this place is just over priced and gave me a tummy ache of regret.
author: Wendy C.

description:
2.5 stars for Yank Sing To-go, 2.0 for the restaurant.

The Dim Sum is pretty good, it's the shock of seeing the bill that will put you off of Yank Sing. As is the is the case with Dim Sum most everywhere you pay by the plate and the price per plate varies with what's on it. Be forewarned as the servers slowly lower yet another small plate of yummies to your table that a group of three can easily tally $100 or more and a group of 5 or more easily tops $200 at this restaurant. Of course this is of no consequence if it's going on your company's tab.

I've been to this location and the other 3 several times and the service is typically solid but today?  Yank Sing... mmm, mmm, mmm - you done f'd up.

My coworkers and I had a reservation for 6 at 12:30 and we all arrived on time, only to be told that our table would be ready in just a minute. 15 minutes later we were asked if we minded sitting at separate tables. "Near each other?" A coworker inquired - wisely, as it turned out. "No, different rooms," the staff casually replied, indifferent to our raised eyebrows. Really? Their thinking on that suggestion eludes me. In any case, we declined and eventually they managed to find a few tables to push together.

The servers missed a couple of drinks we ordered but they were quick to bring them once reminded. They put $15 to our bill for tea we never ordered and corrected the bill, after we pointed out their error. Yank Sing comp'd us nothing for their mishap with our table or the bill. This wouldn't be something I harp on I believe any restaurant has bad days/moments. I would have nicer things to say if they demonstrated a measure of remorse for the snafus. The lunchtime crowd in the FiDi is mainly people at work and do need to get back to the office. This lunch took a lot longer than we planned on account of the mishaps.

Yank Sing 2-Go is more decently priced but the selections are very limited. If you love their chow mein and like their buns and potstickers you could be quite happy with the combinations available and the price.
author: Ben S.

description:
What I Ate
- Dim sum

Dim Sum Favorites
- Peking duck
- Shanghai dumplings
- BBQ pork buns
- Lettuce wraps

Would I Go Again?
This has been my third time to Yank Sing for dim sum, and I look forward to time number four.  I would classify Yank Sing's dim sum as "high-class authentic".  While I've never eaten lettuce wraps enhanced with pine nuts and cilantro in Hong Kong, that doesn't mean that Yank Sing's lettuce wraps aren't delicious in every way.  I love the service, the atmosphere, and the food.  The only drawback is that you pay a premium for the service, the atmosphere, and the food.  All in all, if you work in the Financial District/SOMA and are looking for fantastic dim sum to get you through the rest of the workday, you can't beat Yank Sing!
author: Ben M.

description: I've enjoyed dim sum all over the world, but the Xiao Long Bao here are absolutely the best. Tender thin and light wrap over a juicy succulent piece of pork. Very tasty! Also find the other dumpling offerings top notch, although a bit "touristy" in choices (egg rolls, char shu bao). Very very pricey so not a place I go to often but its fun for a splurge. Very nice dining room with white table clothes and upscale environment, but you pay for it. $83 for two for dim sum recently. Ouch. Go once and make a reservation so you don't have to wait too long in line!
author: K J.

description: Past its prime and too expensive for what it is.  For his price go to Hakkasan.   This used to have very good food,  but now it is bland and over cooked.  It has also become very expensive.
author: Trevor M.

description:
I loveh the food at Yank Sing..but c'mon ladies! Allow my butt to touch the seat before you start peddling the special sea bass....and give me some time to chew down my shrimp har gao before you offer up the desserts..

The whole idea of dim sum is to slowly enjoy the little plates while sipping tea..but everytime I've been here I've felt completely rushed...and trust me..I am a quick eater..
author: Mimi T.

description:
Awesome! Loved it! 

As for the other reviews I see here...

Personally, I thought prices were fair, location wasn't too hard to find, and I'd rather have a clean restaurant with huge windows and simple ambiance than "authentic" decor (in several Dim Sum places Ive been in Seattle that I thought were NOT "clean" but were "authentic").
author: eva s.

description: Way too over rated and absolutely way over priced!! I took my brother and sister here for a Saturday lunch; only 3 of us in total the bill came out to well over $120!! And we were totally not even full at ALL!! That is absolutely INSANE! Since we weren't even full, we walked over to Thai OSHA on Embarcadero just to eat again! That just shows you how expensive and small their portions are...absolutely ridiculous!! Come on! Lower your prices and give a little bit more to the consumer for god's sake!!
author: Bobby C.

description: First off, way over-price for low quality food and poor service. Second, everything is lathered in or marinated in soy sauce or fish sauce, which I thought was pretty awful. Coming from NY, NYC China town and even in Rochester NY, I was able to find pretty quality Dim Sum - a bit too surprised that they structured the pricing around all the financial services firm around the building including my own :) It looks clean - but not really - our chairs had food and when some folks in our table asked for forks, they came out unclean. They use recyclable plastic chopsticks - so I was not happy about that, especially because I was not sure how well they clean them.
author: Thaminda R.

description:
Good cheap dim sum to go. Consistent quality. I suggest the "deem sum platter" for about $9. Includes a steamed pork bun, two shiu-mai, seafood dumplings, egg roll & custard tart.

I would avoid the noodles here... unless you love a grease bomb.
author: Tala D.

description: Dined here a long time ago, the dim sum was good, but not outstanding. The atmosphere is much nicer than the average hole-in-the-wall dim sum spot, but that will cost you $50pp to be somewhat full.
author: Marina C.

description: Where dim sum meets fine dining. It's a pretty penny but well worth it. Everything on the dim sum carts are worth trying at least once. I love the halibut in miso.
author: Ryan C.

description: The food is good, but they seem incapable of getting my order right. Ever. I asked for steamed ribs and I got a steamed bun today, and it's not the first time they have made errors (forgot egg roll, etc. ). If you're busy I get it. It wasn't that busy today at all. Seriously, listen to customers when they order please.
author: Rache C.

description: It's Yank Sing! Five stars! Pricey, but you definitely pay for quality here. The food is top notch. The ambiance is classy. And the servers are efficient. Reservation is also a breeze! Don't come here with a big appetite though- unless, of course, you have a big wallet to match! (I can spend $40+ here and still came home hungry!)
author: KJ S.

description: My husband and I made reservations because we knew how this place gets busy. What we didn't expect was to wait in a long line after we made open table reservations. This place should not take reservations if they still make you wait in a long line. Too many places in SF to eat at without this dishonesty.
author: Laura K.

description: I've been coming to Yank Sing since I was a baby. When people come visit me, the first place I take them is Yank Sing. It's a completely unique experience, and the best dim sum you'll find anywhere. The staff is really nice and there is always something new or interesting to try. Probably the best time spent with my family is on Sunday afternoons when we come to Yank Sing for brunch. SOooo good. It's pretty pricey though, so be careful not to grab too many dumplings off of the carts!
author: Regina L.

description: Singapore juicy dumplings, superb and I would safely say it was better than dim sum in Vancouver!
author: Rachel L.

description:
When you eat Chinese food on a regular basis, it is really difficult to muster up the appetite to crave it for lunch while you are at work. I like to spend my work lunches cheating on my ethnicity, but know that I go home everyday to Chinese food and a clear conscience. Dim sum is clearly the exception; it is comfort food to me and can be eaten any day at any time!

Luckily, we have Yank Sing right behind our building to fulfill my undying craving for dim sum. Haven't quite had the luxury yet of being able to sit down at the actual restaurant and have fresh bamboo steamers delivered tableside for me to point and choose, but for a quick lunch pickup, they have a "Yank Sing 2 Go" store just next door. The line is typically out the door (there is no room for a line here anyway) but it goes VERY quickly. The ladies here work HARD! They take your order when the person in front of you hasn't even had the chance to put their change back into their wallet and your meal is prepared while you are putting your change back in your own wallet.

You can choose from their preset list of boxes (typically includes dim sum and either rice or noodles, a huge portion!) which are about $6-7, their special of the day about $5, or order a la carte. I definitely prefer a la carte because I only want dim sum, but it adds up. A siu mai is about $1.00 and both the sesame ball & egg tart are $1 and some change. It adds up. I'm not a light dim sum eater! Other than that, my only other gripe is that they do not offer the usual staples of dim sum here so it will only give you a taste for your craving, not satisfy it. You only have about five choices and honestly, pot stickers and egg rolls do not qualify as dim sum eats to me. Where are the deep fried taro thingy and steamed meat balls; just to name a few. Sigh.

Overall, a decent place to pick up a decent priced lunch for a lot of food if you go the preset menu way, but a little risky if you go the a la carte way. I hope they expand their "2 go" menu a little more to offer a few more of the staples, I mean, they make it next door just make it available? And I see the mango pudding in the fridge behind the cashier, but it's not offered? That's cruel to a girl with a sweet tooth!
author: Stella C.

description:
I'm used to a fairly hectic and homey Dim Sum experience in Boston.  Yank Sing is a more top-shelf take on the "little carts of little plates" approach to dining.

As with most dim sum, a native speaker --- or former resident --- makes the best guide (especially for the various buns), but most dishes show their usual appearance here.  Sweet rice was probably my favorite of the day's selection, but several things were in the running.

The servers do emphasize the pricier items --- watch out for the sea bass and soup-filled dumplings in particular.  Both were OK, but I'd rather get a little more taro for my dollar.
author: Ken M.

description:
For $80 for a dim sum lunch for two, I would like sprinkled gold flakes in the already delicious xiaolongbao, a lap dance from the chef, and maybe ayce. 

None of these at Yank Sing.  

Dim sum at Yank SIng is an indulgence, especially when you're a stone's throw from other dim sum nearby in Chinatown.  Not getting an MSG attack may be worth some of the extra costs, but not completely.  

XLB are perfect here, and the peking duck is almost perfect.  Their mango pudding had me concocting my own soon after getting home.

So I would love to be taken here, but I'll be leaving my wallet at home.  In the meantime you'll probably see me at Good Luck DIm Sum on Clement, leaving with an overly full tummy $5 later.

As they say, "it's a buyer's market."
author: Joanna M.

description:
Steamed Pork Buns!!!!  (Drops the microphone....)

Ok yelp wants me to write more....
It's hard to get a table... But when you can get a table inside that's the best.
If the weather is suitable, which is all but 1-2 months of the year, there are tables on the side patio (with heat lamps) that are overflow for the table cloth inside dining room.

The dim sum carts are plentiful. The dim sum is tasty.
Be careful...it can add up. They don't tell you the price of each item as they roll by... the duck is pricy and dry. I'd pass on that.
They have a specialty item that is a dimpling that is loaded with juice. It's tasty and worth a try. Be careful when you bite into it, it is extremely full of the broth. No that I've tried it, I think I'll not need to have it on my next visit.
The garlic green beans were very good. Oh and did I mention steamed pork buns? Yum.

If you're in a hurry, they have a walk up window on the side where you can access an abbreviated menu. But it's not always fast. It can take 20 minutes from waiting in line to order, until you get your food.
author: Mike C.

description: Nice high quality dim sum, the peking duck and soup dumplings are excellent.  Some reviews call it overpriced but honestly I think while its expensive you do get what you pay for.  They serve quality dim sum which is delicious.
author: Patrick B.

description: I used to go to YangSing in Embarcadero and enjoyed so much.  Coming to this restaurant before noon while sitting outside, there were 3 carts circulating the same food.  No variety and staffs were overwhelmed with the lunch-time rush customers.  Totally a kitchen FAILURE!!!  Will not recommend or come back!
author: Lukalvin P.

description: Good if you are on a diet because you'll definitely leave hungry unless you have 6hs of your day to spend here. Service is extremely slow and they just bring the same stuff over and over again, no matter how much stuff they have on the menu
author: Gustavo S.

description: Great SF experience. It is a must-do for all tourists to the area. Don't bother looking at the menu, just choose your food from the carts that come by the table. Be choosy - there are several carts with different foods, don't pick the first one just because they tell you to. If you are on a tight budget or very hungry, go somewhere else. Otherwise, enjoy and be prepared for a $30-50/pp bill. No worries, it's all good! Delicious, in fact. Come early, as I believe they are only open for lunch and they reportedly run out of food near the end. Sit outside! No reservations there and it's great to enjoy the beautiful SF weather and people watching.
author: Anony M.

description: The Dim Sum ToGo is awesome and I highly recommend it. Great deal. Get the din sum platter from the daily special.
author: Won't B.

description:
I'm so close to giving Yank Sing 2 Go five stars. Man I love their dumplings--the ha gow are flavorful and bright with great tenderness. The dumpling wrapper has no grainy-ness to it at all. Their shumai have a nice pungent taste that compliments the scallop and/or shrimp and don't get me started on how good their veggie dumplings are.

There is one problem though: They are in such a hurry and don't completely understand English so when you try to modify your order a bit they freak out. Any time I order off-the-standard-set-menu I get overcharged or get things I didn't ask for. Be careful what you order.
author: Paul C.

description:
Okay.  It is really a 2 star review.  But you get an extra star for the business model.  Getting people to overpay for overrated food is difficult.  

Just because a place is nicely designed and serves wine, it doesn't mean it taste good.  

My non-Asian friends,
How are you suppose to know how the food REALLY taste like if you pour gallons of soy and hot sauce all over your food.  It really means IT SUCKS if you need to mask the taste.  FREAKING NOOBS.

Okay.  We waited 30 mins and got a table for six.

I didn't look at the menu and just straight order off the top of my dome.  I was freestyling my order in Cantonese.  The manager was the one taking our order.  We wanted tripe, a classic dish in dim sum.  Nope don't got it.  We order chicken feet, another staple dish.  Nope.  We tried ordering a few other favorites.  None.  The manager quietly said to me in Chinese.  Our demographics don't like that kind of stuff.  TRANSLATION.  DIMSUM FOR WHITE PEOPLE.   The manager looks down in shame.  He knew and we knew we are at the wrong place for dim sum.

Save your money folks.  But if you feel like wasting extra cash on mediocre dim sum, this is the place for you.

Great business model.   HAHAHAHAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHHAAHHA.  Take average Asian food, design a nice restaurant, buy $20 bottles of wine at bevmo, and charge $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$.
author: Norm K.

description: Came here to grab a quick lunch before a meeting downtown. This place was really good. They live up to their name, only issue is it's really pricey. $100 for 2 people for lunch. Sea Bass was melt in your mouth good, shrimp dumplings were okay, great service (for Dim Sum at least). Xiao Long Bao was good and the coconut rolls were delicious, soft and chewy. I love the outdoor seating.
author: Tiff W.

description:
I think i came here at the wrong time (~130pm). I'd heard about Yank Sing from a friend, and was surprised when i saw the 2go section on my walk to work.  i walked by it for a couple weeks and finally got a chance to try it.

I ordered the Seafood Supreme (~$8): Shrimp Dumpling, Scallop / Mushroom Dumpling, Seafood Basil Dumpling, 2 Cheese Won Ton, and an assload of veggie chow mien. 

To describe the  dim sum, applicable to all:
1) Cold
2) Dry
3) Tastes indistinguishable from the others (except for the fried cheese wontons)
4) Roughly the size of a stack of 4 quarters
5) Totes unexpected and uninspiring

In addition to that, the box breakdown is as follows; 10% dim sum, 90% tasteless and boring(not many veggies) noodles.

Plenty of places to get a tastier and more satisfying $8 plate of noodles. Ehhh...1.5 stars because I didnt have to wait in line? I still want to try the sit down restaurant sometime,...but i dont think ill ever be back to this joint, X_X.

My name is Boris Yelpsin, and I approve this message.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Dim Sum at its finest. There's always at least a 45 minute wait time but 
it's worth it. Their food is pricey but consistently delicious. The best part is if the push cart lady doesn't have what you want on her cart she'll go get it for you or tell the kitchen people to make it. Everything here comes out fresh. Enjoy
author: Eye Candy E.

description:
Yank Sing is just down a few blocks from the Palace Hotel on New Montgomery Street.  I was up at a work conference for 3 days.  We had a group show up at Yank Sing on Sunday morning around 10:30 am.  

This is a little more expensive than the typical dim sum place.  If you're looking for a So Cal, Montery Park style place with big spaces and carts all around, Yank Sing is different.  Modern scenery and decor, and you order off the menu which the wait staff then brings to you.

Food is good!  I always get chinese broccoli where ever I go.  But aside from that, I could not stop eating the sea bass and the pork buns.   

Do not hesitate unless you're seriously anal about price.  Otherwise for a great experience, attentive service, and really great dim sum, this place is a win.
author: John C.

description: Very disappointing. Got stuck sitting outside in the cold despite reservation.  Food was cold, service abominable. Treated like lepers.  Even the staff avoided going outside! Servings unimaginative.
author: Rob R.

description: Probably the best selection of Dim Sum around, they make over 100 varieties, about 50-60 different kinds each day. Also have good Cantonese food. During lunch the place is packed with business people. Service is quick and friendly. The food here is real good but not great, I have eaten better Dim Sum elsewhere, but the selection is great. Only drawback to this place is the price. Be careful and pay attention to the bill, you can eat your way to the poor-house here. And of course since it's downtown you will most likely end up in a paid parking facility.
author: Ron W.

description: Yank Sing, you rock!!!!  Amazing service by the staff & managers!!!  Thank you so much Lina & Jonathan & all the service staff!  Our party of 40 people were so impressed by your amazing service, beautiful & thoughtful set ups for our party and yummy food this morning!  We can't thank you enough!!  I've to tell you these were fancy & gourmet food lover guests we had from So. Cal.  If they're extremely pleased with your service and food, I just have to write this epic review!!  The newly weds, family & friends want to thank you from the bottom of our heart!!!  Much love!!
author: Patricia C.

description: One of my prime objectives for a vacation in San Francisco was finding top notch Dim Sum... thanks to my niece... mission accomplished. I was a little disappointed she I discovered the place she recommended wasn't even in Chinatown! How could this be authentic?! Well you can take the restaurant out of Chinatown but... you know the rest. This is spectacular we sampled and shared dish after dish and nothing disappointed! Most dishes resulted in oohs and aahs! Not inexpensive... but why would it be? Major league home run! The sticky rice was a stand out! The only small downside is the out of the way location on an alley in the financial district.
author: Robert B.

description:
Two words.  Shanghai Dumplings.  

Yes, the food is expensive, but this place has bad ass Shanghai Dumplings.  I get like 4 orders of them whenever I come because they're that good.

Everything else is good too, but not that special.  Shanghai Dumplings, very special.
author: Clifford R.

description: Cool experience for a Dim Sum newbie, so take that into consideration with this review. I've read it's pricey, but for what I had (the Shanghai pork dumplings, a half order of fried dumplings, and a massive pot of tasty tea) I didn't think it was too outrageous. It was a little more than I would usually pay for lunch ($23 vs a prefered $10-15 before tip). So for lunch I think you could eat there reasonably maybe for a little splurge. I was new to the concept of the ladies bringing the carts around, kind of cool I guess especially if you're up for going with the flow. I had no idea what I wanted and my neighbor suggested the shanghai pork dumplings. They were nice and hot, served with a light sort of soupy sauce and shaved ginger, mmm! The fried dumplings (I'll admit I don't know what they had inside) were a bit on the cooler side but still tasty. A cool place to check out but I'd be up for comparing other Dim Sum before becoming a regular here.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Setting: Dim sum for four on Sunday. I actually like this location better than the other Yank Sing because it's more intimate the folks are just all around nicer!  The hostess even takes down phone numbers and will call you when your table is ready. On this particular day, our table was ready in half he amount of time she quoted us. Win! 

Order: Shanghai dumplings, crispy Peking duck wraps, sea bass, shrimp dumplings, steamed chinese broccoli, radish cakes...What didn't we order? Actually, I do remember being disappointed that they didn't have chong fung! 

Cost: I ate to my heart's content. I was comfortably full although not stuffed.  Then I got the bill.  $48 per person. Annnnd that's why it's 4 stars not 5.
author: Janet Z.

description:
This place has really good dim sum, and we never had to wait to be seated.  The only downside is that for the two of us, we usually end up spending 80-100 bucks per meal.  Which is so unreasonable for dim sum!  But they can get away with it because it's the only real dim sum place in the area 

Every dish I've had here is so tasty.  Will definitely be coming back here even though it's pricey.
author: Mei C.

description:
Real: 4S

Food: 5S
Service: 4S
Ambiance: 4S

They serve my favorite Dim Sum. I jut think it's really over priced. A meal for 2 can easily cost  your $100 if you don't watch it.  The dim sum is really good. Lovely the mango dessert.  Enjoy.
author: Duke H.

description: This is for the "2 go"  side.  I think the last time I got the Phoenix was 3 yrs ago.   I got it today and was disappointed that they changed their noodles for the chow mein.  The skinny noodles were so much better and gave it a different taste and texture,  and now this current version just taste plain. Bring back the old recipe!! Even the fried rice is different and not as good.   I'll stick to the steamed pork buns that I love from here.
author: Bernadette C.

description: XLB excellent but even being delicious still over priced at almost $13 for 6. And the rest of the dim sum is just average and even more overpriced. If I did come back, I would ONLY get the XLB and nothing else. The skin is super thing and tender, and the dumpling packs a lot of yummy porky juciy goodness. =) I cringed as I watched a table next to us of obvious XLB newbs, they were yanking the dumplings off the tray and all the juice just spilled out. Again, come here for XLB, save your dim sum money on somewhere else.
author: Diana Y.

description: It pains me to give these guys a 3 star rating, but there are a few of things (both good and bad) that makes the net effect being a 3.  I first discovered Yank Sing before I moved to SF about 5 or 6 years ago when I came up to visit with my family from LA.  There was a HUGE group of us, and the overall experience was amazing.  Fastforward now to the last year and half, where Yank Sing is now right behind where I work, and where I'll go to splurge on dim sum. When my mom comes up to visit, she always asks to go to Yank Sing, so I've been here about 3 or 4 times within the last year.  In any case, this place is REALLY pricey for things that will cost a fraction up the street in Chinatown.  One of my trips to Yank Sing with my cousin and her boyfriend resulted in a tab that was about $115.  That being said, there are a few items that well worth the price.  The duck taco w/ plum sauce and scallion is absolutely AMAZING.  I get excited just writing about it.  The other thing that is amazing are the Shanghai dumplings.  My mom claims that they're the best she's had in the US, second to only what we got in Shanghai.  Everything else, (ie. shu mai, har gow, baos, potstickers, spare ribs, sesame balls, mango pudding, etc) is good, but something you could probably get for cheaper in Chinatown.  The other thing that is a pain about this place is that it is REALLY small, so there's always a line.  I'd expect to wait a good 25-35 minutes on a Sunday afternoon if you don't time it just right.  That being said, my mom is coming up to visit in a few weeks, and has already requested a trip to Yank Sing.
author: Lisa I.

description: The best!  I was there on a recent trip to San Francisco and I can't stop thinking about this place. I live just outside NYC and there's nothing even close to yang sing around. The staff at yank sing were soooo helpful. They helped me figure out how to eat the soup dumplings by pouring vinegar on the dumpling on my spoon. Their salad is a can't miss and their pork buns are simply the best. I can't wait until I get back to San Fran so I can go their again.
author: Diana P.

description: Stevenson is a great smaller venue, cozy & comfortable.  The food is great as is the service.
author: Nathaniel H.

description: Some of he best dim sum in San Francisco. Highly suggest sitting down for lunch so you get the full effect of the carts coming around and choosing the dim sum. Otherwise, the to go side is also outstanding. Recommend the eggplant beef special, steamed pork buns, chicken salad. Really hard to go wrong here.
author: Sydney F.

description: This is my favorite dim sum in SF.  Bring on the food!  Go there hungry, because you will get fed!  We barely sat down and immediately they came over to feed us.  We left there with our waist line much tighter.  Pure Gluttony
author: Lily S.

description:
Well, the first time I ate here about 4 years ago it was really good and worthy of the elevated price tag.  Just ate here about a month ago and everything became mediocre.  Seriously, very mediocre.  The xlb's were still excellent, but all the other standard dim sum fare was extremely average.  It's the type of dim sum that I'd expect to pay $2-4 per item for.  Obviously, the bill had a different opinion of this place than I did.

Go to City View instead.  It's worth the walk for better food and (slightly) better prices.
author: J S.

description:
You get a lot for your money when it comes to cheap Chinese food.  It's no better than panda express, but it'll do when you're in the mood for some Chinese.

I ordered the express combo, which comes with a heap of chowmein, egg roll, pot sticker, and pork bun for about $7 after tax.  It's more food than you'll want to eat in a meal, and all of it is tasty enough to want to finish. 

Chow mein - good flavor but the noodles felt too dense, as if they had been made too long ago and had been sitting for a while.

Egg roll - solid.  I should have asked for hoisin sauce though

Pot sticker - really tasty, and next time I might order an extra.

Pork bun - The pork was delicious, and the bun was a good compliment, but it's too much bun.  I ended up scooping out the meat into the chow mein so I didn't have to eat too much of the bun.  When you have this much other food, you don't want to fill yourself up on bread.
author: Dave S.

description: Delish, delish. I hadn't been here in awhile but Yank Sing continues to please. Had the soup dumplings which were amazing...my guest who is a soup dumpling connoisseur said they were far better than any she had tasted...even better than those in Shanghai. The waiter Tony was also very friendly and helpful.
author: Gillian Dawson Y.

description: i ordered at the yank sing 2 go. the cashier could literally not understand a word of english.  struggle is real
author: Leslie M.

description: Dim sum here is delicious and fresh. Since I don't eat pork, I'm happy they have several no pork options.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Really, 2.5 stars

When people say this place is an obscure location down an alley, it is exactly the best description for the location of Yank Sing. What I like about this place is they have a to go area separated from the sit down dining. If you are a student or business person on a short lunch break, this is definitely one of those places that will fit the bill for your time crunch.

The to go menu is select and MSG is prevalent in their cooking, sobe warned the food is just mediocre especially the to go menu. I myself just stick with the pork bun, which again is mediocre at best. What they fail at with cooking, they sure make up for it with quick, emotionless service, classic Asian restaurant mentality, and affordable prices.

Come here for convenience, do not go out of your way.
author: Richard K.

description: Because I didn't want to drive and was craving for dim sum, so I decided to give this place a try since it was within walking distance. Oh boy, the bill came out to be $60+ just for less than five items. Was it worth it? No! The food was just mediocre compare to other dim sum restaurants. Why the price is so high? It's right in financial district and it caters to most working business men and women. Not a good place to bring your whole family. If you really want to enjoy some good dim sum and don't want to break your wallet, then go somewhere else.
author: Cindy T.

description:
I'm a fan of their sit down dim sum service which pays much attention to detail to ensure the discretionary purchase of every cart item.  Sadly, the same care is not put into their quick 2 Go front which tastes on par with other subpar Chinese fast food joints in the FiDi.  Their service is crazy  fast for take out, but the cost is quality degradation.

Spring Roll: Crispy, which is a good thing, because soggy spring rolls suck.  A little bit much on the cabbage, but the ground meat (pork?) added some good contrast.  Overall, too greasy.
 
Pot Sticker: Pork and scallion.  Disliked that the fried bottom was not crispy, a sign that it had been awhile since it saw the pan.

Steamed Pork Bun: Overly bready.  The meat was in short supply, small pieces and had that funky day old BBQ taste.

Siu Mye: Heavy on the shrimp which is always a plus.  Slightly cold which made the texture too dense.

Chicken in Foil: Nice marinade, very salty and soy intensive.  The meat was tough and just the fatty dark meat sections.  Normally not a fan of that cut, but it worked well as a small bite here.

Custard Tart: Really flaky crust, good job!  The center was warm and custardy, I sure hate when egg custard is cold and like jello.
author: Adam B.

description: Food was really good and they were very responsive with service. The sea bass was particularly delicious as were the sesame balls- the best I have ever had. Careful how crazy you go with taking food from the carts. It is really expensive for dim-sum. I think you can get equally good dim-sum for a much better price. The advantage Yank Sing had was convenience. We were able to make reservations on open table and easily able to find a time that suited us for Sunday brunch. That's why I would go again.
author: Jack S.

description: Overpriced    Went to Stevenson st  .  Tables all jamed in. Other site better atmosphere .  Our 4 th time this year.  Going to look for other options in future
author: Rob M.

description: This is comparable to the white dinner cloth restaurants I have visited in China. The dim sum was very good; similar in taste. I love picking off the carts, and thankfully this restaurants does this approach. The staff is friendly and definitely tries to sell the food, another aspect of China, which made me smile. I would recommend this spot for a first timer, or at least to give this place a try, and then go into Chinatown and find a small mom and pop dim sum shop.
author: Jac H.

description: Food was good. Only thing is to watch how they charge you extra if you are not watching. They were busy by over charging and charging for stuff we did not get is not acceptable at any restaurant. The lady seemed a little irritated that I asked why certain charges and she had to go back and fix the bill.
author: Pree K.

description: A little on the expensive side, but always delicious.
author: Mel G.

description:
This place makes me angry. Angry that I've discovered San Francisco has better dim sum than Los Angeles (San Gabriel, to be exact). As a matter fact, there was something about that meal, on that particular day, at that particular time, that made it the best dim sum. I. Ever. Had. 

This place was a bit difficult to locate. There's a reason why there were a few signs out on the sidewalk. It's located in a shopping center inside a building past a fountain. 

The decor and smell was definitely reminiscent of your traditional Chinese Dim Sum restaurant. The Jasmine tea came out in a very pleasant-looking clear teapot. There was also plenty of Chinese hot mustard and garlic hot sauce to go around, which is crucial to this meal. We ordered multiple servings of  Siu-Mai, chicken feet, black bean spare ribs, and Har Gows among other things. Each and every dish was extremely tasty and fresh. Something about it just made it that much better than the countless other places I've tried in the San Gabriel Valley. It's like I was trying Dim Sum for the very first time. 

The place was not extremely packed, but there was a good amount of people. After all, it was a Wednesday. The lunch crowd started to usher in as we were about to leave, so I assume that would be a much busier time for them. This visit has made it a mandatory stop whenever I'm in the city. It was really one of the highlights on the wonderful trip to SF.
author: Randolph L.

description: Been coming here for years.  Good dim sum, but it's pricy.  Pot stickers and sautéed string beans are my favorite.
author: R S.

description: Was back in the bay to cheer my wife on at the Nike Half Marathon so the first thing on our list was a trip back to Yank Sing.  A close two block walk from our hotel.  As good as ever!  We had about 5 orders of dumplings, a couple more of steamed pork bao and a sampling of other steamed dumplings.  I could have stayed there all day eating but we had a plane to catch.
author: Mike S.

description: The dim sum was not as impressive as people claim it to be. The selection was small and some of the dim sum was nothing too special. The shanghai dumplings were pretty good though. meh. For the price, they could've done better!
author: Annie Z.

description:
Won't go there again. The waitress, young, thin and wearing glasses, is so rude and impatient. I guess that is some sort of discrimination, as she seems to care more about other customers. I am not sure if that has anything to do with race.

The food... not so much, to my taste. That is likely because it is adapted to cater to local community. I heard the one close to the bay is more original.
author: Li K.

description:
I'd grabbed a large takeout order from the Rincon Center incarnation of Yank Sing during our last trip and noticed the carts laden with bamboo trays wandering the dining area. We'd vowed to do that version of the dim sum experience on this trip. And it is quite the experience.

We arrived about an hour before closing, so there crowd was spare. Our table was literally descended upon by cart after cart filled with dumplings, fried items, and other food. Our only request during the meal, baked BBQ pork buns, had sold out earlier in the day, unfortunately. But there was plenty of other choices.

The meal was fast. It probably took us longer to walk to the restaurant than it did to eat. It's easy to see how this kind of dining would be popular for a busy lunch crowd. It's also easy to see how it could quickly become expensive for people interested in trying one of everything: our meal was no cheaper here than at Wayfare or any of the other higher end establishments we visited, and I certainly didn't get the feeling like I'd been any more copiously fed than I had elsewhere.

And I have to admit that, having done both now, ordering off the menu is probably my preference. I felt like I got more of what I wanted that way, and didn't feel as likely to make a $10 mistake like the shrimp balls we ended up with. It's my fault, really, since I was blithely pointing at things that looked good without looking at a price list or asking. But having a menu in front of me to order from would have definitely avoided the issue.

My favorite dish was the Shanghai Dumpling which featured minced Kurobuta pork and a small splash of broth encased in a dumpling. The waitress was kind enough to walk us through the traditional way to eat it, and it was outstanding. Probably should have stuck with a plate full of those.
author: Ryan C.

description:
I am a fan of this place and eat here as often as i can, even Christmas day as it has become a tradition with us. My favorite pre baseball game lunch.
Everything here is top notch. Seafood dim sum with basil - killer, the pork buns - exceptional, shrimp and cilantro my favorite.
The carts come fast and furious, just take your time and enjoy,
Tony has been our waiter several times and we really like him.
Enjoy.
author: Curtis H.

description: Go eat and enjoy. Lettuce cups with so much attention to detail they trim the edges in a pattern. Hubby's fav was the spring rolls I loved the chicken lettuce cups. It's all good. Just go. Oh and eat lots of the chili pepper sauce.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Let me be clear, the four star rating is only for the baked pork bun because that is the only thing I have ever ordered.

After seeing all my coworkers come back with one of these massive pork buns, I decided to try one myself. The bun did not disappoint and no one in my office has gone for Yank Sing for lunch without taking multiple requests for baked pork buns. For $1.80 I think this is a must-try.
author: JC C.

description: I was craving dim sum for some time so when my hubby suggested yank sing I was all in. We sat down at our table and within 2 min we had grabbed everything we wanted off the carts. Talk about service! The downsides to this place are they don't have rice noodles and it is the most expensive dim sum I have ever had in my entire life! We had the basics, sticky rice x2, har gow, siu mai, chinese greens, and one other dish and the total came out to $92!
author: Grace M.

description:
Definitely an indulgence (calorie indulgence) but the food is good! I like the veggie potstickers, the eggplant and the veggie chowmein/noodles. Very quicks ervice too! 

Definitely a good option to have at lunch time!
author: Sapna E.

description:
Food was excellent, crispy duck in the bread roll was beyond awesome. Service is fast and lots of dim sum at all times - we even custom ordered something and it came out within a few minutes. 

The real issue with the place is that it was offensively expensive. But it was damn good. Enjoy
author: Chuck R.

description: A bit pricey, but definitely on the better side of dim sum quality... Also tons of space, so waiting isn't a huge problem. The waiters were also great at reading clueless expressions and giving instructions on how to tackle awkwardly shaped pieces for awkward people like myself...
author: Mitch B.

description: This was the highlight of our trip. Great dimsum. Pricey (180 for 4) but worth it. Spectacular duck. Tea was so good we bought some to take home. Loved the soup dumplings. Will definitely be back.
author: Jorge G.

description:
Food: A
Service: C - fast, aggressive, put dim sum down on table without asking permission.  When you sit down, be READY.
Atmosphere: Outside -B+ Inside- B
Price: C, expensive 

Best to go with 3-4 people so you can share more items.
author: JM H.

description: Yank Sing is very close to my work. The noodles are not great, but the spicy sauce is wonderful. The sea bass is good, but maybe a little to pricey. Overall i like the lunch atmosphere, especially, sitting outside.
author: Wansu L.

description: For Chinese fast food, this is our place to go whenever we are in the city. All are pretty good but the green bean is my favorite. Now sure how they did it, but somehow they put together a sophisticated taste and a crunchy texture. Even the carnivores in my family liked it.
author: Jing W.

description:
Not having soup/salad/sandwich for lunch? Yes please.  There's not a ton of good variety in SOMA area for lunch so I was excited to put something different in my belly. 

There is a togo area where you can go up to the counter and order- you better know the names of everything because no pictures but its the general stuff- pork bun, pot stickers, har gow, etc. 

You can order 2-4 pieces of dim sum or combinations. 

I got the vegetable combination that came with 2 veggie dumplings, eggplant with hunan sauce and chow mein.  I also ordered har gow which came in 4 pieces and that was 12 dollars.  They accept card. 

Har Gow- yummy
Vegetable dumplings- a little too salty
Chow Mein- super dry
Eggplant- tasty 

Its busy but these ladies are quick!

If you want to eat there they have the ladies pushing the carts too which is legit.
author: Anya R.

description:
3 Stars definitely underrates this place. 

Yank Sing 2 Go is clear-and-away the best place for a takeout Chinese meal downtown. They move extremely quickly, it's very inexpensive, the portions are large, and the food itself is delicious. 

Great:
Baozi
Dumplings
Portions
Price
Speed

Fine:
Egg Roll
Shu Mai
Fried Rice
author: Alex L.

description:
Yummy dim sum!  That's all we can say.  Went on a rainy San Francisco sunday morning, and must have timed it just right because we got seated right away, but by the time we were finished it was absolutely packed. 

Everything was very good, the dumplings were all very tasty and seemed very fresh compared to a lot of other dim sum places we have visited.  The sea bass is as good as everyone says too.

The Spear St. location is much bigger and has a better atmosphere, but this location was fine considering its proximity to our hotel.
author: Frank W.

description:
I've never had dim sum here but I've been to two weddings that were situated in the lobby of the building where Yank Sing is located. 

Both weddings were wonderful and the food was delicious! The ambience of the lobby is perfect for a Chinese banquet-style wedding with high ceilings and a ceiling-to-floor waterfall. We hired lion dancers for one of the weddings and there was a lot of space for them to perform. 

I don't really remember every dish we had (it was probably about 10 courses!) but I do remember the chilean sea bass that stood out like a shining star! So delicious! The banquet dinner also came with mango pudding, which was a delicious alternative to the usual red bean dessert soups. 

Although I don't want to copy the same concept as my relatives, I would seriously consider having my wedding banquet here as well!
author: Stephanie L.

description: We usually dine at Rincon, but the Yank Sing Cafe was as delicious as the main restaurant!  The Shanghai dumplings are always a must, but you really can't go wrong with anything you order here.  Very attentive service and there was no wait at all (especially if you have larger parties and make a reservation).
author: Rayne S.

description: Amazing dim sum. Their baked pork buns are to die for...basically like eating a meat donut. More pricey than most dim sum places but well worth it.
author: Natalie H.

description:
I had high hopes for this place when I visited SF with some friends. For one, I love dim sum and this place has rave reviews.

The wait wasn't long the day I was in SF (a Sunday) but we got there a bit early. We were seated immediately and food starting showing up as soon as we started settling in. We had the xiao long bao (of course) and Yank Sing definitely does them very well. It was probably the best part of the meal. We also had an assortment of other typical dim sum food, but I don't have a very strong impression of them as it was just average compared to many other dim sum places. 

When the bill finally came out, it was about $40 for each person. I thought it was quite expensive for dim sum, especially since we were careful and restrained from the higher priced items. I was not full at the end of the meal. Also, parking is a problem for that area so you have to add the cost of parking garages to the meal. 

Overall, I thought the food was decent and a dish or two were particularly good. But it wasn't amazing and the value of the meal falls short of its cost.
author: Jean H.

description:
There seems to be a lot of controversy about this place. It's either the best thing you've ever tasted or the biggest and most despicable, unauthentic and overrated establishment you've ever stepped foot in.

Price? Should dim sum really be this expensive? My guess is that a lot of people working in this neighborhood (or if you can afford going to school around the corner at Golden Gate University) don't seem to mind. They can and do get away with charging this much, and people still flock here and to YS's other location again and again. Get over it, people.

Appearance? Does cleanliness scare you? An immaculate dining room doesn't always denote good food, but it's a good indication of such.

Taste? For these one star reviews, does the price just turn you off so much that the food isn't worthy of any higher rating? Or it's just so far from more "true" dim sum it just tastes bad? I think their dim sum is fantastic and high quality (Shanghai dumplings, FTW), and though it's not the norm, it's purposefully that way. It's aimed to be upscale dim sum. And I will eat all of it. Preferably on some one else's tab.

Fin.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
Very tasty. Great Dim Sum. Now that that's out of the way...

Dim Sum places freak me out a little bit. It's like a Chinese food flea market except you stay still and the merchandise comes to you. The thing that's freaky is that the moment the cart rolls up, they are WORKING IT. If you're lucky, they'll stop, you point at something, ask what it is and then say yes or no.

Yank sing has some pretty brazen ladies on the carts. They make those women offering fragrance samples at Nordstrom seem positively disinterested. It's insane. Sometimes, they'd just drop stuff on the table, stamp our card and walk away without a word. They MUST work on commission. 

One woman actually popped a seabass dumpling into her mouth and,  before I could protest, fed me like a mother bird . 

OK, I made that up. But still, it was close.

And at the end, there's the card with little stamps and you get a bill for $120 for 3 people. How can you possibly know what you ordered?

"Excuse me, I think this star with the circle around it shouldn't be on the bill."

Anyway, it's expensive but tasty and they do serve Anchor Steam beer so who's complaining.
author: Brian B.

description:
A semi-secluded location in downtown SF. It's popular with downtown office workers. Clean place and elegant decor. Yes, it's expensive. Definitely not the best dim sum, but the food is decent and the place is nice enough for a pleasant business lunch.

Note: This review is only for the sit-down restaurant, not the To-Go section that serves a cheap lunch menu, which is not of the same caliber.
author: Luis C.

description:
After getting used to cheap dim sum, the price tag at Yank Sing can be a bit startling. But for a clean, delicious helping of excellent dim sum, I know of no better. This is, of course, assuming that you are not planning to drive to Daly City for the endless wait/gorgeous food at Koi Palace.

I vastly prefer this location to the one in Rincon Center.
author: Miriam W.

description: my favorite dim sum in SF. xiao long bao on par with din tai fung. char siu bao, snow pea shoot dumpling, sticky rice, and peking duck were all excellent. restaurant decor and service were top notch. lena the hostess is super friendly.
author: Jamie C.

description:
The food here was quite delish. No doubt about it, they know what they are doing in the kitchen.

The place itself is sardine city -- and man-oh-man they pack the people in. But in doing so, they aren't very good at making sure everyone is offered dishes or can be reached or even see the carts. I totally would have ordered more if they approached me or within speaking distance for me to ask for something. Also, as people are seated and leave, be prepared to be bumped into because there is practically zero room between tables. 

Service, as in many dim sum places, is lacking. Couldn't get anyone to refill the water glass. And trying to get someone's attention to prep the bill was a challenge. 

And for all of that, expect to pay top dollar. I ordered three small dishes and my bill was just over $30. The food was good - but not *that* good. 

I'm glad I had a chance to check them out, but don't think I need to come back.
author: HAnne D.

description:
I love this place because there are *lots* of vegetarian dim sum options (not usually the case in many places).  Can you say pea shoot dim sum?  Super yum!  Yes, it's a little pricer, but I think it's worth it.

And, they have a cheaper "fast food" window around the side of the restaurant where you can go and grab a yummy lunch if you work downtown.  So nice!
author: Cassidy P.

description:
I had lunch here with some friends on the 4th of July. You can always rely on the Chinese to keep their restaurants open on every holiday when most places would be closed. 
Arriving a few minutes before our 4 top reservation we were promptly seated. Almost before my butt landed on my chair the first round of dim was offered. We would have preferred to have beers first but they did not arrive until the second round of dim sum arrived. This place moves real fast and they are a little pushy like used car salesman. I could hear in my head the chef shouting to the servers (in your best Chinese accent) "you chinese whore you come back with empty cart"!!!
The manager Tony stopped by and recommend a beer made in Beijing called Yanjing. It was so light and refreshing I will be finding a few cases for summer drinking! Tony has a good sense of humor as I took the opportunity to mess with him a bit and he was a lot of fun. 
It turned out all the items we ordered were just fantastic especially the dim sum that included shrimp. It was so, so fresh to be mistaken for lobster. I put some of there chile sauce on my shrimp dumplings and a splash of soy and my eyes nearly rolled back in my head. The pork buns were equally euphoric. I don't usually order stuffed mushrooms but these looked so good we went for it and were really happy with them. The tab was $120 +tip for four people. I think that is really fair for how good everything was.  
All in all a great lunch. Try it out folks
author: Raymond L V.

description:
The world doesn't need another Yank Sing review, but I need to put this on my list for visitors, so...
If you visit us in SF, we're taking you here. Great dim sum, including Peking duck by the slice. They offer some vegetarian dumplings, although this is not a place I take friends with food restrictions, other than those who are lactose intolerant, since there aren't any dishes with dairy in them (except maybe the custard tart). This branch on Stevenson is walking dist from the Moscone convention center in SOMA. 

The YS on Spear has validated parking, so it is our go to restaurant on our way to and from SFO. It is NOT close to SFO, but is is convienent to go there on our way in and out of SF, especially when we fly in famished and need to eat NOW (mmm, wheeled carts full of dumplings...)
author: Vena V.

description:
Mmmmmm! Perfectly cooked dim sum morsels, great service and fast (can easily finish within the lunch hour). Its high-end dim sum so its catered to more American taste (not as authentic) but boyyy is it good! Make reservations and be prepared to sit with the suits for lunch. Lunch from $30-40 a head.

Likes: Shimp Hao Gao, Fried Taro, Xiao Long Bao, Sea Bass and Egg Tarts are the bomb here
author: Amy S.

description:
I'm not sure why there are such bad reviews here.  If you go, there is a TON of people who go here to get food, so this tells me that the masses do like this place.  The thing is, you never see the massive lines like at Chipotle.  You know why?  Because they asian ladies are much more efficient than Chipotle and get your food fast.  

Don't argue with me that Chipotle is faster with the comment that when you make your order, you would get your food faster through the assembly line.  That's a garbage arguement because if you include the amount of waiting time in-line at Chipotle, Yank Sing 2 Go is leagues ahead in speed.  

Another yelper here was complaining about the order system and confused about the call number.  Look at your damn receipt.  It says "CALL NO.: XXX".  I mean, how dumb can you get?  Never once has the worker messed orders up.  It would only be the customer's fault.  

Now back to the food.  You get a ton of food if you order one of their set combos.  No matter what, it will be too much for you to eat.
