I find it hilarous that people are complaining about too much food.  When you see how cheap the prices are, why are some of you complaining about too much food?  Nobody's forcing you to eat all of it, fatty.  

It is too much food for me, but you know what?  They have a smaller combo option displayed right at the cashier.  A: Pork chow mein + 4 potstickers or B: Fried rice + 2 shui mai + 2 fried wontons.  Either is for $4.95.  And either will make you filled (A will be more filling than B because the noodles are more densly packed and potstickers are huge).

Now in terms of quality, it's probably at the top in the financial district vs. other chinese take-out places.  Is it greasy?  The noodles are, but it's not as greasy as other chinese take-out places.  So it's pretty normal in that respect.

To sum it up:  Value (lots of food for price), super-fast and tasty.  You'll see so many people come here during lunch time.  Obviously there's something good going on here.
author: Jon K.

description:
Good environment, but dirty inside. Not worth for $30+ 

After I finished my meal, I find small hair on my chopsticks. I told the waitress, and guessed it might came from the chili sauce, because we don't know where was it comes from. They just exchange it and give me a new chili sauce.

If you think it is done? No!!!!!

I ask for a spoon. Yes, they give me a new tea spoon. But we find it is not clean and look likes they don't wash it. Because there is a dry food on it. The residue is very big and obvious!!!!!!!!! I told the waitress to about it. They just give me a new one, too.

Until we leave the restaurant, they don't give us any compensation.

It is a worst experience. If it is a low end restaurant, like $10 per person, I won't be in anger. We paid around $90 for 3 people, but get this service????? We won't be there again.
author: Chengwei C.

description:
I went here for Deem Sum with my boyfriend this past weekend and it was AMAZING.  Everything we ate was delicious, the staff was very nice (you have to be assertive with the cart operators though), and the place itself is well appointed enough.  

Definitely get tea, it's a huge pot, but it's very tasty and fresh, and the steamed pork buns.  Their steamed pork buns are like eating clouds filled with perfectly sweet and salty BBQ-ed pork, I could have eaten many many more than I actually did.  

I am so happy to have found this place, especially considering that I go to school next door and they have a "to go" part of the restaurant. Go on an empty stomach, eat heartily, enjoy!
author: Alexandra H.

description:
I could never afford to come here myself so I had to wait till I was invited to a banquet, and oh my gosh was it DELICIOUS. Every single dish was so perfect. Sorry I can't give you more details, I am still delirious.
p.s. I didn't have dim-sum. It was fancy stuff off the menu.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Went here for lunch with a friend.  Good consistent and clean restaurant.  Not great but good consistent dim sum.

Service is not bad either
author: Bill L.

description:
If you are staying for FREE at the Ritz-Carlton (because you are working a meeting) and you ask the concierge where the best Dim Sum is, don't expect him to tell you somewhere inexpensive.

My bad.

It was delicious but we only had 2 things because it was definitely not the price point we were expecting.  Should have known.

It's worth checking out if you don't have a budget but thanks to my annoying dog who eats anything (prolly even pricey dim sum), I now have a budget that doesn't include $12 dim sum dishes.

The food is fresh & the service is prompt if not pushy.
author: Emily S.

description: A bit expensive, but the dim sum is very well-made. Most of the wrapped foods don't have a lot of excess wrappings so you don't have a lot of wasted portions when you eat here. The big problem with this place is the service is pretty bad. Depending on where you sit, you might get skipped A LOT as the carts empty up from other tables and you have to be a bit forceful if you want something in this case. My table for example only got tagged by 4 carts in 45 minutes which is a bit irritating when you come hungry or if you don't know exactly what to order unless they tell you about it or know it by sight.
author: Derek B.

description:
What you're paying for when you go to either Yank Sings' is the table cloth service. It's super over priced dimsum that caters to the business crowd or tourists. When I came here earlier today, I was a bit surprised to see that we were one of the 3 Asian tables there with the rest of the patrons being Caucasians. I have definitely had as good or even better at much cheaper dimsum restaurants and only go to this Yank Sing at the behest of my friend who is a big fan of Yank Sing.

The service isn't any better than any other dimsum restaurant IMO. We were having to wave down our server a few times to repeatedly inquire about the status of our order. The dimsum selection is pretty limited which is probably another reason why the Asian clientele is lacking here. Pricey, mediocre and limited dimsum selection are reasons why I steer clear of Yank Sing.
author: Soozie H.

description: They easily overcharge you. Keep track of the dimsum you order!. Found a big error on the bill and they corrected it but not sure if it was a simple mistake or not. The food is ok but overpriced.
author: Xteethx B.

description: Love this place.... Great spot for lunch in San Francisco.
author: Kevin R.

description:
Went here after trying to go to Brenda's French Soul Food and Dottie's True Blue Cafe - both packed and a no-go, esp after walking around the city to each location for 2.5 miles. Came here since it was close to our Hotel and this ended up hitting the spot. Thought they could do better on variety and pricing is way expensive for dim sum, but there were a few standouts:

-Shanghai Dumplings - of course, I've had better in Taiwan, but these are some of the better ones in the states. The dumplings have the broth inside and so yummy!

-The sticky rice in lotus wrap - also some of the better ones i've had - the meat inside is super flavorful and saucy within the rice

-steamed pork bun - they kind of skimp on the bbq pork, but the outside bread is nice and fluffy. very good.

-Green onion pancake - this was the highlight. I've never had green onion pancake quite like this; it's flaky and pastry-like; not flat and panfried as i'm used to. You dip it in a peanut butter chili sauce which was unusual but super good. Truly unique.

I would come back just to get the rice wrapped in lotus wrap, dumplings and ESPECIALLY green onion pancake. Just be careful bc they try to upsell you by walking around with an $18 piece of seabass! So easy to just say yes, not realizing how much it costs. Just be prepared to pay double or almost triple than what you would normally pay at a traditional dim sum place.
author: Erica L.

description: Not very good service, poor selection, and way overpriced. There are much better dim sum restaurants in the city that have a better, fresher variety and about half as expensive. For three people it was about $120 and we didn't even have that much to eat. Had to wait until they brought around certain entries. Some dishes were not even edible. Would highly recommend you find another dim sum place.
author: Cheryl C.

description:
When I was in SF this past week my family and I wanted to make sure we got some really good dim sum. Sure, there are dim sum in OC everywhere, but its just not the same or so I heard). 

One of the plus's of this place is they take reservation, which helps when you re traveling with a big group like i was. Many places in Sf do not take reservation and I was surprised that this place does for dim sum.

My family and I got a variety of items to try...like:
-Shanghai dumplings: very good and flavorful
-BBQ pork dumplings: tastes very fresh and the dough was fluffy!
-siu mai: fresh and yummy
-har gaw: my fave dim sum item! 
-Peking duck: I LOVE Peking duck and they pull a cart around and cut the duck table side for you and you can get as many as you want! Very nice presentation!
-String beans: I know its just string beans but my family and I couldn't get over how good they were. Very good flavor!
-Orange jello: so simple but such a clever idea!

This was probably the best dim sum I have ever had. Everything tastes very fresh and I didn't had food coma like how I usually do after eating the dim sum around here. Its pricier than most dim sum spots, but totally worth it!
author: Phuong K.

description:
Food was fabulous for dim sum.  Everything fresh.

Few of the staff members spoke English so if (we did on a few since I was warned it was pricey) you ask for a price, the laugh and walk away..  Maybe they did speak English.  There is a price menu but not on every table and wasnt on mine.

If it wasnt double what i expected it would have gotten 4 or maybe 5 stars but cant dismiss how they gouge you.  Tea was $6.

If youre there on a vacation, you should try it.  If you live there, its tough to do often.
author: S C.

description:
Love Yank Sing. Love your Shanghai pork dumplings. I can keep eating your xio lung bo forever. Love your sauce -pickled ginger vinegar. 

Other dishes are also great. I would also recommend spring rolls. 

It might be a bit expensive for lunch, but you can get what you paid. 
Food are great, the service is nice and the decor is far prettier than other Chinese!
author: Heidi M.

description: Small portions and overpriced. If you want to sit for your dim sun, New Asia is better and probably cheaper too.
author: Chau T.

description:
I am a huge fan of Yank Sing.  Although it is expensive, they have the best soup dumplings, sticky rice and chili bean paste.  I also love the shu mai.  If I go alone, this is all I eat.  I buy the chili bean paste to take home because I love it that much.  

I usually go to the Rincon location, but yesterday I went to the Stevenson location.  Maybe it was on an off day, but it was not as good as the Rincon location.  The soup dumplings were not piping hot.  And, when I ordered the fried wontons (which I do only when feeling particularly decadent) they came out right away.  They were fried some time before, not very crisp and stuck together from sitting around for awhile.  When I order these at the Rincon location, they take forever, but the wontons are fried just for me, which makes them awesome.  The ones yesterday were definitely not as good.  

It also took forever to get get the check and pay.  Much slower than Rincon.  The outdoor seating area is a bonus, though, when the weather is nice.  For all of these reasons, I give the Stevenson location three stars, while I would give the Rincon location 4 stars.
author: Amber B.

description: I went to the smaller location (I think in the Financial District? I'm from Chicago) and it was amazing.  This was seriously the most delicious dim sum I've ever had, and I come from a Chinese family.  Yes, it is absolutely more expensive than other places, but the quality is top-notch.  Every dumpling was crammed full of delicious shrimp, crab, or whatever other kind of meat.  The xiao long bao were the best I have ever had (not usually a fan but they were great) and the dan tat was also incredible--amazing flaky pastry, slightly warm from the oven! I highly recommend, especially for a special occasion (we were celebrating a medical school graduation).  Because we were at the smaller location it was nice and quiet, and they had no problem accommodating our party of 13.
author: Meredith E.

description: This is the best dim sum in the SF area.  The quality is on par with the best dim sum resturants in Hong Kong or the "626" San Gabriel Valley area.  (Don't know the 626 area? Look at this vid from the Fung Brothers and Jason Chen: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3n3HQ9uge0g) It is a bit pricey but well worth it.
author: Lauren L.

description: Rarely will you see an Asian eat here because no person knowledgeable about Asian cuisine will ever justify the outrageous prices for dim sum. This place truly defeats the whole purpose of dim sum which should be cheap and quick. Will never waste my money here again.
author: Yunah R.

description:
First Class Dim Sum.......great food, great service. Again FIRST CLASS.

Pay to play. For the cheapsters...head off to Irving or Clement Street or better yet....head to SJ....I really don't waana hear your yelp when you get your  bill.
author: Matsuo U.

description: I went there because of the 1k+ reviews for the restaurant itself. I got the veggie delight but there was nothing delightful about it. The food is extremely extremely "blah....". I think Panda Express does a similar or better job (esp. PE eggplant tofu tastes better than the eggplant side here). The dumplings were the only better (mind you, just better not best) of all. All in all, I won't come back here.
author: Winee H.

description: This was my first Dim Sum.  Its a great way to be introduced to asian food.  My absolute favorite was the Soup Dumplings!  They are a must try!!!!I could have eaten these all day long!  I also had the mango pudding for dessert.  I loved it, but its not quite the texture that most are used to in pudding.  Its alot more firm and can have almost a grainy feel to it.  The pot stickers were amazing and the BBQ pork buns were pretty good.  Warning: This place is pretty pricey!  The service and quality of the food make it worth it for a special treat.
author: Christi K.

description: they no longer have chili oil, they said they wouldn't carry that any more. only the vietnamese hot sauce. drops them from passible. What kind of dim sum place doesn't have hot chili oil? are they trying to be Szechuan Panda?
author: Dean N.

description: Yank Sing was my first experience with dim sum, so I don't have a whole lot to compare it to within its category. As a dining experience in general, it was worthwhile. The moment we sat down at our table, we were greeted with various dishes of dumplings, shrimp, crab cakes, etc. It was slightly overwhelming, but we were starved so we couldn't complain. We tried something like 15 dishes, so we got a wide range of flavors, textures, etc. I can't remember all of the dishes, but a few that stood out were the potstickers, scallions, and pecan shrimp. The servers were all very sweet and attentive. I hope my future experience with dim sum are half as nice as Yank Sing.
author: Nikki I.

description: I love this place, but why aren't the pan fried chicken buns on the menu anymore?! Those were one of their best items!
author: Mike S.

description:
We can't say much about this place that hasn't been said already. Food is good and somewhat interesting. The ambiance is fantastic, especially if you sit outside. 

However, what keeps this place from being great is the price. You can get great dim sum without all the hype. Yank Sing and Koi Palace need to get brought back down to reality. C'mon peoples-- you know when you've been played! Yank Sing knows that its clientele has a lot of non-Asians, so they inflate the prices. We wouldn't be surprised if Yank Sing opened up a series of chain dim sum joints like P.F. Chang's.

Oh snap, we said it.
author: Kel S.

description:
All I can say is that their sauce is awesome! 
Went on a Saturday at noon and it was quiet, which is unheard of for dim sum in LA. I will defiantly be coming back next time I am in the city.
author: John C.

description: The "2 go" counterpart of Yank Sing is clearly a step down from the experience (and price) of the main restaurant. Got the "Phoenix" combo and was unimpressed. The chow mein was good, but I thought the rest (spring roll [very oily], potstickers, and siu mye) was mediocre. The fried rice was haphazardly prepared, with clumps of  white rice here and there. At least the price was pretty reasonable. Also got an egg custard tart, which was pretty good.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Lets start with the excellent.  

-Xiao Long Bao are excellent here.  Light, cooked perfectly and made with excellent pork/scallion.  Some of the best in the city.

-Peking Duck they serve is delicious and served with some actual duck and not just the skin.

-Sesame balls are very tasty and worthy of their acclaim.

Now for the bad.  

Dim sum should NOT be this expensive.  I realize its the city and all but this is just way too expensive for dim sum.  Personally, I'd head down the peninsula for dim sum.  The cab and the food will still be cheaper than what you pay at Yank Sing.
author: Mark K.

description:
spotted yank sing while walking on market st, so i decided to try it out.
decor is very modern. the founding mom's pic overlooks the dining area.

sampling:
-tea(1.95 per person)
came in large glass "pot". 
-spareribs(4.35)
tender, small bone spareribs, natural taste
-chicken feet(4.35)
fresh tasting, meaty , no frozen aftertaste
-mango pudding(4.65)
generous serving (enough for 2). not jello gelainous like but semiliquid consistency with mango flavoring and half strawberry on top.
-pork & shrimp siu mai(4/5.45)
lg sized mix of pork & shrimp, a little chewy, 
-shrimp dumpling(har gow) (4/5.45)
some shrimp taste, skin a little thick, better than average
-xiang long bao(6/10.60) passed on this one. supposedly their signature dish.
-shrimp crepes 
they don't make any

takeouts:
-11ish saturday, no waiting
-impeccable service, servers almost outnumber patrons.
-patrons mostly english and mandarin speakers
-meats are fresh, little fat visible, some portions generous
-no msg, excess salt, sugar, or other spices noticed. "natural" taste.

-RECOMMENDED AVOID  for lack of value, dim sum cost  reflects high retail cost, high labor costs, (number of employees) and high? markups.
-maybe this is americanized dim sum, menu is short, not trypical of chinese dim summeries. heavy emphasis on dumplings and small plates : value added items. (higher markups).

chinese lessons       mandarin
mango pudding         mang guo bu ting
author: Victor G.

description:
I work right across the street from Yank Sing on Stevenson Street.  The place is one of the best fancy Dim Sum places in town.  However,  all those little dishes sure can add up.  Lunch for 2 hungry people can shoot the heck out of a $100.  They have all the usual items that you would find plus several Yang Sing signature specialties.  The minced chicken & lettuce cups, the Peking duck and sea bass with basil wrap are some of the best I've tasted.  The service is great and all the wait staff is bi-lingual and fluent in English.  Also, in breaking the Chinese restaurant stereotype, the restrooms in this place are super clean all the time.  

They have a take out menu too with the entrance off to the side of the main restaurant.  The prices here are much more reasonable (between $6-8) with many different options.  We like the Phoenix for about $6.50 which includes fried rice, chow mein, 2 pot stickers and an egg roll.  Their Chinese chicken salad is great too which also comes with 2 pot stickers and an egg roll for around $6.50.  There are daily specials as well which are good too.  Every place has a little flavor and the take out side at Yank Sing Stevenson does too.  Don't wait too long to look at the menu and order as the gals at the cash register taking orders are a little rough at times.  They can be quite bossy and don't understand that you are still looking at the menu and are not ready to order yet.....even when it's not busy.  Oh well, it all adds to the experience.
author: Chris F.

description: The most expensive dim sum in the Bay Area (at least 3 times the price of other SF institutions) but only on par as far as quality and authenticity with other great SF dim sum houses.
author: Eddie L.

description:
It's a "Yay! I'm a fan!" or "A-OK"?  I think it's an "A-OK".  I mean, let's be honest, Yank Sing isn't what it used to be, and it's really freakin' pricey.  So forget for a second that it's pricey.  Let's talk about the food.

It was one of those, "We have GOT to try the sticky pork bun because it was in "The Best Thing I Ever Ate" episode on the Food Network."  Really?  Yea, it was good, but damn, it wasn't the best thing I ever ate.  The radish cakes were fine, but they weren't that spectacular.  But what I liked best were the individual Peking duck on a bun.  THOSE were tasty.  The ha gow, shiu mai, were also good.  

Folks, I take my Yelp reviews seriously.  I'm not just dishing out 4 stars just because I like the food.  When I like the food, it's 3 stars.  When it's really good, it's 4.  So, Yank Sing is a 3.  I like the food, but I don't think it's REALLY good, know what I mean?

Now, let's spend 1 sentence on the price.  Those delicious Peking Duck on a bun I was talking about?  $7.50 for 2.  3 stars.  Just 3 stars.
author: Del C.

description: The best Chinese food ever. Eat everything. Our favorite was the honey glazed sea bass and the spicy green beans.
author: karen s.

description:
I love chinese food especially hot and sour soup. It's pretty much my most favorite thing in the world. This place doesn't serve hot and sour on certain days which sucks cause I never end up here on those days. This is a major flaw in going to Yang Sing and serves to piss me off every time I go.

Regardless, the food is decent and you can always order in 1 minute or less and get your food within 3-5 minutes. These guys are efficient.

It's my spot if I want chinese during the week.
author: Michael S.

description: Love love love the shanghai dumplings, sticky rice is better than most as well. I'm not sure that even DTF can compare. Yum yum. You will have to pay a little more, there is certainly less expensive dim sum in the city, so order wisely for an optimal experience.
author: Angela A.

description: I wish I could give this place 0 stars, but I'm not allowed. This place was actually recommended to us by a volunteer tour guide and local, and we travelled quite aways to get there. First things first, this place is only open until 3 PM. This makes it a prime business lunch spot, and it's quite crowded. We got there around 2 and we waited 25 minutes though we called ahead. They had an outdoor area which they weren't using. We were seated and served drinks, then the carts started to come around. We ordered some vegetable dumplings, eating modestly until we could get our hands on shrimp dumplings and xiao long bao. We asked about these things and our waiter kept offering us the same stuff on the cart. Finally we got another waiter over there who told us he would go look in the kitchen. He returned after a long time and said they had run out of all of the things we wanted. When questioned why they couldn't make more, they said that they didn't make the food on premises. What?! We were very annoyed and hungry and mostly just displeased with how rude and unhelpful the staff had been. We felt duped that we had been seated without knowledge that all the good stuff was gone. Plus, the restaurant is only open for 4 hours. You would think they'd have thought to get enough of the good stuff to last? It was also ridiculously expensive: $50 for two people? Though the food we did eat was very good, I will never go to this place again.
author: Erica S.

description:
consistently serving quality dim sum and some unique AZN fusion offerings. somewhat California-ized (is that a word?) Honk Kong style food, but still very good. perfect business lunch spot because the food arrives quickly, service is efficient and friendly and the company is paying for a great lunch. Koi Palace is more HK authentic but the service and atmosphere is much better here at Yank Sing. the XO condiment sauce is incredible. what is in it? it is a combination of dried shrimp, dried scallops, garlic, and other seasonings. slight fire but mucho flavor. 
YS also sells it by the jar.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Very fast service, ordering process. Good line - -but need better markers so people know which line is for ordering vs. pick-up.

Need MORE CHAIRS and TABLES in the eating area -- maybe some tables for people eating alone or just for 2 people eating together. ALL the tables were tables for 4 people. One person ate by himself and hogged all the chairs with his bags? Does his bags need a chair and table to eat?

Would be nice if the selection changed from time to time -- more ala carte items would be good.

Overall, very clean and fast service. Good food at a decent price.
author: John G.

description:
Best dim sum ever.  Ive tried a variety of dim sum places through out CA and this is hands down the best  I've had.  I love the wait staff...they are not your average dim sum restaurant employees. They go above and beyond, like showing you how to eat the dishes.

I would recommend getting there early, right when they open. Although it is a little pricier than your average dim sum places in  china town...it is worth every penny and you won't be disappointed.
author: Alisha R.

description:
Hands Down BEST Shanghai Dumplings I have ever had. 
The Sea Bass is incredible.
To finish off be sure to order the pistachio cake and mango pudding...... Both Amazing! 

The jasmine and oolong teas are delicious as well.
author: Ana M.

description: White linen tables, classy upscale dimsum place. Nice place for formal meetings, or lunch date with someone you want to impress. Opt in for a nice cup of tea and order their specials, shrimp dumpling, siumai, pork buns. I would stay away from the bass. Order the mango pudding and ask for creme on top. Thanks to my good friend for telling me this tip.
author: J C.

description:
I'm a fan

I never heard of the place before, but apparently everyone else in our group had heard of it on F-Network. Went in at Noon on a Monday, had a reservation for 10 and was immediately seated, my expectations may be low, but in SF being seated quickly is a rarity.

The first thing we noticed was the service is "Very" quick and efficient. Not even 1 minute from being seated we had 4 different dishes, including the house favorite soup dumplings.

The food was really good, only "slight" negative is the noise level; it is very noisy in the main room. 

The spicy chicken was a huge hit with our group, but I'd go back for the soup dumplings...

Kid friendly was a huge plus for me, they paid attention to what the kids wanted to eat etc..

Fairly pricey, but I've not been to another dim sum place that I really enjoyed so hard to compare.
author: anthony m.

description: Yank Sing is living off a reputation it earned years ago. Now it's just ridiculously overpriced mediocre dim sum with really terrible service. Reservations are a waste of time since you wind up in the same queue as the walk-ins. Servers push the "specials" incessantly, since they are even more expensive than the regular stuff. The "wait" staff takes orders and then doesn't bother to deliver them. Waited 10 minutes for water, couldn't get a refill on tea, gave up on a fork for my child. And, $17.00 for fried rice with a few chicken bits?  Go to any place in or near Chinatown instead.
author: Bruce C.

description: May be overpriced, but for the quality of food you're getting it's well worth it. If you're in the Bay Area make sure you pay a visit, you won't be disappointed!!
author: Sydney J.

description:
Seriously. 4 stars dude.

This dim sum or deeem sum like their website says it, has a lot fanciness to their dishes.

For the attn deficient Yelper - CNBC Swak Box 2 Min Power Lunch Hour Fast Talk on this AZN house..

White man clean and fancy house.  Dim sum Yummie. No ghetto or nasty poo stains on your plates or fork. Dim sum you pay extra money cuz not have throw up barf omg ghettoness like china town old asian grandpa smell. this place is in financial district so u pay extra money or you no eat here ok ninja man? and have weird old asian woman try to sell you food u dont like.. or u dont eat.. but thats ok..cuz you get it anyway and cost you many much money. but you have job so its ok. if not, dont go here.. fortune cookie say use the green paper or dont eat..

samurai out..
author: Mike H.

description:
First time to Yank Sing in years today...  It was solid.  Not phenomenal, but good.  

- Pot stickers, chicken with lettuce cups, and szechuan green beans were the highlights.
- Walnut prawns and some kind of chicken with red chili peppers dish were good.
- The bao (pork buns) were a little sweet for my taste, as they had some kind of sweet sauce brushed on top of them.
- Chicken buns and bacon-wrapped shrimps were bland.
- Egg custard dessert also was good times.

I left stuffed, so I'm not complaining.  Not sure I need to rush back for a repeat trip too soon though...
author: Clayton S.

description:
Yanked again.  Right in the singer.

No matter how I try, I cannot get out of this place for less than $50.  That always makes me a bit ashamed of myself.  The scallion donuts are $9.  For dough sprinkled with green onion bits.  Four of them.  Sure, they're delicious, but... seriously?  

I forewarn you to check the price list carefully (it's on the table, with the prices facing AWAY from you), ask for the more reasonable things you want, and hunker down and stick to your guns.  You may have to fend off some very persistent ladies (the last time I was there, I refused the Peking duck eight times), but stay strong, my friend.  Maybe you can achieve the impossible and eat dim sum here for less than you'd normally pay for a four-star dinner.
author: Rosie W.

description:
Four-star quality dim sum, but three-star overall experience due to the crazy high prices.

Service was nice, and not as chaotic as a larger/cheaper dim sum place. The Baked BBQ Pork Buns were great (better than the steamed version). I also liked the Walnut Shrimp, though the portion was small. I was expecting something more stand-out given their James Beard Award, but in the end it was just well-done basic dim sum, nothing spectacular...and way overpriced.

We paid $40 (with tip) each for three people eating pretty lightly. I'm used to paying 1/3 of that for equally good dim sum in LA, so I was a bit shocked when we got the bill at Yank Sing. They also charged for tea, which is unusual. Maybe they even charged for the sauces, I didn't look at the bill carefully. ;)

I think I'll opt for a better balance of quality/price next time I want dim sum.
author: Dan S.

description: Upscale dim sum that is a bit pricey. Just like every other dim sum you have to make sure the servers aren't putting food you don't want on your table. But all the food was very good. I could eat the soup dumplings for every meal.
author: Alex R.

description:
I will start this review out by acknowledging that I am probably bias. I have been frequently this restaurant since I was a young child. I was a fan of their location on battery before they moved to Rincon Center and Stevenson, yet their food quality has never strayed. 

However, to go along with my bias, I do not stray far from what I know only because I have grown to love the foods that I also go back for. So take my suggestions as you will. 

I consistently order: Ha gau (my mother calls them shrimp dumplings and it drives me crazy), pork siu mye, spring rolls, greens beans, pork buns, shanghai dumplings which are a must (the minute they burst ur in your mouth you will know why they have to be included in your dining experience), Singapore chow fun.

I also am in love with their chili sauce, which is for sale and I highly recommend you pick one up. Spicy like Sriracha but a more liquid consistency. 

I have also tried a lot of there veggie, chicken, and scallop dumplings, but really the meat prevails at this establishment. If you want chicken feet and some of the other 'authentic dim sum' I am not the person to ask.

Enjoy Yank Sing and all that it has to offer.
author: Megan H.

description:
Went here for lunch with a big group. Food is good - but then again for dim sum at these prices, you should expect nothing less.  Some favorites were the Shanghai Dumplings, Pork Siu Mye, Potstickers and the Egg Custard Tarts. The steamed pork buns (cha siu bao) were disappointing since it was way too doughy and there was not enough meat.  

Overall, I liked this place but I do not plan on coming back mostly because I'm not into the upscale dim sum scene.
author: Amy N.

description:
Yum yum yum DIM SUM!!!

delicious... we got so many dishes the servers thought we were crazy!!!

wait was a bit ridiculous- try to get a reservation

don't get the egg custard...it was so horrible I'm sure my friends and I will talk about it until we're dead.
author: Jillian T.

description:
Expensive, Very; Good, Absolutely!!!
We love this place, yes it is expensive and even maybe a little western for diehard dim sum lovers, but it s good.  The Stuffed shrimp is WONDERFUL, the peking duck is incredible (although the portion is ridiculously too small).  Service can be a wacky at times, here though I don't care, i just love the array of choices and the fun of the carts.  

Want someplace special I highly recommend Yank Sing.
author: Troy C.

description:
The dim sum at Yank Sing is absolutely stellar.   The bill, however, is fat.   Try and come here on an expense account, like I just did.

Still, I wasn't a Yank Sing virgin today, having frequented Yank Sing quite a few times.  I think I finally have the formula:

                                 1
    Service = ----------------------------
                      minutes since arrival

As you sit down, you will literally be ambushed by half a dozen cart and food will literally be thrown at you as stamps quickly multiply on your bill.   10 minutes later, the tempo slows to a manageable level.   30 minutes after that, you'll have to scream and throw a tantrum if you want any kind of service.

Still, I'm a full on Dim Sum junky, so I know I'll be back.  I need to get my occasional hit of Peking Duck.
author: David O.

description:
The line moves quickly so don't be intimidated and since Si Senor is closed that's one less good food option in the area. Eat at the tables right outside and give the evil eye to the folks enjoying the sit-down Yank Sing through the glass walls or bring it back to your office. There's a small plaza towards Market street that has some seating as well, if it's a nice day.

You can order items A La Carte or go with their pre-selected combos. I usually get the Seafood Supreme (because my mom told me seafood was good for me) or the Phoenix (because who doesn't want BOTH chow mein AND fried rice?!?). Menu can be seen at this link (the picture is what you get with the Phoenix combo): http://www.yanksing.com/to-order/index.html.

Yes, the chow mein can be a little greasy some days, but it's definitely a step above your average Chinese steam tray joint, IMO. Walk down Stevenson to 2nd Street. There's a couple of cheap Chinese joints there. Try them and let me know :)
author: Andrew C.

description:
This place is great...that is if you're not paying for it...

Don't get me wrong, the food is very good, but it's definitely overpriced.  You can find the same quality dim sum at other spots, but what you are paying for here is the lively ambiance and the fact that it's a total scene during the work week lunch.  The service is good and you leave satisfied.  

I'd say try to come here when you don't have to pay...maybe a work function or a date.  Everything tastes very good and you end your lunch on a happy note...that is until your $40 lunch bill arrives.
author: Ken G.

description:
One of the best dimsum places in the city! Too bad it's a bit pricey. I would eat here more often if they lowered their prices. 
Best Seabass! 
They have really good dimsum options, but make sure to come early because they tend to run out of the good dishes after lunch time. 
Their mango pudding is okay, i'm not that crazy about it though. 
They have really good service, their servers are friendly and attentive. This place is packed during lunch time so make sure to call and reserve a table (esp. for weekends!).
author: Tessa A.

description:
You know... there is dim sum and then there is dim sum at Yank Sing.  This, from a Chinese who loves her dim sum and no, I will admit, I don't mind paying a little more for good food.  

If you want good, delicate (yes there is a BIG difference between ordinary dim sum and delicate dim sum.  They serve good delicate dim sum here.  Sure, some of their creations are for the gwei lo's but believe me, I have tried A LOT of their food - both the traditional siu mai, har gow and then the odd concoctions of ingredients... they're MOSTLY very good.  

Yes they cost a little more and yes, dim sum is usually one of the cheapest Chinese meals you can get - and most places do charge for tea... but c'mon, this really is good!  This is fancy dim sum.  It's worth it!  I have eaten at all of their locations and once, two of us tried almost everything that walked out of the kitchen (while we were there) and raked up a $200 bill LOL - I don't know why someone's complaining about their $200 bill for six lol.  I told you I've tried just about everything they serve there :D  ...and yes, I'd admit it, I'm an oink oink :)
author: Karen R.

description:
As a minority who likes hot sauce, I can only offer a slightly different perspective. 
This place is not particularly authentic, its' success comes from a pretty directly pandering style of business. (think Bose)
Nothing is particularly memorable except how fast food is shoved unceremoniously in front of you and how huge the bill ends up being.
Those who grew up in this culture will hate it, those who didn't, will, by far and large, wonder what the big deal is.  Some will like even the food. Really.
author: Steven L.

description: first, service wasn't the greatest. they either bombard you or ignore you.  the dim sum was underwhelming.  expected more based on the reviews from food/wine, but didn't meet the hype.  i can get the same quality if not better from my neighborhood joints in mt. view and cupertino that's 1/3 - 1/2 the price of my yank sing bill.  in my opinion, not worth a second second trip.
author: Alex J.

description:
Let's be realistic here... a lot of things in life have an inverse relationship.  Demand to Price of goods in economics, male effort versus good looks in the dating world, and finally, dim sum delivery versus quality.

So obviously with how convenient and fast this place is, I am not expecting freshly steamed dumplings and sizzling plates especially since I am getting dim sum to go.  But even though I am spoiled with Chinatown's secret dim sum places, I still appreciate that this place is a 3 minute walk from my building.  I also appreciate that the ladies behind the counter move with the precision of synchronized dancers.

If I could 3.5, I would so I just rounded up since I am in a good mood.

The only con is that now I have to stay an extra half hour on the stupid cardio machine cause someone had an unecessary steamed  pork bun for lunch.  And yes, their buns are that big that you need an extra half hour at the gym to burn it off or else you will also have big buns...not that it's a bad thing, there's a lid to every pot, and some people like that.
author: Katrina N.

description:
I'm a dim sum addict and when I found out that my friend lives, literally, across the sidewalk from the Yank Sing on Stevenson St., I was beside myself in anticipation. Went to the takeaway side because I was in a hurry, but it was so bad (and pricy) that I threw half the meal in the trash. Thought maybe I'd come on a bad day, so tried again the next day. Same result. My friend says she'd heard that the sit-down food is better, but that's hard to imagine...what, one kitchen cooks crappy "to-go" food, and another kitchen cooks tasty food for table service? The take-out experience was enough to keep me from trying the sit-down food. Back to the mom & pop places in Chinatown for me...

P.S. I later asked the hostess if they have separate kitchens and she said "No...same kitchen." She explained that you can order ala carte in the restaurant, whereas it's mostly combination meals at the take-out. Like I say, I'm headed back to Chinatown.
author: S. K.

description:
Four being out of Chinatown.

Four the staff being able to converse in English.

Four the well prepared options, don't mind paying for it.

Four the place having some type of decor.

Obviously, being out of place this spot gives a nice variety to the area.  Yet, the cost comes from the location, obviously.
author: Rafael N.

description:
Crazy good dim sum, crazy close to my house. Go hungover for eggrolls, fried insanity, and greasy goodness. Go sober and keep it clean with the steamed veggie dumplings, Shanghai soup dumplings (these are clearly made with the purest tears of Shanghai babies, kitten dust, and stirred with unicorn horns), and fresh, crunchy greens. 

Three fairly tall, hungry people can eat until stuffed for around $70 total, including soft drinks. Go early- it's packed on weekends!
author: Autumn K.

description: Went to the Stevenson location which is rather small. Food was good but not hot, variety is plentiful. You have to try the soup dumplings and pot stickers. The filling to dough ratio is perfect as most places are to doughy. A little pricey but you are in San Francisco and the financial district. If your looking for Dim Sum is San Fransisco then this is a great option. Lunch for 4 was $120 without tip.
author: Seth G.

description: Yelp is like my version of "ThisIsWhyImFat" blog. This place is literally behind my building. It's already one of my favorite Dim Sum places but not to long ago started hitting their 2 go window and literally, this is why I continue to be fat. I've ordered several of the different combos that come with dim sum and chow mein or fried rice. Surprisingly it was the chow mein and fried rice that I liked the most. I've also tried their specials over rice like Mongolian beef which is currently my favorite. It's no where near as greasy as the other Chinese spots around here which is relative but it's just the freshest tasting of the bunch. It's usually super quick because if you stall you might get a death stare from one of the little ladies behind the counter at the 2 go window so you order quickly and slide over.
author: Hyung L.

description:
my husband LOVES dim sum (even wanted to have our wedding reception at a dim sum hall... i think not!) so when we travel, he likes to try out dim sum. i had been to yank sing before (probably in '04 or '05) to the rincon center location. our friends suggested this location since you can call ahead for a reservation.  

we actually did not need a reservation since we got there a little after 11am, but when we left around 1230/1, it was packed with a line out the door, so a dim sum restaurant where you can make a reservation is key.... if the food is good.  here it is excellent!  as well, the staff is friendly (hard to come by at a dim sum place) and the restaurant is VERY clean. the staff was extremely attentive and not pushy. they refilled our water glasses and tea, cleaned the table (when we got a little messy) and even heated up some veggies for us as the chinese broccoli is served cold, which was a surprise to us.

our friends love the soup dumplings (shaghai dumplings) and the gyoza. i liked the mixed seafood dumplings with basil. we also had the steamed and baked pork buns, the string beans (watch out for the dried shrimp), scallop and cilantro dumplings, shumai, a shrimp dish, a hot and sour chicken dish and the lettuce wraps.

yes, this place is more expensive (it comes out to about $50 per person including tip and tax without alcohol) than more dim sum places in the richmond or in china town, but well worth the splurge for the food quality, cleanliness, friendly staff and reservation policy.

we wish they had had a little bit more of a selection though.  next time, we'll have to go to the rincon center for the beauty of it all.
author: Nicole R.

description:
Pretty good, but I'm not sure I can't find better & at more wallet-friendly prices. Went here because it was on EAT list & was close to a training class I had to take. Went to the To-Go window. Nothing is explained in the store - just a bunch of names that I didn't know so I had to ask questions (holding up the line) & ended up ordering not exactly what I wanted to try. But here's what I did eat:

Vegetarian Delight:
2 Vege dumplings which were delicious. They had taste & texture & a slight tang. I ate 1 & reheated the 2nd in the microwave for dinner & it held up well to reheating. Would order again.
Eggplant w/ Hunan Sauce - the eggplant was drowning in the sauce & very mushy. Somehow, that combo worked well with taste as the eggplant had no taste except for sauce! Ate it all as there were only about 4 small-to-tiny pieces
Vege Chow Mein - hello entire container of fried noodles! Really could scale down on the amount they give you but not bad. A few veggies thrown in there for good measure - sliced cukes, carrots & bean sprouts. I ate 1/3 & had enough for 2 more servings later. Kind of held up when I reheated a portion later but I wouldn't get it again. 

Shrimp Dumpling (4) - on recommendation from cashier. They were a bit gummy but you could see the shrimp. I think they were overdone & definitely didn't reheat well 

Empanadas stuffed w/ Lotus Leaf - interesting but wouldn't buy it again. The crust was too much, not allowing the lotus leaf to have a flavor except for a paste-y texture inside your mouth.

Sesame ball - the real reason I went here. They were yummy...I'd buy a few of these next time, even at over $1/ball! Fried to a wonderful texture of gooyness/moistness with a coating of sesame seeds to balance the sweet yellow bean paste inside. They are a large size (as is all that's served here) so 1 was plenty for me. No reheating on this one! 

As you've read, I reheated a lot because I got a lot & couldn't eat it all at 1 time. Dim sum should be consumed when bought but sometimes one has to be thrifty. Sadly, not all dim sum can handle "thrifty"! ;)
author: Marissa H.

description: Went with work colleagues and ate a lot of delicious food! I love the steamed buns and the pork dumplings.
author: Russell S.

description:
I'll be the first to admit that I am not a fan of dim sum, but I figured if I was going to like dim sum it would be Yank Sing, so why not try it? Actually I had a business lunch there and I had nothing to lose, because after all I wasn't paying.

We arrived for our 12:30 reservation and were instantly BOMBARDED, the people that work there are more pushy than a push cart (they actually push carts too). Horrendous analogy, but you get the point!

Since there was a big group of us, we ordered lots of different dishes. Eggrolls, potstickers, soup dumplings, stuffed mushrooms, halibut, green onion pastries, bacon with shrimp & asparagus, steamed pork buns, sesame balls and a bunch of other things that I could not identify.

I liked the halibut, the soup dumplings and the sesame balls. The rest of the dishes were pretty greasy and nothing special. Personally when I eat dim sum I feel like I have a mustache of grease the entire afternoon and no, I do not eat like a 3 year old.

Overall best dim sum I've had, but I still have not been converted to "dim sum". I would imagine Yank Sing is pretty expensive, but if I didn't know any better I would say the bill came out to be 15 "R" stamps!
author: Elaine S.

description:
This review is specifically for dim sum ....I had heard so much about Yank Sing from others ranging from good to bad. The most common refrain was that it was over priced and overrated.

But since all these publications say that Yank Sing has the best dimsum, I figured I had to find out for myself.

The verdict is that the food is average and the prices are atrocious. They charged 8 bucks for tea! That is unheard of! For four people, our bill came to over 80 bucks for about 8 dishes. Granted, one was a sea bass dish for 17 dollars...a very small portion of sea bass. The dim sum selection was limited compared to other places. It was embarrassing to bring friends there and have them pay such an outrageous sum and we still left hungry.

I've had better dim sum in the San Francisco bay area -- Coi Palace, HK Flower Lounge, Ton Kiang, Mayflower, HK East Ocean and City View to name a few. All are nice non-hole-in-the-wall places similar to Yank Sing with better quality preparation and more reasonable prices.

If you want to impress a business client (who doesn't know much about real dim sum) or if you have a liberal expense account, then by all means, eat here as the location is central and it looks "upscale".

But if you love good dim sum you want the real deal, go some where else.
author: Y C.

description:
Popped over here for a pre-birthday lunch and I was surprised how smooth the experience was given how batshit crazy-popular this place is. I had been so excited to come here, it was the only present I asked for from my boyfriend (that and for him to shave off his beard) my birthday--it's become some sort of Holy Grail in my little brain.

So they immediately attack you with food carts heaping full of fried, steamed and savory things to snack on. It's difficult to say no for sure. First, get some tea. Then immediately order a few baskets of BBQ pork buns, their signature pork dumplings (comes with a red, gingery vinegar sauce and they're filled with broth!), their shrimp and chive pot stickers, their fried scallop balls, and a few plates of steamed greens and you are more than set. There were many other delights covering our table and floating by on carts that I desperately want to go back and try, like basically everything else on the menu. Finish off everything with a few sweet sesame rolls and it is a meal sent down from the heavens.
author: Laura M.

description:
We got all steamed variations of shrimp dumplings, barbecued pork, the cabbage salad and green beans. The steamed seafood basil dumpling was a revelation.  I doubt it was as healthy as we tried to pretend but still tasty and not greasy.  

I justified the prices by factoring in the validated parking so I was able to enjoy a reunion with someone I don't get to see nearly enough with very little guilt.
author: Seong P.

description:
Great tasting food. Love their won ton soup with shrimp won tons! Staff can be very pushy, eager to push their cart selections on your table but
Lacking friendliness.
author: Mely P.

description: Great for a Sunday dim-sum brunch started with Shanghai dumplings.  Friendly staff, takes reservations, clean and quick service.  Convenient parking nearby.
author: H. H.

description: Yank Sing is the best place if you want dim sum...Although this place can be a bit pricey...the quality of the food is unmatched...The restaurant is very posh and clean and separates itself from your stereotypical dim sum eating ethnic Chinese restaurants...The pan fried crispy noodles with chicken (Hong Kong Style) is my number one choice....you can't go wrong with the shrimp and chive, su mai, or the pork bun (Cha sou boa)....chicken pot stickers....and spring rolls...I always ask for hot chili paste on the side to add to the flavor...Love this place...
author: Brandon G.

description: We had a great experience at Yang Sing on Stevenson. We had a reservation, arrived on time at 11am and were immediately seated at a nice table. The food was delicious, although the menu was a bit limited. The location, service, food quality, noise level and decor were all quite enjoyable.  We found the servers to be friendly, efficient, accommodating and not too pushy. Yes, you can get less expensive dim sum, but the experience at Yang Sing was a bit more elegant than your typical dim sum restaurant. Peking Duck was great as were the Shanghai dumplings.
author: Melissa E.

description:
Comfort food chinese-style.

I got a lunch special today comprised of a serving of pork chow mein and 4 fatty potstickers for $5.09 (including tax) in less than 2 minutes.  Like, what?!  I'll be back...TOMORROW.
author: Michelle W.

description:
after my 100th visit, I finally discovered the menu.  NOW I know what to crave and perhaps wistfully request when I don't see it roll by.

I still multiply order the shanghai dumplings. I will dabble in the shrimp dumplings, stuffed lotus leaf, and taro root dumplings if I'm still hungry. don't get the peking duck. not worth it. unless you realllllly like the buns, because that's what you'll be getting a mouthful of.
author: Sasha R.

description:
Outstanding food on the go. I was in the neighborhood and it was about 11:30 am. Did not have time nor the company for a full sit down lunch. And right at that time, I saw this sign that said Yanksing 2 Go. Awesome.

I ordered their DimSum plater which was a sampler of 5 kinds of dimsum. This was quite possibly the best lunch under $10 that I have had in the bay area. Did not get around to finishing the egg custard tart, but all dim sum items were excellent. 

Highly recommended
author: Nitin B.

description:
Food tastes great.
Great atmosphere.

But I'll never go here again.

Why?

Paying $150 for 3 people for dim sim would be like going to a McDonalds in China and paying $75 for two happy meals.

Only Enron has ripped people off more for something (or nothing).
author: Tony U.

description:
Very good dim sum.
A bit more pricey and relaxed than some of the other larger dim sum houses, but still a good bet if you're looking for consistent food and good service. 
I convinced my wife (vegetarian at the time) to join me and she really enjoyed the experience. 
Conveniently located and nice clean interior.
author: Matt T.

description: Totally awesome brunch, very satisfied...sticky buns mmmmmmmmm mmmmmmm sticky! Hang over cure for sure!
author: danielle G.

description: Very over-priced...they are clearly running on their old reputation.  The service was terrible--flat out rude.  We couldn't get water, our check, or order anything--if we asked someone passing by, they would tell us to ask someone else.  I will no go back.  The flavors were just ok--everything tasted pretty much the same and was heavily loaded with MSG.
author: Kim P.

description: This place is good if you want to take your uncultured friends/families and break them into a super clean americanized dim sum. It is not cheap, not a hole in the wall.  It is great quality but you pay up the $$$ for it.
author: Elizabeth J.

description: Lunch spot.   3.5 stars for food, 4 stars for easy walking distance from the office.  Decent dim sum and easy walk from the office.   Always a stop to fulfill my dim sum hankering though I've yet to be blown away by any dim sum restaurant in SF.
author: Loc V.

description: Yank Sing's menu looks about the same as a lot of other dim sum restaurants. The difference is in the quality of the food, upscale ambience and the presentation. My favorite item on the menu is the Xiao Long Bao. These are fabulously delicate little soup filled dumplings which are the best I've ever had. Peking Duck can be ordered as individual bites for smaller parties that couldn't digest a whole duck. From the serving pieces to the decor, this is not a typical dim sum house (not that there's anything wrong with them) and is several notches up the class scale. All of this fun comes at a price so if you're expecting to stuff yourself for $15 this isn't your place. If you're looking for an upscale dim sum experience your eyes and taste buds will enjoy Yank Sing.
author: Jon W.

description:
Yank Sing is a good go-to when you're hungry and you need food fast. It's pretty greasy, but very tasty. Their lo-mein is particularly good. I'm not a huge fan of their bao, though - very doughy, and it felt undercooked. 

This is one of those places where I feel heavy afterwards - but sometimes, it's the perfect meal. They're also super speedy with your food, so you're in and out of there in about 2 minutes.
author: Nick B.

description:
I ate here during my lunch break.  Service was GREAT.  They switched out my white linen for a black linen because I had black pants on ... What Asian restaurant DOES that??  The servers were friendly and even smiled at me.  Biggest perk was not having to chase down the carts ... they came to ME!  and so quickly! 

We had the xiao long bao, fried shrimp, har gow, shu mai, luo buo gao, chicken stuffed mushrooms (wtf??), and hot tea.  It was all QUALITY.  The xiao long baos were actually soupy, the skin on the har gao wasn't too thick, the texture of my luo buo gao was just right, and the random chicken stuffed mushrooms weren't bad either (although I'm not sure how it fits into a dim sum menu).

The meal was split two ways and it still cost each of us $31 ... In LA, a similar meal would've cost me $10 AT MOST.  But I guess you get what you pay for!  I'd eat here again, but probably only on paydays  :)
author: Dina H.

description: So, the food here was pretty good, even though the service was kind of pushy and rushed. I would go there to for deem sum again. BUT! I was surprised to see on my credit card statement that they charged us TWICE ! I have two transactions on my card that day from Yank Sing. One for 83$, the actual bill, I remember I signed for. Then theres is another transaction for 25$ ?!!!!!!!! WHAT?! how can they do this?! I called them, they did not even apologize, they just asked my info to look for the receipt and refund, saying it will take few days. Curious how this will turn out. Shady! Shady place! Check your card statements people!
author: A Z.

description: Consistently great dim sum with good selection.  Don't go early.  The selection is better around 11:30/12.  I go here every time I'm in the city.  Service is good.  They're friendly vs. some of the other dim sum places I've been.  Be careful ordering, as it easily add ups.
author: Diner S.

description:
I figured my 200th review had to be for something I really like and/or visit often, and I decided Yank Sing 2 Go fit the bill. How many other places in the Financial District can one find an extremely filling lunch for $5.75--and not have to wait very long? Not many, that's for sure.

I've ordered the Vegetarian Delight box a number of times now, and it's always tasty: a huge serving of veggie chow mein, excellent eggplant, and two delicious vegetarian dumplings. One can also order a number of items a la carte, such as sesame balls and pork buns, if one's so inclined, but I can't imagine anyone having room for extra after having eaten an entire box of food.

Lastly, I'd give YS2G four stars if it weren't for the fact that one is never really sure how long one's food has been sitting in warming trays before it's served.
author: Katie I.

description:
The absolute best dim sum in San Francisco (and possibly anywhere...).  Great staff, though the cart ladies can be a bit aggressive.  Try the duck and the pork bao.  

Tip: Call ahead for reservations, especially on weekends.
author: Jason C.

description: I'd probably go somewhere in the Richmond for far cheaper, but since I wasn't footing this bill, anchors away!  PRetty much everything I tasted was delicious.  The crab claws, the shrimp daggers, the turnip cakes, the dumplings, the shrimp and walnuts.  Be careful because the prices will add up and the carts come by at such a rapid fire pace that it's hard to enjoy the plates in front of you without being tempted by the next best thing.  Jeez, it is like gay dating.  Anyway, this is a destination place for lunch.  My words of advice: take your time and only take what you really want to try.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Awesome.  Almost as good as the real thing in Hong Kong.  Har Gow was perfectly cooked and the best we've ever had.  XLB was very good and thanks to the folks online who explained how to eat it properly beforehand.  Chicken and mushroom dumplings were excellent.  Didn't get the Peking duck because they don't sell with the pancakes (only the buns).

So what if it's pricey for dim sum.  You could pay a lot more for mediocre food elsewhere.  It's not super crowded, the service is excellent and the food is fantastic.
author: Neale R.

description:
dude, maybe i'm new to the whole dim sum in SF, but i didn't know tea costs $28!!!!  

1.  it's really an expensive place
2. food was whatever, had way better dim sum in LA area
3.  don't have a lot of choice for dim sum
4.  tea is ridiculously expensive 
5.  spent over $105 for 4 people and we didn't even eat a lot.  (usually i would spend around $20-$30 for two people in LA area)

not worth it if you ask me.  never coming back here.  however, i do admit their pork bun is good.  everything else can be a lot better.
author: mai t.

description:
"Authentic Chinese". My wife is a native Chinese who just loves authentic chinese food. And just like every person I know she has been complaining about Yelp search ever since I joined the search team. One of her friends was visiting SF and she wanted to find Yank Sing when she entered "authentic chinese" in the search box. Sadly Yank Sing did not make the first page for that query. But I do have to agree with her. The food here is really great. All her friends (again CBCs) love this place. 

I have often thought why does 'authentic' food taste much better than if the recipes are modified to suit the taste of the majority. I think this is because food is an integral part of culture. The authentic recipes have gone through 1000s of years of evolution. Modifying them willy nilly would rarely improve them.
author: Sudarshan G.

description: What happened to this place?  Yank Sing has been a must-visit for us when coming to Bay area for the past 20 years.  Sadly, after our experience last Sunday, we will not be going back ever again.  We ordered 6 items that day, the pork suimei was the only one that I can rate as above average, the rest were total disappointment. The Peking Duck did not have a crispy skin and bland even after applying plum sauce all over it, the peapot was tasteless, the turnip cake was cold, had little trace of turnip and had no taste, the vegetarian gow was unremarkable, even the steamed pork short ribs were barely edible, they were full of fat and ligament.  We usually ordered a lot when coming to dim sum, but called the quits after sampling such disappointing food.  Our food bill was $45 after tax, I don't think it was money well-spent for the quality of food offered.
author: Cynthia K.

description:
Yank Sing is a famous place in the City serving up some of the best dim sum (and den sum!) around!!  Having lived in the city for 6 years, I've had dim sum from all over the place.  From the hole in the wall, sticky table, sticky chairs, dirty chopsticks $1.50 for 3 pieces type of dim sum to this beautiful place of a great offering of dim sum and more!

When I think Yank Sing, I think beautifully hand crafted, mouth watering morsels of food!  It is pricey however but the clean and upscale atmosphere, friendly service and amazing amazing dim sum makes it worth it.  And sometimes in life, you gotta splurge a little.  Definitely a place to bring the future in-laws, your best friend to say "thanks, you rock" or I guess.. even your employees to say thanks as 4 of my 5 experiences were graciously given by my old employer.  Oh, and the catering is good quality too!

Shanghai Dumplings - tender dumpling skin with a hot refreshing broth inside with plenty of pork filling with ginger and green onion.  the slight burn from the hot broth for those who can't wait is worth the experience and burst of flavors! It's no wonder they're known for this and that shanghai dumplings are a big deal all over the world..they aren't easy to execute like this. 

Peking Duck - who can resist?? Crispy, crispy skin with a bit of duck fat and juicy meat underneath with the perfect steamed bun, sauce and green onion?? Oh my.. I'm hungry! I think it's one of the best I've EVER had. 

Taro Root Dumpling - wonderfully crispy and not overly greasy i want to bathe in hot tea kind of deal here. 

GREASE - one of my main complaints about dim sum is the greasiness and how I feel gross afterward.  But it's not like that here! Really, it's good stuff. 

OK... i could go on and on forever. They have all your typical dim sum offerings and den sum.  All very succulent, juicy and flavorful.  A diverse menu and still plenty of offerings for a vegetarian as well.  I'm not a fan of getting chow fun, chow mein and things like that because I can get that anywhere anytime, so i'm not sure about that here.   End the meal with fresh fruit, mango pudding, egg tarts, sesame balls and more. EAT TIL YA CAN EAT NO MORE and worry about the bill later :)  Like I said, sometimes you just gotta splurge!
author: Eileen A.

description: I'm not sure what's so great about this place just yet. I tried the sesame balls since they're supposedly famous for it but the whole time I was eating it, I was wondering what was so special about it. Their pork buns (both baked and steamed) are really good except the wait for them was ridiculously long (over 30 mins of just standing there). And this is supposed to be the fast way of getting food here. You've got to be kidding me. Granted, the buns were really good but it definitely did not justify having us wait that long for them, especially without warning that it'd be that long of a wait.
author: Gajan K.

description: I've been going to Yank Sing for years.  Today's experience was by far the worst ever.  The dim sum was chewy and tasteless and it seems they've raised their prices a lot.  I don't think I'll ever go back which is very sad.
author: Mitch H.

description: Sesame balls from Yank SIng was on the 7 by 7 list and I am still scratching my head in wonderment. I definitely have had better. It is overpriced and the dough to filling ratio wasn't good. There wasn't enough filling and it was greasy. I am pretty sure if you went down to Chinatown and walked in to one of the many bakeries there, you will get good sesame balls..even at the end of the day when they aren't so fresh. I do have to say the restaurant is in a pretty location.
author: Eve C.

description:
I have been a big fan of Yank Sing's dim sum for over 15 years now, starting way back when they were on Battery street. To this date, it is still my favorite dim sum place in the bay area, the great food, the attentive service and combined with the relaxing surrounding, all make each of my visits very enjoyable.  In fact, it has become a must-visit place every time  I spend a weekend in the city.

Their shanghai dumpling is house specialty and the best I ever had, so juicy and tender (oh be careful it is often very hot). The spicy chili chicken is fantastic, and the lettuce cup is another must-try.

If you want to try the best dim sum in SF in a relaxing environment, come here, and enjoy, do not worry about the price (yes it is more expensive than most dim sum place but you get what you pay for).
author: Sharon P.

description:
Meh!  Man, I do love me some dim sum but I'll tell you what, I think it's better if you wade inside and grab a table and eat it fresh.  I had the seafood special the other day and the three steamed dumplings were adequate and the fried stuff was icky.  It's true, they give you enough chow mien to feed a lumberjack but it wasn't very tasty. 

Because of my borderline out of control obsession with dim sum I'm sure I will be back, but here's to hoping next time it ups itself to a moderate 4.  For now, it's a meh-ish 3...
author: Claire C.

description:
I'm a fan, but I also know what to order.  So, the spring rolls here can be a bit greasy - which is sometimes appealing and sometimes not.

My usual lunch here pretty much every Friday, is a steamed pork bun, 2 shumai, and 2 pot stickers.  It's under $10, and I don't feel bloated afterwards.  The great thing about this place is that you are in and out really quickly.  Yes, it's fast food, but it's nice-quality dim sum fast food.
author: Joe S.

description: As if this place needed more reviews... The XLBs were good, but I felt could use more soup. Har Kow and Siu Mai were delish with quality ingredients. Miso Chilean Sea Bass was good. A decent place for dim sum, but pricier as many other have said. Good ambiance and friendly staff. Sometimes, it's worth it to pay more to have that than to deal with some of the other dim sum places in Chinatown and get treated like crap and dirty restrooms. Don't think you can go wrong going to Yank Sing, unless you were on a budget :-P
author: Crystal C.

description:
After watching "the best thing I ate" on the food network my wife and I had an itch for dim sum.. Especially for the baked BBQ pork buns.  Unfortunately, we found out that they don't have em on the weekends at this location!  Needless to say I was a little dissapointed! But the boutiqueness of this place with great staff not to mention the mouth melting food, worth the extra $$$, was well worth the trip. 

Location - 2 stars
It's in the cuts so parking would be a nightmare during the business week. Their other location might be a better choice.

Ambience - 5 stars
It's quaint and it looks like during the week they have outdoor dinning. It's an upscale place relative to your typical dim sim.

Food - 4 stars
Hopefully i will be able to change this once I get my BBQ pork buns.  The dim sum melts in your mouth and full of savvory flavor. 

Overall - 4 stars
author: Sid E.

description:
Great variety, and dim sum classics like soup dumplings and baozi were delicious.

Possibly the most expensive dim sum in the known universe, and you can still walk out of there without spending a fortune.  This is why we like Chinese food.
author: Paul K.

description: Wonderful food, good service for the most part. They can be a little pushy when they offer you stuff. I feel as if I'm bartering in Chinatown. But...they are just trying to make money. It can get worse at other Dim Sum establishments. The food is high quality, high priced, clean and never fishy. A+! I have dreams about the shanghai dumplings (soup dumplings). Best in the city! And I had the best mango pudding I have ever had. It was so delicate, not soggy and syrupy and sickeningly-sweet. Vegetarians can eat their fill! Which is rare at dim sum places. I'm only docking a star for charging for tea (but it is loose leaf highly floral) and their intense prices.
author: Courtney M.

description:
12:30 pm 3/22 Tuesday.
Ordered the pheonix and 4 extra shu mai a la carte. Comes out to be $10.67 (with tax). The shu mai was expensive, like 95 cents a piece. But it was worth it.

When I first opened the box, it was like a piece of art. All 7 colors of the spectrum appeared with the different ingredients. 
The chow mein - greasy, but with good ingredients. Bean sprouts, onion, green onion, barbeque pork.
The fried rice - green beans, pork, celery, cabbage. 

All of these were minced together .

I would go back.
author: Jason W.

description: Why are there not six bazilloin stars for this place?  And why have I neglected to review it until now?  This is the best upscale dim sum.  EVER.  They have all the standards (dumplings, buns), the other things (feet, stomach) and original creations (sea bass is to die for), as well as main dishes.  Plenty of veggie choices, too.  Do not let anyone convince you to go to Ton Kiang.  They are wrong.  WRONG I tell you.  (You can't get no Yank Sing hot sauce for your sesame balls at Ton Kiang.)
author: Sondra H.

description:
This place can be a bit pricey but their food was amazing! 

I absolutely love dim sum & this had some of the best! 

Had 4 plates, 2 sodas & it came out to about $40 split between 3 people & it wasn't horrible! It was a good experience overall.
author: Dessa S.

description: Our family always dine here when we visit SF.  Yes, it is touristy and expensive but the food is consistently good.  It is one of the cleaner Chinese restaurants I've been to.
author: Boni P.

description: This is a pretty nice clean dim sum.  Not the traditional Chinese dimsum with Borg crowded tables.  It was nice, clean and more American upscale.  Wait ws about 45 minutes on a sat but they take reservations so make them and save time.  The dimsum was kind of limited in terms of what they had but it was about what you would expect.  Everything was fresh and tasty.  Wish they would bring around more carts though.  We never saw the vegetables and desserts until we were leaving.  I had to order Kai LAN and it ws more like American broccoli but it was fine.   I prefer the more traditional dim sums but this was a reasonable substitute.  Very expensive as most trays were at least 5 dollars and some were as high as 11.  Not bad though.  Give it a try now that y ben is gone.
author: Doug W.

description:
On a trip to the Bay area last week to visit family, I had one, and only one request. I wanted to go back to Yank Sing! Well, I got my wish.

This place is absolutely THE best at Dim Sum. The dishes are flavorful, fresh, served hot, served quickly and the variety is great. Its hard to say no to any of the dishes they parade by you. Our party enjoyed the food until we just couldn't eat another bite. 

This place is not cheap, but a great experience. If you are in San Fran, this place is a must. Save your pennies and come hungry.
author: Heidi B.

description: This was fantastic. Dim sum is not the healthiest of fares, but you just have to have it sometimes. A very nice restaurant. White table cloths and napkins. Not your slam bam dim sum place. Not cheap, but very good. The crab claws are the most expensive item at $12.95 for two. They keep offering. Be aware if you really don't want them. Kind of amusing they keep resurfacing. LOL. Just a simple no is all it takes. Don't be afraid to request something specific from your server. They'll mumble I to their headset and viola!  Enjoy.
author: James M.

description: I read this place is expensive, but thought it was complainers comparing it to the San Gabriel Valley.  But seriously, be prepared to pay more than you ever thought possible for dumplings (nearly twice as expensive as Din Tai Fung, and the quality doesn't come close to Din Tai Fung).  We paid $175 for me and my three small children and still left hungry.  Also, be prepared to be completely ignored if you aren't Chinese.  Worst service ever.   Huge lines out the door of tourists with"sucker" stamped on their foreheads.  Don't go.
author: Melissa m.

description:
Great place for a friendly/business lunch.
Instead of sitting down an ordering form the menu, the waitresses keeps passing by with carts full of small dishes. You simply choose which one you want to eat right now.
There are many dishes to choose from and everything we tired was very good.
All in all - good food, nice atmosphere (business casual) and about $25 per person.
author: Shahar N.

description: Best Dim Sum in the bay area, period.  About 10-15 times a year my wife and i hear about some 'new, better' place-and it's never better.  Been going to Yank Sing for over a decade, and they still are the best.  One point-there are a LOT of great items that aren't on the carts, or the menu-ask.
author: kevin f.

description: All I can say is it is good thing I don't live nearby or my butt would look like a giant steamed dumpling!  Rapid fire dim sum of spectacular tastiness.  Cheap...no,  Worth it for a dim sum experience in downtown SF...yes, yes, yes!!!
author: Melissa C.

description:
OVERPRICED.  I've NEVER before spent more than $100 on dim sum for a family of 5.  We only had enough leftovers for 1 person's snack.  We had luke-warm service.  They brought us the same all-fried items tray 3 times in a row - come on, we need something to go with the fried stuff!  We ordered 2 bowls of rice, they never came.  Water needed to be filled more often.  String beans were laden with dried baby shrimp - ew!

The good:  Shanghai dumplings - the ones with the soup inside were pretty good, but without the suggested heavy dose of vinegar & ginger.  Charsui bao was yummy.  Thank goodness for the bread, because the fried stuff was really getting to me.  The giant glass teapot full of yummy tea helped cut the oil.
author: Cynthia A.

description:
not a bad dim sum place but it's on a pricey side.

their service is very attentive (probably, for  the tourists) and efficient but I have had better food for the better price before.

Do try their snow pea-shoot dumpling, it's fantastic.
author: Sung C.

description:
This place gets busy and packed fast so plan ahead if you're coming with a large party!  We went around 11:30am with a party of 12 and our hostess didn't seem too happy trying to accommodate us.  I believe they take reservations so you might want to do that first.  By Noon, the place was packed and bustling with people.  

The rolling carts came around frequently and immediately went to us as we sat down.  This was a good thing because we were all really hungry.  The Dim Sum was delicious.  Having a large party with us we were able to try everything from Haw Gow, Shu Mai, pork buns, and the sea bass.

Having a lot of people in our party also was a downside because this place is fairly expensive and the bill can add up fast.  I've had fairly good Dim Sum at other places with more traditional selection and less exotic ones and the price was reasonable.
author: Ritche C.

description:
Great place to go to during lunch breaks! Service is always fast, we know what's good, what more can you ask for?

Staples from here are Shanghai dumplings, red sesame balls, steamed spare ribs, and shrimp dumplings.
author: Kym P.

description:
First off, this review is not about the food necessarily (which was good) but about the business itself, the service and the price.

I walk in and as soon as I sit down, they put a basket of something steamed on my table.  I ask what it is and they say it is steamed pork, their signature dish.  I say sure, I will take that so I proceed to start eating it.  It is dim sum right - how expensive could it be?  My mistake, big time.

After I have started eating it, THEN they give me the menu and I ask how much it is.  The say $11.90!  For 6 small steamed pork things!  These would cost less than $2 in Chinatown.

I then ask for some tea and they give me a huge kettle of tea.  I ask if they have it by the cup and they say only the tea kettle, which costs $4.00!  I was eating by myself - why do I need $4.00 worth of tea?

I then order Pork Shu Mai (4 pieces for $5.80, good but rip-off - they should be less than $3.00) and Chicken Egg rolls.  They say the Egg rolls are 4 for $5.80 but they can also do a half order.  I say half-order thinking it would cost $2.90 so they give me two egg rolls, cut them in half, which then becomes the 4 pieces for $5.80! Unbelievable.

I order some Chinese Broccoli and half of it is inedible stem.  I ask and they say people eat the stems so that is another $5.80 down the drain, even though I could only eat half of the vegetable.

At this point I know I am screwed so I order two egg custards for dessert, which were another $5.80 (about $1.50 in Chinatown).  So my grand total at the end of the meal was just over $40.00.  I know the Financial District is a high rent area but they are making so much money off that food.  They were very sneaky about the pricing and I guarantee this same meal in Chinatown would have been under $20.  A $40 lunch for 3 regular/small servings of Dim Sum, 1 small serving of vegetable, 1 dessert and 1 tea.  That is ridiculous and I won't be going back!
author: Chris F.
