description: This place is gross.  I went to see what all the hype was about with this place and how they supposedly have really good dim sum/lunch specials.  Well, I was disappointed.  I tried their 2 go area since the dim sum part is known for being crowded and busy at lunch time.  Everything in the combo was cold and dried out and didn't have much flavor.  The few dumplings that I had in my lunch were small and dried up, they tasted kinda old too.  Their chow mein was gross too.  The noodles were hard and cold.  Not my kind of restaurant.  Sorry Yank Sing...I tried.
author: Leah A.

description: I went here for lunch yesterday and had the Dim Sum Platter.  For $9.25, you get 9 pieces of Dim Sum: 2 reg. Siu Mai, 2 scallop Siu Mai, 1 BBQ pork bun, 2 potstickers, 1 egg roll and 1 egg custard.  The food was all right, but not one item stood out to me.  However, I will say that the BBQ pork bun is huge.  Compared to the actual restaurant, the food at the sit-down is far superior than what you get here.  Furthermore, I expect a lot when I'm paying almost 10 bucks for Chinese food.  Like what others have mentioned: those ladies working the counter are lightning fast!
author: Lisa R.

description:
one of the best dim sum I have ever had ...
the place is very classy, the tea is very high quality & served in a   beautiful clear/glass tea pot 

signature shanghai dumpings (6)
shu mai (4)
har gao (4)
sticky rice (1)
egg tarts (2)
coconut mochi w egg custard (2)
baked black cod (1 little slab)
peking duck ( 1 little piece/less than an 1"/hand carved in front of you)
radish cake (3)
spring rolls (3)

it was $86, excluding tip, i think this a lot for dim sum, right?

so it's the most expensive & high end dim sum I ever had in my life!
it's totally handcrafted & refined though

when i first came here 10 years ago, i thought it was the most amazing dim sum ever but now i just realized it's just really overpriced...
 there are other places that are just as good, half the price...

 *does not make you feel tired though like every other dim sum i've had... useless & sleepy afterwards ;)
author: Christina W.

description:
the dim sum from the actual restaurant is good, but not so good to command such ridiculously exorbitant prices. i came here over 10 years ago with my mom and we both agreed it was best not to tell my dad how much the bill was. i've only been back once since when someone else footed the bill, and i'll probably only come back under the same circumstances.

so it's nice that they acquiesced to us common folk and have reasonably-priced lunch box bentos. although their siu mai is $1 each!! i saw a little girl eating at least 10 of these siu mais in her to-go carton and thought there must be at least 3 siu mai per order, and at only $1?! i love dumplings/dumpling-esque foods so i happily asked for 3 orders for siu mai before the cashier clarified things and i meekly changed my order down to 1.

daily lunch specials, usually some kind of chicken or beef stir fry with rice and potsticker, or their various dim sum combo bentos will run you about $8. the food itself pretty standard take out chinese food (i.e. greasy and saucy), but it just seems better since it's coming out of the yank sing kitchen.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The most positive thing for this restaurant is location and clean environment.  Dim sum selection is very limited, especially on the steamed ones. Too many deep fried items or 1/3 entree size of panda express type dishes (they do taste better than Panda Express however they are NOT dim sum please). For someone who has grown up with dim sum, this is the most expensive one i have ever had (price vs food quality).  Maybe a chunk of the $$ went to advertising as you can see its name on almost all the local tourism ads.

Service can be better, seems the servers there speak very good english however extrememly pushy for ordering food.  This kills my mood for dim sum.
author: Sandy L.

description:
I have been here only once a while back and it was mediocre. 

The overall atmosphere was really nice. They were very welcoming and spoke really good English which is sometimes hard for a Chinese Dim Sum Restaurant. It was also very very clean. 

However growing up in a Chinese family and eating lots of Chinese food. This was not up to par. It wasn't that bad but I definitely had better. I was a little disappointed in taste of the food after i heard about how delicious it was on TV. The food wasn't very authentic and definitely catered to a more "outsider/touristy" kind of experience.
author: Jess G.

description: I went here only because others in SF have told me it's some of the best dim sum ever.  Hmmm...definitely can't agree with that.  The food was underwhelming, not authentic, and way overpriced.  The service was excellent and the ambiance was nice...but all that kind of defeats the essence of authentic dim sum.  This place is meant for non-Asians who can't or won't handle the true experience of dim sum, but wish to say they've tried it.  Dim sum is without a doubt a billion-times better in L.A.
author: Tracy H.

description: I always order the mini, which has the chicken salad and pot stickers.  It's the best
author: Dilly M.

description:
This is just for their takeout but I got the Vegetarian "Delight" and it was far from delightful.  Two decent-but-not-great vegetarian dumplings, a few sad pieces of eggplant in hunan sauce, and a heap of flavorless chow mein that was touted as "Vegetable", but really only had celery, onion, and couple carrot slices.  It was pretty cheap, but I honestly think the food at the New Asia place in the Crocker Galleria is a better value.

Doesn't really inspire me to check them out for a full sit-down dim sum meal.
author: Tmon B.

description:
Fancy, high priced dim-sum... maybe a little too high priced?

Don't get me wrong here.. this is probably the best dim-sum food I've ever had... but overall spending $90 for two people on dim-sum is kind of steep.  This place would be 5 stars for the food... but the price just doesn't warrant it... Sorry Yank Sing... your Shanghai Dumplings are too die for.. but you need to drop your price a little for me to be back.
author: David M.

description:
As a native and 23 years of dim sum experience, I know them pretty well...this place is probably one of the best dim sum places I've tried (in the US)!

Located so conveniently next to my university, came here with some European classmates after a meeting. I think this is an ideal place to take someone for his/her first dim sum restaurant...for the quality of (ungreasy) food, service, and more importantly, cleanliness. The restaurant is beautiful and bright, and I'm pleased that the tables are not as crowded and noisy (as most chinese restaurants are)

My favorite items here are:
shanghai soup dumplings (siu long bau)
shrimp dumplings (ha gaau)
sesame balls (gin dui)
egg tarts (daan tat)

The reason why I gave only 3 stars though is that as many yelpers complain, it really is a bit pricy for a chinese dim sum joint. We ended up paying about $22 per person....but its location and quality is hard to compare with what you get in Koi Palace. (Afterall, my European friends and I had a satisfying and enjoyable lunch!) Not sure if i will come back for dim sum anytime soon, but will def try Yank Sing2Go for lunch sets sometime!
author: Shirley H.

description:
This place has the best Chinese food I have ever tried in the whole wide world.  
I tend to go to the Yank Sing Express to order for lunch because I am broke and I cannot afford the fancy dim sum they serve all the time. 

Their express line is quick.  Their food is really tasty and their portions are humongous.  

Whatever you order in their express location, you will love it.  Everything is delicious and cheap.  I always spend less than $10 whenever I order food so this is  good news for my pocket and my stomach! :P
author: Liza B.

description:
A little hard to walk to because Stevenson is not a thru street, but the food was great and I like eating outdoors on a wonderful fall day.

We stayed with the basics, but I like how they offered Peking Duck, sea bass, and some other delicacies.

Really enjoyed it overall.
author: Steve F.

description: I always love coming here when I'm in San  fransico. The dim sums are worth every penny.
author: John H.

description:
I found a place to satisy my shanghai dumpling craves that is reachable during my lunch hour. This is no Joe's Shanghai dumpling but it will do for now. The dumpling here is smaller but the skin is just the right thickness and the soup is always warm. I like their shrimp dumpling and fried turnip cake. My gf and I always come here when we crave dim sum. It's always a plus when they have good customer service. I can request a specific item if I don't see it in the carts. 

I usually call in to make a reservation and try to get there before 11:45am as it gets crowded right around noon. I like having extra space around me when I eat. The walk to the restaurant is a few blocks away from the BART stop.
author: Candace F.

description: I have been dying to come here for a year...after my hubby came back raving about it.  Where do I go on my first full day in SF?? Here.   i was disappointed....i got here at noon.  It was packed, so I stood around for 20 mins.   (Didn't mind that at all).  When I was seated, a cart came up with steaming baskets of har gow and shiu mai.   I ordered one of each.  Then the lady with. The xiao long bao came... I got one of those.  Then an order of fried crab claws.  All this food on my table in under 1minute!  AWESOME.  My first bite of har gow.... It was somewhere between cold and not really warm.  My xiao long bao?   Had been cooked for a while and they stuck to the paper lining....as I picked each one up, the skin broke as it tore away from the paper and the soup dribbled to the table.  And it was less than tepid.  The flavors were good but it would've been better hot!  The only real stand out was the crab claw (cold too but still tasted good) and the shiu mai which was the only plate that was still hot.  The bill came to $45.... If I'm going to pay that much for cold dim sum, then....I'm an idiot....i should've sent it all back.   But maybe it would've been better at off-peak hours (like right at 11am) when everything is probably still piping hot and fresh.
author: Grace T.

description:
Do NOT come here hungry.  Especially on a weekend.  You'll be waiting a l-o-n-g time ... even with a reservation.  On a rainy Sunday, we ended up waiting about 2 hours with a reservation.  

Food was all pretty good, but who can tell?  We were starved!

In hind sight, portions were small, prices are higher than most if not all dim sum joints (comparable places).  Flavors are good.  Temperature's not always.  A lot of the items came cold (not hot or even warm).

We ended up spending about 50 bucks a person for lunch.

Overall impression?  Good, but just not worth it.
author: Winnie C.

description:
I was disappointed as I've heard good things about this place.  The food was simply ok and does not justify the high price tag.  However, the location in the FiDi is convenient and the place is clean.  We ordered the following:

- xiao long bao/shanghai dumplings - the dumpling wrapper held the soup without being too thick.  However, the dumplings were not flavorful
- string beans - tasty but a bit too sweet
- salt water dumplings - excellent. I liked the 5 spice accent. 
- shrimp dumplings - meh
- shumai - meh as well
- potstickers - slightly bland.  they missed the point of pan-frying as the skin did not have the crunch it's supposed to have
- tea - good.  the glass teapot was visually pleasing

The venue itself is a nice space and the atmosphere is great.  This is a great place for dim sum virgins since Yank Sing still rotate food around the restaurant in a cart allowing one to point and order.  However, with so many food options in SF, I wouldn't go back.
author: Astrid C.

description:
parking sucks around here.  you'll be lucky to find any, during any time.

comparing this Yank Sing to the ORIGINAL on Broadway.  Its not as good.

I say this because of the PRICE.  It went from family right in the heart of China Town to UPSCALE Nice Silverware, Plates, Serving Carts, Candles, Tables, you name it, its upscale, now.

The food is still just as tasty as ever.  Its just smaller.  You will love all the dim sum here.  Yes, its a Dim Sum place  Thats why you should try it.  Its very very good.  Its probably better for a special occasion.

For me, I'll find a reason to get something to eat here.  Whether its in the sit down restaurant or the to go area.  Its just soooo tasty.
author: Bing D.

description:
Came here for a late lunch, which I do not recommend. Ordered the Phoenix which came with a spring roll, potsticker, siu mye, and a ton of chow mein and fried rice. A ton of food

I guess it's my own fault for waiting to have lunch until 3pm, but all the dim sum were cold and rubbery. The spring roll was the only thing that tasted somewhat freshly-made. This marks my second visit to Yank Sing 2 Go and although I wasn't impressed with the first go-around, today marks the last time I knowingly or willingly purchase anything here (though I can't imagine someone wanting to force feed me the bland and gutbusting chow mein). Too many options around to go sub-par.

Good price for the immense plate of food, but be sure to get there earlier in the day.
author: Karly F.

description:
This review is solely based on the meal I had today, but for the first time I had something at Yank Sing that I wasn't too fond of. 

90% of the time I get the Express, but today I saw they had a weekly special of Spicy Pepper Chicken with steamed rice and a pot sticker. Being the daredevil I am, I decided to break from the norm and give this a try. 

The portion size was large and as usual more than I can eat in one sitting, but the contents of this portion is what disappointed me. I have never seen spicy pepper chicken with as much celery as what I got today. I would say I got just as much celery as I did rice and only about 8 little pieces of chicken. As an added kick to the nuts, the chicken I received was either chewy or tough. I wish I took a picture of it before I threw it away. 

Yank Sing is still one of my favorite places to eat lunch. They give you generous helpings and it's usually very taste and hot. However, I would steer clear of this entree. You are much better off sticking with the classics such as the Yank Sing Express.
author: Jason B.

description:
Shanghai soup dumplings.

Yup. That's pretty much all I'm going to say.
author: Jarrod B.

description:
I went to the Ferry Building hoping for lunch on the fourth of July.  Nothing was open so I started walking up Market Street.  And there it was.  Yang Sing, which I had heard so much about.  

I got three plates.  Two were quite good: spicy chicken and the pricey Peking duck.  The potstickers were an embarrassment.  Thick leaden wrappers that contained nothing special.

They really push the more expensive items at you, especially the Shanghai dumplings.  If GM had salespeople as relentless as these it wouldn't have gone into backruptcy.
author: David D.

description: I normally go to the Yank Sing location in Rincon Center, but a friend wanted to meet here.  The Rincon location is much bigger and nicer.  The floors here are tile - like cheaper Chinese places.  I also found something in my teacup so I felt like it wasn't as clean as the other location.  The dim sum quality is roughly the same, though.
author: B. Y.

description: Best dim sum ever.  a bit pricy, but must try sea bass!!
author: John G.

description:
Classy dim sum.  All my life, I've never seen such a thing until a mid-week lunch at Yank Sing.  I'm used to my dim sum with about 11 friends, slightly hung over, at some ginormous place in a strip mall during the lull on a Sunday before all the families come in after church.  Yank Sing is pretty much the opposite, and it was definitely intriguing.   Suits were everywhere, and I heard no one ordering in their native language.  A bit off-putting given my prior experience, but still pretty tasty.

Great service; the carts were always coming around and I never had to wave anyone over.  Pork dumplings and sesame balls were among my favories.  And the green beans with the crispy oniony goodness all over them were stellar.  Would have given 4 stars, but took one away for the cost being greater than any other dim sum place I've visited (even though it was all the usual dishes).
author: Deidre B.

description: Vegetarian delight is awesome choice for all veggi lovers... I really liked chow mein...
author: Santhana K.

description:
There are a lot...and I mean a lot of Chinese Restaurants in San Francisco.  Yank Sing is a cut above the rest. There are two of these in SF.  This one is located in the business district and will usually be full of suited business type during the week....especially during lunchtime.

As with the sister restaurant the Dim Sum is gorgeous - their Blackend Cod to die for (and I really hate dislike eating fish). The Dim Sum is brought round on trolleys - the traditional  way of Dim Sum dining. The food is brought round in an endless fashion so no need to over indulge.  The restaurant is vast and the service overall excellent. If you go to SF do go to this place.
author: Agi K.

description: Been to Yank Sing numerous times at most of their locations.  The food is consistent and it's evident that the food is fresh and light.  Great service and place is meticulously clean.  The prices are definitely expenssive for dim sum so I wouldn't recommend for large groups as it'll be easy to rack up a enormous tab.  3-4 people is ideal and expect to spend $100 if you want to get full.
author: Byoung Kyu S.

description: I loved the food except for the chilled gai LAN and prices.  In their defense, once I looked very carefully on the dim sum menu the gai LAN was listed as chilled.  The sea bass roll was a delight, but the hunk of sea bass for $19.00 was a little pricey.  The shanghai dumplings were good but the price was high.  Overall a good experience when I have money.
author: Steven W.

description:
by far the most i've ever paid for dim sum, but well worth the cost.

their selection is limited, yes, but an incredible amount of thought goes into every dish. especially recommended are their cha siu bao and their soup dumplings.

parking is on the street and can be difficult.

overall well worth the visit
author: TJ A.

description: Excellent dim sum. Everything was great, but the Shanghai Dumplings were a highlight. We also enjoyed the steamed pork buns, turnip cake, and the string beans with shrimp. Service is very fast, you need to pace yourself. We will return!
author: Steve R.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco and was recommended this place by a friend.

Having only had dim sum a handful of other times, I found the food to be very good, as well as the service.  I really stuffed myself.

I do agree that it is expensive.  I didn't necessarily intend to spend $30 on brunch, but the food was very good, none-the-less.
author: Matt B.

description: Not bad, not great. We got there shortly after it opened on Sunday. The server immediately came over with steamed pork dumplings. Good, but $12? I agree with the person who said it's kind of crazy to charge so much for tea too. What I noticed was that the servers kept coming back wtih different steamed dumplings and sea bass, which for $19 was an awfully small portion. We passed. Would have liked more variety--which seemed to be coming around as we finished. Also seemed that the Chinese family sitting next to us were offered more different things than we were. Oh well, my kids enjoyed it. But having had dim sum here some 20 years ago--where the locals go--I was a little disappointed.
author: Sue M.

description:
I live on the Phoenix.  
Seriously, how do you get better than this?!:

PHOENIX    
Spring Roll
Pot Stickers (2)
Siu Mye
Chow Mein
Fried Rice

I have been coming to Yank Sing since I moved here 5 years ago and have never ordered anything else.  Why bother... this has everything I need!  I may just have to go tomorrow too!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Yank Sing is hardly worth going to for sit down. I tried the 2 go today and it was actually not bad. Got the dim dum special w/ egg roll, custard tart, BBQ pork bun, potstickers, shu-mai.

Far from the best but because it was so fast and convenient its worth coming to again if im working in the area. Im one of the few that can park across the street on Stevenson for free since my little company car Scion fits in the only free parking spot in that little alley :)
author: Marlon O.

description: I've had MUCh better DimSum in NYC. Not impressed.
author: Nilo K.

description:
Yank Sing was my first dim sum experience, and it's good to know I started at the top. Even on a cold dreary day, the place was bustling and we were lucky to snag a table on the patio right under the heaters. I'd recommend arriving a few minutes before noon, because as soon as that clock hits the hordes flow in to this place. 

The whole vibe can only be described as organized chaos. Lots of women pushing around carts of tasty treats, trying to sell their wares to you. I didn't catch most of what was served to us, but I have to say there wasn't one thing I didn't like. Shanghai dumplings filled with savory broth, pretty three-cornered shrimp filled Mandarin dumplings, perfectly plump potstickers, sweet fried shrimp, garlicky green beans... I could go on and on. We certainly ate our fill here, and we would have been in trouble if I was in charge of the ordering, as everything looked so dang good!

I'm a total dim sum convert, but now I fear that I won't be able to find anything as good as Yank Sing in the South. Ah well, I guess I can just cry it out over fried chicken.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
One of the best dim sum places in the Bay area but I have to minus a star for the awkward seating in the middle of an office building area. It's weird to be seated in a area where people pass by and gawk at your food while they're waiting for a table. They do have seating inside the restaurant but the wait for those seats would've cost me a fainting spell from starvation.

Otherwise the dim sum is yummy and comparable to Vancouver and HK standards. The price may be steep as other Yelpers have already mentioned but  if you're willing to pay for quality not quantity then look no further. The shells on all steamed dumpling like items (i.e. har gow) were not thick and did not stick to the steamers which meant they didn't fall apart.
author: Debbie P.

description:
I would like this place more if they wouldn't charge an arm and a leg for their dim sum.  It's good quality dim sum with enough variety to satisfy your dim sum craving, better than City View.  No chicken feet, cows stomach and delicious funky stuff that I usually like to order at you local chinatown dim sum.  For your average siu mai, har gow and other little plates that I usually get for $2-3 per plate at those joints, I feel like Yank Sing was underwhelming and not worth the premium for comparable taste.

Service is excellent though, we didnt have to request to have hot water refilled for tea and food carts were always stopping at our table.  

Not sure if I would be planning to spend another $30-40 on lunch here any time soon, I rather just take an extra half an hour and head on out to chinatown.
author: Yun W.

description: Dim sum heaven it is not.  Imagine Starbucks branding themselves as a bakery.  Missing the point, don't you think?  Their stir-fried dishes are better, in my opinion.
author: Kristen S.

description: Quick n' dirty.  YS2G doesn't quite roll off the tongue like apocalyptic computer glitches, but their crispy spring rolls and sleazy chow mien will stick to your insides all afternoon.  Food coma inducing, greasy, and filthy good, if you were looking for an excuse to try out your "Shame Sweatpants," this is the place to pick up from.
author: Michael D.

description:
$6.35 (plus tax) gets you the Yank Sing Express, which is enough food to feed a small army, or rather, enough for lunch/dinner/next morning's breakfast, for me.  This means: a spring roll, vast fields and rolling amber waves of pork chow mein, a pork bun, and a potsticker.  (There are plenty of other options, including a vegetarian combo - I see they have chicken in foil - I might have to break out of my rut just for that.)

Tuesdays or Thursdays often have me running from Wills & Trusts straight into the greasy, warm embrace of Yank Sing 2 Go, only to ditch him forthwith, for a younger, taller, lankier model who will carry my law books, and who looks better in a loincloth while fanning me with palm fronds.  ...what?

It's not gourmet, but it is damn good in its own right.  You put up with the flaws because it's so comfortable... and why should you look for something better and face disappointment, when settling is so *easy*?

The upsides:
- I've never been able to finish this in one sitting, try as I might - lots of food for the money
- It's deliciously greasy, and greasily delicious
- If you go before noon, or after 2pm, there's hardly a line to speak of
- The staff is pretty nice, especially for being harrassed by Angry Financial District People
- It's damn convenient

Downsides:
- It's SO greasy that often when I'm carrying it home, the grease will leak out of the to-go box, through the paper bag, and into my backpack...sigh.
- It can get insanely busy during peak lunch hour times.  
- I'm pretty sure my internal organs cry when I put this food into my body... but oh god, it's so, so good.  I am helpless in the face of such culinary seduction.
author: Jennie K.

description:
I love Yank Sing and used their take out for the first time today. Mongolian Beef on a cold rainy day, perfection. The slight heat from this tender meat helped cut the edge of the cold. Outdoor patio warmed with infrared. You can actually enjoy eating outdoors on a day like today.

There are a lot of choices in the city, some good, some not so good. You decide on Chinese maybe because of connivence, maybe someone wants to meet you at their fave place. If you don't do YS you're doing yourself a disfavor. This is truly Chinese Cuisine, something you can't say about anywhere else in FIDI.
author: Steve S.

description: Dim sum here is really good.ived been  eating here since it was still a tiny place and price per plate was only .50 cents LOL!  Pricesy now but food is still the same, very good.....
author: Celia A.

description: Really good dim sum, excellent location, really expensive.  Two people average lunch 65$
author: Kyle L.

description:
Really good dim sum, awesome service, but pricey.
We were a party of 10 and we paid about $33-36 per person.

Some dim sum I've never tried before made it to the table before I even took my jacket off.

Parking was tough.
author: DayDay D.

description:
I got the Special A which contained 4 potstickers and pork chow mein.  We are anxiously awaiting to see if I keel over and die from MSG poisoning.  Stay tuned.

10 mins passes.

Attention is fading.  Sleepy.  Must not.  where are my toothpicks.  Must prop up the eyes.  I'm too sensitive to MSG.  Seriously, I completely admit it.  I'm such a fragile flower.
author: Christina C.

description: A colleague suggested we have dim lunch here. Tasty but too greasy. Much too expensive for what you get. $80 for lunch and no drinks for two small eaters  puts this place out of most peoples' reach.
author: Barbara C.

description:
When my very good friends and their two little boys said they were coming up from LA for a family visit we knew we wanted to see each other and since we all love Dim Sum I knew the one I would throw into the hat to go to.  Yank Sing is without question the best of the best in San Francisco.  Is it expensive yes, crowded yesss and noisey yessss.  But completely worth all of those things and more.

The food without question is fresh and authentic.  The items are never overly greasy and when you think you have seen diversity of items another cart comes around the corner and presto!  You have more to choose from.  

My recommendations:

Sui Mye
Pork Buns
Pot Stickers
Steamed Shrimp

YUM YUM YUM.  Also get some tea - its wonderful and goes perfect with your meal.  This is a wonderful spot for about 4-6 people any more I would say not to come here as the dinning room is tight and there are lots of ladies with carts in this place it is after all Dim Sum!
author: Heidi S.

description:
Very solid well executed dim sum with good service in a pleasant atmosphere.

Pricey but worth it if that is what you are looking for.
author: Matthew C.

description: A good spot for a take out lunch. You've got the option of picking parts and pieces for an ala carte meal or picking one of the set lunches.   I enjoy the pork buns and the avoid the noodles.
author: Ivan L.

description:
Yank Sing is great WHEN YOU ARENT FOOTIN THE BILL. 

I am oh so serious. 

The lettuce cups, peking duck, and bbq pork rolls are my ffaaaavvvorite. I know its not very diverse or authentic or what not, but everytime i come here i have to order them. i usually eat about two or three orders of the peking duck. I love how the buns are so mini and each portion of duck is perfectly cut  and they give you that little spoon to dish out the hoison sauce...yummm..i've had their speciality noodle dishes as well and they are very tasty. 

When two people can spend close to $80 for lunch on dim sum, I would have to say that its a little overpriced.
author: Julie F.

description: Dim sum is very overpriced! My favorite dim sum is XiaoRong Bao! I usually go there for takeout, they are good and reasonably priced. I like chicken salad and their lunch special rice dishes'
author: Emmy P.

description:
F'ing delicious dim sum.  
Only problem is I only ate about $20 worthof food and paid $134.00.

Yang Sing are you f'ing nuts?  Its Chinese food buddy!

Thank you stupid people for ruining a good thing.
author: Spanky M.

description:
Yeah, I'm Chinese. And yeah, I gave Yank Sing 4 stars. Wait! Before you accuse me of being a banana or Twinkie, let me explain. 

Before last week, I prided myself on the fact that I had never eaten at Yank Sing. In fact, I use to clown on Chinese friends who admitted to liking the restaurant by saying, "That means you're white-washed. You're going to marry a gwai lo and join a country club. You're going to name your kids Adeline and Preston and they're going to suck at math."

Then, last week, I ate at Yank Sing not once, but twice. And you know what, I liked it. I really liked it.

The first time, I went for a wedding rehearsal lunch. Their dim sum assortment was impressive and the food tasty. The carts, constantly zipping around the tables, offered the standards like shrimp dumpling, shu mai, and egg roll as well as the more exotic dishes such as Peking duck. Their xiao long baos were juicy and the skin just thick enough to prevent leakage without being chewy. The dofu fa was light with just the right amount of ginger and sugar syrup.

Then this past Saturday, my friend's wedding took place in Rincon Center. The Yank Sing staff was able to quickly and seamlessly transform the atrium from restaurant to ceremony seating to 400+ guest banquet seating. As co-wedding coordinator, I was more than impressed with their efficiency and professionalism. In terms of the food, the 10-course banquet menu was not as tasty as their dim sum but everything was still above par.

I still think that Yank Sing is way too overpriced and unless someone else is treating, I most likely won't be back. But I do feel like I owe my Yank Sing-loving, ABC friends an apology. By the way, I'm thinking of naming my kids Madison and Connor. They are going to get straight Bs and NOT play any racket sports.
author: .elin f.

description:
Not bad, not bad at all..

Greasy:
Chow mein - check.
1 Egg roll - check
1 Dumpling - check

Total: $6.95 of greaseyness.

Plus stars for the outside comfy seating in the alleyway!!

But too bad the food has been prepared in advanced :(
author: Elliot Y.

description:
Good Lord, I get this nervous tick if I don't eat here at least once a month. And by "eat here," I specifically mean enjoying their Shanghai Dumplings. Served tongue-burning hot, with a soup spoon, so you can bite a little and not lose the broth. The pork inside is a treasure. 

I especially like going with my friend Mena -- she turned me onto them in the first place -- and the even better thing is that she doesn't even eat pork, so I get the order all to my self-centered self!

Sure Yank Sing is expensive, but the quality of ingredients makes it 100% worth it.
author: Nish N.

description:
I'm pretty sure you're paying for the service when you come here. I'm pretty sure the servers here are used to serving white business men too lazy to open a  menu and decipher what in god's name a Shanghai Dumpling is because they simply must peruse the real estate section of The Chron while talking to Muffy McStalepersona on his new iphone.

I met up with a couple friends here last Sunday, and although I thoroughly enjoyed my experience, I did not enjoy shelling out a good chunk of change for food I could get over on Geary for $10 a head. 

Ok, so over on Geary you sit for a good half an hour before anyone actually talks to you. And over on Geary they sit the gringos in the corner. And over on Geary you have to actually circle the items of food you want on a little paper instead of just pointing like a chimp in designer jeans. But over on Geary I can walk away with a minimal dent in my wallet and enough cashity cash to get me a monster Sunday from Joe's.

+three stars for the teapot that looks kind of like a squat bong. I want one of those. So if any of you feel like buying me a birthday present (November bitches!!!!!!!!!!) get me one....or a new set of knives, or a tent. Thanksssssss!

I also dug me some stuffed crab claws. Those mothers were crabby and moussey and crunchy and all sorts of goodness.

As I shoved shrimp dumpling and shrimp and chive dumplings into my salivating trap a giant Cheshire Cat grin spread across my face.

Good thing I was still in a fried seafood-induced coma when the bill came, or else I would have surely passed out, knocked my dome on that precious tea pot and scalded my face off. Fried seafood saves me every time. It also leaves me with a zit the size of my ankle.
author: Sammy S.

description: Enjoyed the steamed dim sum. The guo tie was also really good, as good as the dim sum I've had in Singapore and Taipei.
author: Matt C.

description:
The lines are long during lunch, but they go real fast.  For $7, you can get all the carbs you want... each of the specials usually come with chow mein or fried rice (sometimes both), along with an assortment of dim sum items.  They definitely give you enough food to last two meals, so you get your money's worth!

The food is a bit on the greasy side, but hey... it's good.  The won ton soup is probably the closest thing you'll find to healthy... five shrimp won tons in shrimp stock with a few pieces of green onions strewn on top... delicious.
author: Claire H.

description:
Yes, you might call Yank Sing "Dim Sum for Dummies" but I mean that in the most respectful way.  I've come to love dim sum, but there was a time (as recent as ten years ago) when I was iffy on it (call me ignorant or uninitiated or Caucasian, I don't mind) and I told my then-girlfriend, now-wife that I didn't like dim sum because I'm not into gelatinous foods.  That's what I thought dim sum was... gelatinous unidentifiable dumplings.  OK, I admitted to being ignorant, already!

Well, I think my dim sum lightbulb went off in my head when I had Yank Sing for the first time many a year ago.  I think it was the potsticker and the pork bun that got my mojo going.  Either way, while some criticize Yank Sing for being spendy and maybe too sanitized, I confess to loving it.

We sometimes get take-out from Yank Sing for lunch work meetings, and when we do, I'm always pretty fired up.  It can be a bit heavy, but it's not their fault that I feel compelled to eat every morsel they deliver.
author: Brad P.

description:
Shanghai dumplings conceal broth redolent of ginger and sweet pork, though be careful not to squirt your dining companion as you bite into them.. 

The Har Gow are the best in the city, with the perfect balance of bamboo shoots and shrimp. I also love the translucent scallop and chive dumplings and the spicy clams in xo sauce. Be sure to try the young pea-shoots in season and the salt and pepper sea bass. 

The cart ladies respond well to a firm hand, and remember, the word "No" is your most powerful weapon.
author: Stellah D.

description:
I went, gorged, paid, left, looked at my watch and realized to my shock that the whole thing had only taken 25 minutes.

I now realize that this is due primarily to not having to wait for food.  Heckuva concept.

I do recommend calling to get reservations.  You can usually do this same-day, and it guarantees you a seat inside the restaurant.  In the summer, this is no big deal, but I wouldn't want to sit outside in the winter.

I'm from Wyoming, so I won't weigh in on whether this is "real" "authentic" dim sum.  But I did go there with a dim sum aficionado, and he loves the place.  He used to live here, now lives in DC, and makes it a point to eat at Yank Sing every time he's in the city.  So that has to mean something, right?  I found the food to be pretty standard dim sum fare, reasonably well executed.
author: Ben P.

description:
This past Sunday I took my sisters and their boyfriends out to eat Dim Sum and out of the places I'd had to pick the most expensive one.  Ballin' I think not, I'm straight broke now....hahahaha.  

Yank Sing is always a good place to eat some really good Shanghai Pork Dumplings my favorite - we order four of these babies and I took out two of them among others of course.  Other items we ordered were the three rice and pork filling, 2 orders of the toasted shrimp, 2 orders of the mushroom dumpling (really good), 2 orders of the crab claws, 2 orders of pork sumai, 2 orders of the shrimp gow, 1 order of pork bun, 1 mango pudding, 1 pistachio ice cream cake, 1 mango ice cream cake.  There were six of us and the bill came out to $200.  It was good but we were stuffed - DIM SUM!
author: Kong Y.

description:
I remember when dim sum was cheap and really good.  Lunch would run you about $8.00 and you'd be full of food.  If you have to shell out your black AmEx to pay for lunch, you're being ripped off no matter how good the dim sum is.

This is a place that caters to a certain non Chinese crowd that throws around their money like they just sold their start up to Yahoo.  It's pretty obnoxious when this restaurant fills up.  

The yuppies and hipsters love taking out of town guests here.  The last time I went I saw a sprinkling of Asian folks wearing Chloe and Ferragamo.  It kind of goes against everything I know and love, so I won't be back soon, although I'd love to find a good dim sum place eventually that doesn't cost me $30 for a dumpling brunch.
author: Angelina J.

description: Terrible dim sum, expensive, left out belly unfull and unsatisfy for 50bucks for two people. Another crappy restaurant in SF...
author: James V.

description:
I often overhear people saying that this is the best dim sum in the city. I think it really depends on your taste.  

It is a more upscale restaurant, but as far as the food goes, I've definitely had better... It seems like the type of place you take someone who has never tried dim sum before, especially if you yourself have trouble ordering in Chinese at the other restaurants.  

They have the typical dishes. But for the love of all that's greasy, who in the world eats Peking Duck for LUNCH? Okay, let me rephrase. They serve Peking Duck at lunch if you feel so inclined to order it, but based on my experience, that's a dish that comes out at dinnertime when you're ordering for a banquet. COME ON!  

We ended up getting various dumpling dishes and then a fried noodle dish. The dumplings were good. The noodles, however, were not - WAY too salty.  

For the prices, I was expecting a seafood lunch or something. I left not only disappointed with the hole in my wallet, but also because I was still hungry. How many times do I need to repeat - big appetite!?

I wouldn't recommend Yank Sing to someone seeking a more authentic experience. No Chinese grams and gramps here!
author: Tinna H.

description:
Although my San Francisco trip was pretty last minute, my network didn't fail me (I sound like a Verizon commercial).  The foodie friend that I was up visiting recently in NYC put me in touch with a good college friend of hers from Cal, and said friend decided to meet up with me at Yank Sing for lunch.

Absolutely adorable and delicious!

I loved the vibe here.  It's bustling, the decor is very modern and minimalistic, and there's a general din of motion and conversation.  My new friend was absolutely spot on that we needed to get here by 1140 to beat the lunch rush; and we barely did!  As soon as noon rolled around, there was a throng of people (and moms and baby strollers - weird) waiting outside for seats.  Fortunately for us, we managed to sneak in just before the full tide of hungry lunchers and got a little table for two in the middle of the dining room.

Although the dim sum food served here is a lot more upscale and a lot less plebeian than what I'm used to (I'm comparing against dive-y authentic dim sum), it's all done amazingly well - you'll just end up getting hammered when the check comes.  Don't worry, it's totally worth it to splurge every so often, and I'd consider this splurge-y if you plan to fill up.  Some personal highlights were the gooey fried shrimp and the ginger/garlic green beans.  Savory!

Ideally a place one would go with an expense account and a client to take to lunch.  Still a great joint for a classy lunch date.  I would totally wish for something like close to where I work!
author: Kevin L.

description: The experience is like no other... although i wish i could have more time to make my decisions, i recommend you take your time reading the menu and don't get carry away getting all the food you can on your table, there are delicious salads on the menu that are not offered to you when the carts are roaming the restaurant.
author: A R.

description:
Did Yank Sing just charge my family $9 for tea?!  I CALL SHENANIGANS ON THEM!  Okay, given their inscrutable pricing and billing system, we could be wrong.  But Dad is Chinese, a dim sum regular, and an ex-math teacher at that, so I'm inclined to trust his opinion.

I feel so angry and so helpless because I'll still be back.  I'll always come back.  So will you.  Everything at Yank Sings is the bomb.
author: Lauren C.

description: Lunch with a colleague - got there (crowded), and in the middle of sitting down were bombarded with dim sum carts and dishes thrust in our faces, holy crap can I sit down?  ok ok I get it, this is not supposed to be a delicate dainty quiet and elegant experience..  heh...well, OK and we started with the dumplings, really good, thin skinned, tasty, hot.  Tried a few others - not quite up to the dumplings - shrimp, stuffed mushrooms, a few others.  Although the dumplings were top notch, the rest were good - but knocking them down on price - quite expensive.  Will make my way around town for other dim sum offerings before coming back.
author: Tom R.

description:
If you look at the negative reviews here, the only bad thing anyone says about it is that it's expensive.  And yes, it's expensive.  It is.  Very expensive.  Yes, particularly for dim sum.  Yes, I know.  I know.  Pricey.  So.  Now you know.  If you can't afford it, I'm sorry.  If you want cheap dim sum, go anywhere else.  If you can't believe dim sum could possibly be worth these prices, Chinatown is only six blocks away.

Now, if you've gotten past that, I'm going to assume that you're not going to bitch when you go and have amazing dim sum and end up paying a lot for it.  Go on the company's dime.  Get it reimbursed.  Splurge.  Whatever.  But please shut up about it being expensive.

The food is GREAT.  Wonderful dim sum, both the traditional and the modern.  Their soup dumplings are so flavorful and delicate. Their broiled/sauteed/seared/pan-roasted cod/sea bass was better than Ame's, or just about any other nice restaurant's that I've had.  And their (yeah, yeah, pricey) tea is very high quality, which you may not notice, but I certainly did.  It was delicious, and with reservations, they're very prompt at the seating.  So go, have dim sum, groan when you see the bill, pay it, and then tell us how you liked the food.
author: David B.

description:
Yum, yum, yum. We loved everything we got, though the lettuce wraps a little to be desired. But everything else - the dumplings, baos, etc - was awesome.

Be prepared to spend some money, though. I thought part of the definition of dim sum was 'cheap', but not here. I was a little surprised. I would definitely bring friends here, but won't make a habit of coming all the time. It would definitely be a great place to introduce someone to dim sum. They won't be disappointed.
author: Laura A.

description:
One star is too many. If you have ever had real dim sum then do not bother with this place. The signature dumpling was the only one that was worth eating. The shu mai was nothing special and the shrimp dumpling was the same. The best dish we had was the cold green beans. 

The egg roll was infused with grease as was the taro. The main problem with this place is the fact that they do not tell you the price of the items on the menu. We ate 6 different dim sum items at this place. The bill was $69.00. The same amount of food at a real dim sum restaurant, like say, Great Eastern in China Town would set you back $25.00 bucks. 

The service was great, unfortunately what they were serving was not. I should have known there was a problem when the whole restaurant was filled with tourists and not a single person from any Asian country other than the wait staff was present. That is one of the main things to look for in an ethnic restaurant. If the people that define the food don''t eat it, then you should not eat the food as well.

This appeared to be more of a pretentious restaurant for those who think they are adventurous eaters and those who have more money than to care. I also witnessed two women from who knows where go into shock when they found out the amount of food that left them hungry cost them over $140.00. 

I am sure there were others that went into shock when they received their  bill. I should have known better, but decided to roll the dice. To my dismay I rolled snake eyes.
author: Kevin K.

description:
In the city where $90 lunches are as commonplace as bike lanes, one still needs a good reason to spend that kind of money on lunch.  I mean, we're in recession, and Lee's Deli is just around the corner.  

When my sister and I come here, we usually leave about $100 on the table.  Yup, not your everyday lunch.  Whether you dine at this, small and cramped location, or at the other, large and posh Rincon Center location, prepare to spend some $$$$.   Is it worth it?  Yes.

You get what you paid for.  The quality and selection of dim sum here puts other dim sum restaurants to shame.  Everything we had this time (shrimp dumplings, shiitake mushroom dumplings, chicken dumplings, steamed pork buns, snap peas, Peking duck, Shanghai dumplings, mango pudding, sesame balls) was great.  Every single piece was piping hot and bursting with flavor.

The service is exquisite and rivals, perhaps, that of Harbor Village.  When I said no to the Shanghai dumplings, which may be the best dim sum they offer, the waitress inquired why I didn't want them.  I told her that my sister doesn't eat pork, and I can't eat 8 dumplings by myself.  (Ah, who am I kidding?  I can, but I shouldn't).  She immediately brought us a half order.  Now, that's attentive and proactive service, at a dim sum place, no less!

Remember: early bird gets the har gao!  Get here before 11:45 or make a reservation.  Otherwise, you'll end up standing in line for 30 minutes watching others devour little bits of greasy heaven.
author: Yan G.

description:
Yeah, this place is problematic to review. Let me first say I've never dim summed in Millbrae/Daly City, and haven't been to Hong Kong since I was 3, so I don't know if Yank Sing matches the best places in those hotbeds. But their ingredient quality is better than that of any other dim sum joint I've been to - no shortcuts, no lumps of fat or gristle to wreck the taste. (The possible exception is shrimp.) And their cooking is also better than that of any other dim sum joint I've been to - even the difficult items, like wu gok, were flawlessly prepared. Given this, you'd think Yank Sing would be by far the best dim sum I've had, but for some reason, it was the best by only a small margin, and I'm not sure if that margin is worth 2-3 times the price of some pretty good, if dirtier, places in Oakland. Here's what I remember having:

wu gok - delicately crisp, by far the best I've had
siu mai - really good, salty and porky, among the best I've had not made by my Mum
shallot pancakes - not something I usually have, very good as far as I can tell
har gow - good but should've been better if this was the dish they charged us $7.70 for; shrimp was fresh but not wow fresh
spare ribs - just OK
chicken feet - bad, spice was really toned down: why Americanise this of all dishes?

Advice: if you suspect something's expensive, ask the price.
author: Brad L.

description:
Closest and best Deem Sum to YelpHQ.   Notice I didn't say in the WORLD, just closest to work.  The best way IMO to experience Yank Sing is through the back door (If i had a nickle...) in the express line (If i had another nickle..).    $7 for a to go container filled to the brim with Chow Mein,  1 potsticker, 1 spring roll and a Steamed or Baked Pork Bun (their specialty).   Try to finish that mothertruckin platter, I dare you.

Yank Sing FTW.
author: Todd F.

description:
My dad, boyfriend and I went to Yank Sing when my father was visiting us a little while back.  My dad used to live in SF and loves both the city and dim sum, so, after a recommendation from one of his "dim sum expert" friends, he insisted that we go to Yank Sing.  I tried to steer him towards Ton Kiang, the bf and I's favorite Sunday morning dim sum place, but he was adamant about Yank Sing.

The food was good (barring the grotesque, how can you ever hate dim sum?), and the atmosphere was nice.  However, nearby parking meant a quarter for every five minutes, and I was quite shocked to see our tab coming in around $120.  A gorging meal at Ton Kiang, without alcohol, usually results in about $30 for a couple of people.

I have admittedly not sampled every dim sum joint in SF*, but I think one would be better off at Ton Kiang - if anything, I think the food at Ton Kiang is better, and it certainly is a lot cheaper.  My dad, just in for another brief visit, this time insisted on Ton Kiang, and thought that it was hugely better.

*yet
author: Tanya N.

description:
Apart from the places I went to Hong Kong, this is hands-down the best dim sum I've had in the States.  Not only is the food delicious (ask for the special house dumpling), the servers are unbelievably nice.  If you have ever been to a dim sum place in Chinatown, you know that customer service and dim sum are like polar opposite.

Yank Sing is a fabulous place to have a weekend brunch/lunch with your family and friends.  To avoid being crowded, go to the one in Rincon Center.
author: Tony P.

description:
Really tasty dim sum for way too much money.  I love their place, their food, their service.  But it's too expensive for me.  Chinatown has comparable food, and for way less money.  

But I'd definitely save up my pennies to eat here again sometime.
author: Honey L.

description:
Pricey but goooooood.

Seabass special and Xiao Long Baos are a must have. You can tell they cater to all the business expense accounts cuz they swarm you when you get in and place the dishes on the table before you can tell them no. 

Best dim sum in the financial district and you always leave full (if its for business, of course). or else be prepared to cough up a hefty penny for lunch.
author: Patrick M.

description: Yes it;s expensive but the quality of the dim sum was extraordinary. The wrappers on the har gao wete perfectly done - not soggy and oversteamed - the innards were succulent, the skin for the Peking duck was crisp but not dried out while the duck was tender and not the least greasy. The Shanghai dumplings were wonderful and melted in my mouth. The minced chicken in lettuce leaf was tasty without having to add hoisin sauce and the combination of textures from the water chesnuts, and pine nuts was entertaining. The service was perfect - the waitresses were wired and when one came by and I wished for something not on her tray - she passed along my order.
author: Steve G.

description:
thumbs up:
xiao long bao/shanghai dumplings
har gow/ shrimp dumpling
shiu mia/ pork & shrimp dumpling
spinach dumplings
nai wong bao/ steamed custard bun
turnip cake
rice noodle roll with shrimp

thumbs down:
peking duck with steam bun
crab claw
burning my tongue on the very hot tea
author: Josie M.

description:
This place smacks of pretention. We knew were were in trouble when we ended up at their old location and they had a shuttle via Mercedes-Benz sedan to their new location.

Dim sum should not cost this this much money. Plus, I have no idea why they were serving edamame and other Americanized non-dim sum dishes. I guess the tourists and the unitiated don't know any better. If it was cheaper, I might give it a better review, but there are so many other great dim sum places in San Francisco that I don't know why you'd waste your time or money here.
author: Arnold G.

description:
I prefer this place over the one on Spears St.
1) Better service (Winnie is a pro, and your dim sum servers are much more descriptive and knowledgeable which tells me there is better management here)
2) Better setting (intimate, not a clusterfuck inside a HUGE ballroom where dim sum carts roam but don't stop to serve you like the other location)
3) Better variety, generally, than Spears St (yes I go often enough to know this)
4) FRESH FRESH FRESH FRESH

Not that Spears St location is a huge variation in terms of those 4 factors, but at the price I am paying I deserve the very best they have to offer.

Yank Sing, while pricey, is the best dim sum you can get in san francisco and they really have very consistent quality.

You will eat some unique treats here as well as the absolute best of a few common favorites - Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai Soup Dumplings, filled with minced pork and giner mixture and pork broth - the consistency and size of the filling in proportion to broth and the thinness of the dumpling skin is the best I've see), the best steamed bbq pork bun, baked pork bun (chicken, pork, vegetables in a steambed bun then grilled on either sides), amazing vegetarian dumpling varieties (so tasty! - snow peas, curried vegetables, spinach, shitake mushrooms) and desserts to die for. I didn't care much for some of their seafood items - I"m not a big fan of fishcakes and the Chinese are, like they like to make paste out of all kinds of sea food then bread it and deep fry it and that is not good to me. Also if you're with a big party try the string beans with pork (spicy), walnut prawns (has this sweet mayo sauce over it), wonton soup, sechwan chicken... you won't really find a thing you don't find yummy. It's hard not to get suckered into saying yes to every offering, but you have to watch yourself because it adds up.

The highlights of this restaurant in addition to what I've described are that everytime you visit you'll taste something new, it's always clean, and you'll want to come back... for your next meal.
author: Y K.

description:
Over-priced and they don't even serve most of the traditional chinese dim sum.  Selection tends to gears toward American style, which loses the traditional dim sum culture.  Food is served luke warm.  A real chinese person will not come here for dim sum.  It's for ppl who has no idea what real dim sum means.

******3/19/2007 Update*********
I think I was a little too harsh on judging this place.  I think their dim sum is not that great, but I recently came here for dinner and I think that they are on par w/ the traditional chinese restaurants.  but I stick to my view that Yank Sing is way overpriced.  If you want real chinese food, there are plenty in the bay area that are just as good and would cost half as much.
author: AhLin C.

description:
It's dim sum EN VITESSE!!

Sure, a lot of the staples - the siu mai, potstickers and such - are cooked in bulk and warmed in hot shelves for I don't know how long until they're ready to be dished out when ordered.  It's all good.  And TRES RAPIDE!!

At the very least you can't help but marvel at the assembly-line setup.  It's necessary for handling that hungry worker bee lunch crowd.  It's how they get your grub to you IMMEDIATEMENT!!

So lunch here whenever you've got the craving but not the time.  And get a red bean sesame ball for dessert.  Nine times out of ten it'll be fresh since it's not that well requested.  Oops, there goes my secret!

;p
author: Eileen P.

description:
Absolutely wretched excuse for Dim Sum.  I ordered a Yank Sing Super one day - greasy egg roll, Singapore noodles; bland, tiny siu mai; dry curry chicken puff; wilted and soggy egg custard.  

The only thing to recommend this place is that it's so close to the SF offices on the same block.
author: Claudine C.

description:
This girl has travelled to 16 countries, tried everything from oysters and escargot to durian ice-cream but never had dim sum?!?!?!

Time to fix that -- an almost business lunch in the financial district. Seated promptly, attacked by a lady with a dumpling cart almost immediately. All the veggie dumplings are delicious, so are the shrimp ones. Beware anything with either "scallop" or "crab" -- both imitations. Do make sure you have a sesame ball for dessert. A fried slice of heaven with red bean paste inside.

Now, can we do something about those prices?
author: Gina M.

description:
I've been to this location several times and hope to someday visit the other locations.  I enjoy the take out and  was one time too naive to eat there.  I ordered 4 amazing dishes and was duped into paying a bill of over $35.  Watch out underpaid downtown workers, please be careful that the dining is super expensive.  
I enjoyed the house special dumpling that has soup inside.  A soup dumpling is a great invention.
They are fast and efficient during the busy lunch rush.  I go and get the daily special togo items.
author: Sharon T.

description:
Just so you know my mom refuses to come here w/ me coz it's overpriced and not authentic in her mind.  She rather that we go to Koi Palace in Daly City or Joy Luck Place in San Mateo.  Mom is probably right. Yank Sing isn't a authentic dim sum joint like the ones you see in HK, but for me who loves dim sum but is vegetarian, I pretty much have nothing to eat there.  Not only that, I enjoy the service and ambiance at the Stevenson St. Yank Sing (... I've heard diff. stories about the Rincon Center location). 

For me, it's a treat to get there early on a Saturday, illegally park my car on Stevenson St (where I can see it) in case the Traffic Nazi comes around, sipping on tea, and indulging myself in:

- Snow Pea Shoot Dumplings
- Savory Vegetable Dumplings
- Spinach Dumplings  
- Curry Vegetable Dumplings
- Deep Fried Tofu Roll (OK. So I have to confess. I'm 100+% certain that there are bits of shrimp in this dish.  So, I cheat sometimes. You got a problem w/ that?! -- For those who don't know what I'm talking about, these sinful rolls look like http://www.yanksing.com/our-cuisine/deem-sum-gallery/deep-fried-items/tofu-roll.html)

I've never gotten things take-out from here.  To-gos just don't do dim-sum justice!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
This place is superb it's no ordinary dim sum this is straight out of Hong Kong quality yam tza.

I came up to the City this weekend from Palo Alto to visit my sister for the weekend. I have been to Yank Sing a lot since it is a family favorite. Not until recently did I have a chance to peek at the bill. wow, dim sum for 3 for $80.00!!

Here is why its worth it:

First of all, its in SOMA. I mean the Fairy Building serves fish and chips for $17.50.  So you got to expect the price to be high. You are in a nice neighborhood, it doesn't smell like china town with that odd mixture of rotting garbage and good food. It smells fresh, its in a  part of San Francisco where the some comes out a lot. Prices are going to be higher for that reason. I mean, there are million dollar apartments around you.

And you have to talk about the quality of dim sum. Yes, I admit I have had better dim sum before, in Hong Kong. Each piece of dim sum is smaller then the dim sum peaces at places around the bay area. And you might be confused and start thinking that they are trying to rip you off  by using less filling in the dim sum. I can see that happening in this super sized culture we have created in the US. They aren't trying to cut the portions, its how dim sum should be. Tightly packed with pork or shrimp not filled with fillers like corn starch. The quality of dim sum is really high.

Service, last week I went to dim sum with a non-asian friend of mine. She asked why the waitresses were so rude. My simple reply was, "it's dim sum you aren't paying for service, you are paying for dim sum." Well, thats not the case here! Excellent service, I mean really superb. They speak multiple dialects of Chinese and you don't have to worry about them not being able to make out your English like you do in China Town. There was an old Jewish couple at the table next to us and they got served just fine. Speaking of being served. The carts come fast, there is no waiting for the cart with the dim sum to come around to your table, it's there. And! if it's not? Every cart serves has a headset and you can ask them for whatever you want and the order goes through the headset and comes in less then a minute. Ridiculously awesome.

The place is clean, super clean. This is authentic Chinese fine dining-- no fusion involved. This is something you see straight out of Hong Kong, a restaurant equivalent to a nice steak place here, culturally different of course. This is why things are a little pricier, the dim sum places you find in China Town are equivalent to going to Denny's for steak or maybe at best Outback Steak House, you get my point.

Anyways, enough with defending the price, here is my latest experience:

It was a nice Sunny Saturday morning here in SOMA, we were headed out for brunch then, we were going to head over the the fairy building for farmers market, we stuck to the basics:

Sui Mai - Har Gau - Lo Bak Goh - Wu Gock - Pai Gaut - Nua mi fun
http://chinesefood.abo...

They also had these really good Taiwanese dumplings called - xiao long bao. Goodness I haven't had xiao long bao since I was in Taiwan.

And to top it off we had some Pan Friend crispy noodle- which came with a generous portion of seafood, I mean, really good stuff.

Satisfied we paid and bought two jars of their house made hot sauce and we were on our way, full and satisfied.

So there you go, $80 bucks, great service, superb food; 5 stars for sure.

note: Don't get me wrong, I love going to china-town too. I really am not all posh and stuck-up as this review makes me out to be, there just needs to be a clarification of what this place is all about.
author: Steve L.

description:
My friends and I planned to meet at Yank Sing around 1 PM on a Saturday and there was quite a line to get in. For a party of five, the wait ended up only being about twenty minutes surprisingly. 

Once we got seated, food started coming out right away. There were so many carts and things coming out that I am not sure of everything we ate. It was actually a bit overwhelming.  From what I do recall, we had the potstickers, phoenix tailed shrimp, sea bass roll, stuffed crab claw, scallion prawn, mushrooms, and a snow crab dish..

Overall everything was good but as compared to other Dim Sum places, probably on the more expensive side. All of us had water to drink and, with tip, we each paid $35.
author: Jillian J.

description:
Yank Sing must mean "expensive" in chinese. 

Spending $70 on lunch for 2 is quite expensive for me. Despite the ultra-steep price, the food was very, very good. The wait staff was also above par, being extremely nice and helpful. It seemed like there was always a cart on the way with more tasty dishes to choose from. I'm not sure if I'll be back anytime soon, but if I've got some money to burn and I want dim sum, this is definitely where I'll go. Only recommeded for those with deep pockets or those with a craving for great dim sum.
author: Brad M.

description:
Let's get this out of the way first - if you're looking for inexpensive dim sum (and some believe that there should ONLY be inexpensive dim sum since it should be appealing for the masses) then turn around and walk away from this place before you even step foot inside.

BUT - if you are looking for a special treat and are not as hung up on the high prices, then keep reading.

This place is about as clean inside as you will EVER see in a Chinese restaurant.  They also have very polite and helpful and (gasp) FRIENDLY wait staff.  Clearly a rarity in Chinese restaurants.  

On to the food.  The dim sum is visually exquisite.  We brought friends and their kids here recently as a special treat.  We had a great time.  They have a house-special dumpling that is sort of a round shaped Fun Gor with a mini amount of won ton broth sealed right into the dumpling.  You eat it on a Chinese soup spoon so that you don't lose the broth when you first bit into it.  Wonderful flavors and texture and you wont find this at many other places if any.  Also the single serving Peking Duck is almost worth the price of admission.  4 out of the 8 in our party had some and it was hoovered down so quickly I barely had time to take a snapshot.  The Siu Mai and Har Gow were delicious.  As were the other dumplings.  We did not even get to try them all.  We also had a piece of baked Sea Bass.  Delicious.  And the Nor Mai Gai (sticky rice in bamboo leaf) was just a touch more refined and a bit more tasty than your usual.  Two orders of potstickers were consumed by the kids.  But nothing extra special about those.  We also had chrysanthemum tea with our dim sum.  And we finished with Don Tart - traditional baked custard tarts that were fresh out of the oven.  If you like Don Tart then you will love theirs.  As good as any you will get in town.  But if you are not a Don Tart fan already then you can pass.

This is a fun fun place to have dim sum, especially if you're enjoying a special occasion with friends.  And that we were.  Joy ghin.  (that's "see you again later" in Cantonese ... in case you cared)
author: Lewis C.

description:
This is my first one star review....

*deep breath*

I was stoked for my vegetarian combo because it was only $5.75 which, for all the food it said I was getting and because Yank Sing proper is so upscaleyummygood, seemed like an awesome deal.

Well.  The eggplant was flat out disgusting.  The noodles didn't taste like anything except grease.  Seriously.  I dumped literally about 6 packs of soy sauce onto the noodles before they tasted like ANYTHING other than grease (it instead tasted like soy sauce saturated grease.)

The only thing that I could really stomach were the two little veggie dumplings.

I'm all for some greasy Chinese food.  And I was majorly hungover and sleep-deprived so this should have hit the spot.

but yuck yuck yuck.
author: Ashley B.

description:
LOVE this place.  Even my Dad's favorite Dim Sum joint in Seattle is no real competition.  I have eaten here three times (all with the same friend).  I don't know how others leave for only 22 bucks.  I have never left for less than 50 bucks.  I don't mind the price because they have such a fabulous selection.

I wish I could give 3.5 stars because the usual problem here is the VERY long wait for a table.  They need to move to a larger restaurant.  Please open a Yank Sing in Santa Clara/Milpitas area!
author: Dean B.

description:
Some people say Yank Sing has the best dim sum in San Francisco.  Well, who the heck has time to try everything anyway?

Regardless, the food here is incredible--  it's high-quality, gourmet, fairly authentic (I mean, it's still got that California flair).
author: Abendigo R.

description: Way too expensive for what you get.  Definitely a tourist trap for those who don't know any better.  But, it's not all bad.  The food is just OK.
author: Joe C.

description: Worst experience at a restaurant in the city to date.  I went here with some friends from out of town.  The food was average and definitely WAY overpriced.  I much prefer the taste at Good Luck Dim Sum and it's about 1/10th the price!  The waiting staff was rude and unhelpful.  My friend had to chase them down once just to get their attention (Actually ran them down to get the dessert platter :) )  The dessert was awful and bland.  I will never return here and recommend you don't waste your time either.  You have been warned!
author: Aaron B.

description:
The Little White Girl's Guide to Eating At Yank Sing Without Breaking the Bank:

1) maximum of 2 serving dishes with food on them at a time (two people -  for more... 3 but definitely not more than 4 plates)

2) waive away all offers for more food until you either finish what you already have, or decide that you really didn't like that little adventure after all. 

3) stop when pleasantly full.

4)  now this is the tricky one:  choose your Dim Sum partners well.  The end bill isn't broken down by dish, and lets face it - you all had a little of everything, so the only *reasonable* thing to do is split it evenly by how  ever many people there are.  So:

- if you're a little person with a small appetite go with other people who also have small appetites.  

- if you're a person with a large appetite (runners, hockey players, really active people, etc...) ideally go with people with small appetites... that way you can out eat everyone and still pay less!  if not, go with your sports buddies and be ready to face the proverbial music.  

- if you have a sugar daddy / momma, ignore rules 1-3 and pig out!

On the practical side... following the above rules with two people relatively small appetites led to damages of $50 before tip.

And... for the first time in my (short) dim sum eating life, I managed to walk away from the table instead of rolling!

Clearly, I liked the food.  Else I'd have given it a lesser rating. But the food's already adequately described in other reviews.
author: Hilary K.

description: Others have said it: best Shanghai dumplings/soup dumplings. Well worth the price. I just wish I could have them emailed to me as an attachment.
author: Matt P.

description:
best shanghai dumplings ive ever had!!

steamed bun with BBQ pork was amazing!

solid peking duck but ive had better

sesame balls, pork sui mye, har gau were all great

friendly service

expensive but well worth the price
author: jo jo j.

description:
I love the taste of their overpriced dim sum.  I've had great lunch experiences here and really enjoyed their food.

On the other hand, you better know what you want to order from the pick-up window because the ladies behind the register will not give you a quiet moment for you to decide what you would like to eat.  I hate places that rush you so they can take more orders and make more money.  You can take quick orders and make your money but be nice about it...sheesh!
author: Michelle D.

description:
This is my favorite place to go for special occasion lunches in FiDi.  My first time here was when my division manager took me out to thank me for working as a summer intern for her team.  Fast forward two years to the present and I'm now working as a consultant for the same team and still loving every business lunch at Yank Sing!  

Today while dining in the outdoor, covered patio, I tried the siu long bao, and it seriously brought me back to eating dumplings in Shanghai. Although dining at Yank Sing is expensive, they always deliver the best dim sum and great service.
author: Kimberly J.

description: Cheap, fast, and greasy.  It's not great by any means but it's so inexpensive you can hardly expect any better.  I heard the sit down restaurant was 100% better, but i never have time to go.  If it is anything like the take-out food, don't waste your money.
author: Jordan F.

description:
Omg what a rip-off. This place is incredibly pricey dim sum. If you want dim sum, go a couple blocks up and eat in Chinatown, where dim sum is priced how it should be priced! They charge $5+ for tea - tea should be complimentary!

If you have money, sure, why not, go eat here. You've got money to waste.  But if you appreciate good dim sum and refuse to pay more on principles, eat somewhere else.
author: Carol L.

description:
Our party of four was in quick search for a pleasant lunch spot while amidst the towering office buildings. Fortunately, we had a local expert among us, thus relieved of any decision making where to go. She led us to this place navigated through a myriad of secret passages, back streets, and office buildings.

The food was spectacular. We had a delightful conversation while being flooded with delicacies of all sorts trolley-ed into our proximity with a speed of a streetcar. All sorts of goodies were coming our way and temptation to try them took better of me.

Being the first timer to the premises, I was somehow uneasy about the speed required for decision making. Being struck with all the choices, I found myself overwhelmed, the feeling gradually replaced with ecstasy of tastes.

Heavenly feast was abruptly brought to an end with a bitter aftertaste once the bill has been presented and awareness sunk in that all that is good may have a price tag that is somehow less palatable .... Given the company and quality of food - what could have been the greatest lunch in long time turned into an uneasy feeling of ... expensive and beyond-reasonable ....

Is this wonderful city spoiling me with expectation of good and inexpensive... ?
author: Rob R.

description:
My first experience with a dim sum restaurant and it was awesome.

The staff was very helpful from how to eat everything to recommendations. They served us everything we wanted in a very quickly. It almost reminded me of an Asian version of a Churrascaria except your paying by the piece and they never stop coming.

I see why people say they can rack up a bill pretty easily, but we ordered a lot and we ended up only spending about $50 for 2 people. We had pretty much everything that wasn't seafood since my fiancee is allergic. The dumplings were very flavorful and well cooked. The BBQ duck was awesome and perfectly made. The steamed pork buns were pretty good too.

We had a lot of fried items like the spring rolls, won tons, and the pot stickers. They were all really good and perfectly fried. I had no complaints on all of our food. Everything was great.
author: Len D.

description: In times where I can't get into the restaurant (showing up around 12:30 or 1), the 2 go place is perfect, if I want the hargow, pork buns or salad.  Really good, really fast.  The bbq pork buns are the size of my head!
author: Flip F.

description:
I don't understand what's so good about this place.  I can't justify its high prices, other than the fact that they probably have a monopoly in SOMA for dim sum.  Everything was greasy, and I left the place feeling sick and wanted to bang my head on my desk so I could fall asleep.

End rant.
author: Jenny L.

description:
What happened?  It was so good.  
Stale food, lack of parking, outrageous prices and pushy dim sum girls.  YUCK!
author: Alex L.

description:
DISCLIAMER: this is for their Take-out section. 

*cough. choke. die*.... well almost. i survived to bring you this warning = don't do take-out here!! it's just morsels of cheap plain chinese noodles fried in oil and...um..more noodles and oil? and side dishes are vegetables fried in oil...and well..more vegetables and oil :) see! how brilliant of me to figure their secret recipe for the take-out section!!  

based on all the other great reviews....my conclusion is, they serve the incredible tasting stuff to the guests who have time for the "sit down" lunch...and serve really over-priced bad bad food to those who just do the "grab and go" take out. 
so eat here ONLY if you are lucky enough to have the TIME AND MONEY to spend at the sit-down section.
author: Purple B.

description:
I'm a hardcore cantonese person, so I can get pretty picky about Hong Kong-style food. And I wasn't impressed with Yank Sing.

Overpriced dim sum that tasted fine, but nothing spectacular. I saw more creative / fusion-y dim sum dishes that I think would cater more towards an American crowd, but that's not what I go to a dim sum place for. My friends and I paid $18 per person for lunch, and we weren't even full enough. It's a good idea to check with the servers to see how much each dish costs before you decide to get it. Some of them are just ridiculous. 

I will say, however, that the service is great. And the servers can generally speak pretty good english. And they have nifty clear glass teapots. 

But overall, I'd rather go someplace else with cheaper, better, more traditional Chinese food, even if that means a restaurant that's not as pretty with servers shouting in raucous cantonese.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Although I enjoyed my dim sum experience here, it's overpriced for what it is. We spent over $100 for 4 people on just dim sum alone? Yeah. Two times more than what we normally spend at a dim sum place.

You'll definately see unique items that you can't find at other dim sum establishments, but I can't say they're as authentic seeing as though they're trying to do the fancy fusion thing to please other crowds of people other than Chinese customers. Also, none of our dishes were hot, but rather at room temp, while others were cold.

Their banquet food is pretty good though. I've been here for two weddings and the food was quite tasty on both occasions. It's a nice set up for a special occasion esp w/the water coming down like a waterfall in the middle of the banquet. 

The prices here are on the high end, but still worth one visit. I prefer my reg, more authentic and cheaper dim sum places over this one. If you're one who stays true to your dim sum, don't come here.
author: Veronica H.

description:
I work across the road from Yank Sing - so it wins on proximity and convenience. It is on my repertoire of take outs at lunch time, especially when i need a Chinese food fix (when feeling hung over/ tired/ feeling under the weather in general!).

As I partaked in some mid-week par-taying last night, today's YS 2 Go order was; 
1x small hot & sour soup
