1x YS Express pack - chow mien, steamed pork bun and pot sticker

To be honest the food isn't all that bad - have had much worst in rural towns of Australia - it is, however, Chinese for westerners.

The hot & sour soup is neither spicy or sour enough... it is disappointing since the US consumer has, generally, a preference for strong flavours! it could be such a big seller if they dial up the heat and use of vinegar!

Hot & Sour Soup is one of my favourite Northern Chinese cuisines  and have tasted many versions around the world (western and eastern countries)... the YS version needs a little more work. What they did get right in the soup was all the required bits floating in a gravy like broth... tofu, sliced fungi, strips of pork, bamboo etc.

The steamed pork bun I got in my lunch pack was so NOT a pork bun. The filling is too sweet (common westernised Chinese food problem) and the bread is definitely not fluffy enough... nor was it the correct shape.

The pot sticker was OK - the meat not moist enough. It is an item that really shouldn't be in a to go pack... should only be eaten when its still in the steam pot.

The chow mien... liberal use of onions and celery (very Chinese!). The flavour is good - I don't like my food salty and its the right level for me. They did give me the pack with 2 packets of soy sauce... can see many dousing the noodles with it.

As a whole - I am satisfied  with a full belly on this cold, wet Friday. It is a decent feed but no way I'll be taking my HK Chinese parents there (or choose to go there on a weekend).
author: Joyce L.

description:
It's not that the food is bad and that the service is horrible... it's just so damn expensive!  Dim sum shouldn't cost this much!  
I completely agree with minna t. on this one.  You're paying for cleanliness and service, two things that aren't common in most dim sum places.  But I can't get over the price.  I'm sure you can find cheaper dim sum that tastes just as good, if not even better.
I must admit that they had really good service though.  They all have walkie talkies, so you can get whatever you want right away.
author: Monica P.

description:
Unlike many posters, I didn't find the Dim Sum to be especially Americanized.  I also didn't find much of it to be exceptional - with the exception of the Shanghai Soup Dumplings, everything else was good, but not memorable.

And oh, so very expensive - $55 for two.  Same meal, except better, at Ton Kiang for $25.   Go there instead.
author: Jim D.

description: Quality Dim Sum, expensive but you get what you pay for. Great food!!!
author: Foshow O.

description: I love the their to go window. Their lunch special is simple but fresh and always hot. It comes with a potsticker, sweeth radish and huge mound of rice. The ladies behind the counter have a system so the lines move quickly. There are tables you can sit and hide from the busy crowd for an hour.
author: Dee B.

description: I love this yank sing, I'm never disappointed when we go there. It's always crowded, the service is prompt (they bombard you with carts of food as soon as ure seated) the food is always yummy. You can be seated, served, fed and be out the door in 30 minutes with a $60 - $75 lunch bill...it's pricey (everyone complains about the price) but it's worth it. I've been to other dim sum places and it's never as good as yank sing. I'm not too fond of their other location tho. the food is the same but it has a cafeteria feel there.
author: Lucy N.

description:
amazing food! very accommodating for large parties! 30+
the soup buns are a must
author: Val S.

description: Sesame ball: It tasted normal, like any other sesame ball I've had. The difference was it probably was fresher than others I've tried. It's super tiny for $1.15. I'd like to try their other meals, when I'm super hungry. They look like they have good deals.
author: Vera W.

description: When I was last in San Francisco, I ate Dim Sum here every day!  I lingered over a pot of jasmine tea & felt like life had never been better.....well, almost.  I daydream about the green beans with teeny shrimp  & the mango pudding.  Yank Sing is a couple blocks from the Bay, near the Bay Bridge & the huge Calder bow-&-arrow sculpture.
author: Joan S.

description:
I've ALWAYS thought Dim Sum is overpriced. You get just a little bit of Chinese food for a whole lotta money. Boy, this place definitely proved my point. Sure, the food was good - thus it gets 2 stars, but was it worth 50 something bucks for 2 people? Heck no! I wasn't even that full afterward. This is just one of those over hyped places for Chinese food that I can go without.

Oh yeah, the person in front of us had a reservation - he called ahead early. He arrived on time, but guess what, when he got there, those who had come in after he arrived were still seated first. Go figure.
author: Regan C.

description:
Dim Sum w/ Class. 

No traffic jams of dim sum carts being pushed by greasy-aproned staff.  No overcrowded seating and sharing of tables.  No screaming babies and naggy Asian grandmas.  ...but of course...the price reflects.

I still think it can be a cheap lunch/brunch, but just not compared to typical dim sum prices.  Steam trays are somewhere between 2x-3x other places...but that just means $6 instead of...$2..which isnt exactly crazy.  Makes for a good first dim sum experience for American-born folks.  Ingredients taste fresher than most other places too (and probably no MSG).

Just be careful of the "gourmet" dishes they try to sneak in.  We ordered a small cube of seabass unknowingly, which was apparently $17.  It was delish though.

Some dishes I recommend: seabass (pricey), shrimp dumpling, shitake mushroom dumpling, mango pudding.

TIP:  As always true in SOMA, parking isnt easy.  They supposedly have a parking lot that will validate on First/Minna.
author: Kendra W.

description:
I really enjoy the take out counter. I think the quality is very good and the prices are fair. I love the pot stickers. 
I have not gone to the sit down side, but would like to. Place is always very busy at lunch.
author: Lisa A.

description:
you have to be in the right mood for yank sing 2 go, but when you are it's really pretty perfect.  for me, "yank sing days" are those really gross cold grey kind of drizzly fridays where it seems unfair that i have to be at the office or really, anywhere but in bed.  the food is a little greasy but it is cheap, the service here is incredibly fast and efficient, so even when there's a line this place doesn't take too long.  the best meal here in my opinion is usually the dim sum platter, it's more dim sum and less greasy chow mein for your buck.

TIPS: they will sometimes get you dim sum that isn't on their menu if you ask for it.  also, you can get fried rice instead of the vegetable chow mein - which helps cut down on the grease a bit even if it's not *technically* any better for you.  lots of visible grease just does bad things to my psyche...
author: KT R.

description: Love Yank Sing...but the pricing is out of control!!!  Har Gows and mushroom dumplings are my favorite.  Watch out for the tea service that costs $7!!!  ouch!!!
author: Chris A.

description:
I was out with the go-anywhere-do-anything girlfriend about a week before she moved to Arizona.  We were puttering around the downtown area when hunger struck, and before I knew it she had me walking through the front door of Yank Sing on Stevenson Alley.  Normally I would have put up token resistance, but she'd be moving away in a week or so....

Food-wise it wasn't all that different than a lot of dim sum places I'd been to.  The decor was a bit upscale and the wine selection was a heck of a lot better.   On the other hand,  the dishes didn't seem to be much different than any  other dim-sum I'd tried.

What surprised me was when the tab came.  COW-A-BUNGA!!!  $60.00  for lunch!!! (Includes drinks & a tip)  Those little bite-sized dishes add up quick! This isn't Chinatown...this isn't the Richmond...It's Stevenson Alley for crying out loud!   Forget the complementary dinner mints...a side order of Vaseline would have been more appropriate  to accompany the check!   My sidekick was surprised too...and apologized with a mischievous grin after the tab came.  Nonetheless, three twenty-spots came out of my wallet reluctantly, each one of them good for a two person lunch at Brandy Ho's on Columbus. 

Nice atmosphere, but nothing breathtaking.  Good fare....but nothing extraordinary. No menu (for dimsum at least), and nothing has prices on it.  And as the old saying goes, "If you have to ask how much....."
author: Mike W.

description:
Yeah, I get it. It's good. But it's not THAT good. 

I don't think that spending over $100 for lunch for two (w/out booze and tip) was worth the incremental increase in taste.

[review was for Stevenson location, near 1st & Market]
author: Matthew R.

description:
Hard for me to get past the price. There were two of us, and granted, we ate enough for 3 and had leftovers, but still, you're supposed to stuff yourself silly when you eat dim sum, right? Isn't that the point? Anyway, it came out to $73. That seems like an awful lot to me for 2 people for brunch.

Their Shanghai soup dumplings were really good. The place is quite clean and upscale, so if you're trying to give a vaguely authentic experience to someone who has dirty-food-phobia and you're on an expense account, I'd say this would be an ideal place to go. 

Otherwise, go get some real dim sum in Chinatown or out in the avenues.
author: Melinda K.

description: It's good for what it is. Fast and cheap. One of the dim sum items has shrimp or something in it. It was gross. Stick to the egg rolls, pot stickers and buns and you're set. The fried rice is meh, and the chowmein is made with super oversize noodles. Not really my style. I've definitely had better dim sum, but this place is close to my work so I'm willing to settle.
author: Alfredo A.

description:
Puh-pow!

I seem to keep coming back for a variety of reasons and a variety of friends and this place is nothing if not consistent...with disappointment.  The food is on a par with anything you get up the road in Chinatown and the pushy interuptions of the wait staff to serve another dish are frightfully frustrating.  The signature dumpling dish is puh-pow!! and the final slap in the face each time is the cost!  I keep saying never again and after this last visit, I'm totally boycotting this overpriced, pushy on the sales, so called dim sum wannabe .... !!
author: J M.

description: I came here when I was vacationing in San Fran. Its a hidden spot, but its great. The service was great, the servers were very nice and attentive. The food was great. It was a little more than what I expected. I left feeling fat and happy. I will definitely be going back when i'm in San Fran again.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Excellent Dim Sum -- some of the best in the SF area. It's upscale, so some would dock them a star or so for that (as if being upscale somehow degrades the quality of Dim Sum--weird).  But the food really is excellent, and despite not being a hole in the wall *grin* they still had really good xiao long bao (soup dumplings), which we've become addicted to (see Shangai Dumpling Shop in Millbrae).

But after a recent lousy restaurant experience in Sausalito (see Poggio) the thing we appreciated the most was the absolutely awesome, friendly service.  From the call we made on the phone, to the welcome when we arrived, to the friendly info about the great jasmine tea and the cool teapot (which they told us where to find at MoMA and other web resources) to the folks coming around with info on their dim sum platters, we were very impressed. Never had to ask twice, and got offered half-orders on the excellent soup dumplings.

12-23-08 Update:
We've been to Yank Sing many times now, and they never fail to have awesome service and great food. We like the Stevenson location better than Rincon simply because it's less crowded and more low key--but the food and service are the same. If you go to the Stevenson location, have someone hop out of the car and prepay for parking in the lot around the block. Most convenient place to park by far.
author: Doug B.

description: The portions are inexplicably giant, and the food tends to be a bit bland and dry. This would be a 2 except for one thing: the pork buns. Some of the best steamed pork buns I've had are Yank Sing pork buns. Sometimes, you just crave some white mystery starch filled with mystery barbecued meat. If now is one of those times, then swing by Yank Sing's hidden to-go window and pick up a couple.
author: James B.

description: It's a convenient location for weekday lunches...that's pretty much the biggest draw for this place.  All the combos are pretty much Americanized dishes...but edible if you are craving Chinese food and are near Rincon.  I do appreciate how quickly they turn out all the orders though...it's helpful when you have no time and just need to grab lunch and run back to work.
author: Monica P.

description: 2 Go is great. Cheap, fast, and tasty. I like the Phoenix... less than $7 gets you a big portion of fried rice and chow mein, 2 potstickers, a siumai, and egg roll. You can also add a la carte items like a bbq pork bun or custard tart, but the Phoenix is plenty.
author: grant l.

description:
Yank SIng is hands down the greatest dim sum dining experience in the world. It is a San Francisco Gem.
I have experienced the Maxim palace in the City Hall of Hong Kong. It was an excellent experience, but still no match for the yank's menu diversity suiting all palates. Service is extremely efficient.
Snowpea green dumplings, chicken buns, soft shell crab, I could go on and on but there is no use writing the entire menu. This is a food lovers paradise, not for those on a budget. I've never felt it wasn't worth it. 
I have grown up in the city and tried many Chinese dining establishments, but this is the spot for lunch, if it were open for dinner it would be the best too.
author: Adam S.

description:
Fried Guilty Pleasure Comin' Up!

I love this place, I can't deny it.  The egg rolls, pork buns, potstickers, and chow mien make my mouth water.  I know I shouldn't have another helping of the pork fried rice, but I'm gonna, and you CANT stop me!  And even if you tried to stop me I would just go to Yank Sing 2 Go! (Yes, I'm devious!!)

I would feel better about myself if I had some of the fried vegetables, but alas my stomach only has so much room and the potstickers called and reserved the space (sorry veggies).

I would give it 5 stars because it Is the best Dim Sum, but I feel guilty about eating too much of it! hehe

Git In My Belly Beautiful Fried Food of Fun!
author: Chris G.

description:
Nothing special about the dim sum. The hai gow, sui mai, and Shanghai dumplings were good, but the other items were not very special. They tasted similar to dim sum I had eaten at many other Chinese restaurants. In addition, given the price of the items, I did not think that the dim sum was worth it. Lastly, the noodle dishes we ordered were too salty.

Food: Dim Sum was not special. I was expecting really delicious dim sum...but it was similar to everything I had eaten in the past. The noodle dishes we ordered were too salty.

Service: Service was really bad. My sister was going to go pick up our noodle dishes because the servers did not give them to us. When the server saw where my sister was going she stopped my sister and said that she would get it. For a nice restaurant, this should NEVER happen.

Price: Expensive...Too expensive given the quality of the food and service.
author: MishEddie G.

description:
This is a white man's version of dim sum.  A great place to start if you're bringing over friends/family who aren't familiar with dim sum and afraid of the bustling Chinese restaurants during brunch time or looks of the food.  This is the place to go on a business lunch where you don't have to worry about the bill.    I don't think there's any other reason to go to this place aside from these reasons.

Being new Californians, when my friends and I stumbled in, we expected tasty food for the prices.  Unfortunately, the food was very white washed and predictable.  There were no bold or interesting flavors --- everything was clean and "meh."  The pushcart ladies were extremely pushy --- even pushing some tea onto my pants.  No apologies there for me!  I think we felt some lo-grade racism here (both my friend and I were the only Asians in the joint at that moment and we definitely were not given enough attention as the other patrons were), but I could have just been paranoid at the moment.

So bottom line --- if its your job to lead someone by the hand into the world of dim sum, and that someone is paying, this might be the place for you.  If you're here on a business meal, this might be the place for you.  This place is all about show and being a "nice, friendly and approachable" Chinese/dim sum alternative.  Once you're over it, move on.
author: Guava C.

description: Delicious traditional Dim Sum with communal tables and fresh tea. The place is immaculate and the location is in the stunning Rincon Center. If you are a Dim Sum lover, Be prepared for the most expensive Dim Sum you have ever had. My son and I had lunch for $85.00 but what are vacations for anyway.
author: Debra S.

description:
Yes. I'm addicted. I'll admit it.  My coworker calls Yank Sing my crack..

Now, while I've never ate on the restaurant side, I'm a frequent of the to-go side.  I'm obsessed with the seafood supreme. Dim sum + cheese wontons+ chow mein = about $7 including tax? Kinda awesome. Especially since its goood food.

Check it out and get the seafood supreme. The line moves quick, you can eat outside or take it with you...yumm
author: Shafaq C.

description:
I don't see what the hype is all about...

Nice outside patio, though...
author: Nathan W.

description:
Since im a so cal guy, I accidently found this place, thinking i was heading to the the Rincon Center Building.....Thank goodness for a bad memory.  This place is way better than the Bigger one.

The food was very good.  Regular dumplings are avg.  But their not so regular stuff are fantastic.  The Xiao Long Baos, Sea Bass, Chow Fun Noodles, were highlights.   Decor is clean, modern, and comfy.  I was however taken back by the number of caucasian customers.... There were only 3 tables of asians.....

Service was outstanding.  They are very helpful.  Not pushy like old school dim sum houses.  When you are full, they know it, and stop pushing food to you....

Clear Glass teapots were slick!  Never saw that in a chinese restaurant before.... Damn... they are good....

Im actually surprised by the negative reviews..... dim sum nazis...
author: Shon T.

description:
This is tough. I don't like the fact that I'm giving this the same rating as Ton Kiang, despite being far better dim sum, perhaps even the best dim sum I've ever had.

But as none of the selections were able to produce an orgasm in my mouth, $80 for dim sum for two is absolutely ludicrous.
author: Mark A.

description:
Good lunch spot. Good Veggie options. Make sure you boss is paying. 

To die for really and I don't even like this genre of food.
author: Pink G.

description: From the metric of quality, this is great dim sum that is amongst the best I've experienced in the Bay Area. My enthusiasm is tempered, however, by the exaggerated price. Upon initial inspection, the staff were extremely gracious, the servings were generous (we stuffed ourselves), carts were constantly circulating (food was aplenty), atmosphere was pleasant, and we enjoyed ourselves. Amongst the various selections; ha kao and in particular xiao long bao were nicely done and satisfying. That being said, Sunday dim sum for two ended up being $80+... from the amount of food, I expected half that much. Despite being dramatically overcharged, the quality was nice, though disproportionate to the price.
author: C A.

description: OK, so I blew almost $70 for 2 on dim sum, so that isn't exactly cheap for dim sum.  But, the quality is consistently good and the place is clean with service to match.  For larger groups, the Rincon Center location is much better and has many more tables.  But many of the tables at this location are for two, so it may be more of a wait for groups.
author: Peter L.

description:
Like most people on here, I love dim sum and am always looking for new and interesting places.  Yank Sing was new but not that interesting.  The quality was definitely evident, everything fresh and well prepared - but our pot stickers were cold and oily and the the fried stuff was way too greasy (even for fried!).  I did enjoy some of the steamed dumplings but for the prices, there is definitely better.  Also the choices were very american, not very interesting if you're used to dim sum but good if you're new to this! 

Also the bathrooms were gross, they need to check those more.
author: sasha y.

description:
Now, this is what I'm talking about. I was really impressed by the food here. They have a great selection and make frequent tray rounds to keep you busy. The place is a bit expensive but totally worth it.

I'm going back soon, and am I'm taking L.P.
author: Sav B.

description: Phenomenal dumplings. All of them. Basically, you can't go wrong. The Xiao Long Bao Singapore Soup Dumpling was the best I've ever head. The chicken and mushroom dumpling was outstanding. A total keeper of a place!
author: Pawel S.

description:
An institution in SF. Amazing tasting food.  The carts make their way around with the standard dim sum.  Waitpeople walk through carrying the specials and each one is better than the next. 

I simply love this place.
author: Daniel P.

description:
I came here with a big group -- there were maybe 7 of us -- for dim sum on a Saturday. A good number of us were visiting from out of town, and I didn't feel comfortable or confident enough to say, "Hey, dim sum outside of Chinatown? That doesn't make any sense."

The space is touristy and a little creepy, sort of feels like a mall without any stores. The quality of the food is average at best. They have a number of shrimp dishes that all taste the same (fake). The service is ok. 

But it's the bill that sent me reeling. $35 for dim sum. That's beyond a ripoff. 

This place might be ok under different conditions, but stay far away if you want dim sum.
author: Nick B.

description:
I really prefer the hole-in-the-wall dim sum joints in Chinatown, but Yank Sing is close to work AND takes reservations (do that!--it's gets really busy there).  Even though it defeats the whole yummy but reasonable dim sum experience, as it's pricy for that genre, I must admit it's convenient and really quite delicious.

Above all else, try the wu tao gok (aka awesomeness in a little flaky, fried taro ball;  it's embarrassing really, but I'm Chinese but only speak Chinese menu, numbers and swear words).  It does have pork in it, FYI. 

Also, you can choose what tea you have.  I always ask for the chrysanthemum tea; it's caffeine-free, fresh, and it's really cool to look in the clear bowl and see the pretty flowers.
author: Kimberly Q.

description:
A co-worker and I had decided that we were going to treat ourselves to a good meal for lunch every Friday. Since he has never been to Yank Sing, and he was craving for dim sum, I suggested this place. Upon arriving we were seated immediately and maybe it was because we got there after one o'clock. Anyway, we chose a lot of dim sum. It wasn't greasy and there was a lot of flavor. Th cart kept coming, which my co-worker liked cause he has a healthy appetite. 
This place is not cheap but then if you want good quality food you are going to pay for it. One more thing, one of my co-worker from Hong Kong wanted dim sum to take his client to and I suggested this place. He was so impressed with the food and service that he brought back 2 dozen egg custards for me.

So, I'm giving....
One star for the fast seating
One star for the not to greasy food
One star for the flavor
One star for the plenty of carts.
author: Kathy T.

description:
Ohhh, mouth-watering morsels, piping hot and fresh out of the kitchen, this place is as good as it gets! 

After taking an early morning flight from San Diego, we arrived in the city with grumbling bellies. There could be nothing so satisfying to start our food-filled weekend. This is worth the flight just for lunch at Yank Sing. 

Recommended by a former resident of the city, we arrived at 12 noon on a Friday, and realized we were right in the middle of the lunch crush of the Financial District. We were asked to wait 15 minutes, so we went for a short walk in the mist. When we returned, there was a line out the door. We had to wait for an additonal 15 minutes, but the smell of the food was intoxicating. We had picked out half a dozen items we wanted to try by the time our table was ready. The hostesses were extremely gracious, apologetic, and thankful for our patience. The service was prompt and very pleasant. 

This place was hopping! As soon as we sat down, the parade of carts of steaming hot dumplings started whizzing by. We had to start refusing things, because within 2 minutes we had 20 dumplings on the table to consume, and we couldn't eat fast enough! Not only are there dumplings, but lettuce wraps, duck, egg rolls, and much, much more, all available to size-up before comitting to a plate of 3-6.

The highlights, the scallop dumpling skewers, shrimp and mushroom crescents, and their signature Shanghai dumplings, also know as the soup dumpling for the succulent liquid that envelopes the pork. Make sure you ask the waiter to show you the proper way to eat it, or it will end up on your lap!  Har gao (shrimp) were also filled with LOTS of perfectly ground shrimp. And the pot stickers were delicious with a perfect balance of steamy stickiness and crispy bottoms.
author: Joni J.

description:
After trying dim sum several times at different places, I've finally figured it out... I don't like dim sum.

I'm not usually a texture type of person - I'll eat anything - but dim sum is so slimy it borders on gross out food (you know, stuff you'd see on fear factor). Then, it's bland, so you have to drown it in hot mustard and chili sauce to make it taste good - but then all you taste is hot mustard and chili sauce. 

Now since this review is for Yank Sang in particular - I'll just say that $22 (my part of a 4 person bill) was not worth it at all for the 3 things I ate - since I'm a veggie now, there were only 3 options for me: Spinach dumpling, Vegetable dumpling, and Snow pea shoot dumpling. All tasted the same to me - boring.

I might have rated it higher had my company paid like I was expecting but apparently they're being cheap bastards right now (and if you knew which company I work for, you'd be confused too - they have plenty of money to buy me lunch every day of the year).

So yeah, not a good experience, not good food, too pricey. NO GOOD.
author: Sarah P.

description:
Being form SoCal, I've tried many o many Dim Sum joints, and this one was very good, they QUALITY of the food was much better than the other places I've been to in LA, Diamond Bar, San Gabriel, and even others I've been to around the SF area. Yes, there is a price disparity, it's really pricey here, but you get what you pay for, I think a majority of the people that expect a cheap lunch in the Financial district are in for a suprise, this is where business people go to impress their clients and /or have money. IMO its expected and you should really ask how much something is before you sit down there, in my opinion, those are the real suckers like Mr Clark J.

Let me say this one more time ..... DO NOT GO TO A PLACE TO EAT AND JUST EXPECT IT TO BE CHEAP, ASK HOW MUCH THE FOOD IS FIRST BEFORE YOU START ORDERING ESPECIALLY IF ITS A DIM SUM PLACE BECAUSE THERE IS NO MENU
author: Joe G.

description:
Decent place to go, a bit on on the pricey side for dim sum if you ask me. I hit this place up a every other month or so since it is by my work. Usually long waits for lunch though and the service is so/so. If I didn't work so close to it I probably would go to a better, more traditional place that is going to be much cheaper.

No major complaints though, I am sure I will be back, I hear it is a good place for Sunday brunch however there are too many good places in the city for me to travel there on the weekend.
author: Bobby B.

description:
can't beat their lunches.  It's not exactly authentic but hey, neither is panda express and we all love panda express!  their ys express always has asians standing in line so it can't be that bad right? : )  perfect lunch spot if you're on a budget as their special A or special B is a mere $4.95.  i've been eating here about once a week for the last 5 years to get that yank sing fix.

one stupid question though.  why do they say "your phone number is ..." when they give you the receipt?  I'm chinese and all but I can't seem to understand.  Can anyone help??
author: Caesar C.

description:
"So the first thing you need to know about this lunch spot is: screw formal dining.  Go to the take-out counter and sit outside (heaters in the winter - well, when it is cold...its SF, so that could be summer). Or, hit-up the many beautiful public spots just around the corner.

The Dim Sum is just as good when you take-out.  And, the take-out is much less expensive.  

That being said, if you want to class-out, there is nothing wrong with the main restaurant - its clean, busy, and has a larger selection.

Pick your pleasure..."
author: Kiki I.

description: Fpr 25 years, this small restaurant has been the benchmark for Xiao Loong Bow, Har Gow, Cheung Fun, and every other manner of Dim Sum in the financial district of San Francisco.  DON'T get suckered into their other location, as only this is the real thing.
author: Rich R.

description:
Probably the most upscale dim sum dining experience in San Francisco. The quality of the food is very high, although I was slightly dissapointed in the shu mai the last time I went. 

The dim sum is not the most traditional, and with the decor and pleasant service, makes it a prime destination for non-Chinese.

It's always been a solid choice for a good experience, but also the most expensive dim sum you can probably get. It has always cost more than $40 per person in my experience.
author: Adrian L.

description: Lived in manhattan for 35 years.  Ate more dim sum than a container ship could hold.  Yank sing is our favorite.  It is a little more money but so worth it.
author: Cynthia T.

description: Good dim sum in a city with so many choices can be hard.  Unlike some of the other reviewers, I really like this restaurant.  Their specialty, shanghai dumpings are delicious and the sticky rice and steamed snap peas are good.  The service is efficient and the restaurant is clean. Downsides include the single restroom and depending on what you like, you may get something that is not a specialty item.
author: Soo C.

description:
This place was over priced. Food was good tho. 

We made reservations for 2 but got placed near the kitchen entrance. It was a small table and we were bumped by several carts.
author: J-nine I.

description: OK, so it's good, but honestly, it is SO expensive.  It's probably the best in SF but if you go out of the city, there are places just as good and much cheaper.  Maybe my friends and I should have asked before we ordered them, but we got the soup dumplings from the dim sum cart...and figured they wouldn't be too expensive.  They were nearly $10 - almost $1.50 per dumpling.  That is just ridiculous.  Nevertheless, the food is good and if you are looking to stay in SF and get in and out of a restaurant, this is a good place for you.
author: Wendy L.

description: Not unless you like mediocre chow mein (of which you get quite a bit) with a side of dim sum the size of after-dinner mints.
author: tal n.

description: This isn't one of my favorite places for dim sum. The presentation is nice but the flavor isn't as good as you might find at a more authentic dim sum restaurant. The food is a bit pricey and the servers are a bit pushy even by dim sum restaurant standards. Also this place is near impossible to find.
author: chris l.

description: effin yummy.  I go every time im in SF.
author: R U.

description:
I haven't been here in a couple of years, but from what everyone else is saying, sounds like things haven't changed much.

While living on Treasure Island, every Sunday we would drive into San Francisco for our regular Dim Sum fix.  We always went at around 11:30 or 1:30 to avoid the crowds.

When it comes to Dim Sum, I may not know much about what's authentic and what's not, but I do know that of all the Dim Sum places I've been to from San Francisco to San Jose and Eastward, Yank Sing has always been my absolutely favorite.  The dumplings, deep fried foods, the sticky rice baked in banana leaves (dunno what it's called, even after all this time) is another favorite, the minced meat in large lettuce wraps, did I mention the dumplings?  Oh, and the mango pudding dessert is just perfect.

The one bummer is that it is a little pricey.  Oh, and another is having to adjust your schedule so your wait isn't too long.  But other than that, it's perfect.

It's too bad that San Francisco is so far away for me now.  Otherwise, I'd still be going there every weekend (^-^)
author: Tetsu N.

description:
*4 stars for the food but minus 1/2 star for price increase minus another 1/2 star for less food than usual...*

Whenever I have a dentist appointment, I come here and get take out for lunch (you can see it when the 38 stops).  I almost always order the same thing: the Yank Sing Mini (Chinese chicken salad, 2 pot stickers and an egg roll).  The food was as good as ever - and dare I say it, even better.  However, and this is why I'm taking away a star, prices have gone up AND they're serving less salad.  I was so bummed and so was my tummy.   (It was my first food of the day since I wanted to keep my teeth clean for my appointment.)

It's just such a sad day to pay more for noticeably less food.  You would think that for 5 bucks, that's a good deal but it's really not...  Oh well, I'll probably just be back in 6 months anyway...  hopefully not complaining, though.
author: Christine T.

description:
This dim sum establishment is widely reputed to be the best around; my visit failed to reveal the reason for this acclaim.  While the dim sum is certainly fresh (probably the key feature of good dim sum) and generally well-done, I found little to distinguish it from any number of places in S.F. or elsewhere.  Some dishes, such as soft shell crab, are unusual to find in a dim sum menu, but nothing to go out of one's way for.  

  The quality was all over the map: the soup dumplings (aggressively pushed by the waitress as "best in the house") were an enjoyable version of a Shanghai staple seldom seen stateside.  Peking duck was also delicious, though the minuscule portion was a bit disappointing.  On the other hand, shiu mai, a ubiquitous dim sum staple, were bland, underseasoned, and totally forgettable.  

  One category in which Yank Sing unquestionable excels is price: theirs are astronomical for a dim sum joint.  I had tea and dim sum.  No wine or beer.  The bill was sixty bucks.  Just for me.  I was dining alone.  It was sixty bucks.  

  Now, dim sum is unusual in restaurant dining in that prices are generally not printed on a menu, but tallied at the end of the meal based on how many dishes you had.  Thus, price is truly an afterthought, unless you ask.  With the multiple dishes ordered from multiple servers in dim sum service, this would be unreasonable and annoying, so I assumed that their prices would be on a par with other dim sum joints.  I also assumed that the chunk of fish ("sea bass" or "sweet bass," I couldn't be sure) I had wouldn't be anywhere near fifteen bucks.  Wrong again.  

  In summary, Yank Sing serves B+ grade dim-sum in a nice setting, at unreasonable prices.  You can do better (or at least no worse) and have more fun for less money if you investigate some of the city's more hole-in-the-wall establishments, avoiding both the beaten path and the long wait for a table.
author: Nate S.

description: Delicious dim sum. Pricey for dim sum, but very good quality. Try the honey glazed sea bass.
author: Michelle W.

description:
Go ANYWHERE else.  You'll either get better dim sum or pay less.

I've had my fair share of dim sum and I'm not really that picky about quality, but I expected a lot more from a fancy place like this.  The food wasn't bad, it's just not good, and definitely not $30 good.  I was very disappointed and I was still hungry.

The wait wasn't too long but I did go at 1p just in case.  The check-in stand was a little hard to find since tables were sprawled all over the atrium.  They give you a little buzzer so you can walk away but SOMA is really dead on weekends so you're still stuck there waiting for a table.

It gets two stars because 1) I didn't get sick and 2) free validated parking in the garage on weekends (but I just parked a block down the street).

P.S. They have this weird jello in orange skin concoction which I didn't have a chance to try.  So, it's really too bad that I'll never go back again.
author: Bertilla M.

description:
Great dim sum, but it's a bit extravagant for a weekday lunch (and they don't open for dinner)! For the best experience, be selective in what you order. Like most dim sum places, it's hard to tell how much the dishes actually cost.  Every dish even the simple ones will be more expensive than most dim sum restaurants so go for the kinds of dishes you won't find anywhere else.  Don't be afraid to look at the menu online ahead of time and order dishes that you want if they don't end up coming to you. 

I recommend the sea bass roll and scallop dumplings. The Peking Duck wasn't that great. It had lost its crispiness once it had gotten to us. I think that sesame balls, veggies, and desserts were just filler. Go for the good stuff-seafood delicacies and the various dumplings.

I think the thing that really made this place great was the staff. This was one of the few dim sum places where the staff will actually converse with you and help answer questions.
author: Sutee D.

description:
Overall, the actual dim sum at this place is pretty decent (of course, there is much better in San Francisco).  However, their egg custard tarts, which are my absolute favorite dim sum dessert, is sub-standard.  

The service has also been iffy when I have gone.  I went with two vegetarians--which I have to admit, going to dim sum as a vegetarian is at your own risk--and they kept asking for the vegetarian cart.  They had to ask five times before it came... after the rest of us were finished eating.

Also, they charge (a lot) for tea.... what's up with that?  Tea should be included as a staple at dim sum.
author: Lindsay L.

description: This was my first experience with dim sum and I thoroughly enjoyed it.  I had been hesitant to eat dim sum because I was concerned about there not being enough vegetarian items.  Yank Sing has a TON of vegetarian food.  I really liked everything.  The pace was a bit rushed as the waiters just keep coming (pause).  Maybe that's just dim sum.  Have to knock off a star for what I thought were astronomical prices, but I would definitely return.  Shout out to the homie Whonger for picking up the tab.
author: Luke D.

description: Gave this place another try because I was in the area during lunchtime. Bought some steamed pork buns and they were pretty good.
author: Prague G.

description:
I see that many people love this place.  I will make a slight disclaimer that I don't really love dim sum in large quantities which will be explained shortly, so that might have something to do with my rating.  

I will give Yank Sing that it was very clean.  But I found the service spotty.  When we first arrived, they carts came by about every 4 seconds making it difficult to make decisions and more importantly, difficult to eat anything.  Then, later on, when we were interested in getting more food, no one came by for 10-15 minutes.  I understand there were baskets on the table, but they were empty and we were still hungry.  Then, we specifically asked for several dishes, and it was clear that they forgot about our request despite telling someone to bring the dishes over into their little microphones (which I'm convinced are fake - they're just trying to look cool like Secret Service agents).  

I thought the dim sum was good - but nothing above and beyond any other good dim sum place.  But clearly, the price is exceptional, and it's easy at dim sum to rack up a larger bill than you intend.  The sea bass was excellent, everyone raved over that one even though we almost didn't get it because it isn't typical dim sum.  Warning - we think that one might be SUPER expensive as the other dishes warranted a blue stamp, and that one was the only dish with the ominous RED stamp.  

Gas Rating: 4
Dim sum is pretty greasy so it gives me a lot of gas (which is why I don't really like it in large quantities).  More importantly, I drank WAY too much tea.  We're talking 6 little cups or something.  I almost died on the 10 minute walk back to the office and then peed 8 more times before I left which I'm sure did nothing for my already sky high productivity.
author: Soo C.

description:
So before I start this post, I have to say, I have yet to taste Yank Sing's food.  I am reviewing the restaurant because I had to voice my objection to how they handle their clientele. 

My mother was in town and I wanted to take her someplace for good dim sum and had always heard that Yank Sing was a place you had to experience.  So we were in San Francisco - touring, on a weekday between Christmas and New Year;s and I called the restaurant in the morning to make a reservation for lunch at 1:30pm.    Over the phone, they told me - no problem.

I don't know about you, but when I make a reservation at a restaurant, I donot expect to show up and have to wait in a long line to get a beeper on order to wait.  What's the deal about making a reservation?  To have the privilege to wait in another line to get a beeper.  What do they do with the walk-ins?  

I was shocked by their system.  If I want to be treated like a number, then let me know ahead of time.  When I call to make a reservation, you should say you donot accept them.  

It was crazy and it angered me.  My mother and I ended up at Shanghai 1930  which is down the street and has excellent food.

I have lost my taste for Yank Sing without even trying it.
author: Ingrid P.

description:
I like this place.  It's good food, not a long wait (if you get there on time), and yes, it can be a little pricey, but I think it's worth it.  Especially if you've spent the night at The Palace hotel on a Saturday night, it's definitely worth it to cross the street, go down the alley, and have some Shanghai dumplings.

I went with a friend of mine last time, and amazingly, she knew one of the servers there.  As anyone knows, if you know the Chinese people, they hook you up.  She introduced us to the Shanghai dumplings, for FREE.  I was a little wary with the vinegar and ginger slices, but once she showed us how to eat it, it was all good.  After I got past the hot liquid inside the pouch, I completely enjoyed the bite.

The dumplings are a wonderful little present filled with pork, ginger and some other stuff.  Then you take some red vinegar and lay a couple of ginger slices, and in your mouth it goes.  Once bitten, the tasty broth in the purse bursts in your mouth and spreads the love among your tastebuds as it melds with the vinegar.

I give the dumplings alone 4 stars.  The service is good and the chrysanthemum tea is the best.  Always a good choice on a Sunday afternoon.
author: Alison N.

description:
We went there for lunch.
The food was excellent, but way too pricey (80 bucks for 2 people without drinks).

I loved the food but there's gotta be more dim sum places out there with comparable food and cheaper prices.
author: Durif M.

description:
This is the best dim sum I have ever tasted in the US. I'm not kidding when I say their soup dumplings/Shanghai dumplings are to die for. It is the first dim sum they bring over to you, and you're not expecting it to be anything special...until you bite into it. And then my boyfriend & I just stared at each other - deer in headlights thinking the same thing. I WANT MORE! The soup inside the dumplings just spreads throughout your palette...and you can't stop wondering how they do that. 

The selection, quality, service of Yank Sing - I have never experienced at a dim sum place. Even though we were only in San Fran for a few days, we contemplated going back to eat dim sum again here just to taste those dumplings and the dishes we were too full to eat later. 

I would definitely recommend this place to everyone - and to get there early if you want a seat! Also at the same time, don't order/grab the dish if you just wanted to try it out. It isn't cheap, and I learned it the hard way after we got the tab. Just for the 2 of us, with tip it was over $90...I still felt it was worth it 'cuz it really was the best dim sum I've tasted in a very long time.
author: Seiko H.

description: we stopped in yesterday just to eat xiao long bao's, they are $12 for six but were very good. The dough is think enough to not let the soup broth leak out like other places, and I think I ate like 10 of them easy. Also the har gow  were good and were big sized shrimp and the shu mai were good too. We were here at 3:30pm (they close at 4pm) and there were only two other couples in the whole place...yet our waitress was very attentive, the food was very hot, and it was very worth the price. Late sunday afternoon is a good time to get into Yank Sing w/out reservations...
author: Anthony L.

description: Best Dim Sum in SF! Call ahead to reserve a table for brunch or prepare to wait half an hour or more, because the line will be long. And it's definitely worth it. Yummy!
author: Vicky C.

description:
I made reservations for Christmas Day for approximately 15 people at Yank SIng about seven weeks ago. I called today to give the final count for my reservations and the hostess said she could not find my reservations;  she intimated that I had not made them. After insisting that I did, she said the only thing we could do was just arrive at 1 p.m. and wait until 2 p.m. to be seated.  Since we had Christmas last year at Yank Sing and had to wait until  2 p.m, I knew that many dishes were sold out by that time. She told me that the manager would call but she never did. I never got an apology. There was no concern on their part about my group finding a place to dine on Christmas Day, nor did they offer any viable solution.  The total lack of customer service at this large seemingly successful restaurant is shocking. I would never book this restaurant again, no matter how good the pricey dim sum is.  

I'm sending this review on a positive note.  I called Hong Kong Lounge II, 3300 Geary Street. The manager said he was booked up,  but he would accommodate our large group, no problem. Now that's service. I'll be booking that restaurant for Christmas 2014.
author: kathleen f.

description:
Dining in:
Very good dim sum.  Very expensive.

Yank Sing 2-Go:
Very good dim sum.  Very quick.  Very reasonably priced.

For $6.50 I just walked away with three dumplings, two wontons, and a heaping serving of veg chow mein in my hands.

For a special lunch with friends, or a quick work lunch to go, this place has it down.
author: Caryn K.

description:
Talk about over priced! This place was suggested to me by a local and it did have unique dishes, but C'MON they charge you for the tea as well?
What Yank Sing needs is some hearty dim sum competition that drives the prices down. 
Over priced, nothing too special and a wait in line just to get it.
author: Justin N.

description: A good place to come for lunch. There are combination platters for under $5. There was a long line when I went but it moved quickly. Plenty of outdoor seating under heat lamps. The potstickers were very good but the noodles were average. This is still a great deal at just under $5.
author: Andrew M.

description: This place is pricier than the average dim sum place.  I wanted to get that out of the way so you don't get sticker shock.  I took my summer intern her for her farewell lunch and it was $60 for two persons, and we ordered about 6 different items total.  She loved this so much - I am a vegetarian with shrimp allergies and I told her she would have to eat all the meaty type things or take them home because I wouldn't be able to eat them.  I thought she would get a takeout box BUT she ate everything that she ordered!  We had the Xiao long pao, 3 different kinds of vegetarian dumplings, the shrimp hakka, and the pork siu mei.  They also bring a fish dish by and try to get you to order it - it does look very good but if you are on a budget, keep in mind that it is a $22 dish.  The place is very clean, and if you don't have reservations, I suggest arriving before 11:30 am to get seated.  I liked that they have a huge selection of vegetarian dumplings and they have radios so they can call in what you want and whoever has that tray will walk by so you can order it.  While I eat dim sum fairly frequently, I don't go very often to yank sing simply because i usually go on weekends, and it's hard for me to get to the city on weekends and also it is on the pricier side so I would only go here with one or two other persons and not a big group (which is usually how our Saturday dim sum sessions work out),  but it's a treat when i do go and well worth it (especially when on the company dime!)
author: Bebe W.

description:
I think this is the best Yank Sing location and while Yank Sing isn't the barometer with which I judge other Dim Sum places, its definately good. I don't say that for the variety, but more for the quality and consistency of the food. I've eaten at maybe 15-20 other places, and I also like some of the crazy take-out steamtable places out in the Richmond that have no english names;  Yank Sing is a place where you take your parents or out of town guests who want some easy SF dimsum.

One neat valley moment that I had here was eating Chicken Feet with Vipul. Guess it wasn't spam :)
author: Tom S.

description: Hadn't been to Yank Sing for a long time. Went to Yank Sing at Stevenson Street. Overpriced. Had better dim sum at other restaurants.  Maybe tourists like their dim sum and prices.
author: Melody S.

description: This place has probably the best dim sum I've ever had. The Xiao long bao was perfection: tender, soupy, and delicious! The tea was also really good and went well with the food. Everything was cooked well and tasted as good as it looked. It's a little on the pricier side but definitely a good treat. The only reason I'm not giving this place five stars is because the service was slow. Not sure if it was the location of our seat, but we seemed to keep getting repeated carts coming to us. Finally my dad got up out of his seat to request the cart that kept missing us. When we finally got the food though, we were definitely satisfied.
author: Tina W.

description:
While visiting San Francisco, a foodie friend said we had to try the Shanghai (soup-filled) dumplings at Yank Sing. We are happy to report that they were the best we've had outside of Toronto. (If you're in Toronto, though, make sure you get to Shanghai Dim Sum in Markham!) 
However, we also had a lot of other dishes. The chive pancake was bland and disappointing, but most everything else was good or great, with the chicken skewers as a surprise hit. But not as much of a surprise as the bill. 
Holy Toledo! We had foolishly, very foolishly, not looked at the menu prices before eating. We go for dim sum a lot and in a lot of different places (Toronto, New York, Chicago, etc.) so we just assumed it would cost about as much as usual, maybe $10 to $15 per person. Oops!  This place is expensive. Moreover, dishes we're used to thinking of as fairly cheap weren't. $9 gets you a double portion (6) of pot stickers, but $12 only gets you four skinny fried shrimp rolls? Really? 
We'd be happy to return to Yank Sing next time we're in San Francisco, but for our next visit, we'll stick to the soup-filled dumplings!
author: E. W.

description:
Avid Dim Sum Fan for most of my life, can not stand the Dim Sum they server, some of which taste like it set somewhere over night! 
Also the price, for much much better Dim Sum somewhere else for half the price! Just spend 100 on table for 2 and didn't even feel like ate anything worth remembering! Very very disappointed!
author: Bo P.

description:
Came here once for lunch (actually for to-go). Once is enough. This is not good Chinese food. It's not "ok" Chinese food. Hell! Any dim-sum joint in Chinatown is waaaaaaaaaaaaaay superior than this place.

Food is expensive. Food is LOADED with MSG. I had a chow-mein with a few pieces of dim sum, and after eating it, I drank THREE bottles of water straight, because I was so dehydrated and thirsty. I would NOT recommend this place. Yuck!
author: Sam W.

description:
Dumplings, pot stickers, and chow mein.  Good for lunch and a bit greasy, but worth a try.  Hot sauce was different and next time I would get only the chow mein, the rice was nothing to write home about.  However, I would go back again.  I ordered the following combo:

THE PHOENIX
Spring Roll
Pot Stickers (2)
Siu Mye (pork and shrimp dumpling)
Chow Mein
Fried Rice

I am sure there is something great on their menu....
author: Chase B.

description:
Picked up 'vegetarian delight' for lunch from their 2go menu. Boy I was surprised to find a piece of meat in there when it was time to eat. 

Such crap of a place they do not follow proper cleanliness and mix up the food. Their Chow Mein is oily and tasteless. Never again ..
author: Vikram B.

description:
Yank Sing certainly does not deserve a high ranking for its dim sum.  Growing up in Canton, I am a total dim sum snob and I went to Yank Sing out of its reputation.  It was a total disappointment.  It was very much Americanized (and maybe that is why many people think it is good).  If you want more authentic dim sum, I would recommend the Canton Dim Sum Seafood Restaurant down on Hawthorne and Folsom, much more authentic and good dim sum.  

Yes, the serving staff in Yank Sing speaks English, but so what, most other Chinese restaurants' staff do too.  If that is more important than food quality then you probably would choose Yank Sing (or better, eat at home and turn on your TV).  Yank Sing has relatively good ambience, but to me, it is a little over done and commercial.  It is in a good location, convenient for business lunch to please your clients.  But for me, food is really the essence of a restaurant and Yang Sing certainly is overrated.
author: Kai L.

description: I think I would give this place a 3.5 but my husband loved it so I'm rounding up!  We went around three and were seated right away.  Take note that I haven't had a lot of dim sum so i don't have a good comparison. Nothing to really complain about from our experience I just wasn't blown away by the food although I've heard from others that its pretty authentic and that they know of this place even in Hong Kong.  We had shrimp dumplings, seafood shumai, spring rolls, BBQ pork buns and fried crab claws. My favorite was by far the dumplings. I thought the batter with the crab claws was real fishy so I didn't even go beyond the first bite but the hubs claimed these as his favorite.
author: Esther C.

description:
I wouldnt normally think of having dim sum for breakfast but it just worked out that we were in the area early Sunday morning and hungry. I have had a few not-so-great experiences with dim sum so I am always a little hesitant. Yank Sing definately changed my mind. 

We tried shimp, pork, chicken and mushroom, and the pork and ginger dumplings. Fried Prawns, peking duck, and pork buns. With a huge pot of jasmine tea, we totally stuffed our faces for $45! Many have complained about the prices, but I felt it was resonable for the quality of food. Everything was very fresh and delicious. I will definately be going back.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
My very first experience of Dim Sum was at Yank Sing. I was impressed. I have been told by a few people that there are many good places throughout the city for Dim Sum. 

Yet, something about Yang Sing that made a good impression. The service was excellent and friendly and the food was delicious and abundant. This is a great place to go with friends or with those who are new to San Francisco. 

See web site for details:
http://www.yanksing.com/locations/index.html
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Well this was only my second dim sum experience, and it was mediocre. I was taken here on a casual first date and was surprised by the way the food is served; they walked around with carts of different foods and you get to choose what you want. One word for the wise, you can have them take the portions and cut them in half. Don't pass up the duck sandwich's they are to die for. Our tea was a little burnt, but otherwise pretty OK. 

I never find myself down in the financial district unless I am making the horrid commute to work where my sunglasses and headphones are my protection. But needless to say this place is just OK.
author: Katie H.

description:
Stay out of the way of the fast moving, steam cart wielding, ninja waitresses until seated and then sit back and enjoy some of the city's finest dim sum.  If Tiffany's sold tasty and convenient munchable morsels they'd likely look like the product produced at Yank Sing.  Everything is edible and beautiful from mundane Chinese broccoli to the exquisite artful dumplings.

Likely Tiffany's would charge the same too, so don't come hungry expecting to leave wealthy either.  But it is worth it and certainly cheaper than Hong Kong or the trip there where you might be able to find a comparable culinary experience.  Their larger outlet at the Rincon Center is more graciously proportioned and a (slightly) more gentile way to eat but I like the urban feel of the eatery on Stevenson.
author: frederick f.

description: Disappointing. Dumplings were kind of tough and lacked flavor. I stopped eating before I was full. Might be a good choice if looking for a sterile, non-chaotic, quiet sit-down place as opposed to the noisy, dining hall type ambiance of other dim sum places.  Didn't find my dumpling happiness here.
author: J J.

description:
They totally have their assembly line in check. Though the line looks intimidating, the women have a tight ship and know how to serve people their dim sum. I've been a regular here for the last few years that I've been in the Stevenson block. You can never go wrong with their dim sum and their different packages. However lately, I've been ordering ala carte and find I can get a filling meal for less than $5.

I think the real steal here is the Steamed Pork Bun. It's pretty big and only $1.40. Now their Shu Mai... it's $0.90 ea. kinda weak, but they are pretty hefty and stuffed with shrimp and minced meat. 

Their pork fried rice is decent, and for $4.35 you can get a side of fried rice, 2 shumai and 2 cream cheese wontons (and these have shrimp inside too). So you have lots of options... including rice plates and soup. They change weekly so there is lots of variety.
author: Alyson C.

description:
I put some thought in it and changed my review.  I initially gave one star because I was so pissed about the bill and I am not used to paying so much for Chinese food.   But when you think about it, the food was great (and well made), the service was good, I loved the green tea and the restaurant is very nice... except the pricing which is not listed anywhere.  Or at least no one is in a rush to tell you how much dim sum costs but instead pushes the carts and plates on you like there is no tomorrow.  So to be fair, I changed from one star to four.  If the prices were right, you could have gotten 5 stars.

I am a fan of this place but I cannot afford to eat there haha.  So I will probably not come back (unless my boss is paying) and instead go to Canton on Folsom street as usual.  But you are free to try, if you feel like splurging.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
My initial reaction:
Don't get me wrong.  Dim sum was great.  But when the bill arrived, I almost dropped my chop sticks!!! $99.60 for 3 people??? You must be kidding me.  I never paid 38 dollars (w the tip) for lunch in my life.  I would go broke if I had such lunches all the time.  

Back to Canton Dim Sum on Folsom street.  It's only two blocks another direction (on Folsom between 2nd and 3rd).  We go there all the time but we were heading to Osha's on Christmas Eve to discover that they were closed, so Yank Sing was our random choice. We get take outs there sometimes (which are around $10)  but never dined in until today.  A big mistake!  Who can afford to eat there?  Surprisingly, the place was almost packed. 

I feel bad for giving one star but I just cannot help it.  People should be warned before being ripped off like this.  And the ladies there are not hesitant to push food on you at all.
author: Ellie M.

description:
I was a Yank Sing virgin until my lovely friends treated me to brunch on a beautiful sunday morning. hey, who's to resist free food, right? however, i seriously think my chinglish does not mix well in these chinese places (read below for review on Creations and 100% Healthy Dessert).

lady: would you like some chicken lettuce cups?
me: yes, one please

lady then proceeds to give me ONE (yes ONE) lettuce cup with the fillings inside. when I said one, I meant one order, not one lettuce cup. Sadly I was too embarassed to eat that one lettuce cup so I let it spin round and round around the lazy susan while admiring one lettuce cup thats worth $4

Lettuce cup aside, the food was tasty but nothing stood out in particular. I did enjoy eating in the lobby of the rincon center though!
author: Nancie T.

description:
If I were a rich man, I would be here every day. Sadly, I am not. So, I'll have to really savor trips to Yank Sing Restaurant in SF. This is the best dim sum I'm ever had. Its not really the kind of dim sum I'm used to. Every piece of pork and shrimp here is a culinary feat. This is fine dining dim sum. 

Word to the wise, I heard the one at rincon center is an inferior restaurant as far as the decor... so, maybe you should just venture to this one if you feel like taking a shot at some $60 dim sum.
author: Andrew W.

description:
This is where you take scared white people, too scared to step out of their comfort zone.

The outrageous prices must make them feel secure that they are getting a quality experience; that if it's expensive it must be ok.

The food is fine but $30/person is too much to pay for dim sum.
author: E. M.

description:
What makes a dim sum experience is the choice, price, and gratification of eating right when you sit.

While Yank Sing did a great job of providing choice, the prices and wait  were clearly outlier to what a dim summer would expect.

adding .5 stars for overall cleanliness, and the fact that many of the servers speak some English.  Adding .25 stars for having several vegetarian alternatives that are tasty (pea vine dumplings and mushroom dumplings were pretty much fantastic)

3.75 stars.

happy eating!
author: Sam K.

description:
How is Yank Sing different from other dim sum restaurants?
1) Dim sum for 2 is at least $70.
2) The Yank Sing cart ladies' grasp of English is above average.
3) The place is clean.  So clean they publish their health inspection scores.  Impressive:  http://www.yanksing.com/about-score.htm
4) I liked everything I consumed.

Yes, this place is delicious as its reputation. And yes, it's as expensive as its reputation.  I wish I was related to Alice Chan, the founder of Yank Sing.  I'd be living the easy life from the family's dim sum riches. (They have to be rolling in the dough...ingrediants for dim sum are not that expensive).
author: mandy f.

description:
Um, overpriced, fancy, Americanized dim sum.  Yet, can any dim sum ever really be bad?  It fits a purpose, if you have out of town visitors who would die in a dim sum place filled with Asian people then this is your answer or people from out of town who heard how wondeful the presentation is here.  Which is why I ended up there last April, with my friend and her friend from LA.  

But if you have friends who don't mind mingling with the natives then take them somewhere else, you can eat 3 times as much for the same price.  I do give them the extra star for service, and the fact that it's super clean and they do have a few dishes you can't get many places.  

But some of the noodles were dry, and the seafood portions smaller than elsewhere.  Again, it fills a need for certain occasions, like that friend visiting from Nevada that has never had Asian food.
author: Denise B.

description:
First off, I'm not a chicken-foot type of guy, so I'm glad Yank Sing provides an un-ending myriad of delictables. It's easy to pass on one, because there's so many to choose. The weekday lunch rush gets crazy at all locations, but it's well worth the wait.

Deem Sum anytime!
author: J Z.

description:
Being a FiDi resident for a long time, I've been to Yank Sing quite a few times. Their dine menu is pretty large, but the food is just OK. Their to-go selections - a big NO. 
I just gave them a try after not eating Chinese food for quite a while and what a disappointment. 

I expected more from the food after seeing a line of 20 people.
author: Katja S.

description:
The fact that this place is full of white people on a weekend, drinking San Pellegrino with their dim sum should set off all kinds of alarms.  

I have no complains with the dim sum.  They all taste good, just like dim sums at any good dim sum restaurant.  Only Yang Sing charges 3-4 times more.   I don't mind paying the $$$ for uniqueness and originality, say a mushroom foam on the dumpling.  But the only surprise dish here is a Peking Duck on a cart.  A clean toilet and English speaking servers do not justify the high cost.  

Overrated and overpriced!!!  If you going to wait in the long lines, might as well go to Koi Palace...
author: Shane L.

description:
I'll admit I was a Dim Sum virgin.  And I think Yank Sing has ruined me for life.  The place was amazing!  The food delish!  I'm in love and considering a move to SF.   

I have never eaten so much at one sitting in my life.  I was fortunate to go with real foodies who ordered foods off the steam trays like the pros that they are.  I still don't know the names of some of the stuff we tried.   

Their shrimp eggrolls are heaven.  I'm still having dreams about them.  Their house dumpling  (the speciality) was a little steaming piece of heaven.

I'll admit when we walked into this place I got nervous.  There were alot of non asians in the house and I've always made it to point when I try ethinic foods to make sure it's got the said ethnic people in it.   By the end of our meal there were tons of Asians (I guess that Johnny come late doesn't just apply to us Mexicans!)

Anyhow if a steam tray didn't have what we wanted, the sever got on her headset and ordered one up for us.   It was pricy.  But well worth it to me I would have paid double.   Only get's 4 stars because one of my table mates ordered Chinese Broccolli and it was cold.  You could tell it was cooked well because it was seasoned good and crunchy but it was cold.
author: Sara D.

description:
Yum Cha! We intended to do so in the Chinese style but the frenzy of the carts got to us!

Not having regular access to this type of cuisine* really helps to build the anticipation of a visit to SF and Yank Sing didn't disappoint. Everything we had was good but EXPENSIVE. The bill for 2 with tip came to $120 and all we had to drink was tea! A slight disappointment was that the Xiao Long Bao wasn't as rich as we would have liked.

 I would still consider this my favorite Dim Sum place but would definately try some of the many other places in SF. For those who are wondering - I think both locations are equally good.

*While in HNL I have ready access to very good Dim Sum but I am only there part (not enough) time.
author: Alan N.

description:
Great lunch specials Monday-Friday in their YankSing 2Go location (right next to the restaurant). I particularly like their Seafood Supreme.

Overpriced dim sum and Americanized chinese food in their regular dining area.

For the best dim sum in San Francisco, see my review of Ton Kyiang.

Enough said.
author: Lara D.

description:
Unexceptional dim sum at outrageous prices.

Half of the items were cold despite coming in the middle of service.  I usually like it when a dim sum joint uses carts, allowing me to have the entire meal on my table in five minutes.  But this place is too small and crowded for that.

Definitely for the PF Chang crowd.
author: Max F.

description:
So this review is actually for the "Yank Sing To Go" counter at the Stevenson location.  I have definitely eaten inside, but $75 for two people was a bit much (great hangover cure though!).

The to-go area has 4-5 different platters usually consisting of a large amount of Chow Mein or Fried rice and a selection of dim sum.  I like the seafood one the best, but the Chow Mein is very greasy.  I usually end up throwing away half of it, because they give you so much.  

However, there is also an a la carte menu.  They have delicious Hot and Sour soup on Monday and Wednesday, and you can get that and a potsticker or spring roll for under $5.  It's plenty of food for the money and you get your fix for a little something fried as well as the healthier Hot and Sour soup.  Yum.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Yank Sing is the restaurant I most frequent in all of San Francisco. When I was in college and didn't have a lot of money, I developed a great love for Dim Sum. When I had more money, I discovered Yank Sing and truly loved it. 

I love the surprise of Dim Sum and everything Yank Sing offers is fabulous. This review does not include Yank Sing 2 Go, but strictly the sit-down restaurant.  If one cart comes first, that is your first impression. If another cart comes, you might be eating a little bit healthier. Here are some of my favorites. 

I love the:

Onion Cakes
Shrimp
Peking Duck
Baked Fish
Steamed Snow Pea
And so many more.......

I could lunch here everyday if allowed. They certainly charge for it, but it is the best in San Francisco in my opinion. I have tried a lot, but this is superior to others. I may go to others, but this is my personal favorite in San Francisco for dim sum.
author: Christopher W.

description: I enjoyed the entire experience and food was good.
author: Christopher Z.

description:
Good quality dim sum. 1 star off for being a bit pricey.
But the food is fresh. It helps if you go with someone who speaks chinese b/c if they dont have what you want on the cart and you ask nicely, they radio it over to the kitchen, and someone brings it to your table.

Their shanghai soup dumplings are pretty good and the soup is always in tact. At other places, the broth leaks out as you pick it up, or the broth was long gone and all your left with is a wonton looking thing.

I also love their chicken feet. YAAA, ew! spew! whatever, you guys dont know what you're missing. They are really good if they are done right.
However, my friend who lunched with me gave me a bad mental picture and said " It's like your sucking someone's toes!:"  Gross.... Maybe I won't eat chicken feet for a while.

Make a reservation or get there by 11:30 for lunch or you'll be waiting in line with all the suits in that area.

I love how non asian people try to tell their non asian lunch partners what the correct asian etiquette is...was laughing my butt off at the next table. He was telling her how to use chopsticks and just happened to drop his har gow right in his lap. HAHAHA fool.
author: Kat T.

description:
My wallet was screaming in pain and anger when I walked out of the place with my receipt.

Lunch for two plus a $4.95 to-go order for a coworker left me $90 lighter for dim sum that, while tasty, was no better than some of my favorite places in Chinatown and about $70 more expensive than it should have been.  I will throw them a sympathy star for their decent service.

Unless I'm in SOMA and an earthquake rips a 7 mile deep chasm running down Market while I'm in desperate need of dim sum, I'll never come back.  Even then, there's a mildly okay place over on Folsom where I'd rather whip out the wallet.
author: Josh C.

description: I was in the Bay Area for a weekend for back-to-back work weeks.  I posted on FB to my friends that I needed "scavenger hunt" requests, etc.  Friend said I had to go to Yank Sing.  She and her mother went there when visiting one time. I had the pork dumplings - delicious - and shrimp on stop on way back from errands in Chinatown.  Would recommend.
author: Andrew F.

description: I went to the take-out place. I got the daily special. I found the dim sum to be more oily than usual. The beef dish had too many onions. The prices are much higher than what I am accustomed to. Obviously doing good business though.
author: Andrew K.

description: For the price one pays to eat here, it is not worth it. The food is decent, not great, it's too damn loud, the cart ladies are abysmally obnoxious, and you can't turn your head without hitting the table behind you. Memorable, I suppose, but one can get a cheaper, better experience a block away at the B&M, or at any number of locations in Chinatown.
author: Tim B.

description: I'm always just a bit disappointed after I eat here.  It's still a great spot when you're downtown and craving dim sum, but... the pork buns are more bun than pork (and not particularly fluffy either), the ha gow don't really "pop" in your mouth, and the egg custard tarts aren't super flaky.  It can be pricey too, but none of us should expect to pay Chinatown prices for food in the financial district.  An ambivalent 3-stars.
author: Laurence W.

description:
overpriced but good, i like city view more, also they kept bringing us shrimp, and the poorly organized group i was with kept accepting the shrimp, maybe thats not yank sing's fault, dim sum employees are supposed to be pushy right?  "you want pot stika? you want pot stika?!"

Also we made reservations, but we still had to wait around a while.
author: Michael E.

description: I love Yank Sing for group lunches.  Anytime there is a special occasion I want to go here for lunch.  Food is good but it is pricey.
author: Karen C.

description:
xiaolongbao: very good! 

everything else is ok.... not amazing.

but this place is so so overpriced it is not even funny. it was 120 dollars for two of us, and we didnt even order drinks. mostly because the ducks are sold per slice lol!!!!!

for a 1inch by 2/3 inch slice, it was 5.75. so we ordered 4 slices (which really is just 4 bites), and it was 20+ dollars..... never ever seen that before at a dim sum place.

i'd go back if the price was right.
author: Danielle A.

description: I gave this place another try, therefore I'm upping it 1 more star. I come here now because I like their B special for $4.95 (pork fried rice, 2 cream cheese curry wontons & 2 shumai). I also really like the steamed pork bun.
author: Krystel M.

description: The dim sum was good but definitely not worth 3 times the price.  $4.95 for 2 not so good steamed pork bun is robbery.  The xi lun bao was good but not worth the $12.50 for 6 little dumplings.  We spent $100 with tax and tips for 3 people and we were not even that full, I will definitely not come back again.
author: Indigo B.

description:
I only get to go here when I have a final to take at Golden Gate University.  If I take my best friend, we don't get out of there for less than $100 ... just for the two of us.  If I am alone, maybe $30.  I love the pistachio desert.  They have a To-go stand where they have prepared meals for about $7.  I like the Phoenix, which has potstickes, egg roll, siu mi, fried rice, and chow mein.  This place is a little hard to find, but it's right by 2nd Street, and if you walk on the sidewalk near 525 Market, it's right there.  

Oh ... the food!  Good duck, chicken in lettuce cups, (my favorite!!) good buns, dumplings, and rice noodles, but you have to ask for those!  Just be prepared to spend money.  It's cheap if you just buy a few samples, or do the take out.  But on the whole, it's strictly average dim sum.
author: Michael M.

description:
Maybe it's all about lowered expectations, but.. we had a pretty good lunch here yesterday. The atmosphere inside is minimal, but I think (based on 1 visit) that they do a better job getting out fresh, hot, well-assorted food here than they do at the Rincon Center location. Everything -- except the leathery potstickers -- was at least good, but the soft-shell crab and the crab-and-shrimp shu mai were standouts. Tasty soup dumplings, so-so sticky rice/pork in lotus leaf, nice soft char-siu bao, and lard-o-licious custard tarts rounded out the things we tried.

Very filling lunch for 2 with sodas was $50-ish, woof.
author: anita c.

description:
Have been to this place numerous times for lunch. They serve really tasty dumplings (every kind with very thin rice flour wrappers.) Chinese are pretty big on fresh seafood and this place always uses good quality shrimp, scallops, cod, etc. This restaurant service is more friendly and much less touristic than the one at Rincon Center (except that once there's the DMA conference going on and apparently the conference people all knew about this restaurant, and made the wait to be 45 mins while we never have to wait more than a few mins!!) The great outcome of this is that since then the hostess remembers us as the impatient patrons who normally only get an hour of lunch!

Service wise, if this is your first time there, they seem to have a radar knowing it and would push all kinds of dishes onto your table. I still remember the first time being there, while hesitating whether to get a specific dish, the server (one who rolls the trolley) said, "yeeeees you want the dish."

A note on the timing, the best time is to be able to get there and sit down after 12pm. Food is only lukewarm before noon and after 1:30pm.
author: T L.

description:
Third time here.
Clean, 'fresh" dim sum.
Yum yum shanghai dumplings.
Chili sauce tasty
Expensive.
author: Jerry L.

description:
We were in San Francisco for the weekend and a friend wanted to try Yank Sing.  Well I read reviews and some seemed hit and miss mostly miss.  But a friend told me it was worth a try.  
We were able to call and have our name placed on the list (score!)  once we got there we only waited 5 min for a table but the room was pretty packed.  We sat down and we were served right away.  We started with Shrimp ha gau, rice dumplings, steamed pork buns and pork shumai.  I also was saving room for the shanghai dumplings.
