The Shrimp ha gau was ok...they ended up kinda chewy after awhile.  the rice dumplings were also ok...not as greasy as others I've tried.  the steamed pork buns were good...nice light fluffy bun with yummy filling.    The pork shumai was yummy it actually had a a good and different flavor from the typical pork shumai I've had.  Then the shanghai dumplings we saved for last...the host taught us how to actually eat them without burning our tongues.  They were the best part of the meal...the inside broth was nice and flavorful with a lovely filling.  
Overall the meal was satisfying but I have had better dim sum elsewhere...I would say im glad I tried it but would definately go back for the shanghai dumplings.
author: Christina P.

description:
If you have an expense account, you go to Yank Sing or you end up paying waaaaay too much for dim sum that you could get in Chinatown. However if your friend works downtown and you both have a hankering for dim sum, you go to Yank Sing. 

Dim sum for Downtown prices. Brillant strategy.
author: Thao L.

description:
Great lunch spot, wonderful dim sum...

Generous portions, good prices, fast service.  I was there during the lunch rush and it was terrific.  They got you in, fed, and out in an orderly manner.

I have a weakness for steamed pork buns and they do not disappoint here!  I recommend the "Phoenix" with a steamed pork bun.

Update 3/8/7:  So, I thought that the sit-down portion of the resturant was essentially the same as the "To Go" part....We went there for lunch today and decided to eat there.  $75 (for 2) later we left broke but satisfied.
author: Daniel A.

description:
I love this place, it's great.  The service is friendly & fast, the chili sauce is tasty, and they have a nice assortment of dim sum to choose from. It's very clean there, and it's easy to get to (short walk from Montgomery BART. )

Also, they have a very good website with a section showing photos and descriptions of each dim sum, so you can show it to first timers who ask "what is dim sum?"  I think this is a good place to bring a dim sum beginner before taking them to places like Dol Ho.
author: Asteridae A.

description: Delicious food. Completely absent service. We tried to order something from the menu a couple of times. Each time, 15 minutes, later, someone came by to say "we're out of (chicken / shrimp)." I think they just didn't want to deal with special orders (even though they handed us a menu) - unless they were the first Chinese restaurant in history to run out of chicken. Thirsty? Good luck.
author: Seth L.

description:
Great place for dim sum and may I remind you to save your pennies because the good stuff ain't cheap. It's a perfect place to take out of towners for that "unique" San Francisco experience. You will definitely find dim sum here to be more mainstream; in other words, the chicken feet don't make it to the cart, but I believe if you want it you can probably special order it. It's a great place to get a cross-section of the city's diverse population, and I think you'll feel at home, even spoiled by the staff.

Advice: go early, like others say, and pace yourself for heaven's sake. Don't get every single dish you lust after...but choose carefully or else you'll have a table full of half eaten dishes! Dim sum is best shared with friends so you can try everything that way too. There is an a la cart menu as well, so don't feel shy about asking for chow mein/fried rice if you really want some too. If you are there on a weekend (the Rincon Center one) walk on over to the Ferry Building for some sightseeing...and to walk off that food coma that you'll inevitably have after eating there!

The Stevenson site is smaller and a little longer wait. If at all possible for either site make reservations, esp. for holidays! You can wait up to an hour at peak time.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Pretty PRICEY for dimsum, but TASTY
Nice OUTDOORSy area, but can be HARD TO FIND 
Great SERVICE, but NOT LOTTA CHOICES  
Lotta choices for DESSERT!

BIG PLUS: they do serve that Sea Bass dish .. damn it's like butter

TODAY IS SUCH A BEAUTIFUL DAY -- So, ONE MORE STAR - bcuz I got a chance to eat w/ my hubby for lunch (yes, i played hookie from work)
author: Stel D.

description:
I went here for a wedding reception last year and was so blown away that I knew I had to come back to try their dim sum. 

Had the opportunity to come by again last wknd and experienced superb service & amazing dim sum! The place is definitely pricey ($22/person for a 3 person party), but you definitely get the service and quality that you pay for.

Their BBQ Pork buns & some sort of dessert bun that's similar, but w/ a custard filling, were like little pillows of goodness. They were so yummy that we decided to get some to go. Their Pork Sui Mye was also well crafted, along w/ a few other items that I can't recall the names of.

The servers knew exactly how to treat their customers- one even took the time to show us how to eat one of the dumplings w.out us even asking. Their head server, Christina, met all of our needs- ordering our to go items through her little headset, tracking down any dim sum items we were looking for, and carefully packaging our food. You never get this kind of service at any other dim sum place. 

Ambiance: Very, very clean which was refreshing since all the dim sum places I've been to have been diirty. The whole feel of the restaurant is modern, yet classic- their non-traditional, glass tea pots even reflect it!

I'll definitely be back when I've got the money to splurge and the energy to make it down to SOMA.


p.s. Check out Steve L.'s review too! It's very on point.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
The best dim sum we have ever had!  Some locals had recommended to us while we were in town, and yes, it's also the most expensive dim sum.  

Amazing duck buns, the Chilean Sea Bass, the soup thing... man what was that called??  

Wish we could go tomorrow.
author: Miyoko R.

description:
Was told that this was the best dim sum in San Fran, I hope that really isn't the case. What made it worse was the bill at the end and it just really wasn't value for money.

Having spent time in Hong Kong for a few years, I am pretty used to dim sum being pushed around on a trolley cart although it's slowing being phased out now. So I was kind of happy to see it still being done this way here at Yank Sing in San Francisco because I feel that it adds to the whole dim sum experience. However, I've not ever encountered being pushed to order food before. It's like the waiters here have been in intensive training in hard selling. I was barely able to eat and chat without a lady telling me how tasty everything was on her push cart. I think in total I'd ordered around 10 dishes or possibly even more, I'd lost count... it was like a blur... one minute I'd arrived and the next I had a table full of dim sum in front of me. Secondly, the food was mediocre at best, some of the dishes were just wrong. I enjoyed the glutinous rice and the steamed pork ribs (which isn't usually something I would order) but everything else was disappointing. The sea bass which was one of the dishes I was compelled to take was okay but pricey (I actually think I said no but somehow this meant yes here!). Some dishes looked over steamed. The texture to the Turnip cake and Siu Mai were just plain wrong.

Maybe I'd just gone on a bad day as some people seem to really enjoy it and have given it a great review. I mean, some even claim it to be the best dim sum restaurant in San Francisco so I may have to give this another try in the future. For now though, I will be trying out other dim sum restaurants particularly the ones in Chinatown itself.
author: Nigel L.

description:
I have not eaten AT this location, but I got the take out version once.

In my takeout box were several pieces of possibly THE WORST dim sum I've ever had... and I've tried a lot of bad dim sum. Granted, my disdain was compounded by the fact that I just shelled out about 6 bucks for what I could have gotten for 2 bucks in Chinatown (which ironically is where I work).

The skin on the dumplings were too think and cold or understeamed or something. The sui mai was just plain gross on par with the ones you get in the costco frozen section. It was terribly disappointing because the sit down (at least at the rincon center branch) is usually quite good.

(i know it's unfair to rate just the take out at this location, and just the sit down at the other location, but thems the breaks - although I suspect the take out at the rincon is equally bad)
author: Bernie L.

description:
White washed DIM SUM...I'm alright with that...who likes chicken feet anyway...I don't!
The pistachio and almond ice cream is to die for and so are the dofu fas
author: BoraBora T.

description:
I like getting quick lunches here, especially their "Pheonix" meal which consists of chow mein, fried rice, 2 potstickers, and 1 xiu mai, all for $5.95. 

Their sit-in dining for lunch does get very busy. Their dim sum is more on the expensive side compared to dim sums in Chinatown but if you're craving this in the financial district then I would opt to eating here. It's also nice and clean with its usual oriental decoration.
author: Oanh N.

description:
Good location and quality dim sum...but only 3 stars.  There are better, more authentic, less expensive places in the city.  That said, I love me some dim sum and they don't disappoint.

Word to the wise - learn how to Just Say No before going.  If you just nod your head and smile every time the Aiming to Please dim sum ladies cruise by, you will find you have received 25 dishes in the course of a meal.
author: mademoiselle m.

description: Yet another great place for lunch if you have a generous expense account. I am a huge fan of Dim Sum and Yank Sing has modernized it a bit (meaning the staff wears headsets to order things from the kitchen when they don't have it on their cart, and it is cleaner than your average dim sum joint). They have also managed to keep the food simple and not very greasy (Which also seems to be a challenge for other spots). The dumplings are sophisticated and the Peking duck is savory...watch your dollar amount here- about 5 items could set you back about $75.
author: Sarah M.

description: A dimsum place where I've been a customer over the years, both at the Rincon Annex and this one on Stevenson Street. The food is so-so, the Yank Sing brand is overhyped. New customers can experience real dimsum for a song. A pricey one at that. The take-out counter is "manned" by a barking beast; she is rude and ruthless. No patience when a customer asks questions. She just wants you to order from the menu and go, like a trained communist contemporary from her country. I ordered one of the items and customized 2 crab claws. Maybe I shouldn't have asked but when the bill was over $21 for take-out, I clarified how much was the crab claw. She said $6.80. I was charged twice, so maybe she should've told me $13.60. As a paying customer, I have the right to ask, last I checked. The experience was unpleasant and the potential customer (a white woman) behind me, left without ordering anything. Good for her!!!
author: bohemienne r.

description:
Overpriced.  Overhyped.  Overrated.  I cannot understand how anyone can possibly think that this is one of the best Chinese restaurants in San Francisco.  

The food is mediocre:  the dumpling fillings were decent but not stellar, and the skins on the crystal shrimp dumplings were tough and dry.  

The selection is small, and some classic dim sum dishes were notably absent (what, no cheong fun rice rolls?).  

And the price.  Even without the $17 sea bass, it still came out to almost $20 per person including tax and tip, which is twice the amount you would have to pay for excellent dim sum in Los Angeles and maybe 50% higher for Koi Palace, the most pricey dim sum I've had so far in the Bay Area.  The Asian in me was offended by the bill.  And I was still a little hungry afterwards!  

The beauty of dim sum is that you get to eat a lot of different stuff without sacrificing your wallet, and this restaurant failed on both fronts.  While I normally avoid the tourist trap that is Chinatown at all costs, you will find better dim sum at a better price at New Asia and City View.  Or head to the Richmond district for even more dim sum choices.  This review is for the location on Stevenson; perhaps the experience at the Spear St. location is better, but I will not be heading there any time soon to find out.
author: Nina W.

description: Best Dim Sum, hands down. If you're visiting, it is a must go to place. If you live here, Yank Sing is a bit expensive to be a go-to place unless you get food from the to go window and it that case, it is ridiculously cheap (but not the same food as inside). Get the house special. Amazing. dumplings filled with soup and meat served with amazing ginger sauce. Very expensive though. I deducted one star because a) this place is so expensive and it adds up very fast and b) the servers are pretty pushy. You have to give a very firm "no" when they are pushing every plate of food onto your table and stamping your card at the blink of an eye. The sesame balls are practically famous. I'm not a big dessert person but everyone I come here with loves them. My personal favorite is the coconut dessert. During lunch, this place is swamped. Make a reservation or go after 1.
author: Darah P.

description: Excellent Dim sum and even better service!  I try to make it to Yank Sing at least once a month.  The staff is one of the best and the dim sum is spectacular.
author: Jonathon J.

description:
I'm really not too sure why this place charges so much for dim sum you can find for just as good if not more authentic in nearby Chinatown for pennies. Is it so its patrons can sit down and feel like they've arrived in the dim sum world? So that girlfriends can feel good about telling people their boyfriends proposed to them in an expensive suit over dim sum? It's not a good sign when Chinese people make fun of people who like it there so much. The service certainly isn't as fast or convenient as they want you to think, even when going through the express line. 

But okay, I'll say it's cleaner, more elegant and prettier than most dim sum joints I know. The cart wheelers can converse in English better than other places too, which means less messed up orders. If you're a regular dine-in, they do take good care of you. The maitre d' makes sure to reserve you your preferred seating, and you get waited on by people in sophisticated black tuxes... hang on people... it's dim sum. Who thinks of dim sum and thinks hoighty toighty haute cuisine?
author: Clar L.

description:
This is the best dim sum I have ever had, and I have traveled extensively in the major California cities, Portland, Seattle, Vancouver BC, DC, etc.

The dim sum is worth the price.  Why do you think there are lines at peak times?  People are willing to pay for the best.

The sheer selection of plates is mind blowing.  The occasional dim sum sampler will find this haunt to be truly amazing.
author: dave a.

description:
The xiao long bao is probably the best thing that they have going for them there.  Everything else that I've had there has a good consistent taste as well, but is comparable to many other dim sum that I've had.  Come with deep pockets, or a half full stomach if you don't want a bruise in your wallet.  

Other than the pricing, this place is a must go!
author: Dimitri Y.

description:
I love Dim Sum!
I think that being a white guy with white guy taste buds, Yank Sing is as solid as you can get. Not to say that it lacks authenticity, but I know that this place caters to the downtown SF scene. That's just fine with me because this place is KILLER!!!

This is the typical visit for me. 
It's a family affair with my 2 year old son, my 8 year old son and my wife. We have been frequent visitors to Yank Sing for years so as we walk through the door, we're usually greeted by name.  We prefer to sit inside and they seem to always remember this and we usually get seated promptly (call and make a reservation ahead of time!!) As the food starts coming we start grabbing it!! The food is always fresh and hot and I have never left let down. As we go through all the different things to eat,  and start to get full, we always know that the sweet ht tofu is soon to be at the table.

The only downside to my family going here is that we EAT! A typical lunch for us costs about $130.00...but it's worth it! I love this place and will continue to be here about once month.
author: JR H.

description:
Not too much selection in terms of the "traditional" Chinese dim sum, like the ones you find in hole in the wall dim sum places in LA.  

But the dishes they did have were pretty tasty.  Fine ingredients and a somewhat formal setting make this a great dim sum spot.  Basically it's like fine dining dim sum.
author: Diana C.

description:
This place is wonderful, but expensive!  Yikes!  And it's so easy to run up a huge check.  My sister and I went there for lunch and spent $60!  We didn't even get drinks.  Ugh.

That said, it's damn delicious.  They have some very tasty vegetarian dumplings that make happy happy happy.  The green beans are super tasty too.  Sesame balls.  I wonder if they could make a vegetarian bun.

Their chili sauce is made especially for them...or by them...or something.  Use it!
author: Tamara M.

description:
(-) Overpriced
(-) Seating is tight and Dim Sum carts bumb and tap on you while servers plow down aisles.  
(-) Not an authentic Dim Sum experience.
(+) Convenient location
(+) Good for a quick business lunch
(+) Pork buns
author: Caryn W.

description:
please someone prove me wrong

expensive chinese food is one of those oxymorons like 'jumbo shrimp'.  i've treated myself and two other people to dimsum at a place like good luck on clement for less than $20.00 total.  and at yank sing i dropped just a bit over $20.00 for some dim sum?  personally i think the dim sum at good luck or you's is better.

if you've got a nice cushy job in the financial district, this is where you dim sum. if you're job is to maximize efficiencies and you work where there's just as many homeless people as there are home'd people, this is a waste of your cash.
author: Ameer N.

description: Yuck - they too serve Shark Fin Soup... Downgrade.
author: Elizabeth Z.

description: I had lunch at the Rincon Center, Yank Sing, just decided to give it a try since its such a popular place.  The food was okay considering it cost over $100 for two.  Remember folks this is for lunch.  I was also disappointed in one of the  vegetable dish.  I believe it was Chinese broccoli  served cold.  I'd expected it to be hot, maybe its suppose to be that way.  Who knows, I never had it cold.  The only thing that is worth while is their take out.  I wont go there again, maybe take out but not going to bother getting a table.
author: S F.

description: I enjoy treating myself to lunch at Yank Sing on Fridays.  Although it can be very busy, they are usually accommodating.  I like to attempt to try one of everything, but there is so much it never works.
author: Jana P.

description: I hosted my wedding banquet this past weekend, and my guests and I were extremely satisfied with both the service and food presentation.  I worked with Daisy Hung, the event sales/coordinator.  She listened to my request, stayed in touch during planning, conveyed message clearly, and was very thoughtful.  For the day of the event, I asked to have great customer service and great food presentation, and they fulfilled the expectation.  Everyone liked all the dishes, especially the Honey Glazed Sea Bass, and all waiters and the manager, Lina, were very attentive.  They made sure the glasses were full at all time, tables are cleaned, and checked on guests when they spotted guests might needed services.  I strongly recommend this place if you need a venue for your event.
author: Sharon L.

description: Hands down the best dim sum experience I've ever had.  My only regret is that I ordered too much early in my visit and didn't have the stomach for many items I've never seen before.  This place has it all: world-class service, extremely clean and upscale dining experience, and the widest variety and freshest dim sum on the planet.  It's definitely more expensive but if you're a true dim sum lover, it's very much well worth-it.  I will absolutely plan to come back during my next visit to San Francisco and have not found a place in Chinatown that comes close in terms of selection.
author: Chris C.

description:
I just had Dim Sum with my husband yesterday morning. I have to say what a spectacular experience! Yank Sing in Chinese means Guangzhou. They serve the breakfast as traditional cantonese style. They are unbelievably fresh!
The waitresses constantly wheeled out the carts loaded with  goodies. You see something good, you pick it up and they stamp on your order sheet.
We had Shanghai Xiaolongbao (shanghai style steam juicy soup dumplings), seafood basil dumplings, chicken spring roll and 2x shrimp dumplings, plus a pot of Oolong tea. 
Every single item was good! good! and good! 
We would love to try more items, but we were too full. 
However, we will have to try them for our next visit.
So you wonder why I rate it 4 star instead of 5 star? hum....I say it is somewhat pricey. However, it is not so bad. The final bill we paid is $61 (tip included). So I guess if you are looking for a under $40 breakfast or lunch for two people, you need to go somewhere else.
I go this place for the taste, fresh and clean. :) 
Also, it is a very nice place with a good clientele.
author: chinesegirlinLA c.

description:
I went here today. My sisters took me here to celebrate my bday and I must say that the food was pretty good. The only part that bugged me was that they are mega expensive for a dim sum house. The 3 of us ordered Shanghai dumplings "signature dish", shrimp ha-gows, sticky rice, bbq buns and 3 other items. The waitresses are a bit agressive tho; twice we declined them from plating us with  the $15 miso sea bass!  Its a far cry from the hong kong tea houses where you can slowly peruse the carts and hang out for 2 hours. 

Beware: This location does not serve the rice crepes or dessert tofu wi/ginger sauce.. that was a disappointment.
author: Meredith C.

description:
All I've heard about is how amazing Yank Sing is.  Maybe they were referring to the sit down restaurant.  I finally ventured over to the 2 Go location and was excited to dig in to Chow Mein, a Pot Sticker, the spring roll, and most importantly, the Pork Bun!!!

The Pork Bun was amazing which is why the get two stars and not one, like Ashley B gave.  The rest was a bad trip down too-greasy lane.  I felt ill after eating the portion that I got through, but BABY the Pork Bun was yummy in my tummy!

If I go back it will be for a pork bun only.  ;)
author: Sparkely K.

description:
Food was greasy and over priced!  We spent $50, then went home and ate again because we were still hungry.  Each dish at this dim sum place is $8 to $11  Oh My God!
We heard this place is great but were sadly disappointed.  We've found much better dim sum in Richmond
author: Patrick Z.

description:
HUNGRY for some Dim Sum, my bf and i decided to try Yank Sing. It's ZAGAT rated so it must be good! We wanted to shop around Union Square and yank sing was only a block away and a good walking distance. When we first got there, i notice their customers are very diverse (i thought to myself ..cool ). All of their servers speak english and are very friendly. They all wear little ear pieces to communicate so they can be more attentative and work at a faster pace.  They come around once in a while and fill your tea pot and to make sure everything is ok. They pay attention to what you say cause I overheard a customer at a different table say to a server that he doesn't eat pork. The server immediately as he walked away quietly into his mouthpiece  and told the other servers that that table does not eat pork, so therefore, do not ask them if they'd like any dim sum containing pork in it. i thought to myself...WOW..thats so cool. it makes it so much easier for the customer. 

We ordered sew mai, fong jow, chuarng fun, xiao long bao(shanghai dumplings...YUM), and  egg rolls. Everything was delicious!

i give it **** because they have a limited selection of dim sum and not a big variety like other places. the cost is double..each dish is apprx $5   or more and usually other dim sum places is half of that. My boyfriend and I did go back though!
author: nancy t.

description: What can I say? It's fast cheap Chinese takeout. Chow mein was just your ordinary oily yellow egg noodles with BBQ pork and celery. I got the Express combo that had a greasy crunchy egg roll (best part) and pork bun. All the 7-ish dollar combos are good for grab-and-go lunch, as the name suggests. Nothing much to rave/rant about.
author: Hannah H.

description: This place rocks! It's pricey but worth every cent! The quality and consistency is always on point! Never had a bad meal here ever! And the wait staff is more friendly than most dim sum places that I've eaten at. If you want quality I recommend this place! It's a James Beard award winning resturant so what more can you say???
author: Simpson W.

description:
OOOOH, I miss Yang Sing! I cannot find any Dim Sum in the  northern end of Los Angeles.

Dammit ,Yang Sing- you are the best!

Terri
author: Terri G.

description:
Only tourists, foreigners, and those unfamiliar with Cantonese cuisine would deem this place excellent. 

Fancy shmancy does not mean GOOD. 

Try Dim Sum in the South Bay, Peninsula, East Bay. Anywhere, but here? Service at restaurants in these areas will more than likely be horrible, but it's all about the food!

Go to places a Chinese grandmother and her friends would go to. Not a place where you would find a vast majority of bougie-ettes.
author: Thao T.

description: Great food but pricey.  If you want to go here during the lunch hour reservations are a good idea.  Keep in mind that for a business lunch - if you want it to go for any length of time - this might not be the best place.  You are stuffing your face within seconds of sitting down (at least I am) and once finished, if not after the lunch rush, they can make you feel the pressure to scoot out of there.  The place can do some amazing turnover.  As for food recommendations, the pork dumplings cannot be missed and the pork buns are very satisfying; the prawns with candied walnuts and the schezwan spicy chicken are probably my favorites.
author: Matt C.

description: The food here was good, we had lunch here yesterday, but it did not wow us like other less expensive places we've gone to in Chinatown.  There was a nice variety, and it was cool that they had peking duck by the slice (though the "pancakes" were doughy & mushy.  BUT, at the end of the meal we were shocked that it came to $65 per couple.  I mean that is nuts considering we could've gotten the same amount, and probably tastier food, for about $25 per couple in Chinatown.  And, usually we leave those places feeling stuffed, here we did not.   It is a nice ambiance, but the service wasn't much different than other dim sum places we've gone to, most servers have zero personality.  At least most knew English enough to tell us what things were.  The honey glazed pork buns were one of our favorite things here.
author: D R.

description: Really love this place, whether you visit the to-go counter or dine in at the restaurant.  The food is great; my fav choice is Singapore Rice Noodles.  But if you do choose to get food at the to-go counter, I would suggest to stop by after 1pm, the line is shorter....this place can be very crowded before then.
author: Tiffany P.

description: Grossly overrated and overpriced. Its definitely dim sum catered to westerners. Fresh ingredients served hot, but with a limited menu. Koi in Daly City is truly a dim sum dining experience regardless of what ethnicity or culture you are from that you must try as an alternative. The one thing I can say about Yank Sing though is service is great, execution is great, but the delicacy of the preparation of the dishes and complexity of the dishes are not there. The nice part is the baked and fried dishes are always crispy and hot.
author: Jeffrey W.

description:
Way too Expensive to even think of going back.
Don't sit outside - eating from an uneven table really sucks especially when you pay top dollar.
Not enough variety - probably because they cater to the American clientele.
Service was okay. The food was safe.  Plates were somewhat dirty.
author: yohs m.

description:
Nothing new to add - everything has been said. Just feel the need to add comments to validate previous reviews:

Date: 09/30/2007

Pluses: 
1) Good dim sum - clean, tasty, a level above most normal dim sum places
2) Validated parking

Minuses
1) Expensive (3 people $92) - I'd say bordering being exorbitant  
2) Didn't seem to have that much variety that most dim sum places have - Maybe I'm wrong here but they had about two major carts (one steamed stuff another fried). The desserts were very limited too.
author: Eric C.

description:
Some average chinese food that a white guy would think is awesome and maybe think is even more awesome because it's a popular restaurant advertised everywhere for their super-average-yet-very-disappointing dimsum.  but anyway...i had nothing to eat for lunch on friday at work so i decided to go somewhere close but also one that i'd never been to.  NOW I KNOW WHY I'VE NEVER TRIED THIS PLACE.  I went down to stevenson streetto try some yank sing to go.  It was cheap ...a phoenix lunch box will cost you roughly $7 more or less...or rather $7.27 with a can of soda to be exact.  Basically you've got: 

one 3 inch eggroll (i'd give it 3 stars for being not your average eggroll)
one shiu mai (i'd give it 1 star for being normal and being very small)
two fried potstickers (i'd give it no star for being average)
half a handful of fried rice (i'd give it 2 stars for texture, but that's all...flavor-wise it is definately less tasty than white rice)
half a handful of chow mein (i'd give it 2 stars also because of texture...however as with the rice...it lacks alot of flavor)

soy sauce was an important ingredient in this lunch box.  If you dont get soy sauce please grab the nearest bottle of salt or hot sauce or some kind of flavoring...because youuuu are going to need it.

basically i'm being nice by giving it this rating.  i was actually going to give it 1 star but i gave it 1 more because of the nice people that served me there.  anyway...

bottom line: if you're thinking about going here...and are ready for some super-average-chinese food....then go right ahead.  if you're looking for something different...stay home and cook some ramen.

hey! at least ramen has "some" flavor!?
author: Jack N.

description:
Let me start out by being completely honest:  Dim Sum is my least favorite form of chinese food. 

Yank Sing is the exception to the rule.  Ordered about eight dishes at lunch a week ago.  Don't know what half the things were, but that's the beauty of dim sum; you just point and eat.  The food came out quickly, but the variety was lacking.  Too much fried stuff and too many carts full of the same things.  Nonetheless, I think I've fallen in love with the fried crabs legs stuffed with shrimp.

Unfortunately, I nearly coughed up my lunch when I got the bill.   I'm trying to make myself believe that $80 for two people for lunch REALLY isn't that unreasonable.  Still a nice place if you don't mind paying the steep prices.
author: Vince S.

description:
Basically, this place is pretty darn tasty, but you live in a free market economy where there are other options that are just as tasty if not tastier and less expensive.  You owe it to yourself as a capitalist to go there.  

The shangai pork dumplings (the ones with soup in them) were excellent and they give you about 5 per order, so that's not bad.  The vegetable dumplings are tasty as well as the chicken and mushroom.  It's a good place, and it would get 5 stars if it were in KC, DC, or Miami.

Here are the problems I had:
First of all, we had phoned in a reservation for a party of eight at 12:15.  Naturally, the place is packed, so we felt all smug for calling it in.  However, we had to wait an extra 35 min. before our table was ready.  35 min is a long time waiting outside, especially when they give you bullshit excuses like, "the table is being set", and it takes another 20 min.  

Secondly, if you sit in the patio, after some of the lunch crowds leave, there's damn pigeons flying around everywhere.  I'm as serious as a heart attack.  One was flying around the restaurant and brushed the back of my neck with it's feathers.  I was lucky it didn't crap on me.  Then it starts eating the left overs on the table next to us.  Another one was feeding from another table.  Gross.  I would be forgiving, but the wait staff didn't care.  They saw them and didn't do anything.  I mean, it was a little gross, and the restaurant is so expensive, I feel the least they can do is keep the winged rats off of my back.
author: Ricky R.

description:
Reservation + good quality + great service + cleanness = 5 Star + our favorite dim sum place

Think about all the parking and seating problems in other dim sum places, we just decide to go back here since there are no hassles and no chaos in dining here.  Dim Sum quality is good and of great variety.   And we keep discovering new dim sum we like every time.  What else we should ask for?
author: Ile F.

description: As there are so many reviews, I will offer just one possibly helpful suggestion: get the (and I don't know the pinyin spelling) ChiaSu Bow (warm out of the oven pork bow). It's only 1.45 each - I'm set for the afternoon with 2 in my tummy.
author: Holly F.

description: Oh Yank Sing...how delicous yet expensive you are for dim sum!  That's what I get for going to a dim sum place in the FiDi, guess I should've been more prepared for the prices. Took a friend here (visiting from out of town) for a quick dim sum lunch and it was yummy yummy!  Service (being seated, getting water/tea refills, variety of dim sum carts that went by) were great!  I recommend coming in around 1 or 1:30, at the tail end of the lunch rush.  We were in and out in about an hour, and we only had to wait that long b/c we special ordered some things that they had to bake fresh. If you ordered just from the carts I'm betting you could be in and out in less than an hour.  Some of the items were a little cool but that is doable...just be ready to spend some cash!
author: Tracy N.

description: I've been here once when I was a kid and it left a hugge impression on me. Coming back as an adult has left a big impression on my wallet. I never realized how expensive their food was!! I got 5 different things: Shrimp toast (super greasy, so it tastes like shrimp grease), the spinach dim sum and the Shitake mushroom dim sum (good), the baby broccoli w/oyster sauce (gross because it was served cold!), and the Sesame balls with red bean paste (awesome). My 5 items cost me $52 w/ tip!! My friends got the Shanghai dumplings which were great and interesting to to eat and the Char Shu Bao which was by far the best bbq pork bun I have ever had. I love this place but the prices are a major turn-off.
author: Melissa L.

description: Their Shanghai Steamed Dumplings were outstanding!  Steaming hot and juicy, just the way they should be.  However, the other items were just mediocre and their prices were sky high.  I guess they cater mostly to tourists and "Kwai-lohs."  Would return just for their expensive melt in the mouth dumplings.
author: Julie L.

description:
The location is a little hidden, but that's the city for you, not the restaurant's fault.

Get there before the rush and you can get a table pretty quickly.

Fast service; they're efficient at getting the carts around, so the dim sum is still hot/warm when it gets to your table. 

If you're unfamiliar with dim sum restaurants, you need to eliminate any expectations that the staff is going to chit chat, or provide elaborate explanations of what it is and how it was made. (I'm fine with that b/c I prefer to eat my dim sum hot, just give me the basics -- what is it, vegetable, chicken, pork, etc???  -- and by looking at it, I can figure out if it was steamed, or fried, or etc).
author: Bella B.

description:
came back again on my own dime, and another company luncheon. the good things still stand out as great, and then there's everything else. 

which is to say, BEST XIAO LONG BAO in the SF restaurants. Yup, i said it. and i've been to shanghai dumpling king, shanghai house, got the fresh frozen xlb from kingdom of dumplings, and yank sing is still the best dumplings i've had. light thin skin with a mouthful of soup inside, served hot with vinegar. yes, it is $10 for about six dumplings, but they really are the best ones I've had in the city. (you can probably get 10 for $5 elsewhere, but we're just debating quality, not overall deal). i can justify the price every once in a while, because its a bit rich for my blood, but yes, best xlb.

the other things that amaze me about this place:
--super clean and orderly for a dim sum place (everything is more expensive across the board)
--good tea in a nice tea pot ($3 a person, ay)
--egg custard tarts are FANTASTIC ($4-6, i think?)
--quick service

most other items are pretty run of the mill. but with the XLB and egg tarts and tea, that's all i'd really want for a lunch that i pay for.  just DON'T poke a hole in your bao so that the soup leaks out otherwise i will have a cow and glare at you for the whole lunch. bad bad karma.
author: Jade L.

description: Great dim sum but a limited vegetarian selection.
author: Stacy L.

description:
I don't normally write reviews but I felt compelled to write one today.  My buddy and I just had dim sum at Yank Sing.  We are each foodies who eat all over the world.  I have had dim sum literally hundreds of times -- in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Los Angeles, New York, London, etc.

This was hands down the WORST dim sum experience we have ever had.  Dim Sum for two people -- TWO PEOPLE -- ran 160 dollars.  We never saw a menu.  They just kept coming at us with carts, and I assumed the meal would run what it runs in every other city in the world.  Fifty, maybe sixty dollars tops.

A small piece of fish -- 17.50.   A tiny morsel of Peking duck for each of us -- 24.00.   Plates that normally run 3 bucks in almost any dim sum place were four or five times the price here.  The worst part was that the food was ICE COLD and GREASY, and not particularly good.  And they literally threw the food at us.  We were in and out in 25 minutes.

Avoid Yank Sing at all costs.
author: David B.

description: Extremely overpriced for what it is. Poor quality dim-sum (compared to much cheaper places). Limited selection to start with and A LOT more limited if you go in the afternoon when they are out of half the items on the small menu. On top of all this, the service can be pushy.
author: Rascal M.

description: Pricey, but the quality is there. Convenient location for some dim sum. We've had these guys cater to us for parties at our office, and everything was delicious.
author: Jorge S.

description: Totally stuffed myself.  The place is pricey.  Still -  if you want to bring a guest for terrific dim sum and be certain of high quality, this is the place.  I had a yearning for shrimps and had several types - all fresh and tasty!
author: Diane M.

description:
Fine i'll give it 4 stars, but simply because the quality of the food. However,  it would have been 5 if the price was somewhat resonable. The atmosphere was good and clean. Not your typical chinatown restaurant. Their selection of dim sum could have been better with more frequent stops from their cart ladies. 
They are good, but not that good.
author: benjamin c.

description:
Maybe the sky was blind, uppss, star is blind and bland.
i dunno why all reviews gave them four and five star,you are being poored by them
F.I.R.S.T of all I felt being cheat and fooled,
S.E.C.O.N.D  it was overprice and I felt underfeed
T.H.I.R.D  I overlooked the waiter counted my bill when i approached him by the flash of his hand,he closed the bill with his crocodile smile
F.O.U.R.T.H their foods are bland,if you know what I mean,far from how does Chinese cuisine suppose to be,BUT NOT BETTER THAN ONE DOLLAR FOR THREE DIM SUM IN CHINATOWN
author: chris j.

description:
I guess we're not in Kansas, uh, i mean Chinatown anymore. Why, you ask? 

1. The wait staff here actually smile and cater to your needs. It's was almost kinda creepy...in a good way, i guess. Massage-parlor-ish.
2. Most of the patrons are suits on their break who like to try something "exotic" but don't really want to venture outside of their comfort zone.
3. $75 for 3 people? For dim sum?? Come on now.

Ok, so more about the food. The Yank Sing signature dish, the Shanghai Dumpling, was excellent. All the other seafood dishes, such as the Phoenix Shrimp and the Stuffed Crab Claw were great, as well. What was strange was the fact that all the dim sum staples, like the Pork Siu Mye and the Ha Gau were very disappointing. How can you screw those up? You can go to any dirty little dim sum place in Chinatown and pick those up for about $1.

Again, did I mention it was $75 for three people? I thought maybe I was missing something and I had to use the secret signal to get my happy ending. Well, that didn't happen. For $75, I might as well go to Ton Kiang on Geary. There you can get twice as much food at that quality for the same price.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Best Shanghai dumplings...EVER. Of course, they cost about $10/plate. This place is ridiculously expensive, especially considering how much cheap dim sum there is in SF. 

BUT, I do think it's expensive for a reason. I have not found place with better quality. They are lacking in variety at this location, however. The other location has way more dishes to choose from.

Make a reservation for lunch time. It is always packed.
author: Anna G.

description: Great place for dimsum but it is a bit pricey. Great food though.
author: Pavee S.

description:
i'm a really huge fan of this place.  granted, i have gone only twice and they were both work-related functions..  but i was fully satiated both times by their delicious dim sum.

as mentioned by everyone else that has reviewed this establishment, the shanghai soup dumplings were divine!   just the right amount of melt-in-your mouth broth in a thin tasty dumpling lining.

also sampled: snow pea shoot dumplings (i am pretty much 180 degrees from being vegetarian but these were delicious!), taro root dumpling (oh my goodness, if you have not tried this before, do it now!  filling of shrimp, pork, mushrooms and scallions surrounded by mashed taro and deep fried.. mm..), pork sui mye and bbq pork bun.  

don't forget to sample some dessert as well!  the egg custard tart and the sesame balls are not to be missed!

yes, it is rather pricey.. and yes, i probably could not afford it on my own.  .. but if you're looking for a fancy lunch date, an impress-your-significant-other dinner, or delicious meal that you can expense to your company, i would definitely come down to yank sing.
author: Lily B.

description: I'm visiting San Francisco, and couple friends had recommended that I try this place out since it is close to my hotel (Four Seasons).  I've been to various dim sum restaurants in the U.S (NYC, Washington, DC, Baltimore). and abroad (Hong Kong, Seoul, Singapore)--but this place is by far the best dim sum restaurant compared to anywhere else I've been to.  I'm not a huge fan of dim sum--but what sets this place apart is the quality.  Highly recommend this place.
author: John S.

description: somewhat classy dim-sum joint.  Great for lunch if working downtown.
author: wolf c.

description: This is a dim sum restaurant... I looked around and there were not a lot of Asians eating here.  Normally, not a good sign.  Indeed this is a very Americanized place.  The dim sum were good, but pricey, and nothing out of the ordinary.  The service was friendly and fast.  Watch the prices as they can add up fast.  I would look for a place in China Town the next time I am here.
author: Glenn O.

description: This is not ordinary dim sum. A lot of the dishes here are fancier dishes than the dim sum I'm used to but I can't complain, it's all good. My mom even agreed that their food was excellent and she's extremely picky about not only food but the value of food for what you pay. It does get pretty pricey so make sure your wallet is prepared.
author: Tiffany J.

description: (Actually reviewing the Yank Sing in the Rincon Center.) My favorite dim sum place.  Yeah it's pricey but it's so worth it.  The food is excellent!  The service is great!  The place is clean!   They even validate.
author: Chonlana J.

description: This is the one of the best Dim Sum restaurants east of Hong Kong.  If money is no object, it's woth the trip.
author: Bourdain, A.

description:
no.  this is not ok.  not ok for many reasons, the first of which is that i am used to dining at the spear st location - which is a huge, nice dining room and just a wonderful experience.

the stevenson location is like the unwanted stepsister...small, not that pleasant and they really didnt even seem to have the wide array of dim sum that they have elsewhere.  It also didn't help that my dining partner forgot about my shellfish allergey and we ended up with 4 shrimp dishes (cruel), the foil chicken (disappointing and i usually love them), egg rolls (greasy) and chicken stuffed mushroom tops (saving grace and keeping this review from being a 2 star).

definitely go to the spear st location.
author: Brooke M.

description:
Summary:  CRAZY OVERPRICED MEDIOCRE DIMSUM.  One redeeming dish:  xiao long bao.
OK, dish by dish review:
1) xiao long bao:  KICK ASS  bursting with soup.  Solid A!   Best I've had in the city!  Only complaint:  what's with the red vinegar?  where's the black vinegar?
2) siu mai:  SUCKED.  Not much flavor.  Texture lacking.  bleh
3) ha gow:  SUCKED.  Not much flavor.  small, not much shrimp
4) peking duck:  SUCKED BALLS.  WTF is up with the meat still being on the skin?  WHY IS THE SKIN CHEWY WHEN IT SHOULD BE CRISPY?!??!  TOTAL. RIP. OFF. Quick chinese food lesson:  Peking Duck is served with the super-crispy skin cut up and separated from the meat.  ALWAYS.
5) chive-shrimp dumpling:  SUCKED.  Not enough chives.  was a vaguely shrimpy paste. TEH SUCK
6) yam wrapped cod:  eh, not bad.
7) chinese broccoli:  SUCKED BALLS.  HOW CAN YOU SCREW THIS UP?!?!?!?  All you do is drop the frickin vegetable into boiling water, pull it out, and put oyster sauce on it.  This was COLD.  Not just room temp, but COLD, as if they did it intentionally, or they just mass produced it and put it in the fridge.  Chinese broccoli is more bitter when it's cold, ruining the flavor balance.  It also didn't have enough oyster sauce, and the oyster sauce HAD NO FLAVOR.  WTF?!?
8) pot stickers:  bleh, below average, but not too bad.
9) mango pudding:  SUCKED.  Not enough mango.  Tasted more like mango yogurt than pudding.
10) Oolong tea.  BAD, but not as bad as teabag tea.  Bleh, more black tea like.  This is coming from a taiwan tea snob, and we love our oolong in taiwan.
11) Jasmine tea.  BAD.  Why can't they just get some cheap stuff from Ten ren?  Dimsum is just snacks.  the whole experience is called YAM CHA = YIN CHA = DRINK TEA.  The measure of a good "dim sum" restaurant is the quality of the tea.

So there you have it.  AWESOME xiao long bao brings this up from 1 star (crappy food for high prices) to 2.
if you want REAL YAMCHA, go to KOI PALACE in Daly City, or if you don't want to deal with the crowd, go to FOOK YUEN in Millbrae.
author: Fong L.

description: Yuck! I hate when we order from this place for lunch. It's always full of grease and salt and I feel like puking an hour after eating it. Sometimes I do puke. Either way, it's not pleasant and I've got to learn that just because my company buys me lunch, I don't necessarily have to take them up on the offer - especially when it's shitty places like Yank Sing.
author: Suge K.

description: This is a solid place for Dim Sum but due to the location I thin the prices are higher than they should be since nothing is out of this world good. I wasn't disappointed but I feel it wasn't in line with traditional Dim Sum places I've been to in NYC (for example). The food was definitely good but the majority of the items really shouldn't cost $10.
author: Daniel A.

description: BBQ Pork Buns - SOOOOOOO good. The shrimp & scallion dumplings delightful! The curry won-tons, not regularly served, you got to ask for em, sooooooo yummy. Yeah, YUMMY!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Excellent dim sum that serves until 4pm.  We had pork dumplings, shrimp dumplings, shrimp egg rolls, shumai, egg custard buns, and the house specialty dumplings in vinegar sauce.  Everything was quite flavorful and the house dumplings were particularly good (I'm a sucker for vinegar sauces).  The shrimp egg rolls were also a nice surprise with shrimp, potato and spices inside instead of the usual lettuce or cabbage.  They also had a really crispy shell that was not too greasy.

The service was great and the waitresses/waiters were very friendly and helpful. 

The only down side to this place is that it was a little pricey for dim sum--it ended up being about $60 with tip for two.  But you definitely get great food for the price and the location makes it very convenient for days spent shopping at the mall or wandering around downtown.
author: Hillary B.

description: I've eaten at Yank Sing more times than my muffin-top cares to remember.  No doubt, Yank Sing is more expensive than most other SF dim sum.  But I don't think the quality can be beat.  I've only been here during the weekends so I don't know if it's any different during the week. What I do know is that on a weekend morning at Yank Sing, the service is great, the dim sum is tasty, and my belly is full.
author: Aimee G.

description: my meat eater friend was in heaven. I was looking around to make sure I didn't miss the veggie options when we went for dim sum. the veggie options are far less than non-veggie options, but that said, there are multiple veggie options which is more than you can say at some dim sum places. next time, I may get an entree, but everything was so well done that I was able to eat that I trust their making of food and will be back for another go. my friend says the coconut tempura shrimp were the best and next time, he just wants to get 5 small plates of them. (if you're into that sort of thing)
author: Liz S.

description:
4 stars on customer service.  all the wait staff was extemely attentive.  make sure to get a reservation for lunch, it gets crowded around 12:30pm.  they do also have open tables on a first come first serve basis on the outside patio.  it wasn't too cold and the heat lamps def helped.  

3.5 stars on the food.  the food was very clean tasting and very pretty.  yes, i said pretty.  yang sing does a really good job with consistency of shape and size of dim sum, making it look almost perfect.  it's also not very greasy and heavy like other traditional dim sums places.  unfortunately, when you cut out the fat you lose a bit of flavor in the food as well.  yang sing isn't the most flavorful dim sum i've had in my lifetime, but very decent.  all the food was hot though, which is key!
author: Wendy S.

description: I guess it was Chicken w/ Black pepper sauce.  Anyhow, it was ok.  Pretty peppery but definitely not what I expected.  Wasn't terrible either.  3 stars still.
author: Casey F.

description: No no no no. Dim Sum should not be a million dollars. Little pieces of fried food, or stuffed little something or others, pushy little Asian waitresses, this is not anything different from your average China Town dim sum place. Just because this place is in Soma, has white table clothes, does not mean they should charge like they do. Dim Sum should be $5 max.
author: Rada I.

description: When I become queen, every restaurant will serve me a la the brilliance of dim sum. Steamy balls (steamy balls he he he) of breaded goodness delivered with the frequency akin to striped shirts in the Marina. As my first experience in this genre of cuisine, it was divine. I heart dim sum.
author: Julia M.

description: Okay - their to go service - tasty and cheap.  Their inside seated dim-sum service... *deep breath*  I went with a friend, and we ordered 6 orders of dim sum, a coke and some tea... and 80 effin dollars later, we walked  out completely confused as to where the happy ending or car wash came in for having to pay so effin much for tiny portions of appetizers.  The service was decent enough, and the food was above mediocre (by not much), but 80 dollars?!  Never again
author: Lea R.

description:
Let me say that this place is in my work building so it is total go-to for me, both for take out from YankSing2Go at least once a week, and for the regular restaurant for many, many a business lunch.  They are obviously totally different experiences so I'll note both separately.
Dim Sum Restaurant:  Really, really good dim sum and by that I mean tons of volume so lots of fresh food, but if you like dim sum you know you are getting salt, grease, carbs - deliciously so, but it is what it is.  But the food and variety is outstanding.  I partciularly like the duck , the chicken lettuce cups and the Chilean sea bass, but of course like all the dumplings as well, especially the shitake mushroom steamed ones. Yum! These onion rings they have are just fab as well. The service is efficient, sometimes a bit alarmingly so, as they really try and move you through their fast. But for a business lunch that is generally appreciated.  Worth a lunch if you are in the financial district/SOMA area and a great place for a big group lunch.  Big lines without a reservation so plan ahead - and bring your wallet as it is NOT cheap - I never get out of here for less than $40-50 a head.
Yank Sing2Go: I must go here at least once a week.  They have 6 types of combos that include dim sum choices and either a chicken salad, chow mein or fried rice, plus a couple of a la carte items and soup.  Very simple and quick and good -- again you know what you are getting if you are looking for simple dim sum, so don't exactly expect the healthy option. But the food is fresh and quickly prepared and very, very reasonably priced.  The combos are $5-7 each and the additional items are $1-2 each. Well worth a stop in if you want an option different than sandwiches for lunch.  They have an outdoor heated seating area for the take out too, and obviously the way more affordable version of the dim sim sit down restaurant but don't expect the fancy stuff - dumplings, noodles and soup and that is it.  But  a great financial district lunch option for sure.
author: Kirsten M.

description: I was there today, and loved it.  The Cod in the ginger/Mirin sauce was to die for.  As usual, the dumplings were fantastic.  The location is off the beaten track, and a little more pricey than China town, but I have never been disappointed, and its quick.  Its a wonderful fast delicious lunch!
author: Mary H.

description: Not typical of your average dim sum experience.  Nice clean restaurant with great service!  The carts actually come to you!  They don't run out of har gows!  More of a selection of dim sum than I'm used to!  Why only 3 stars?  Well, the price!  I've never paid $60 for the two of us for dim sum.  Our average bill is $25 at the most.  But you get for you pay for!  Need I remind you....clean restaurant, great selection & service ???
author: Minna T.

description: It appears that they are open every frickin' day. The thing that sucks is that they close at 3pm... what the heez?! We unknowingly came here 15 minutes before they closed... oops. after feeling like complete jerks they came out with a cart full of food.... and it was gooood. Some of the yummiest dim sum i've ever had. The staff was really friendly as well... smiles and all. The prices definitely are pretty steep, but the quality of the food is pretty damn good. I want to come back here again., but it'll have to be on a payday :)
author: Richard T.

description:
a little more convenient than the spear street location when i just want some quality dim sum to go.  situated at the intersection of two alleys, but i don't get that dirty vibe at all.

i used to order the yank sing express for convenience, but now i know ordering from the dim sum menu is the way to go (so as to avoid the kinda bland and oily chow mein).
author: spiff e.

description: Yank Sing is a little bit pricer than your typical Chinese dim sum place, but it is clean, and the service is better than most Chinese restaurants. What they call "dim sum" is basically American's idea of small Chinese dishes, not the authentic Cantonese dim sum for tea. Nonetheless, most dishes we have had there were pretty good. Their steamed dumplings (xiao long bow), a traditional Shanghainese dish, is much better than most restaurants in the U.S., whether it is in New York, Los Angles or San Francisco. I would go there just for their XLB whenever I feel home-sick.
author: S M.

description: i think yelp needs 3.5 star rating :)..i'd give this place a 3.5 based on the food quality and price. 20$ barely makes my tummy full (like i have any tummy ;))..over all better than avg food , good ambience, avg to good service, lots of selection. I do admit that I go there quiet often..like better than koi palace
author: Neelesh V.

description: I love clean and I love nice but I'm generally not too in love with dim sum... I know, what kind of Asian person am I, right?  Well this place is actually kinda yuppie so I sort of fit right in, and I must admit, I did enjoy the food and surroundings.  I won't complain becuase I was on a lunch date and I didnt' pick the place but did get a glance at the bill...close to $80 for two people??? You do know this IS San Francisco and Chinatown IS about 10 minutes away, right?
author: laura q.

description: High-end dim sum place where you know you'll get good service and a clean bathroom.  Good place for dim sum virgins and business lunches.  The food is pretty good, but they didn't have some very authentic dishes at this location.  Fortunately they do make very delicious chicken feet, my all-time favorite dim sum item, and I finished two baskets all by myself.  ;)  It's pricey, but you pay for the ambiance.  Parking could be a problem.
author: Shoyi C.

description: Best dumplings all around!!!! Very fresh!!!! My bf loved them as well but wanted to see more selection.  ( such as bbq pork, peking duck)  We were there when they opened so they didn't have those selections until later on.  Aslo they had these snap peas that were made to perfection. Yes, it's probably pricier than other places, but it is a very clean enviornment and you can taste the freshness, best chinese food I've ever had!
author: Elizabeth G.

description: A downgrade; I was wanting a dim sum treat to go.  I saw exactly what I wanted but the dessert was a custard.  As I was trying to barely get the request was out of mouth I was promptly told "no substitutions."  We'll that is all I need to hear and left.  There was a rudeness to my request and I think a simple replacement for an item that was actually cheaper is a two way street.  A business who's purpose is to make customers happy is only self serving when simple requests cannot be honored then I will go the next purveyor to make me happy.  I am happy to spend my dollar when service, food and experience are superb.  If they are not interested in my dollar some else will be.  A disappointment.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Probably the best dim sum I have ever had and its unfortunate they are so damn expensive that I can't enjoy it more often.  $70 for two is not unusual at all, but I find I have had dishes here that I have never seen or heard of at other dim sum places....and the stuff is really tasty.  Go early or be prepared to wait...sometimes I'll get take out if I REALLY must have some of their dim summery goodness.
author: Don O.

description: Fabulous food! Beware of the cart onslaught, though. They purposefully attack you all at once so you're confused and will order whatever's in your face. Don't go if you're super, super starving b/c you will order too much. Service quick though and this is the nicer Yank Sing. Great place for traditional SF dim sum!
author: Samira S.

description: I love this place.  After a lame boyfriend took me to one of the nastiest dim sum places in this fine city, depression set in.  Really, San Francisco and not a decent dim sum place.  Yank Sing, you reaffirmed my faith in SF dim sum.  Bless you.
author: Tamir G.

description: The food is always good. No question. The seafood dumplings, lettuce wraps and peking duck are my absolute favorites. They seat you fast, food is always being rolled by, tea is promptly poured. For a business lunch you can get in and out pretty quick cause they don't dawdle with the check. The only thing that stopped me from giving them five stars is how pushy some of them can be with trying to get you to take a dim sum item you don't want. "oh best yank sing dish," "very very tasty." Man, I said "no thank you" like three times!!!!
author: Jeanie G.

description:
3.5 stars to be honest. 

Went here for lunch, as i had heard it was the best dim sum in the city. Very upscale looking place, and i got there right when they opened at 11 on a Thursday morning.

I ordered one of their specialty dishes, the shanghai dumplings, some shrimp har gau, snowpea shoot dumpling, and pork sui mye.

All of the dishes were pretty good, better than most other dim sum places i have ever tried. The seafood and pork seemed more abundant and flavorful, and the vegetables, especially the snowpea dish, tasted very fresh. 

My favorite dish was the shanghai dumplings. The lady showed me how i was supposed to eat it, with pouring the vinegar on top and all. And boy was it great. As soon as you put it into your mouth, the dumpling breaks open and the broth mixes with the vinegar to create a really tasty first impression. The pork was good as well, and the dumpling part was very well done, not too thick and chewy. Just right.

I would probably come here again, as the food was pretty good. The only downside to this place is it is pretty expensive. I spent $40 for my lunch, and was charged $2.40 for each tiny glass of diet coke i had. The food is better than most places, but so is the price, so it kind of evens things out.
author: Andy C.

description: Best Dim Sum I've ever had, yes it's expensive but was well worth the price.  It really impressed my out-of-town guests too.  A little busy during the 12-1 hour, it's best to go early or wait until after 1 for better service.
author: George K.

description: Good service, good food, high prices, not a lot of variety.  Catered more to American business people but they make great dumplings here and the place is pretty clean.  I would give it five stars if the prices weren't so high and if they had more of the traditional dim sum dishes like tripe/stomach etc..  Mostly seafood dumplings on the carts.
author: Luke T.

description: went here yesterday after arriving for the last dodger-giant series of the season.  as soon as we got seated, a bunch of carts descended upon us with dim sum galore.  within seconds, our table was full of yummy dumpling treats.  and the carts kept coming with servers convincing us to eat more.  pure gluttony.  definitely a spot to go to satisfy your cravings....
author: Randy D.

description: My mom and I came here for lunch the other day since we were both in the mood for dim sum.  We split the shanghai dumplings (XLB), har gow, and 2 other things that going to dim sum for my entire life has not taught me the names of.  It was all very delicious and fresh.  Everything was warm and the service was friendly.  My one complaint about this place is that, at least when I went, there was not a lot of variety nor was the food being circulated frequently.  We waited a good bit after sitting down before anything even came to us.  Maybe it was just the time we went (1:00 pm) but that seems unlikely.
author: Caroline B.

description: Quality, if expensive, dim sum without the normal dim sum attitude.  When I go to dim sum in chinatown (unless I go with a Chinese-speaking friend) I have a hard time, to say the least, getting simple things like tea and water.  In contrast, there's actually a semblence of service at this place.  Does get a bit crazy on weekends, so expect to wait a little bit for a table.  The parking lot has some of the most inassessible parking spots I've ever seen, but I guess I shouldn't be complaining - this is downtown SF afterall.
author: Jason S.

description: Best Siao Long Bao........ Although a lot of the menu is rather westernized, it is still very delicious.  Pricy, but a fun experience none the less.  And there is nothing like nice pot of tea and Tsing-Tao at 11 am on a Sunday.  I will be back.
author: Brian D.

description: Yank Sing dine-in is better than take-out. Avoid chicken items there, always a disaster for me. May be, my timing is bad, or my menu selection. I would say an overall OK,
author: Ritesh G.

description: Spring rolls are immaculate here. Hands down the best in the City. Almost 5 stars based on them alone. If you abstain from pork, in my case just because I think it's a nasty animal, nothing more, this place isn't precisely ideal. And it's not cheap. Hence the 4 stars. But if you have the $ and a dim sum craving you simply cannot do better.
author: Steve P.

description:
WOW!  we were a family of 4 and our dinner came to $133!  The worst part was spending all that money and then I still had to stop at McDonalds for a teenage boy afterwards because I couldn't afford for him to keep eating!

They conveniently put the menu with the prices next to the 8 year old!  Hello, is he the one paying?  They also do not tell you the tiny cups of soda cost $3/each and no free refills!  Again, thanks for asking the kids directly if they want refills without my ok.

The food was only ok.  Nothing to write home about for sure.  There were only 2 items that everyone really liked and we ordered a 2nd plate.  After getting the menu from the little one, I had to let the kids know which plates were ok to order.   This restaurant will be off my list as I can not afford to take the family there to eat.
author: Julia S.

description: I thought about taking off a star for being too pricey, but then I guess they deserve to distinguish themselves for having the best, most delicate dim sums in town. Only been here once last year, and I don't remember which specific dishes we got, but they were all superb. I think the daily specials were even unique and inviting. If you ever want to impress your date, parents or a business partner with dim sums you would bring them here. No, you must bring them here.
author: Inbae L.

description: This high-trafficked dim sum joint gets an unprecedented award for the Best Dim Sum Service EVER (stateside and in Asia).  Dim sum connoisseurs know that cart pushers are notorious for three things 1) minimal proficiency in English, 2) lack of patience when questioned about a dish and 3) high velocity at which they push the carts.  None of this happens at Yank Sing.  Furthermore, the staff does everything with a smile and is impeccably cordial.  The food is quite good.  All your dim sum staples will not disappoint.  However, the menu is missing the more authentic fare.  The Anglo-ized selection plus the "too-good-to-be-true" service nearly disqualifies this place as true dim sum!
author: Sindy Lin M.

description: I am far from a dim sum expert so take my review for what it's worth. I felt this was the best dim sum I've ever had. I only have two, somewhat minor complaints: 1) the chicken and mushroom bun was more bun than was called for; and 2) ordering a la carte seems to really mess up their procedures. A fellow diner ordered a salad and we were nearly done eating by the time it came. Still, I'd have to say I'd recommend this place if someone asked me where to go for dim sum. Assuming, of course, that they have the ducats.
author: Joe H.

description: The dim sum here is probably one of the best in the city. Every piece is almost like artwork. Very fresh, delectable, and superb...
author: Sue L.

description: Bring your stun gun to ensure you can halt the flow of dishes when you've had enough.  I like this place because of the relentless service and the quality of the individual items, but more importantly, the selection.  I find a lot of other dim sum places go heavy on the gelatinous, slippery dishes and there is not enough variety of other morsels.
author: Kevin S.

description: The food, service, and atmosphere are all great. Just be careful, of what you order. My co-worker and I racked up a $90.00 bill for a weekday lunch...
author: Brian L.

description:
damn good dim sum. damn good the entire staff speaks english good, mmm i mean well. damn good they serve cocktails (as hit and miss as they may be) damn cool ass locale, ricon building is cool. damn expensive

last trip there, party of two, 250 dollars. go steal moms credit card and get some nice dim sum.

of course theres better, well maybe "betters" not the word, but rather "justifiably expensive".... ehh no mmm but yeah whatever,  but i  no speaky de chinese.  wish i did. would make my love affair with chinese food easier..... maybe i should get another cantonese gf? is that considered shallow?
author: Euge L.

description: This location's a lot smaller than the Spear St. one, but is right by my old office building. The food's the same and the prices are the same, so it gets the same rating.
author: Josh O.

description: Super expensive Dim Sum, but really good quality food.  One of the first Dim Sum restaurants I used to go to as a kid when my grandfather used to come and visit from Texas.  Still the same quality, but now there are locations popping up all over the city.  I try not to go here too often because it burns a huge hole in your pocket, but if you're down for some good grubbin' Dim Sum, this is definitely better quality than the hole in the walls in Chinatown.
author: Jin B.

description: I love DIM SUM!  Its like all the ways that Bubba Gump had no idea how to cook shrimp.  Those sweet little ladies with their pimpin' out the bomb food mentality.  I swear my meal was like $5 a minute * 39 minutes = WAAAY too much for lunch.  Thank goodness it was payday cuz $hitballs, I feel like I got bent over and they a shoved a freakin' egg roll up there and sent me packing.  Oh... I'll be back... on payday....bitches!
author: Chard M.

description: Solid lunch selections and fast service.  A little off the beaten path, but still popular.  The "express" lunch gives a little bit each of some of the more common options, so you get a decent amount of variety.
author: Andy B.

description: A bit overpriced, but always an incredibly delicious experience. Definitely recommend it to anyone who wants to have some grade-A dim sum, but who isn't on a tight budget.
author: Tadeek P.

description: I love Yank Sing for dim sum. Yes, it's no cheap date but it is so satisfying and the shanghai dumplings are beyond words. We brought my mom here for her first dim sum and she was overwhelmed. This is not the place for a slow eater, sorry mom! But we were happy and filled with delicious morsels of goodness. And sesame buns.
author: Lisa L.

description: Totally pedestrian and super expensive. The servers are extremely aggresive. They try to just plop items on your table and hope that you'll keep them. So not worth it.
author: Carla B.

description: I came here for dim sum for lunch.  I spent $80 on just myself and I was STILL hungry.  I don't know how my people can afford this lifestyle.  yeah, that's right. I said it: my people.
author: Margaux S.

description: So we are in San Francisco for a Sunday Dim Sum and choose Yank Sing beause of their reputation. The food was mostly ordinary and EXPENSIVE!!!!! How can Dim Sum lunch for 5 adults and a 6 year old be $170 (no drinks) and we walk away hungry. We have many favorite Dim Sum places in San Diego that are better and a third of the price. Not worth it!!! I put this place in the category of "Tourist Ripoff".
author: Peter W.

description:
I needed my dim sum fix since I have not been here for a few months. Mind you it was raining last week but I decided to brave the rain and walk almost two blocks. I must really want it!

I went for the Seafood Supreme, Spring Roll, Seafood Basil dumplings, Scallop /Mushroom Dumplings. I didn't have breakfast so I could eat and yes it lasted all day and ready to roll on my way home.

The dumplings are huge but it was a little bland. It did not speak to me like some of the dim sum I tasted before. I have been in both places - seat down, to go and brunch but for some reason, it was not as good as if I was eating inside. 

I've always ordered the Chinese Chicken Salad and this one I love because the sauce is mixed with wasabi. A little hot.

I will see next time how I feel before I order my food. Til next time!
author: Lileth M.

description: I love dim sum.  It is probably one of my favorite styles of food.  I don't even need to go beyond the shrimp dumplings to get my fix.  When I am in Hong Kong, my no-fail answer for "What do you want for lunch?" is dim sum.  So, I wanted to love Yank Sing.  I really did.  But, it was just OK, and really expensive.  The atmosphere was nice, i.e. the tablecloths were clean and it was well-lit.   The unintelligible and kind of cranky servers came around constantly, just like they do in Hong Kong.  But the variety was pretty limited and only one thing really stood out for me which was the steamed sea bass.  Which when you think about it is not very dim sum-y, so I don't know if I'd return just to have that.  I don't really understand the hype with this particular restaurant - maybe there were secret things I was supposed to know to order?  And why was the only vegetable offered pea pods?
author: Liz S.

description: I can't say much that hasn't already been said.  Best dim sum I've ever had.
author: Will H.

description: If I hadn't lived in Hong Kong for a while I would rate it higher, but Yank Sing is really dim sum for gwailos and is overpriced for what they offer.  Still, it's an acceptable choice for lunch downtown.
author: Beau G.

description: Quite different from the one in the Rincon Center.  The atmosthere is not as ostentatious and it is quite quaint and reserved.  I think I enjoyed my dim sum better at this location since I didn't feel as rushed.  My family and I ate the crap out of the darn green beans... we ordered a plate each.  The signature dumplings weren't as good as I remembered from my last visit but over all their food and service is impeccable for a Chinese eatery.   Hitting up Yank Sing is a must if you are visiting the city.
author: Shiho F.

description: I'm so glad I got to try this place during a recent visit to SF.  The food overall was tasty and the service was better than most dim sum places.  My favorite dishes are the sea bass, mushroom dumpling, crab claw, spicy tofu wrapped in seaweed and the mango pudding.  This place definitely caters to the business crowd as everything is more expensive but I will say that it is with good reason.
author: Diana D.

description: If you'd like a cotemporary dim sum, believe me, go to Yank Sing. A little bit expensive, but you will thank me later.
author: Kenn E.

description: I love this place. Been here 3 times only and unfortunately so far from San Jose. The dim sum are delicious. Perfectly made, served hot and fresh  and they offer vegetarian options. To some hard core dim sum-ers, this may not be an issue. But for me it is. I'm a texture guy and when I bite into dim sum that has foreign parts (like cartilage or bone) I'm immediately turned off. This place give you "pure" meat parts. That didn't sound right, but I think you get the idea. I've been to hundreds of dim sum places and it never fails that I end up eating something I didn't order. I'm also really allergic to shellfish (I know, sucks). So when I order a pork dumpling, I expect to only eat pork. Not always the case when entering a dim sum place. At Yank SIng I've never walked out feeling like I ate something I shouldn't have. The price is up there, but it's so worth it.
author: Raymond G.

description:
quite pricey for dim sum, and the only reason we chose this place was because of the rave reviews our hotel gave the restaurant. like previous yelpers mentioned, the tea was $5. WHAT?! tea should be free. it was good tea, but nonetheless, TEA SHOULD BE FREE. 

the dim sum was decent at best and the restaurant had a wide variety of tasty treats. the food tasted really fresh and each cart was "reloaded" with food every 15 min. 

unfortunately, i wouldnt return to this restaurant anytime soon. there's a much better place in chinatown at a fraction of the price. $134 for dim sum?!?....pssshhh, get out of here!
author: marlene m.

description:
yank sing, how i miss you so!  i know that the bbq pork buns are a staple in all dim sum cuisine, but for some reason yours are far superior to the rest.  the quality of the food is much higher than any other dim sum joint that i have been to, and i try to make a visit every time that i go to the bay area.  its an excellent place to go for brunch before the grueling trip south on the 5.

i hope to see you very soon!
author: Courtney L.

description: MY first San Francisco dim sum experience and I tell you this was a very delectable surprise.  Good compay, good service and great food.  We came here on a Sunday morning, was seated promptly and carts of small dishes of steamed dumplings, fried delicacies and specialty platters were rushing through the isles.  So many choices and the aroma was mouth watering.  The signature dumplings were juicy and melted in your mouth.  The sauces were tastey and they even carry their own signature Yank Sing hot sauce which is quite good.  I prefer this place over Ocean River over by Emeryville, although that place has a great view.  Very kid friendly and parking below the building.  After your meal take a stroll by the pier and relax and enjoy the day!  Excellent place and very satisfying.  This place is worth several visits!
author: Jenn C.

description: Quite unimpressive. Yes, clean establishment and traditional place to take visitors and clients (Mostly because they've read their guide books featuring Yank Sing and are insistent).  For the money one is better off at City View or one of the other hidden gems in China Town or the Inner Rich'.
author: Johnny C.

description: My friend introduced me to this place today. We came here for a late lunch. I had the hot and spicy soup. It was actually spicy and hot (which I love!)  I tried a couple of other things but the soup was off the hook! I like this place...its a good change...
author: Mel P.
