description: One of the best restaurants I've ever been to - perfect for a business lunch! The food is yummy and the choices are excellent.  Fresh, tasty and constantly in your face - the dim sum service is certainly worth five stars.  My only complaint is that the servers are a little TOO pushy: we were offered sea bass about five times.  Great location, great atmosphere - just GO!
author: Josh T.

description: This has to be my next favorite place.  I went to the 2 Go section for lunch, and for $7 I got some of the best Chinese food I've had in the states =)  Chow Mein was good, not too greasy, not too heavy.  The pork bun was large and very tasty.  Cheap and really really delicious.  I'm going again for lunch this week!
author: Art C.

description:
pretty expensive for dim sum, but i was craving siu mai like nothin else. ooh, but the service is incredible, which is a plus seeing that service is so-so when it comes to dim sum restaurants in general.

wasn't a big fan of the vegetables served here, but those soup dumplings  are awesome. it's like, broth inside a dumpling. so when you bite into it a burst of warm goodness explodes in your mouth.  i want to learn how they make them.
author: C F.

description: I appreciated the laid-back, classy surroundings and the abundance of vegetarian options. Just tell them you want some veggie dim-sum and they'll radio back to HQ on their headset. The problem is that a lot of the stuff here is SUPER FREAKING EXPENSIVE and even though the servers update a little card on your table with marks indicating prices, what they write is not in English. I gorged myself here with two coworkers and then --dude--  the bill for 3 people came to like $180. (!) Then we couldn't figure out who owed what because the bill was incomprehensible. That said, in the end, the food was really good. There's probably some hidden away dim-sum places out in West San Francisco that are better, but this place is decent for the Financial District if you have money to burn.
author: Nick A.

description: Very good "Americanized" dim sum in the SF area.  Took some nervous nelly friends that were new to dim sum to try and ease them in slowly.  It didn't take long until they were in love.  Great steamed buns, vegetarian dumplings and onion rolls.  Unfortunately my friends weren't too in to some of the more exotic dishes, so we didn't get a lot of things I wanted to try.  But, next time I am in San Fran I will be back for more.
author: Tiffany T.

description: Yank Sing is always my default place of lunch if I can't decide what I want to eat and when I'm in a rush. Never been here for a sit down meal so I can't tell you what the service is like but the to go service is awesome. You go in and order one of their combination meals and you're out in about 5 minutes flat. Never had a disappointing meal here and you can always count on the food being yummy and extremely fulfilling. I usually order my Yank Sing Express which consists of a spring roll, 1 potsticker, 1 steamed pork bun, and a large heaping of bbq pork chow mein all for a whopping $6.35 plus tax. Now how awesome is the price considering the norm of lunch prices in the FiDi.  In any event, come here if you want great food, quick service, and full factor.
author: Karen R.

description: Incredibly good dim sum but doesn't rate much higher because of the price, pretty outrageous.  If you're on an expense account it can work otherwise beware!  They have really good egg rolls and chow fun.  A delicious treat is the mango pudding, would love to get my hands on that recipe.  I work close by and always fall victim to the take out part of the restaurant for some quick food but its so pricey.  Also I do not care for their chow mein it always tastes like clay or something.  The 'express' is the best for a dim sum fix.  As for the restaurant, if you want a seat go early during the lunch hour because they are packed by 11:45.
author: La C.

description: I'm an SF native so I'd never been to Yank Sing before and I wanted to try it.  As an SF ABC native, I should probably hate it and chide it for its inauthenticity, but the dim sum was honestly pretty good.  Overall, it was good but not amazingingly superior.  The one exception was the shanghainese dumplings which we all agreed was the absolutely best thing we ate that afternoon.  The xiao long bao had the right flavor and just the right amount of juice.  So, food-wise, the rest of the dishes were okay but subpar for the price you are paying.  Reservations (on weekends at least) are recommended.  We sat down right before noon, and at about 12:15pm, crowds starting forming.
author: Melinda C.

description:
Only been to the express side for quick lunches. The Dim Sum is good if I'm in the mood for it. Express lunch menu SUCKS and you can't substitute. They should have a more varied menu where you can choose the sides, etc. 

Not a go-out-of-your-way place.
author: MT U.

description: I crave Yank Sing like no other.  Their Shanghai dumplings, in my opinion, are INCREDIBLE.  Soft, hot, meaty, brothy amazingness!  It is a tad on the expensive side, so I have to control myself.  I would probably eat at Yank Sing every week if I could afford it.  Great dim sum!!
author: Lauren H.

description: First time trying deem sum so the hubby and I decided to go balls to the wall! Right when we sat down, a cart was right there and we were picking everything that looked good. This included spring rolls, soup dumplings (their special for the day), chicken and mushroom dumpling, Steamed pork buns, pot stickers, shrimp dumpling, Phoenix tailed shrimp, and some kind of scallop dumpling. Yes, yes alot for two people but we ate every bite of it along with jasmin tea, and then topped it off with some mango pudding. OMG, everything was delicious! My favorite though was the soup dumpling. They ended up selling out of them so I am glad I at least got to try it! The service was very good and the restaurant along with downstairs bathrooms were very clean. Yes, the food was a bit overpriced but I felt it was worth it since everything tasted great and we still go out of there being completely stuffed for less than 80.00. Will I return? For sure! If you ever travel to SF, you must try Yank Sing!
author: Jennifer G.

description: For Dim Sum, it's not worth it. My girl friend and I ate 4 dishes: 1 Shanghai Dumpling, Spareribs, Chicken Feet, and a small sea bass = All totalling $51.95! Quality-NOT GREAT.  Way overrated...and overpriced!
author: Carmen L.

description: This is my favorite dim sum restaurant in the city.  Typical sit and point as the big carts come by.  The shanghai dumings are fantastic.  The service is very good.  The price is a bit on the high side, but worth it.  They offer food to-go, but I have never gone that route.
author: Ryan W.

description: its a typically overrated restaurant. their food was not bad but can be found anywhere. i recommend people should avoid spending their money. also their impoliteness makes me and my company leave this place at constant. they were making fun of people from other culture eating Chinese cuisine and perceived it as almost hate crime in the public place. please just visit any other valuable restaurants around this area. opportunity cost of visiting this restaurant is too huge for tourists to miss.
author: Hongseok L.

description: Nothing at Yank Sing is best of dim sum show but it is all astonishingly consistent. It probably has the most polished dining room and service for SF dim sum. Take your mother and have some peking duck.
author: patrick g.

description: Good dim sum, but I must dock a star for the fact that they serve Pepsi instead of Coke.
author: Grace W.

description:
if you're paying $30+ PER PERSON for dim sum, those cha siu baos better be coming out on gold platters and have gold flakes IN the damn filling.

i've only eaten dim sum here once, and while it was good, it was $25 per person and i was not even close to full.  

not. worth. it.
author: Jolene T.

description: Diners beware! Always look at your bill before you pay. Myself and two friends went to Yank Sing for dim sum lunch and where very surprised to see a total of $145! We looked surprised at each other and though there must be something wrong with the bill. We looked a little closer and noticed that they had added an extra 0 to the tax. The host was surprised and said she had calculated it 3 times. So did she calculate it 3 times and got it wrong each time and was not happy until she would be able to reasonably cheat us? I'm sure there are many businesses that take their employees for lunch and just charge it as a business expense without looking at the details.
author: Sky C.

description: This place has really great dim sum, and the service has always been excellent. However, it's really pricey. I still give in when asked to meet here for lunch. It's just that good.
author: k. w.

description:
when i lived in sf and worked less than a block away, i would try to come here all the time.  it was difficult trying to get friends or co-workers to join me that often, because not only is dim sum in general totally carby and many of friends were carb-conscience, it's freaking expensive for dim sum.  we usually couldn't get out of there without dropping $25-40/pp, depending on the number of people and how much we ordered.

BUT i love the dim sum here, and would come back again and again, if only for their xiao long bao (shanghai dumplings).  soooooooooooooooooooo good, i can't even begin to describe it.  i could eat 3 orders of them (but at $12 an order for 6 dumplings, i usually stopped myself at 2, hahaha).  the rest of their dim sum is good, but i wouldn't go back just for them.  the shanghai dumplings are a MUST here.
author: Reina M.

description: This is the most expensive dimsum place that I've ever eaten at. I don't think that the food is that great. There are a lot more choices but I think that its just average. Its over-rated.
author: Elly G.

description: Been eating here for 18 years. Finest dim sum I have ever had, anywhere. And I go to China 4 times a year. I miss some of my friends that used to work there, but never fail to go when I am in SF.
author: James R.

description: We came here to eat dim sum a couple of times and even though the food is good, the price and portion of the food is not really worth it. For four people we paid around $135 and we had to go to Burger King after since we weren't full yet... It would be ok if it was filling.. but spending $135 and not be full is ridiculous!
author: Cynthia C.

description: Everyone loves Yank Sing. Yank Sing is great. I only have a few things to impart: I worked in the same building on Stevenson, and for that location at least the dim sum is driven in, not made on site. That's not agood thing for dim sum. Another comment: it's very expensive, and that's kind of, well, lame in regards to dim sum. But it's good, and you can get various types of tea, and they are great at translating the dishes for you (bilingual servers! So decadent.) and my mother loves it. So hey, long live Yank Sing.
author: Anna B.

description: Went here with my friends. At first we were hoping to find a dimsum place in Chinatown for the full experience, but the concierge at my friend's hotel recommended this place and since it got good reviews on yelp, we decided to check it out and we were very glad we did! The dimsum is served by waitresses pushing the carts around from table to table. I have no idea what anything is called, but couple of my friends that are more dimsum-savvy than me picked out our selection of plates. I liked everything we had and the portions were just right for a party of 4 allowing us to try many different plates. My favorites were what looked like shrimp dumplings, scallion pancakes, and another shrimp dish (helpful, I know). They were accommodating when the things we wanted were not on the cart, and made sure to make a special return trip to our table with the turnip cakes and egg custard tarts that my friends really wanted. Enjoyed the big pot of jasmine tea on our table. I'll definitely go back next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Leina A.

description: Good service, good food ~ 'upscale' dim sum, not as greasy, but you definitely pay for the quality + location...prepare to dole out the dough if you go there hungry.
author: Cathy K.

description: I went here during WWDC in '07.  I think we are going again this year.  I think this place is great!
author: MJ W.

description:
My very good friends from LA introduced me to this restaurant.  I was really surprised that Yank Sing was for me the best Dim Sum in San Francisco.  True that it's expensive, crowded, and noisy,  but completely worth all of those things and more.  I go on special occasions and to see if my Asian friends agree with me about this place, and without fail everyone loves it.

The food is fresh and not overly greasy.  The carts have a great variety of food and many items you don't find at other dim sum restaurants. If you want to order something different from the cart offerings, you can ask any of the cart attendants and they order what you want by walky-talky and the order comes quick. 

I would give recommendations here for things to order, but everything I had here including the tea was just great, so just try your favorite things and some new things you've never tried before - either way you won't be disappointed.

Enjoy :)
author: Ziva A.

description: This is dim sum like I knew it as a child tasty, greasy and satisfying.  If you like authentic Cantonese dim sum with good service don't miss Yank Sing.
author: Amber L.

description: If I don't think about that surprise of a bill, Yank Sing was a great dim sum lunch outting.  The dishes are beautifully presented and are more creative than most dim sum places.  The food is delicious and high quality...some of the most memorable dishes were the peking duck, the shanghai dumplings, and the egg custards.
author: Debbie Y.

description: I think the dim sum here is pretty good.  Comparable quality to places in LA and Canada.  They offer a pretty wide variety of items.  Stay away from the peking duck unless you have an expense account.  Just to add some perspective, for two people to be full, you're expecting to pay $80.  The shanghai dumplings are yummy...the lady told me that they use Japanese pork for those.  The sweet items are alright only.  The mango pudding is a little disappointing actually.  And so are the egg tarts.
author: Winnie L.

description: Yes, it's great food, but do you have to get a home equity loan for Dim Sum?!?!?
author: Rene D.

description: Continued domination of upscale Dim Sum category.  Sat outside today and not sure I would recommend it.  Despite heat lamps, it was still cold; pigeons dive-bombing now and then, table slanting noticeably and we got the feeling the folks inside were getting better service with fresher or at least warmer dishes.
author: Xander S.

description: It's literally right next door to where I work... so it is very convenient.  I have dined inside as well as gotten the take out.  Both are exceptional.  Great Dim Sum for inside dinning... the take out is a bit on the oily side but I still enjoy it.  I usually go for the specials as to get a bit of variety when I am there.  It is also not too expensive.  Well the take out isn't.  When you sit down and eat, you can get a bit carried away because there is so much to choose from... you kind of just pick and grab at everything.  In the end, well worth it.
author: Kara G.

description: This is a reliable standard in San Francisco.  You always know you will have good food.
author: Amme P.

description:
this review is for the 2 Go portion of the place.

i remember going to yank sing years ago and being unhappy that i paid so much for decent dim sum.  i'm glad that some big wig at Yank Sing, Inc. decided that they should offer their product for a lower price.  the problem w/ that is that they told their employees to act like they are selling a product for a lower price.  the ladies running this joint are loud, relentless and ready to take the order from the person after you even before taking your order.  service and ambiance are not what yank sing 2 go is about though so on to the food.

i got the yank sing express which consisted of a spring roll, potsticker, steamed pork bun and chow mein.  i tacked on a siu mye and a sesame ball too.  the spring roll and potsticker were standard fare. the siu maye was tasty but i guess for cost cutting measures i was given only 1 piece.  the sesame ball was alright and needed to be a bit more crunchier.  the steamed pork bun and chow mein on the other hand were damn good.  i'm still freakin thinking about the chow mein right now!  not bad for a decently priced meal!
author: Swarup B.

description: Charged $5 for tea, this place is so Americanized and is NOT a good Chinese dim sum place. Everything is so expensive.  We paid too much money for food that we couldve gotten much cheaper and way better at a real place in Chinatown. Total tourist trap.
author: Kim T.

description: Yank Sing is renowned for being one of the best dim sum joints in San Francisco and after feasting here, I can validate that reputation. With over 100 varieties of dim sum concocted on a daily basis, it's possible to encounter a different menu every time you go there. I've been there twice and both times, I adopted a dual ordering approach: order what I know and love and then try a few new dishes.  Read more here: http://www.ballyhoo.us/NetDispatch/news.cfm?ID=25&GroupID=3
author: Baochi N.

description: Expensive Dim Sum! It is good though. Nothing to complain about the food, service and the place. Yup, a place to go with your parents, because, as a perks of going out with parents, they got to foot the bill ^^. I love them!!
author: Kat S.

description: The smaller, kinder, gentler of the Yank Sings about town. I think this was the first one with a 'to go' window as well. I love the dim sum here, even though it always ends up costing a lot.
author: Colleen B.

description: The Yank Sing lunch specials are good. The service is fast.
author: Dee Z.

description: A very pricey and overrated dim sum place. There was a great variety to choose from and everything we tried was fresh, but it just didn't taste like anything special. It was just OK. As mentioned by others, you have to pay for your tea which is complimentary in most chinese places. The pot stickers and pork buns had more dough than filling and the shanghai dumplings were good but cost $10(!!!). I wouldn't go back when there's so many other dim sum places all over the city at about $1-2 per item, which is how much dim sum should cost.
author: Chris D.

description: Over-rated, overly priced and definitely not the Yank Sing I once raved about and highly recommended to go for dim sum. My recent visit and the LAST TIME was disappointing and burnt a huge hole in my wallet- $85 for two of us!!! Heck, I might as well head over to Tong Kiang (if I can find parking) or to Lucky Dim Sum in Clement (granted it is take-out but way better and cheaper) or better yet to Milbrae.
author: Daryl C.

description: Wanted to grab a quick Chinese bite for lunch, and wound up here not realizing it was dim sum time. The selection was amazingly small. Shanghainese dumplings were worth checking out and why this place gets 3 stars rather than 2. The women with carts mobbed us as soon as we sat down, so it was at least speedy. Oh, and it was overpriced!
author: hello y.

description: THE BEST POTSTICKERS I've had in the city...hands down!  I love that I work just blocks away!
author: Sarah D.

description: I used to hit the Yank Sing where the Elephant & Castle is now, and I loved it.  I must get to the new locations.
author: Max C.

description: YUM. My favorite dim sum in SF. I love the pork dumplings with soup in them. Everything here is good. Pricey, but worth it.
author: Jacqui M.

description: I dunno, I must be the only person in San Francisco who wasn't impressed by Yank Sing. I think what turned me off most was a) the outlandish prices b) the Americanization of the food, with a heavy focus on the deep fried items and c) mixed drinks with dim sum brunch and d) the rush and the crowd.
author: David Y.

description: The cleanest Chinese restaurant I have ever seen. So clean that none of the soy sauce, chili, or mustard containers that sit on the table had any grease, dust, fingerprints, or even a spot on them. Serously, the condiments look like they came straight from the package...it was that clean. Food was pretty good too, although expensive and not enough variety. They had one special today that really tood out: an avacado half topped with curry chicken and baked to perfection. Good service, nice tea, great desserts. Extremely flaky crust on the custard. So good!
author: Johnny O.

description: I had lunch here on a Friday afternoon and found the dimsum to be pretty good.   We asked for a lunch menu a couple times and halfway through our meal they finally brought out a list of several rice or noodle dishes.    I asked for hot and sour soup anyway - they actually had some to bring out and it was pretty good too.  The tea came out in glass pots...an indication of what sort of atmosphere they're aiming for.  I've never paid so much for such small peices of dimsum but you can't deny it is pretty tasty.
author: Aileen N.

description: If you have never had great dim sum, then you will be happy with Yank Sing, except for the price.  If you have, then look somewhere else...maybe try Mayflower on Geary.
author: Kapeli M.

description: I don't usually eat dim sum.  It isn't the most friendly cuisine for vegetarians.  That said, I enjoy Yank Sing.  While the vegietarian selection is small relative to the entire menu its still large enough to have a variety of dishes, something you don't find at most dim sum places.  Ask the server what they have with vegetables ... while they may be offering a shrimp roll they likely have something with spinach or mushroom hiding on the cart as well.
author: Eric P.

description:
before i begin, may i ask for a moment of silence for harbor village.

...

ok, so harbor village used to be my defacto dimsum joint in SF.  after that closed, i ventured back to yank sing after 7 years of avoiding it...and found myself coming back, and back, and back.  what can i say?  the dimsum is damn good.

just so you all know, my standard for dimsum is "how good is their lo mai gai?"  it's the sticky chicken rice wrapped in lotus leaf.  yank sing's is about as good as it gets - good proportion between rice and filling, not too greasy, none of that weird egg yolk, and lots of chinese sausage.  plus it's always tender, juicy, and of course...sticky.

otherwise, the shiu long bao are quite good (probably second to HC soup buns in cupertino village), and they have a nice selection of specialty dimsum dishes.  (IMO, a good dimsum joint does the classics well, and mixes in a couple of excellent signature items.)

and yeah, it's definitely on the expensive side.  so you leave a little lighter in the wallet, but not sickly full of grease and salt like other dimsum joints - and to me, that's worth the extra cost.
author: brian w.

description: It's all about the $4.50 lunch specials from the takeout counter at the Stevenson St. location. I've only sat down once, and I'd have to agree that you can get more for your money up in Chinatown proper. But shumai, BBQ fried rice and wontons for $4.50? Or beef with broccoli, ginger chicken, or anyone of the daily boxes? Go sit in the park on Market in the summer and it's a tasty lunch break.
author: mahi m.

description: This is not the best Yank Sing location. The dishes they have are much less varied than at Rincon.  The heat lamps outside work if you are directly under them, otherwise, they are useless.  Not the best dining room either.  If I'm going to pay that much I'd rather go to Rincon.
author: Margaret F.

description: Food is good, service is good, but damn it's expensive! I've been there a couple of time since it's right next to my work. It was about $125 for 3 people. I'm just going to go to Koi Palace since it's about 1/3 the price and similar quality.
author: Alton Y.

description:
On a recommendation, we decided to head to this place on our last day in SF. We should have known better...

At the end of the meal our check totaled over $250 for a party of six and half of us still left hungry. Sure the digs were nice but the actual dim sum wasn't exponentially better than anything you'd find elsewhere. $9 for tea is pretty much highway robbery. Expect your bill to be about three times higher than any other dim sum place you've ever been to.

Maybe I'm just a cheap ass but for the amount of money we each spent,  the six of us could have had dim sum five different times. I'd say spend your hard earned money elsewhere but I'm sure there are those with money to burn who swear by this place.
author: Henry C.

description:
i usually hit up the quick & easy take-out, yank sing 2 go.  usually a long line, but service is speedy.  my usual mainstay is the $5.15 mini - 2 potstickers, 1 egg roll and the chinese chicken salad (love the spicy mustard dressing, hate picking out the cilantro - sorry, not a cilantro fan!)  if you're feeling super hungry, fill up on the $5.95 phoenix - 1 egg roll, 2 potsticker, siu mye, fried rice AND (not greasy) chow mein.  add a sesame ball for a buck and a sweet treat to end your meal.

when i do splurge (on the company card) and eat in, the freshness and variety of selections is worth it.  there can be some lag time between carts, but you can't really complain when your piping hot siu mye & har gau arrives.  be sure to order the minced chicken lettuce cups, the peking duck, spicy/garlicky green beans...and i'm a big fan of the fried taro root dumpling - not many are, but that means more for me!  and don't forget to make a reservation, otherwise it can be a long wait before you're seated...
author: Jen P.

description: damn! it was upscale for dim sum place!! it has a outside patio surrounded by glass. I came here for lunch with three of my friends.. lots of choices of food. I had peking duck with bun.. you can get a five pieces of peking duck.. and you can still try other food. Chicken with peanuts sauce is gOOd.. Wouldn't mind coming here AGAIN!!! their pudding was good... our bill came out to be 7o buckss.. not bad at aLL!!
author: Lily T.

description: The quality and creativity of the dim sum at either Yank Sing is easily equivalent to anything I've had in China. IMO, having tried all the highly recommended in the city, it's easily the best you will find in SF or anywhere else in the US. Yes, you will pay for the best, but it's worth every penny. Incredibly delicious, very clean and classy!
author: Michael W.

description: Probably one of the best Dim Sum restaurants I've eaten at in the US. Not only is it very clean, the food excellent, the wait staff friendly, but most of all it has a decent vegetarian dim sum selection.  Most of my family is vegetarian, so having dim sum is not something they look forward to.  We've normally had dimsum in the NYC area, and unless we go to a place that explicitly serves veg. dim sum, we really haven't found a place that serves satisfies both factions.  I love the jasmine tea they serve at Yank Sing.  The place is a bit pricey for a typical dim sum restaurant, but it's worth it for all the points I mentioned above.
author: SG D.

description: delicious.  $17 seabass.  tasty.  $18.50 braised noodles.  yumm... but expense it.   it's 2-3x more than up the street...
author: Tida S.

description: Wow.. Their coconut (yumyuOOyumyOo) custard desert is soo good. It's kind of chewy, with a bright yellow custardy cream in the center. On the outside of the chewy gelatinous thing are coconut flakes. YUM!! Get Yank Sing to go, but if you there the service is nice. YUMYOO
author: O K.

description: My initiation came from a Chinese colleague's invitation when we worked on 1st and Market. And, it is the BEST dim sum in the city. Prepare to drop some $$ as the seamingly hundreds of carts go whizzing by your table with their inumerable choices. Veggies, shrimp toast, chicken feet (he got it I tried it and, now I order them...they're good!) Chrysanthemum tea with a sesame ball for dessert and I'm in heaven. Lunch is typically $76= for the 2 of us. But, sometimes it's more...
author: L P.

description: Best dim sum I've had in the citaaay.  It's all very tender and moist and wholesome goodness.  Note, corporate crowd.
author: Jonny L.

description:
$160 for 4 people at lunch and still hungry.  it can mean nothing more than "EXPENSIVE."  

the food was good and the atmosphere was clean. but  i don't think i would ever come here again after that price tag.  insane.
author: lucie l.

description: Very, very good and very, very expensive. (Something I'm not used to with dim sum.) I went with a friend for lunch when I first moved to SF. The bill for the two of us was $100, and neither of us ordered alcohol. (My friend does have a big appetite, though.)
author: The Other Jeff A.

description: I have had two recent experiences at Yank Sing.  In my first experience, we sat at the outer edge of the restaurant outside and the cart never came by.  In the second experience, I sat in the center of the restaurant and the carts wouldn't stop coming.  I guess your location determines your happiness here.  The food is pretty good, considering we are not in chinatown, and the service is overall pretty friendly.  They work hard to remember your name when they come around to check on you.  Nice touch.
author: Joanna S.

description: Ok, excluding $$$ factor for this review; that is, if you have $$$ to blow, then I think you'd be happy dining here...  But I had better jumbo niku mon in Japan.
author: Francisco S.

description: Yank Sing is very, very good. The service is excellent and the place is nice and clean. However, it is disturbingly pricey. I mean, it's almost twice expensive than Tong Kiang. That's really too much. And it's not the best dim sum in town either.
author: Donato M.

description: I think it's the best dim sum in the city. Good service. Wonderful selection of delicious vegetarian options. Very, very expensive.
author: Eater S.

description: Yeah, it's pretty good Dim Sum.  I've had much better...in LA...yeah, that's pretty sad, actually.  Very expensive for what you get, which I was prepared for, I just thought it was going to be something special, which it wasn't.  They get you in and out pretty fast and the dim sum was mostly hot.    $37 per person and we didn't really get THAT much food.  I don't know, I just hope I can find better in the city and if I can't I'll be very very sad.   I remember liking Ton Kiang but it's been years since I've been there so I may have to go back and try again...
author: Erick Z.

description: Good dim sum, but its to rich for my blood. I think the only reason my friends like to go here is just for bragging rights..so dumb. They have good food, but I wouldn't pay this much
author: Danny R.

description: Soup dumplings and the seaweed wrapped tofu are the bomb here.
author: Bibi B.

description:
Great lunch value - never eaten in, just gotten to-go.

The veggie dumplings are amazing! Plus, a big lunch of lo mein, eggplant and dumplings for around 6 bucks within a hop, skip and jump of work? I'm sold.
author: Kristina G.

description: Great dim sum for the Chinatown intimidated.  Quite a few items are excellent: garlicky beans, lettuce wraps, mushroom dumplings.  The tea is good too - my favorite is Chrysanthimum.  I've been offered different things each time, and have often missed out on past favorites but found some new ones.  You have no idea what the bill will be, and ours have varied quite a bit, from $10 to $30/person, despite feeling like we eat about the same amount each time.
author: nick w.

description: The food was okay...but DEFINITELY not worth $65 for two people! My husband and I have had just as good dim sum around town for much less than that.  This must be a tourist trap.  It has to be.
author: Gillian F.

description: Very good Dim Sum, with a cool area to eat outside.  It is a bit pricey however.  Personally I think the Canton House is almost as good, but it is much cheaper.  It even has a to go store on the side for a more reasonable price.
author: Pele N.

description: This place is very good but very overpriced.  $20 a head will not fill you up.  You are better off ordering from Yank Sing express.  It's this takeout lunch depot that offers specials on the weekdays.  I believe the express outpost is closed on the weekend.  The take away lunches are a very good deal.  So that's the route I'd take if I wanted affordable delicious dim sum!
author: Dorothy L.

description: It's the best Dim Sum I've had. The Shanghai dumping was amazing and very consistent (it's only a notch below Ding Tai Fung in LA). Excellent shrimp dishes.
author: Spiffman S.

description: I'm torn - the dim sum was just as good as in my largely-Asian SoCal hometown, and that's saying something. $20 per person for a moderate number of dishes however is a little steep, but the carts come RIGHT to you and you've got a full table in less than 5 minutes - great service!
author: Debby C.

description: Yank Sing is terrible.  I don't know where this place gets its reputation.  I think it is from people who have not had much exposure to dim sum, since I notice that those are the people who tell me this place is the best.  I work nearby and have given Yank Sing MANY chances.  It is WAY overpriced and the dim sum lacks any kind of authenticity.  My favorite Chinese treat is egg custard tarts.  The custard tarts at Yank Sing just taste like gelatin.  If you think this place is good, try some dim sum restaurants on Geary or in Chinatown and you will never eat here again.
author: Kandi K.

description: This is my favorite place for Dim Sum! It's close to my ofifce and the food is fantastic!!! Plus, it's instant gradification...once you sit down, the cart comes around. The only downside is that during lunch, it's always packed. Expect a wait. It's also a bit expensive. I call it "adult lunch" because only in my adult life are lunches over $30 pp.
author: Jennifer M.

description: This place I think has the best dim sum in San Francisco.  It's very pricey for dim sum but the variety of dim sum that you get and also the quality of food add together I think is all worth it.  The service is also excellent!
author: JenJen W.

description: This place is absolutely fantastic IF you have a company expense account which you boss never bother checking where you spend your money. I mean, who would have thought you could spend more than $50 for dim sum?!I would be very suspicious if I was your boss. If I could easily spend less than $15 for the same quality food 5-10 minutes walk away, I am not sure why I would waste my time waiting in line to get ripped off. Don't get me wrong, the dim sum is good, but not $50-good... I have had better dim sum for less than half the price. Yep, you guessed it, I do NOT have a company expense account.
author: Pascal C.

description: BEST Dim sums in SF !!! Have a good vege options too. Their deserts (if you dont go too overboard on the dim sums) are good too.
author: Vijay R.

description: I found the food only fair.  A bit too oily on some dishes, a bit dull on the rest....  OK if you're in the neighborhood and need take out, or don't mind waiting for seating.
author: H.A. ..

description: If you can catch the egg tarts when they come fresh out of the oven, they are the best!
author: Mike T.

description:
i've only come here when my company is paying for it...well, i do do the "yank sing 2 go", it's the perfect friday lunch deal after boozin' too hard on thursday.

this place makes me do my happy eating dance (while sitting). i've left here on more than one occasion - ok, all occasions with a little grease stain on my shirt, and frankly i must say it is well worth it. overall, i give them 3 stars, the 4th star is because i never have to pay.

my only complaint is that the place is jam packed like a roll-o-quarters, not cool. so if your company wants to take you out to lunch, and you want to pig out and rock the grease stains - go here!
author: Brittany E.

description: Go there for the Yank Sing 2 Go for lunch. Food is okay there at best. I have definitely had better. I hear the sit down is much different though so I'll have to go back some time, sit down, and re-review the place. I'd say pass on the 2 Go if you can. If you're craving chinese, at least it's pretty cheap, and will fill you up some. Just lower your expections there a bit.
author: Mike C.

description: Best Dim Sum I have ever had - that may not be saying much since I am from Michigan.  However, be careful, or you will end up spending a fortune!
author: Daniel B.

description: It's very good dim sum and very good service.  Yes, it cost more than you would expect, but I haven't found somewhere less expensive that is better.
author: Cliff M.

description: This joint IS the finest dim sum restaurant I have ever been to.  It is ridiculously clean and service is actually very good, especially for a Chinese joint.  I would categorize this restaurant as an authentic Chinese dim sum restaurant catered for the yuppie crowd.  It's one of the first dim sum restaurants where every piece of dim sum arrives at your table hot, steaming, and delicious.  I actually liked this place better at its original location.  But they wanted to go high end and move to the Rincon Center.  I ain't go' hate when they're just trying to accomodate the ridiculously large number of people that visit this establishment.
author: David C.

description: A place loved by white people but not even on the radar for Chinese people.  Why?  Because the dim sum is average at best, not authentic at all, and priced 2-3x what you'd pay elsewhere just because they can get away with it since - if you haven't figured it out by now - they only target the white folks.
author: P B.

description: dim sum at it's best.  mushroom dumplings, shanghai dumplings, potstickers, pork sui mye, chicken lettuce cups... one thing better than the last.  i live in new york, now the challenge will be finding a place as good as this.  the bill with tip was $100 for three people, but this involved about 8 dishes, which included dessert (sesame balls - don't miss these) and a large pot of tea - that's $33 pp and we were stuffed...
author: Darlene B.

description:
I go to the takeaway window. There's a $9 seafood special that's not at all bad. I've had better dim sum in the City but Yank Sing is the best within a short walk of my office. The bao are decent. The location also explains the high price: there aren't many inexpensive, non-revolting alternatives nearby. If you want change from a ten at lunch, there's Chipotle and not much else. Ugh. 

The sitdown restaurant is ridiculously overpriced. If someone else is paying I don't mind going there though.
author: A.B. F.

description:
Excellent Dumplings. Great Quality. Very Clean. Upscale dim sum placePricey$$$. One of two Locations. Not as authentic as ones you find in elsewhere in the city, but you pay for the Service and the quality of the food, especially the dumplings.
Key is to make a reservation so you are seated. 

Tasty items.....
1. Shu Mai - Pork and shrimp dumplings, savory tasty, delicate
2. Signature dish - dumplings filled with soup. This is the first dish they rush to serve you. Sweet dipping sauce with strips of ginger.
3. Pork Buns - Meaty pork and sweet sauce stuffed in soft bun
4. Shrimp Dumplings
5. Spicy Chinese green beens (not on carts)
author: S S.

description:
OMG! $92 for two for dim sum??

It's been a few years since we'd been to Yank Sing, and our last visit was to the Stevenson St. location (mediocre food and indifferent service). But we decided to brave Yank Sing again at the Rincon Center and were very pleasantly surprised (at least until we got the bill). Now, we get dim sum every week or two, and it typically runs us about $25 to $35...from what I remembered of Yank Sing, I expected this bill to be about $50-$60 for the two of us. Uh, no.

The restaurant was already packed by the time we arrived at 11:30 on a Sunday morning. The setting was very nice if a bit sterile and corporate, and the servers were all uniformed in crisp, clean uniforms. The food was surprisingly good and arrived at the table piping hot (luckily, we were seated near the kitchen which in a dim sum restaurant is a good thing). Standouts included the haw gao, shiu mai, and steamed spareribs...all were seasoned perfectly and were impeccably fresh. The star of the show, however, were a relatively new menu item (they weren't on the menu the last time we were here)...the Xiao Long Bao (XLB). Now, there was no reason to expect that they would be very good here, which is really more of a spot for tourists and "gwei-lo" (white devils, lol). Furthermore, dim sum is a Cantonese creation and XLB are Shanghainese. Nevertheless, these soup dumplings were absolutely fantastic. The wrapping was properly thin, and they were burstingly plump with scalding soup. Absolutely delicious...we immediately had to order another portion (6 dumplings)! Yumm!

The fried softshell crab was less successful...it had to be special-ordered (and took quite a while) but still arrived lukewarm. I really did not care for the mushrooms stuffed with chicken, which were also cold but were flavorless to boot. We concluded with some beautiful mah cho, fried sesame balls filled with lotus seed paste. These were fresh from the fryer and still hot and crispy. Soooo good. 

Up until this point, we were thinking this was the best dim sum experience we'd had in years. The food was great and the service was actually friendly and efficient, a rarity in a Chinese restaurant. Then came the bill...WTF????

Shamefully, I am an illiterate ABC (American-born Chinese for you Gwei-los) and could not really decipher the intricate code on the bill. After extensive analysis, we concluded that the XLB were $21.50 each (!) and the crab was $17.50 (!). Gulp. 

Oh well, lesson learned. We  had a delicious meal and wonderful service in an elegant setting. Yank Sing is the perfect place to take Americans who may otherwise be nervous about exploring the nearby Chinatown and the everpresent grunge. I found the dim sum to be far superior to Ton Kiang in the Richmond district, and the XLB was head and shoulders above that from Shanghai Dumpling King (this place has really gone down hill). Yes, Yank Sing is expensive. But for really good food, can't Junior just go to community college? I miss Harbor Village.
author: Jason K.

description:
i have had their takeout food (pretty greasy) for weekday lunches but tastes really good.

i have had their dim sum (weekday and weekend) and it is pretty good.  very clean.  great staff if you speak cantonese, else it is mildly awkward like all dim sum places (less so here).

limited selection of dim sum.  everything is pretty well done.  my only complaint is their xiao long bao - they more often than not stick to the bottom of the basket and tear when you lift them out and they should not.  that is just plain sloppy for what they charge at this place.

the tea is good.  decent.  the shrimp dumplings are decent.

the egg tarts are decent although i do prefer the ones at hk flower lounge in millbrea.

slightly americanized place, i think.  the most expensive dim sum in the city, friendliest to non-chinese and the safest bet if this is your first time trying dim-sum.
author: tc h.

description: The three times I've gone here for takeout I was disappointed. Why I came back three times, I don't know. I thought if i changed up the combinations I would be less disappointed I guess. The food was too salty and just mediocre- from the potstickers to the fried rice to the cheese stuffed wonton. But it is somewhat cheap. I wish I could say the same about the sesame balls, which are over-priced and did I mention - tiny?! I have dined in the actual restaurant and there is a difference there. That one I can recommend. This one, not so much.
author: Missy L.

description: This is the best dim sum I've ever had. Every dish is great. There are only two drawbacks: it's not cheap, and you usually have to wait to get a table. But it's well worth both of these. I eat here as often as I can.
author: Marc H.

description: very good for what it is. heavy on the starch - fried rice, chow mein. they aren't idiots -that's what's cheap! i wish there were more dim sum combo options - there's one, but it's a weird assortment of some of the only things i'm not wild about. it's a TON of food for the money - the phoenix combo is like $5.65 and is huge.
author: Erica W.

description: Mrs. Phil B used to spend a lot of time in Hong Kong and swears this Dim Sum is up to that standard.  Higher compliments are hard to find for the food which is wonderful.  The selection is huge here and some of my favorites include the sea bass with basil, the potstickers and the crispy duck.  Top advice is to hold out for a while and don't overorder from the first trolley - there is a lot of fun things to try.   The only issue I have is that the service is "in your face".  On the last meal I was trying to talk a little business but this is hard with interruptions every 30 seconds.  Plus you'll be in and out in under an hour easily - not for a romantic lunch.  Overall its worth it for a delicious lunch.  Enjoy!
author: Phil B.

description: I order solely from the to-go counter.  Service is quick.  Food is ok.  I really like the schezwan beef and the chicken salad.  The chow mein is greasy, and tasteless.
author: Zaneta C.

description: I know it's expensive (which is why only 4 stars) but I LOVE this place.  The food is great, choices vast, the service fast and professional.  I go here often and am almost never disapointed.  This is a high reccomendation!
author: Pete D.

description: this place is the bomb. its the best dim sum ive had in my life. the things id recommend is the shao long pao (soup dumplings) and the BBQ pork buns.
author: Matt M.

description:
This is the best dim sum in the city.  The variety is fantastic and the service is great.  Be sure to ask for the lettuce wraps (sometimes they don't bring it around on a cart).  The tea is especially good.

They do a good job taking care of regular customers.  They will remember what you like and where you like to sit and will seat you quickly.

It is a bit pricey, but their great dim sum is worth it.
author: Karen B.

description: this place really confused me.  i had never experienced such pushy servers or so many.  ever.  it was very hard to concentrate on either the food or the conversation because of the endless interuption.  i didn't enjoy what i had very much and was shocked to find out both the price and the reputation it has. the two stars are for the decor and the well, unforgetableness of my experience.
author: Karen K.

description: Amazingly expensive for dim sum. $240 for 4 people. Take $50 off for the alcohol and it's still expensive!!! I really liked the food but not to the point of paying twice as much as I would pay at other good dim sum restaurants... Make sure you have an idea of how much you're paying for each of the dishes you order
author: Francisco L.

description: solid place. chicago has very good dim sum, but i was impressed with yank sing.  a little surprised to see a quality dim sum place in the middle of a psuedo mall, but regardless, the atmosphere combined with the quality service and delicious dim sum made for a quality meal.  within 5 minutes of sitting down, we had our 1st dish.  perfect!
author: richard p.

description: i've always liked this place but it used to be so much better when it was smaller over on battery street and less pretentious. now it's always so crowded and rushed, it's not the same experience it used to be. the dim sum is very tasty, however my big turnoff is that they use msg.
author: lisa w.

description: Really good dim sum, but man, do they gouge! They're less pushy on moving baskets from steam carts to your table than at my favorite East Bay dim sum locale, but once they do, expect a minimum of $6.95 an item. I tried to get information on how much each item cost a few times but go "we'll be right back" until a waitress finally gave us a price sheet and the 5 plates came to $40.00! It's the best I've found in the city, but you're paying for it! For example sesame balls (better ones, at that) are $2.95 at the place I mentioned earlier and $7.95 here! This place is tasty, but definitely caters to the "business lunch" crowd.
author: Michael H.

description: holy expensive dim sum!  yes, the food is good, but is it worth it?  i ended up spending 2.5 - 3 times what i have spent at other dim sum places.  granted, the food is really good....hmm....i'll have to think about this one.  i might have to scope out other places before heading back to yank sing.  still worth 4 stars though.
author: Amy K.

description: Bullshit - This place is a there to get you if you don't do your research on the prices before hand. That's what happened to me. I went with a group, they didn't give us a menu, food would go around in trays and you pick what you like. It being a Chinese restaurant, I assumed the prices would be market rate. They don't tell you the prices, you pay later. I was attacked by surprise when I saw the bill. It's insanely expensive for a Chinese food. Yes, the atmosphere is cool and the service is OK. But you pay....$$$. And the food is not memorable for me....simply over priced. I will not go back ever.
author: az H.

description: There are many good places for dim sum in the city. But if you are not native chinese, you may not appreciate them as much as you will Yank Sing. My family and I love the dim sum here. Pork Soup dumpling is particularly amazing. Though it is all pricey, it's worth it.
author: M P.

description:
I don't even want to share my secret but I'm feeling charitable today. The trick to Yank Sing is to go at 11:30 before the Fidi lunch crowd comes out. Yank Sing=Dim Sum Heaven. I've eaten Dim Sum  in many U.S. cities, and China and HK. This is it! YK is hella yum. Once you are seated, you will be swarmed with food carts....so many choices. STAY CALM! Definitely have the house special pork dumplings filled with piping hot broth and served with red vinegar sauce.Those usually come over first. But after that, take your time and consider what you want. Tea is lovely. My recommendations: sea bass (to die for), lotus chicken, the fried shrimp, green beans if you're in the mood for healthy eating....well there are many, many things that are good. Its expensive but worth every penny. Bypass the fruit, puddings, and sesame ball deserts and go for the incredible pistachio ice cream pie. Its incomparable. And another secret, the pie they carry around on the cart? its fake! 

If there is something you want, just ask,  the staff is equipped with headset walkie talkies to put out an APB for the food that you desire :-) If you don't know exactly, you can use words like "steamed," "chicken," "fried," etc. Service is generally kind, lovely, and friendly.

This place is a real treat. I hope you get to enjoy it!
author: Hayley S.

description: If you are looking for Dim Sum... search no more. This is the place. We'll be honest, we are fairly new to the Dim Sum world but are getting our feet wet one delicious dumpling at a time. Sorry for the descriptions only but when they run around with the carts, we can never quite understand the name of the dishes. We just know it's good. The cabbage salad with candied walnuts and a light citrus dressing is a great way to start. I am a huge fan of the pork bun which is just perfect here. The rice squares, pork, spicy beans, spring rolls and pretty much anything fried is just a tasty treat. We would like to try Dim Sum with some serious professionals so we know the in's and out's of what to order. However this is the place to learn. If you go on a weekend, go early because you are going to be looking at a serious crowd. The secret is definitely out that this place is fantastic!!!
author: Melissa P.

description: too expensive....but servers were really nice and of course, it seems very clean. $80 for 2 ppl.....ton kiang  is way better, but they annoy you with the carts....
author: Val R.

description: Awesome dim sum. Freshest veggie dumplings. Wish I had room to order the turnip cake and dessert!!!
author: Mona F.

description: very good dimsum... not to oily and service was so much better compare to other dimsum place. they actually can speak english :) i like the teapot... it is way more upscale and pricy than the regular dim sum place.. money talk, right ?! this is the restaurant i definetely will bring my parents to.. ( they are really picky *sigh )
author: sherly A.

description: Best pork buns I've ever had, and it's not even close.  The rest of the food is good too, and if it wouldn't take decades off my life, I wouldn't mind eating here several days a week.
author: William N.

description: delicious dim sum! the dumplings and potstickers were not remarkable, but their other dishes (scallion pancakes, sesame balls, bacon wrapped prawn, shrimp balls) were made from high quality ingredients. watch out, though - this place can be pretty pricey if you're not thinking about how much you're ordering/how much it all costs!
author: Jane H.

description: Dim sum in an upscale setting, and you'll pay for it too. Still, it's quite good, as good as Ton Kiang, but not as good as Koi Palace. A friend and I ate here once, and we had to watch our spending and didn't eat as much as we might have, and the bill was still about $25 per person, which is way too much for dim sum. They sell those nifty glass teapots, which is a good gift idea. They take reservations, which besides always being a good idea, are best made. The best things to order here are the char siu bao, the soft-shell crabs, and the Shanghai xiao long bao (aka soup dumplings). This place closes at 3PM, so no dinner. They have another branch in Rincon Center, at 101 Spear St, which used to be Wu Kong (quite large, enough for wedding banquets). Yank Sing was founded in 1958.  The name "Yank Sing" translated means "City of the Ram" and is a synonym for the City of Guangzhou (or Canton), the capital of Guangdong Province in China.
author: Hao L.

description: Okay, I was very disappointed with Yank Sing. Although, this is a dim sum restaurant it is not the type of dim sum restaurant I am accustom to. I should have known when I walked into the restaurant and there were only a couple of Asian customers. The restaurant is super tiny and very very crowded with every race other than Asian. I still wonder how the employees manage to drive the food carts around with out hurting someone. It is a somewhat trendy atmosphere. The restaurant also has an outdoor seating area, but please be aware that along with the patio sitting you will have the ugliest crows eating with you. The crow situation is so bad that the employees kept apologizing for the bird situation. I was also unhappy that the employees pushing the dim sum carts were pushy. Five of the employees would bombard you at the same time and at times they would just place the dim sum on the table without you agreeing to accept the dim sum. Last, I thought it was over priced for just your average dim sum. I am very happy to pay good money for delicious food, but the food was average. I was disappointed when I asked for one tiny piece of fried duck. The small piece of fried duck was smaller than the size of a miniature hot wing and they charged me $5.00 for that one single piece. There was three of us for lunch and the bill came out to $130.00 and we had very few dim sum plates. I walked away still starving. Maybe, I am a little prejudice because I am a Latina girl married to an Asian man and he has taken me to the BEST dim sum restaurants in San Francisco, New York and Los Angeles. Unfortunately, that day my husband was not with me. I will never return to Yank Sing when I have many other authentic and delicious dim sum restaurants to choose from.
author: arlinda k.

description: upscale dim sum chain that is high on quality of service and food.  it gets knocked sometimes for being american-chinese, and while it may cater to a more round-eye crowd (ie less authentic dishes), it still delivers a good experience. i've eaten at countless chinese restaurants in china, oakland, sf and nyc and i know good chinese food and i know i'll be back at yank sing. perfect for brunch with a big group.
author: Kevin J.

description: 3 stars just for the singapore rice noodle. that's a little pricey on its own. otherwise, for the calories, this is probably one of the better deals in town.
author: Sarav C.

description: This place is absolutely wonderful. I wish I had discovered it before the last few months I had in the Bay Area before moving to Phoenix because boy, do I miss it now! Yes, it's expensive (my husband and I spent about $70 for lunch, including tax and tip), and yes, some of the dishes are not the most authentic, but every dish I tried was flavorful, savory, enjoyable, and delicious! The real standouts were the Peking duck (they give you pieces of duck with crispy skin, buns, scallions, and Hoisin sauce), the spicy green beans, the shrimp dumplings, the sesame balls, and the honey walnut shrimp (sounds typical, but the coating on the shrimp was extra crispy and not overly sweet, and the dish comes with a lemon wedge, which adds an unexpected but delicious twist). Another great thing about this place is that it's busy enough to have a sustained flow of carts going around with fresh, hot food; I personally hate dim sum places where the same carts go circling around and no new items come out in the 30 minutes to an hour that you're there. When my husband and I came here a week before moving away from the Bay Area, we knew this place would be one we would miss terribly, and we were right because I'm experiencing longing and nostalgia for that Peking duck right about now!
author: Christine O.

description: Amazing! I love the dim sum at Yank Sing and you can find items here that you don't see in most dim sum restaurants. It does get a little pricey - we spent almost $50 per person after tax and tip last time we were here - but we ordered a ton (mostly seafood) which adds up.
author: Kimberly S.

description: i was in san francisco for a trade show and stopped by yank sing for some dim sum. the food was amazing and the experience was great! it did come with a price ....it was a bit expensive but still a cool spot. i highly recommend
author: EDDY B.

description: okok this is the BEST dim sum place around that area.  but only because it's the only one.   i don tlike this place.  way over priced due to it being in the financial district.  dim sum ladies are pushy with their dishes.  the food isnt that bad... but you can find better.
author: Doug ..

description: A decent selection for vegitarians. The service is super fast. The food is always fresh. Moderately priced. The fried green onions and spicy tofu are great.
author: Anna J.

description: uncomprising excellence for over forty years ... from its humble beginning on broadway street, packed with chinese families on weekends to its current elegant surroundings ... and catering division to hotels ... indeed!
author: tim y.

description: dim sum is yum at yank sing. the place is ALWAYS packed but you still get all the plates you want in a "timely" manner.  you would first think its overpriced dim sum but after trying out some other dim sum place, youll go back for some more.
author: Bren L.

description: damn this place is expensive.  me and 2 co-workers came here during lunch and we end up with a bill of about ~$240.  it was damn good though.  we order everything...   have to knock them  a little since its so damn expensive,....  probably couldve got the same delicious dim sum at mayflower for a little cheaper.
author: Peter L.

description: It's good and there's a lot of variety, but really too expensive to wholeheartedly enjoy the food.  I might change my mind if I'm rich though...
author: Jennifer D.

description: This was NOT "get what you pay for."  We paid $60 for a fairly small and limited meal for two (nothing fancy at all).  Some great tasting dishes, and some of a quality that you can find at the cheapest mom-n-pop places.  You're better coming here and  having at least some good quality than going up Grant street to the tourist traps (hence the extra star). However, this clearly seems to be a place resting on reputation.  Particularly poor selection at this location, as well.  If you're entertaining out-of-town guests down town and want to make sure (at any expense) that they have at least some good dim sum, this place should do fine.  If you can get out to the Sunset or even Milbrae, you'll have at least equal quality (probably better overall), and save about 30%.
author: Chris W.

description: good, clean, somewhat less greasy, delicious dim sum. loving those teapot.
author: gado.gado D.

description: Overall, a 2 star experience.  Not sure if they like round eye customers....
author: James B.

description: pretty good dim sum.  only problem is its a bit too pricy.  you get what you pay for, but yea.  i'd prefer good luck dim sum for myself, but when with a group wanting finer dining dimsum, this is the place.  fast friendly service.  the mango pudding is subtle and a nice break from the salty flavors of the dumplings and patagonian toothfish.
author: joseph k.

description: The Yank Sing express that I had today was just so-so.  Although a bargain at less than $7, the chow mein was not that tasty and a bit overcooked.  The piece of dim sum was over cooked.  The pork bun was very good.  Disappointed today, but will return again.
author: Brian L.

description: i love me some dimsum especially if it's from yank sing! it's how the chinese do tapas. shanghai pork dumplings are tdf. it's like hot soup in a delicate pouch. careful not to burn your mouth. peking duck, lettuce wraps, crunchy shrimp thingies & steamed pork bun are really good too. yeah, prices are a little steep but you get good quality dimsum in return & the restaurant is imaculate-you won't see any mice running around here. beat the weekday lunch crowd or make a reservation. either way, you've got to try this place. you won't be disapointed.
author: foodi e.

description: I love Yank Sing.  My parents love it when they come to visit.  We think it's really good and clean and yummy.  Yes it's a bit pricey for dim sum, but it's a nice environment and the staff are great - they work hard to make sure you get the dishes you want.
author: J W.

description: i was not used to that kind of service, its intense, you can really go nuts because one good thing comes after another, then you get full and something else goes by and you think....oh man, can i eat that too.  so good, so soooo good.
author: Richard C.
Candy T.

description: if youre looking for cheap dim sum, this is not the place for you.  this is what you would call dim sum to the next level.  this place is about as far away from your typical chinatown chinese restaurant than you can get.  everything here speaks first class, even the location, at the street level of an office building.  the presentation of the dim sum is quite literally, works of art.  the flavors are good here, not as flavorful as you would find at a typical chinese restaurant, probably because they don't add msg or something.  the thing that most impressed me was the way they dressed up orange jello.  it is an actual orange skin, with orange jello taking the place of the actual orange.  i know, i'm easily impressed, but to see the effort it takes to put these works of art on the table is something to be appreciated.  parking on the street if youre lucky.  service is good.  1st class place, what do you expect?
author: will m.

description: meh. dim sum was quite good but the prices are tourist-bilking fair and the selection is pretty limited.
author: matt e.

description: extremely over priced!  beware! they don't give you a menu and then push tons of food on you- that is good but not amazing.  i feel cheated!
author: monique r.
